SUBJECT STYLING:
• If the subject is male: heroic firefighter model wearing open uniform shirt or tank top, helmet, suspenders, posed confidently in front of firehouse or fire truck
• If the subject is female: swimsuit calendar model wearing stylish, tasteful swimsuit, posed confidently at beach or poolside
• Preserve subject's facial features and recognizable characteristics
• Subject integrated naturally into the scene, not composited

MOOD & TONE:
• Fun, cheeky, and glamorous — never sexualized
• Poses feel like commercial calendar shoot
• Not suggestive or explicit
• Professional photography aesthetic

CALENDAR LAYOUT (MANDATORY):
• Full calendar grid with accurate dates for the specified month/year
• Month name prominently displayed
• Year visible
• Days of week labeled (Sun-Sat or Mon-Sun)
• Bold calendar title at top
• Clean, readable typography
• Calendar positioned at bottom or side of image

STYLE:
• Professional novelty calendar photography
• Bright, well-lit, commercial quality
• Clean graphic design
• Looks like actual retail wall calendar

FINAL RESULT:
A complete calendar pin-up page featuring the subject in appropriate glamorous pose with a functional, accurate calendar grid for the specified (or randomly selected) month and year, designed like a real novelty wall calendar from a gift shop.

name: CANDY
message:
Take a picture and completely REBUILD the entire image so that EVERYTHING is made entirely out of candy.

ABSOLUTE REQUIREMENT: No photographic pixels, skin, fabric, metal, plastic, paper, or real-world materials may remain.

The subject, clothing, facial features, hair, background, environment, objects, shadows, and depth must ALL be constructed entirely from candy materials.

DO NOT apply candy textures to a photo.
DO NOT overlay candy on top of existing objects.
DO NOT trace, mask, silhouette, or reuse the original photograph’s structure.

The image must look as if the original photograph never existed and was replaced by a fully constructed candy sculpture world.

Candy materials may include (used structurally, not decoratively):
• Gummies (gummy worms, gummy bears)
• Gumballs
• Hard candy (Werther’s Originals, Nerds, Jolly Ranchers)
• Chocolate (Tootsie Rolls, Hershey’s Kisses)
• Licorice (Twizzlers, Red Vines)
• Lollipops
• Chewy candy (Jelly Belly jelly beans, Bayside Candy fruit slices, candy corn, gumdrops)
• Sugar crystals and popping candy (Pop Rocks)
• Marshmallows, caramel, sprinkles, candy canes
• Candy wrappers ONLY if physically folded, crinkled, and used structurally

Candy construction rules:
• Hard candy for rigid forms (bones, structure, buildings)
• Gummies for flexible areas (skin, muscles, cheeks, folds)
• Chocolate for smooth surfaces and large masses
• Licorice and candy ropes for joints, outlines, and connections

Shading and depth MUST be created ONLY by:
• Candy translucency
• Color variation
• Gloss and reflection
• Candy density, layering, and stacking

Lighting must behave like real candy:
• Glossy highlights
• Sticky reflections
• Subsurface glow in translucent candies
• Slight melting, sagging, or stretching where appropriate

FINAL VALIDATION RULE:
If the image looks like a normal photograph with candy placed on top, IT IS WRONG.

The final image must look like a real, physical candy sculpture or candy-built environment photographed in real lighting.

name: CAPTCHA VERIFICATION
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a realistic CAPTCHA verification screen where the subject appears inside a 3x3 or 4x4 image grid.

FORMAT (CRITICAL):
• The image must look exactly like a legitimate CAPTCHA challenge
• Clean web interface layout
• Subtle browser window framing
• Realistic UI typography
• Checkbox labeled: "I am not a robot"

CAPTCHA INSTRUCTION (CRITICAL):
• The instruction must begin with: "Select all squares with…"
• Use observational flavor text about the subject's visible traits
• The text must describe real, observable details (clothing, posture, expression, accessories, context)
• No abstract concepts (no happiness, no intelligence, no emotions)

EXAMPLES OF VALID INSTRUCTION STYLE:
• Select all squares with visible forehead shine
• Select all squares with uneven button alignment
• Select all squares containing suspicious side-eye
• Select all squares with visible collar fold
• Select all squares with mid-blink timing
• Select all squares with untucked fabric
• Select all squares containing mild confusion

GRID RULES:
• The subject must be divided naturally into squares
• Some squares clearly match the instruction
• Some squares clearly do not
• Subtle checkmarks may appear in selected boxes

STYLE:
• Clean white UI background
• Light gray borders
• Modern sans-serif font
• Slight drop shadow around grid
• High realism — must look like a real verification test

IMPORTANT:
• Humor comes from specificity
• Do not distort the subject unnaturally
• Keep identity recognizable
• Avoid meme-style graphics

FINAL RESULT:
The image should convincingly look like an authentic CAPTCHA verification challenge featuring the subject divided into clickable squares with a hyper-specific observational instruction.

name: CARDBOARDALITY
message:
Take a picture and transform the scene so ONE subject appears as a life-size cardboard cutout, like the kind used for photo opportunities at events or theaters.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• Exactly ONE subject is converted into a cardboard standee
• All other people remain completely normal and photographic
• The cardboard figure must be full human scale
• The illusion must be immediately recognizable as a cardboard cutout

SUBJECT SELECTION LOGIC:
• If ONE subject is visible: that subject becomes the cardboard cutout
• If TWO OR MORE subjects are visible:
  – Choose ONLY ONE subject to become the cardboard cutout
  – All remaining subjects stay real and unaffected

CARDBOARD CONSTRUCTION RULES (CRITICAL):
• The subject appears printed onto flat cardboard
• Visible cardboard edge thickness around the silhouette
• Slightly uneven or hand-cut outline
• Matte, slightly desaturated printed surface
• No depth, curvature, or realism

SUPPORT & PHYSICAL DETAILS:
• The cutout must be standing upright
• Include a visible fold-out cardboard stand or base behind or at the feet
• The cutout may cast a thin, flat shadow consistent with its shape
• The cutout must NOT float or hover

FACE & BODY PRESENTATION:
• The subject’s face and body are printed as a single flat image
• No 3D facial depth
• No animated expression changes
• Clothing details appear printed, not dimensional

ENVIRONMENT INTEGRATION:
• The cardboard cutout exists naturally within the photographed environment
• Other people may stand beside, behind, or interact casually with it
• Perspective and scale must match the real room

CAMERA & LIGHTING:
• Normal, everyday photography
• Lighting affects the cutout evenly, like a printed surface
• No dramatic spotlighting or surreal effects

ABSOLUTE PROHIBITIONS:
• No partial cardboard transformation
• No realistic skin texture or depth
• No floating or leaning without support
• No converting more than one subject

TONE:
• Playful
• Deadpan
• Slightly absurd
• Grounded in reality

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must look like a real photograph of a life-size cardboard standee placed in a real environment — unmistakably flat, printed, and supported — standing alongside real people who remain fully normal.

name: CARICATURE
message: Take a picture and make it a caricature. Defined by exaggerated features, bold expressions, and a humorous twist while preserving likeness. It captures the essence of a person or scene in a fun, over-the-top way, like something you would get from a street artist at a fair, bursting with personality and charm.

name: CARRY ME
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a scene where one person is carrying the subject on their shoulders.

If there are TWO subjects in the image: Have one subject carrying the other on their shoulders. Choose based on context, size, or humor - the carrier should look strained, proud, or playfully struggling while the person being carried shows excitement, triumph, or awkward balance.

If there is only ONE subject in the image: A famous person (specified via master prompt, or choose an appropriate celebrity if none specified) will either carry the subject on their shoulders OR the subject will carry the famous person. The interaction should feel natural and humorous.

Both people should have realistic expressions: the carrier might show effort, determination, or playful annoyance; the person on shoulders might show joy, victory, fear of falling, or awkward balance with arms outstretched.

Preserve recognizable facial features and body proportions for all people. The physical interaction must look believable - proper hand placement on legs/thighs, realistic weight distribution, natural body positioning.

Set the scene in an appropriate context: concert crowd, celebration, sporting event victory, parade, beach, park, or casual outdoor setting. Include realistic background elements and other people reacting to the moment.

Lighting and photography should be photorealistic, as if captured during an actual candid moment. The final image must look like a real photograph of this playful, triumphant, or humorous shoulder-carrying moment.

name: CAUGHT IN THE ACT
message:
CONTENT INTENT: This is a lighthearted comedic scenario depicting harmless, sitcom-style mischief (like eating cookies or sneaking snacks). No actual crimes, no harmful behavior, no victims - purely humorous family-friendly content like a TV comedy freeze-frame moment. This is G-rated or PG-rated humor about relatable everyday mischief.

Take a picture and place the subject in a clear, humorous moment where they are visibly caught in the act of doing something mildly wrong, mischievous, or socially embarrassing — frozen at the exact moment of realization that they have been discovered.

CONTENT SAFETY (CRITICAL):
• This is COMEDY and HUMOR only - like a sitcom scene
• NO actual crimes or illegal activities
• NO violence or harm to others
• NO sexual content
• NO defamation or harmful stereotypes
• Harmless mischief only (cookie stealing, sneaking snacks, etc.)
• Family-friendly TV comedy aesthetic
• G-rated or PG-rated scenarios only
• Relatable everyday situations
• Nobody gets hurt

ACT SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies an act, USE THAT ACT
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 20:
  - 0: Stealing a cookie from a cookie jar
  - 1: Sneaking food from the fridge late at night
  - 2: Eating cake meant for a party before it's served
  - 3: Taking an extra slice of pizza when no one's looking
  - 4: Reading someone else's mail out of curiosity (non-sensitive, comedic context)
  - 5: Peeking at gifts hidden in a closet before a holiday
  - 6: Writing graffiti on a whiteboard and getting caught mid-doodle
  - 7: Taking office supplies home (pens, sticky notes) - comedic, harmless
  - 8: Cheating at a board game with cards hidden behind their back
  - 9: Sneaking a bite of food while cooking
  - 10: Drinking directly from the milk carton or juice container
  - 11: Taking a "Do Not Touch" item and freezing when noticed
  - 12: Falling asleep at work or school and waking up busted
  - 13: Eating snacks during a "no food allowed" situation (library, museum)
  - 14: Switching price tags as a joke (clearly playful, non-realistic, comedy)
  - 15: Taking selfies where they shouldn't (serious meeting, boring event)
  - 16: Cutting in line and being caught by others waiting
  - 17: Sneaking into a room marked "staff only" out of curiosity
  - 18: Hiding crumbs or evidence of eating behind their back
  - 19: Taking the last cookie/donut without asking

TONE & INTENT (MANDATORY):
• Harmless, humorous, and lighthearted
• Sitcom freeze-frame comedy
• Relatable everyday mischief
• Nobody is harmed or victimized
• No serious consequences
• Funny because relatable
• Family-friendly humor
• Feel-good comedy

SUBJECT RECOGNITION:
• Subject must be clearly recognizable
• Face fully visible
• Expression is critical to storytelling
• Identity preserved naturally
• Subject is themselves in funny situation

"CAUGHT" MOMENT (CRITICAL):
• Subject is mid-action — not before or after
• Eyes wide, startled, guilty, or shocked
• Body language shows surprise or embarrassment
• Action frozen at the moment of discovery
• Clear visual evidence of what they were doing
• Hand caught mid-reach for cookie/food
• Deer-in-headlights expression
• "Uh oh, I've been spotted" energy

ENVIRONMENT STORYTELLING:
• Environment must explain the act without text
• Props visible (cookie jar, fridge, board game, sign, etc.)
• Context clues everywhere
• Scene readable in one glance
• Setting clearly shows what's happening
• Visual comedy through props and setting

CAMERA & COMPOSITION:
• Candid perspective
• Slightly off-angle, like someone just walked in on them
• Not a posed portrait
• Feels accidental, unplanned
• Eye-level or doorway perspective works well
• "Just caught them" camera angle
• Documentary-style catch

LIGHTING:
• Natural indoor or outdoor lighting
• No dramatic or cinematic lighting
• Real-world realism
• Kitchen lights, office lights, room lights
• Authentic everyday lighting
• Bright enough to see guilty expression clearly

EXPRESSION & BODY LANGUAGE:
• Guilty smile, wide eyes, frozen movement
• Hand caught mid-reach
• Object half-hidden behind back
• Awkward posture encouraged
• Embarrassed laugh
• "Caught red-handed" look
• Comedic frozen pose

REALISM RULES:
• Subject must physically interact with the scene
• Correct shadows and grounding
• No floating objects
• No compositing artifacts
• Realistic physics and proportions
• Natural integration into environment

PROPS & DETAILS:
• Cookie jar clearly visible (if cookie stealing)
• Open fridge with food (if sneaking snacks)
• Board game with cards visible (if cheating)
• "Do Not Touch" sign visible (if taking forbidden item)
• Milk carton or juice container (if drinking from container)
• Visual evidence of the mischief clear

HUMOR STYLE:
• Relatable everyday situations
• "We've all been there" comedy
• Harmless rule-breaking
• Sitcom-style humor
• Physical comedy through expression
• Innocent mischief
• Family-friendly laughs

NOT ALLOWED:
• Serious crimes or illegal acts
• Violence or harm to others
• Sexual situations or content
• Realistic illegal acts
• Harmful or dangerous behavior
• Defamation or negative stereotypes
• Anything beyond PG-rated humor
• Mean-spirited comedy

STYLE:
• Photorealistic
• Feels like a still from real life
• Humor through timing, not exaggeration
• Relatable and human
• Could be from a sitcom
• Natural, not overly staged
• Documentary comedy style

FINAL RESULT:
The image should depict a single, clear, humorous moment where the subject is unmistakably caught in the act of a harmless misdeed — frozen at the exact second of realization with guilty/startled expression — with expressive body language, clear environmental storytelling showing what they were doing, realistic lighting and perspective, and a candid sitcom-like authenticity that makes the viewer instantly understand the funny situation and relate to the harmless mischief.

name: CELL PHONE WALLPAPER
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a vertical smartphone wallpaper that looks like a fake, humorous phone operating system.

Use a tall portrait aspect ratio (about 9:16 or taller). The subject should be the main character of the ‘phone,’ either as the lock-screen wallpaper or as a character integrated into the interface.

Overlay a fake phone UI including:
• a fake clock and date
• silly or themed app icons inspired by the subject’s traits (e.g., "Fart Tracker", "Overthinking", "Drama Meter", "Nap Mode")
• fake battery, Wi-Fi, and signal indicators with humorous labels

Add subtle cracked-glass lines across the screen — fine hairline fractures, small chips, or spiderweb cracks — so it looks like a phone with a lightly damaged display. The cracks should sit on top of the image like real broken glass, but must not block the subject’s face or important UI text.

Design the interface so it feels like a real smartphone screen but with absurd, playful details. Icons should be large, readable, and placed naturally like a real phone home screen.

Leave the top and bottom areas clear enough that the subject’s face or main features are not blocked by UI elements.

The final image should feel like the subject owns their own ridiculous, slightly broken custom smartphone — funny, charming, and clearly readable on a small screen.

name: CELTIC ART
message: Take a picture and convert it into a Celtic art piece inspired by the Book of Kells; highly detailed, intricate knotwork, flowing lines, and mystical geometry with the visual language of ancient Celtic art; ornate patterns and symbolic forms.

name: CENSORED
message:
Take a picture and add comedic censorship elements to make it look like something inappropriate is being hidden, when in reality nothing inappropriate is actually present. The humor comes from the implication and overreaction of censorship.

CENSORSHIP TYPE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a specific censorship type, USE THAT TYPE
• If no type is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE type using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT modulo 10:
  - 0: Black censorship bar over eyes (like witness protection)
  - 1: Pixelated blur over face or object
  - 2: Large "CENSORED" text banner covering part of image
  - 3: Black rectangles blocking out random innocent objects
  - 4: Cartoon-style sign with symbols (stars, spirals, @#$%!) held in front of mouth
  - 5: Japanese-style mosaic blur over completely normal items
  - 6: Subject with arm extended, hand blurred/censored (implying rude gesture)
  - 7: Multiple small "CENSORED" boxes scattered over innocent details
  - 8: Solid black silhouette of subject with "IDENTITY PROTECTED" label
  - 9: Aggressive scribbled-out marker lines over mundane objects

CORE REQUIREMENTS:
• Subject's features should still be somewhat recognizable despite censorship
• Nothing actually inappropriate in the original or censored image
• Censorship applied to completely innocent things for comedic effect
• Over-the-top dramatic censorship treatment
• The absurdity comes from censoring normal, harmless content

CENSORSHIP APPLICATION:
• Apply censorship to random innocent elements (coffee cup, plant, hand gesture, smile, etc.)
• For option 6: Subject positioned with arm outstretched, hand prominently blurred or pixelated to imply offensive gesture
• Make it look official and serious despite censoring nothing scandalous
• Can include warning labels like "VIEWER DISCRETION ADVISED" or "INAPPROPRIATE CONTENT REMOVED"
• Official-looking "CENSORED BY [AUTHORITY]" stamps
• Parody of overzealous content moderation

STYLE:
• Realistic censorship graphics (actual blur effects, official-looking bars)
• High contrast black bars or bright pixelation
• Professional broadcast censorship aesthetic
• Can include fake ratings labels (MATURE, EXPLICIT, etc.) for comedic effect

HUMOR APPROACH:
• Suggest something scandalous while showing something completely benign
• Censorship is disproportionate to actual content
• Multiple unnecessary censorship layers
• Comedic overreaction to innocent imagery
• Parody of media censorship and content warnings

FINAL RESULT:
An image with dramatic, official-looking censorship applied to completely innocent elements, creating humor through the implication that something inappropriate is being hidden when nothing scandalous exists. The subject should be recognizable but the absurd over-censorship of normal objects creates the comedy.

name: CERAMIC FIGURINE
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a small ceramic figurine. The subject should appear glazed, hand-painted, and slightly imperfect, like a decorative shelf figurine. Use realistic reflections, chips, and glaze texture so it looks like a real ceramic object photographed on a table or shelf.

name: CERAMIC TILE
message: Take a picture and convert the image into painted ceramic tiles. Glossy glaze, repeating patterns.

name: CH-CH-CH-CHIA PET
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a Chia Pet terracotta planter. Subject should be shaped like a clay pottery figurine in terracotta orange-brown color with porous ceramic texture. Dense green chia sprouts growing from the top and surfaces, creating hair/fur effect with small green leaves. 1980s infomercial product aesthetic, sitting on surface, 'Ch-ch-ch-chia!' retro novelty gift appearance. Handmade pottery look with chia seeds sprouting lush greenery.

name: CHALKBOARD ILLUSTRATION
message:
Take a picture and render the subject and scene entirely as a chalkboard drawing.

The image should look hand-drawn with white and colored chalk on a dusty black or green chalkboard. Lines should be rough, imperfect, and textured.

Include humorous chalk-written flavor text, arrows, labels, or diagrams pointing to exaggerated features or situations.

Use smudges, chalk dust, and erased areas to enhance realism.

DO NOT create a realistic photo with a chalk filter — the entire image must be illustrated in chalk style.

The final result should look like a funny classroom chalkboard drawing.

name: CHALK DUST PORTRAIT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a chalk dust portrait, as if the image was formed by powdered chalk rubbed, smeared, and blended onto a surface.

CORE CONCEPT (NON-NEGOTIABLE):
• The image must be made from loose chalk dust
• This is NOT chalk drawing with sticks
• Powder behavior must be visible

MATERIAL RULES (CRITICAL):
• Fine chalk powder texture
• Smudging, blending, and residue visible
• Uneven density and soft edges
• Chalk dust buildup in heavier areas

SURFACE RULES:
• Blackboard, chalkboard, pavement, or rough paper surface
• Surface texture visible through dust
• Residual dust outside main subject area

IDENTITY PRESERVATION:
• Subject recognizable through tonal dust placement
• Facial features formed through density variation
• Expression preserved without hard outlines

ANTI-CHEATING RULES:
• NO sharp drawn lines
• NO painted strokes
• NO airbrush or digital gradients
• NO photographic skin texture

PROCESS CUES:
• Finger smears or cloth wiping marks allowed
• Chalk residue beyond image boundaries

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like a real chalk dust portrait created by rubbing and blending powdered chalk onto a surface, soft, imperfect, and unmistakably powder-based.

name: CHAPULÍN COLORADO
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into El Chapulín Colorado, the beloved Mexican comedy superhero. The subject should wear the iconic red suit with yellow heart emblem on the chest, red and yellow striped short sleeves and pant legs, red antennae on the head, and carry the chipote chillón (squeaky hammer). Preserve the subject's recognizable facial features but add El Chapulín's characteristic expression - wide-eyed, earnest, and slightly confused. Place them in a comedic action scene with dramatic lighting but humorous situation - perhaps striking an exaggerated heroic pose while something comical happens around them. Include other elements from the show like the chirimoya (horn of plenty device) or antenitas de vinil. Use bright, saturated colors typical of the classic TV show. Capture the essence of this beloved character - well-meaning, clumsy, but ultimately heroic. Make it photorealistic as if the subject actually became El Chapulín Colorado.

name: CHARACTER CREATION SCREEN
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a life-simulation video game character creation screen.

SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a personality archetype, USE THAT archetype
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using LAST DIGIT modulo 5:
  - 0: Overconfident but Underprepared
  - 1: Socially Bold, Logically Questionable
  - 2: Highly Ambitious, Easily Distracted
  - 3: Permanently "Just Woke Up"
  - 4: Suspiciously Optimistic

CORE CONCEPT:
• The subject appears centered as a polished 3D avatar
• A floating green diamond-shaped indicator hovers above the head (generic, not copyrighted)
• Clean modern life-simulation character creator interface
• No copyrighted logos or brand names

ACCESSORIES (NOT RANDOMIZED):
• Include a visible accessory panel in the UI
• The character may wear a mix of normal and slightly silly accessories
• Examples of normal: watch, simple necklace, glasses, sneakers
• Examples of mildly silly: tiny backpack, novelty wristband, exaggerated belt buckle, oversized sunglasses
• Accessories must look like selectable in-game items
• They should feel believable within a game environment

UI ELEMENTS (MANDATORY):
• Character rotation arrows
• Outfit tabs (Everyday, Formal, Athletic, Sleepwear)
• Accessory tab visible
• Personality trait icons reflecting selected archetype
• Skill sliders (Logic, Charisma, Fitness, Cooking, Creativity)
• Randomize button visible
• Soft blue or teal gradient background

SKILL SLIDER LOGIC:
• Sliders should humorously reflect the selected archetype
• Some high, some low
• Balanced and believable — not extreme parody

STYLE:
• Clean 3D game render
• Soft studio lighting
• Slight game-engine polish
• Crisp UI panels with subtle drop shadows

IMPORTANT:
• Maintain recognizable likeness of the subject
• Do not distort anatomy
• Do not use official game trademarks
• Humor must come from trait labels, slider balance, and accessory choices

FINAL RESULT:
The final image should look like a polished character creation screen from a life-simulation game, featuring the subject as a customizable avatar with personality determined strictly by the modulo selection unless overridden by an external master prompt.

name: CHARACTER BOARD
message: Take a picture and transform it into a classic tourist character board photo. Place the subject’s face inside a cut-out hole of a painted character illustration, while the rest of the body is a flat, illustrated scene. The board may depict a humorous, heroic, historical, or themed character. Align the subject’s face naturally with the cut-out and slightly exaggerate expression for comedic effect. The painted board should look weathered or hand-painted, as if found at a tourist attraction. The final image should feel playful, kitschy, and instantly recognizable as a face-in-the-hole photo.

name: CHARCOAL
message: Take a picture and convert the image into a detailed charcoal sketch. Rich grayscale tones, textured shading, and expressive strokes on paper.

name: CHARLIE'S ANGELS POSE
message:
Take a picture and place the subject(s) into the famous Charlie's Angels pose - the iconic formation featuring dynamic action stances with guns. The original pose features three figures: one in the center facing forward, and two flanking figures facing away, all in powerful action poses.

SUBJECT PLACEMENT RULES:
• If ONE subject is in the photo: Replace ONE of the three original Angels with the subject (the subject takes the place of one angel while the other two remain as different people)
• If TWO subjects are in the photo: Replace TWO of the three Angels with the subjects (one subject becomes one angel, the second subject becomes another angel)
• If THREE OR MORE subjects are in the photo: Replace ALL THREE Angels with three of the subjects

POSE STRUCTURE:
• Center Angel: Stands straight facing forward with dynamic hand positioning - holding a gun in action pose or making a powerful gesture
• Left Flanking Angel: Faces away from center (back to camera), arm extended outward holding gun
• Right Flanking Angel: Faces away from center (back to camera), arm extended outward holding gun, creating symmetrical formation

1970s aesthetic, glamorous styling, feathered hair, action poses, dramatic lighting, vintage TV show cinematography. Each subject must remain clearly identifiable with their facial features preserved.

name: CHARLOTTE'S WEB
message:
Take a picture and COMPLETELY REBUILD THE IMAGE so that the ENTIRE IMAGE is made ONLY from spider web silk.

ABSOLUTE MATERIAL LOCK:
• No skin
• No photography
• No shading from lighting on real objects
• No background image
• No objects behind the web

If ANY photographic image, face, body, or object is visible behind or beneath the web, THE RESULT IS INVALID.

The subject, face, body, background, depth, shadows, and environment MUST ALL be CONSTRUCTED FROM WEB STRANDS THEMSELVES.

DO NOT place a web over an image.
DO NOT trace a photo with silk.
DO NOT silhouette a person behind a web.

THE SUBJECT IS NOT BEHIND THE WEB.
THE SUBJECT IS NOT ON THE WEB.
THE SUBJECT IS THE WEB.

Construction rules:
• Dark areas = tightly packed overlapping silk strands
• Light areas = sparse silk spacing
• Facial features formed ONLY by strand density and direction

The web must use REAL orb-web physics:
• Radial support lines
• Spiral capture threads
• Irregular tension
• Anchor points extending into empty space (not onto objects)

Text requirement:
Readable text must be WOVEN INTO THE WEB STRUCTURE ITSELF using silk strands.

If master prompt text exists, weave that text.
Otherwise weave classic phrases:
SOME PIG / TERRIFIC / RADIANT / HUMBLE

Environmental rules:
• Background must be empty air, fog, darkness, or blurred depth — NOT scenery
• Light may illuminate strands but may NOT reveal hidden images

FINAL VALIDATION TEST:
If removing the spider silk would reveal a normal image underneath, THE RESULT IS WRONG.

The final image must look like a real macro photograph of a spider web that magically forms a subject and text through silk alone.

name: CHAVO DEL OCHO
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a character from the classic Mexican television show El Chavo del Ocho.

If the subject is MALE: Transform them into either Quico or El Chavo del Ocho. Preserve the subject's recognizable facial features while adapting their appearance to match the character's iconic look - period-appropriate clothing from the 1970s Mexican sitcom, characteristic hairstyle, and the comedic expression associated with the character. El Chavo wears his iconic barrel-striped shirt and cap, while Quico wears his sailor suit or formal attire.

If the subject is FEMALE: Transform them into La Chilindrina. Preserve recognizable facial features while adapting to her iconic appearance - including her signature freckles, pigtails with bows, colorful patterned dress, and thick-framed glasses. Capture her mischievous, playful expression.

The setting should reflect the show's environment: the vecindad (neighborhood courtyard), with its characteristic architecture, stairs, doorways, and the nostalgic 1970s Mexican aesthetic. Include warm, slightly vintage color tones and lighting that matches the show's classic filmed appearance.

The transformation should be photorealistic but capture the comedic, innocent, and nostalgic spirit of the beloved show. Expressions should be playful, exaggerated, or characteristic of the specific character's personality - El Chavo's innocent confusion, Quico's spoiled bratty attitude, or La Chilindrina's clever mischievousness.

Maintain the subject's identity while fully immersing them in the iconic visual world of El Chavo del Ocho with period-accurate costumes, setting, and the show's signature warm, nostalgic atmosphere.

name: CHEAP REALITY
message:
Take a picture and recreate the scene as if reality itself were underproduced, incomplete, and cheaply constructed.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• This is real reality, not a set, not a game, not a parody
• The universe looks rushed, low-budget, and unfinished
• Everything technically works, but barely

CHEAP CONSTRUCTION RULES (CRITICAL):
• Surfaces may be unfinished, mismatched, or incomplete
• Materials feel low-cost, improvised, or substituted
• Reality looks like it shipped before it was ready

UNDERPRODUCTION ARTIFACTS (MANDATORY — MIX SEVERAL):
• Missing textures (flat gray, beige, or default surfaces)
• Placeholder geometry (simple cubes, planes, cylinders)
• Wireframe bleed-through on edges or corners
• UV seams and texture stretching
• Repeated low-resolution textures
• Hard edges where detail should exist

IMPORTANT EXCLUSIONS:
• NO loading bars
• NO progress meters
• NO "loading" text
• NO UI indicators

ENVIRONMENTAL DETAILS:
• Walls, floors, and objects may show:
  – Default material colors
  – Abrupt transitions between finished and unfinished areas
  – Geometry clipping or overlap
  – Simplified shapes replacing complex forms
• Some objects may look like stand-ins for what they represent

SUBJECT INTEGRATION:
• Subject behaves completely normally
• Subject accepts the cheapness as expected reality
• No reaction, awareness, or comedy posing
• Subject is not stylized or exaggerated

PHYSICS & LOGIC:
• Physics remain correct and consistent
• Gravity, scale, and perspective are accurate
• The failure is visual fidelity, not physical law

LIGHTING:
• Flat, default, or utilitarian lighting
• Inconsistent light quality between areas is acceptable
• No cinematic or dramatic lighting

CAMERA:
• Observational, neutral framing
• No stylized angles or effects
• Feels like an unremarkable photograph

TONE:
• Dry, existential, quietly absurd
• No jokes or visual gags
• Humor emerges from inevitability and neglect

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like genuine reality rendered with missing assets, placeholder geometry, and incomplete visual fidelity — as if the universe was released underfunded and unfinished, yet everyone inside it continues as if nothing is wrong.

name: CHECKMATE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into ALL the chess pieces from one side (either white or black) positioned on an actual chessboard.

The subject's facial features, expressions, and personality should be adapted into EACH of the six different chess piece types: King, Queen, Rook (2), Knight (2), Bishop (2), and Pawn (8). Each piece should be a miniature sculptural version of the subject, maintaining recognizable identity while adapted to the specific piece's form and role.

Design variations for each piece type:
- KING: Subject with crown, regal posture, tallest and most ornate
- QUEEN: Subject with elaborate crown/headpiece, powerful stance, second tallest
- BISHOPS: Subject with pointed mitre hat, diagonal-moving poses
- KNIGHTS: Subject with horse-themed elements, dynamic action poses
- ROOKS: Subject as tower/castle form, strong geometric base
- PAWNS: Subject in simplified form, smallest and most numerous

All pieces should follow classic Staunton chess piece proportions but personalized with the subject's features, clothing details, or characteristics. Each piece should be clearly identifiable as both the subject AND the chess piece type.

Arrange all 16 pieces (1 King, 1 Queen, 2 Rooks, 2 Knights, 2 Bishops, 8 Pawns) in proper starting chess positions on a realistic wooden or marble chessboard. Include opposing traditional chess pieces on the other side for context and scale.

Lighting should be dramatic and strategic, casting shadows that emphasize the three-dimensional sculptural quality of each piece. Use proper perspective showing the full board setup.

The final image should look like a photograph of a complete custom chess set where every piece on one side is a personalized version of the subject, ready for an actual game. The subject becomes an entire army of chess pieces, not just one.

name: CHEER-LEADER
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a female cheerleader regardless of their gender. Dress them in a classic cheerleading outfit with pom-poms, skirt, and team colors.

Give them energetic poses, big smiles, and stadium or gymnasium background.

The result should be playful, confident, and clearly recognizable as a cheerleader scene.

name: CHEESE TOUCH
message:
Take a picture and transform the entire scene as if everything has been infected by a mysterious 'cheese touch.'

Convert the subject, clothing, nearby objects, and visible environment into cheese-based versions of themselves. Use a variety of recognizable cheeses (cheddar, Swiss, mozzarella, brie, blue cheese, etc.) with appropriate textures, holes, melts, crumbles, and rinds.

The subject should still be clearly identifiable, but their skin, hair, and clothing should appear sculpted from cheese rather than flesh or fabric. Objects should retain their original shapes but be unmistakably made of cheese.

Avoid cartoon flatness — cheese should look tactile, slightly glossy or matte depending on type, with realistic imperfections. Use playful lighting to emphasize texture.

Ensure the entire composition remains readable on a small screen. The result should feel ridiculous, slightly disturbing, and very funny — as if reality itself has turned into cheese.

name: CHILDHOOD VERSION
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a realistic younger version of themselves, depicting natural age regression while preserving identity.

AGE REGRESSION SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies an age range, USE THAT RANGE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY — you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 11:
  - 0: Age 4–5
  - 1: Age 6–7
  - 2: Age 8–9
  - 3: Age 10–11
  - 4: Age 12–13
  - 5: Age 14–15
  - 6: Age 16–17
  - 7: Age 18–19
  - 8: Age 20–21
  - 9: Age 22–23
  - 10: Age 24–26

TRANSFORM THE SUBJECT:
• Subject MUST remain clearly recognizable
• Preserve facial geometry and bone structure relative to age
• Maintain eye shape, nose structure, and facial spacing
• No fantasy, cartoon, or exaggerated baby-like features
• Gender-neutral presentation

AGE-SPECIFIC REALISM RULES:
• Ages 4–9: Softer facial features, fuller cheeks, childlike proportions
• Ages 10–15: Early facial definition, subtle maturity
• Ages 16–19: Teen features, leaner face, youthful skin
• Ages 20–26: Young adult appearance with minimal aging, smooth skin

EXCLUSIONS:
• No infant or toddler depictions
• No stylized, animated, or novelty effects
• No artificial beauty filters
• No aging artifacts inappropriate to the selected age

CLOTHING & STYLING:
• Age-appropriate clothing only
• Neutral, timeless styles (avoid strong era-specific fashion)
• No costumes or themed outfits
• Hair and grooming appropriate for the selected age

LIGHTING & TONE:
• Soft, natural lighting
• Subtle nostalgic warmth (photographic, not artificial)
• Avoid heavy filters or aggressive color grading

SETTING & COMPOSITION:
• Same environment and framing as original image
• Full-body or mid-body view preferred
• FULL image visible with all four corners present
• No cropping, zooming, or reframing

STYLE:
• Photorealistic
• Respectful and authentic
• Looks like a genuine photograph from that stage of life

FINAL RESULT:
The image should depict a believable younger version of the subject at the selected age range, preserving identity and realism while presenting a natural, age-appropriate appearance.

name: CHILD SKETCH ARTIST
message: Take a picture and make the subject look like a childlike black and white sketch using simple shapes as if drawn by a six year old.

name: CHINESE INK WASH
message: Take a picture and transform the image into a traditional Chinese ink wash painting. Use flowing brushstrokes, monochrome tones, soft gradients, and poetic negative space.

name: CHOCOLATE SCULPTURE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a sculpted chocolate figure. The chocolate should appear glossy, slightly textured, and solid, with realistic reflections and subtle imperfections from molding.

Include a clearly visible bite taken from the subject, showing the inner texture of the chocolate. Preserve the subject’s recognizable facial structure and details through the chocolate form while maintaining realistic thickness and volume.

The subject should appear as a real chocolate sculpture placed on a surface, with appropriate shadows and lighting. Avoid CGI or drawn appearance. Ensure the composition is readable on a small screen and the chocolate looks physically edible.

name: CINEMATIC HORROR
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a cinematic horror character while preserving the subject’s recognizable facial structure, body proportions, and identity. Apply unsettling but non-graphic visual traits such as desaturated or ashen skin tones, darkened eye areas, an intense or vacant gaze, and subtly distressed clothing.  Ensure the subject appears physically present in the scene and fully integrated with the surroundings. Render the final image with photorealistic detail and a suspenseful horror aesthetic.

name: CIRCUS STAR
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a circus or carnival performer with authentic vintage circus styling.

CIRCUS ROLE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a role, USE THAT ROLE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 15:
  - 0: Ringmaster - red tailcoat, top hat, white gloves, handlebar mustache, whip or baton, commanding presence in center ring
  - 1: Clown - colorful baggy costume, oversized shoes, red nose, white face paint, exaggerated makeup, silly props, comedic pose
  - 2: Trapeze Artist - sequined leotard, athletic build, mid-swing on trapeze bar high above, graceful dramatic pose, safety net below
  - 3: Lion Tamer - safari-style outfit, chair and whip, standing confidently with lions, brave fearless expression, circus big cats
  - 4: Strongman - leopard print singlet, handlebar mustache, lifting enormous barbell or dumbbells, bulging muscles, oil-shined body
  - 5: Bearded Lady - elegant Victorian dress, full natural beard, dignified sitting pose, sideshow banner, confident regal bearing
  - 6: Contortionist - flexible pose (backbend, splits, twisted position), minimal costume, circus mat or small stage, impossible flexibility
  - 7: Juggler - colorful costume, multiple objects in air (balls, clubs, torches), focused expression, dynamic motion capture
  - 8: Tightrope Walker - balancing pole, high wire stretched across big top, confident balanced pose, crowd far below, sequined outfit
  - 9: Human Cannonball - helmet and protective suit, emerging from large cannon with smoke, dramatic flying pose, circus cannon visible
  - 10: Sword Swallower - theatrical costume, sword down throat, concentrated expression, sideshow stage, dangerous feat
  - 11: Fire Breather - tribal or medieval costume, flames shooting from mouth, dramatic nighttime lighting, torches visible
  - 12: Acrobat - form-fitting costume, mid-tumble or handstand, circus ring or stage, athletic grace, multiple poses suggested
  - 13: Knife Thrower - dramatic costume, throwing knives at assistant on spinning wheel, showman pose, sideshow tent
  - 14: Fortune Teller - ornate robes, crystal ball, tarot cards, mystical tent interior, mysterious atmosphere, carnival aesthetic

TRANSFORM THE SUBJECT:
• Subject's face remains recognizable
• Costume authentic to selected role and vintage circus era (1890s-1950s)
• Appropriate props and equipment for the role
• Body language and pose characteristic of the performance
• Makeup or styling appropriate (face paint for clown, theatrical makeup for performers)

SETTING:
• Vintage circus big top interior with striped canvas
• Center ring with sawdust floor
• OR sideshow tent with painted banners
• Circus lighting (spotlights, dramatic shadows)
• Audience visible in background on tiered seating
• Other circus performers or animals in background
• Vintage circus posters, banners, or signage

STYLE:
• Vintage circus aesthetic (golden age 1890s-1950s)
• Sepia tones or faded color photography
• Slight grain or aged photograph quality
• Dramatic theatrical lighting
• Photorealistic but with nostalgic vintage feel
• Subject appears as authentic circus performer from the era

ATMOSPHERE:
• Excitement and spectacle
• Danger and daring for dangerous acts
• Wonder and amazement
• Vintage carnival magic
• Greatest Show on Earth energy

FINAL RESULT:
The image should look like an authentic vintage circus photograph showing the subject as a genuine circus performer from the golden age of American circus, complete with period-accurate costume, props, and setting that captures the magic and spectacle of the traveling circus.

name: CITY IN TIME
message: Take a picture and place the subject standing naturally within a realistic urban environment. The city, location, and date are defined externally. Integrate the subject seamlessly into the scene so they appear physically present, with correct scale, perspective, lighting, shadows, and reflections. Match architecture, street layout, vehicles, signage, clothing styles, weather, and overall atmosphere appropriate to the specified city and date. Preserve the subject’s facial identity, proportions, posture, and personality while making the scene photorealistic and historically or contemporarily accurate.

name: CLASSIC TV COMMERCIAL-ADAPTATION
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a scene from a famous classic television commercial. Select the commercial automatically based on the subject’s surroundings, visible objects, clothing, actions, or mood — for example:
• A soda or bottle → Coca-Cola or Dr Pepper
• Fast food context → Wendy’s or McDonald’s
• Party or outdoor gathering → Budweiser
• Family or wholesome setting → classic Coca-Cola or cereal ads

Place the subject directly INTO the commercial as if they are the main actor or spokesperson, fully integrated into the scene rather than pasted on. Adapt wardrobe, pose, expression, and lighting so the subject naturally belongs in the advertisement.

Recreate the commercial’s iconic visual language: era-appropriate color grading, film grain, lighting style, set design, camera framing, and product placement. Use a cinematic still-frame composition that feels like a paused moment from a TV ad.

Include a famous, recognizable tagline from the chosen commercial displayed clearly within the scene (on-screen text, signage, packaging, or lower-third caption). The tagline must be fully visible, legible, and feel naturally embedded in the ad design.

If a real brand logo or product appears in the original image or is provided via external master prompt, prioritize selecting that brand’s commercial.

Ensure the full frame is visible with no cropping of the subject, product, or tagline. When a brand is selected, prioritize its most iconic and culturally recognizable catchphrase from classic television commercials (e.g., Wendy’s “Where’s the Beef?”, Budweiser “Whassup!”, Coca-Cola “I’d Like to Buy the World a Coke”), and display it prominently. The scene should feel like a nostalgic parody or affectionate homage to the original commercial, not a modern advertisement or exact recreation. The final image should feel nostalgic, instantly recognizable, humorous, and clearly readable on a small screen — like a classic commercial screenshot frozen in time.

name: CLASSIC TV COMMERCIAL-FORCED
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a scene from a famous classic television commercial.

COMMERCIAL SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a commercial/brand, USE THAT COMMERCIAL
• If a brand logo or product is visible in the photo, use that brand's commercial
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 30:
  - 0: Coca-Cola "I'd Like to Buy the World a Coke" (1971) - hilltop, diverse group singing, peace and harmony
  - 1: Wendy's "Where's the Beef?" (1984) - elderly woman at counter, tiny burger, demanding more meat
  - 2: Budweiser "Whassup?!" (1999-2000) - friends on phone, watching game, casual hanging out
  - 3: Apple "1984" (1984) - dystopian, woman throwing hammer at screen, Big Brother, Macintosh launch
  - 4: McDonald's "You Deserve a Break Today" (1970s) - family at McDonald's, happy meal, golden arches
  - 5: Nike "Just Do It" (1988-1990s) - athlete in action, swoosh logo, motivational sports moment
  - 6: Pepsi "Pepsi Generation" (1960s-1980s) - young people having fun, beach or party, Pepsi can prominent
  - 7: Miller Lite "Tastes Great, Less Filling" (1970s-1980s - sports bar, athletes debating, beer
  - 8: Life Cereal "Mikey Likes It" (1972) - kids at breakfast table, trying cereal, "He likes it!"
  - 9: Alka-Seltzer "Plop Plop Fizz Fizz" (1970s) - tablet dropping in water, relief, upset stomach
  - 10: Oscar Mayer "I Wish I Were an Oscar Mayer Wiener" (1960s-1970s) - kids singing, hot dog car
  - 11: Folgers "The Best Part of Wakin' Up" (1980s-1990s) - morning kitchen, coffee brewing, family
  - 12: Burger King "Have It Your Way" (1970s) - customizing burger order, flame-broiled
  - 13: Volkswagen "Think Small" (1960s) - minimalist, VW Beetle, clever copy, simple product shot
  - 14: California Raisins "I Heard It Through the Grapevine" (1986) - claymation raisins dancing, Motown
  - 15: Clairol "Does She or Doesn't She?" (1950s-1960s) - hair color, woman with beautiful hair, mysterious
  - 16: Memorex "Is It Live or Is It Memorex?" (1970s-1980s) - Ella Fitzgerald, glass shattering, audio quality
  - 17: Energizer Bunny (1989-present) - pink bunny with drum, keeps going and going
  - 18: Tootsie Pop "How Many Licks?" (1970) - boy asking owl, "The world may never know"
  - 19: Kit Kat "Gimme a Break" (1980s-1990s) - breaking chocolate bar, jingle, snack time
  - 20: M&Ms "Melts in Your Mouth, Not in Your Hand" (1950s-present) - colorful candies, animated characters
  - 21: Mastercard "Priceless" (1997-present) - list of prices, final item priceless, emotional moment
  - 22: Old Spice "The Man Your Man Could Smell Like" (2010) - shirtless man, bathroom, surreal transitions
  - 23: Dos Equis "The Most Interesting Man in the World" (2006-2016) - bearded man, adventures, "Stay thirsty"
  - 24: Got Milk? (1993-present) - milk mustache, celebrity, white upper lip
  - 25: Snickers "You're Not You When You're Hungry" (2010s) - person acting strange, eats Snickers, transforms
  - 26: Geico Gecko (1999-present) - British gecko, insurance savings, 15 minutes could save you
  - 27: Frosted Flakes "They're Grrreat!" (1950s-present) - Tony the Tiger, cereal bowl, enthusiastic
  - 28: Subway "Eat Fresh" (2000s) - Jared or fresh ingredients, sandwich making, healthy choice
  - 29: State Farm "Like a Good Neighbor" (1971-present) - emergency, jingle, agent appears magically

SUBJECT INTEGRATION:
• Subject as the main actor or spokesperson in the commercial
• NOT pasted on - fully integrated into the scene
• Subject appears as if they ARE the commercial talent
• Wardrobe matches era and commercial style
• Pose and expression authentic to the ad
• Subject's face recognizable but styled for the commercial

COMMERCIAL RECREATION:
• Era-appropriate color grading (1950s-2010s)
• Period film grain and video quality
• Authentic lighting style of that era's TV production
• Set design matching original commercial
• Camera framing and composition of TV advertising
• Product placement prominent and authentic
• Brand logo clearly visible

TAGLINE DISPLAY (CRITICAL):
• Famous tagline from the commercial CLEARLY VISIBLE
• On-screen text, signage, packaging, or lower-third caption
• Fully legible and integrated naturally
• Authentic typography for that brand and era
• Tagline is the punchline - must be readable

FULL FRAME VISIBLE:
• Complete composition shown - no cropping
• Subject fully visible
• Product clearly shown
• Tagline completely readable
• All elements within frame
• Suitable for small screen viewing

STYLE:
• Nostalgic commercial aesthetic
• Paused TV ad moment
• Affectionate parody or homage
• NOT a modern recreation - period authentic
• Frozen-in-time classic commercial screenshot
• Instantly recognizable to those who remember the ad

ATMOSPHERE:
• Warm nostalgic feeling
• Slightly cheesy retro advertising
• Earnest commercial sincerity
• Pop culture time capsule
• Humorous but respectful

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject fully integrated into a classic TV commercial scene as the main actor, with era-appropriate styling, authentic set design, product placement, and the famous tagline clearly visible - looking like a paused moment from an iconic television advertisement with full frame visible and easily readable on small screens.

name: CLAYMATION
message: Take a picture and transform the image into claymation-style. Characters appear fully sculpted from clay with fingerprints and textures.

name: CLEANUP CHAOS
message:
Take a picture of a room or indoor space. Analyze the scene to determine whether it appears mostly clean or messy.

If the room appears messy or cluttered, transform it into a clean, organized version of the same space. Remove clutter, straighten objects, clean surfaces, neatly arrange items, and improve overall order while preserving the original layout, furniture, and lighting.

If the room appears clean or orderly, transform it into a realistically messy version. Add believable clutter such as scattered clothes, papers, cups, toys, or everyday items. Introduce mild disorder without destroying the room or making it unsafe.

Maintain realism, consistent lighting, and the same camera perspective. The transformation should feel like the same room before and after tidying or neglect, and remain clearly readable on a small screen.

name: CLONE
message:
Take a picture and subtly duplicate the subject so that ONE hidden clone appears somewhere in the scene.

CLONE PLACEMENT (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a hiding method, USE THAT
• If no method is specified externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 5:
  - 0: Clone peeking from behind an object (door, wall, tree, furniture)
  - 1: Clone photobombing from the edge of the frame
  - 2: Clone reflected in a mirror, window, or reflective surface
  - 3: Clone partially obscured in the background, clearly watching
  - 4: Clone interacting mischievously (waving, making a face, pointing at the main subject)

CLONE RULES:
• EXACTLY ONE clone is allowed
• Clone must be smaller or less dominant than the main subject
• Clone must be clearly the same person
• Clone should not be centered or immediately obvious

IDENTITY RULES:
• Main subject remains the primary focus
• Facial identity preserved for both subject and clone
• Clone expression should contrast with the main subject when possible

TONE:
• Playful, humorous, and intentional
• Should feel like a visual Easter egg
• No horror, no surreal distortion

ENVIRONMENT:
• Environment must logically support the hiding spot
• No floating or impossible placements

CAMERA:
• Normal photographic framing
• Viewer should notice the clone AFTER a second look

RESTRICTIONS:
• No cartoon or animated styles
• No text overlays or captions
• No additional clones beyond one

FINAL RESULT:
The image should feel like a normal photo at first glance, with a single mischievous clone quietly hiding or photobombing the scene once the viewer notices.

name: CLOUD NINE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject so it appears **entirely made of clouds**, with no remaining human, animal, or object materials visible.

The subject’s **entire form — head, body, limbs, and features — must be constructed exclusively from cloud matter**. Do not show skin, clothing, solid surfaces, or mixed materials. The subject must not appear inside clouds; the subject itself is the cloud.

The **overall cloud shape must follow the subject’s silhouette, posture, and proportions**. The subject’s outline governs the form.

Determine the cloud **type** as follows:
• If the subject is animate (person or animal), select the cloud type based on the subject’s apparent emotion:
  – Happy or playful → **Cumulus** (bright, puffy, well-defined)
  – Sad, tired, or withdrawn → **Nimbostratus** (heavy, low, rain-filled)
  – Angry, intense, or aggressive → **Cumulonimbus** (towering, dense, storm-like)
  – Calm or neutral → **Stratus** (smooth, layered, subdued)
• If the subject is inanimate, use **Altocumulus** clouds with a neutral, evenly spaced texture.

Use cloud density, lighting, internal shadow, and volume to imply facial features, limbs, and expression without outlines or solid edges.

Avoid solid ground unless contextually appropriate. Use sky gradients, mist, or distant horizons to support the illusion.

Ensure the silhouette remains readable on a small screen. The final image should feel surreal, expressive, and poetic — as if the subject fully transformed into a specific type of weather.

name: CLUE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a playable CLUE character card and depict a full CLUE guess laid down by a player.

CHARACTER SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If external master prompt specifies a character, USE THAT
• Otherwise SELECT using RANDOM SEED modulo 12:
  - 0: Mr. Boddy
  - 1: Dr. Black
  - 2: Boden Black
  - 3: Miss Scarlett
  - 4: Colonel Mustard
  - 5: Mrs. White
  - 6: Chef White
  - 7: Mr. Green
  - 8: Reverend Green
  - 9: Mayor Green
  - 10: Mrs. Peacock
  - 11: Professor Plum

LOCATION CARD SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If external master prompt specifies a location, USE THAT
• Otherwise SELECT using RANDOM SEED modulo 9:
  - 0: Study
  - 1: Hall
  - 2: Lounge
  - 3: Library
  - 4: Billiard Room
  - 5: Dining Room
  - 6: Conservatory
  - 7: Ballroom
  - 8: Kitchen

WEAPON CARD SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If external master prompt specifies a weapon, USE THAT
• Otherwise SELECT using RANDOM SEED modulo 6:
  - 0: Candlestick
  - 1: Dagger
  - 2: Lead Pipe
  - 3: Revolver
  - 4: Rope
  - 5: Wrench

IDENTITY & COSTUME RULES (NON-NEGOTIABLE):
• The CHARACTER card MUST use the subject’s real face
• Facial structure, eyes, nose, and expression must remain clearly recognizable
• Do NOT replace or blend the face with generic illustrations
• The subject must wear the full iconic attire of the selected CLUE character
• Clothing colors, hairstyle, accessories, and props must match traditional CLUE depictions
• Subject gender does NOT restrict character selection
• The subject must appear as if cast to portray the character

CARD COMPOSITION (CRITICAL):
• The final image MUST show THREE cards placed side-by-side or slightly fanned:
  – Character card (with the subject’s face)
  – Location card (official CLUE room)
  – Weapon card (official CLUE weapon)
• Cards should appear physically placed on a table or game surface
• Perspective should resemble a player revealing or declaring a guess
• Card sizes, borders, and proportions must match real CLUE cards

STYLE:
• Full four-corner playable card designs
• Classic CLUE visual language (illustrated, painted, or vintage-style)
• Clean borders and readable layouts
• Slight tabletop shadows for realism

FINAL RESULT:
The image must convincingly depict a CLUE gameplay moment, showing a valid player guess — for example: Reverend Green in the Study with the Dagger — with the subject’s recognizable face on the character card, alongside authentic location and weapon cards, as if laid down during an actual game.

name: COEN BROTHERS FILM
message:
Take a picture and place the subject into a Coen Brothers film scene.

FILM/SCENE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a Coen Brothers film, USE THAT FILM
• If no film is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE Coen Brothers film using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 15:
  - 0: Fargo (1996 Minnesota, snow-covered crime, wood chipper, Marge Gunderson investigation)
  - 1: The Big Lebowski (bowling alley, The Dude's apartment, dream sequences, rug that ties the room together)
  - 2: No Country for Old Men (Texas desert, motel shootouts, coin flip tension, Anton Chigurh)
  - 3: O Brother, Where Art Thou? (Depression-era South, chain gang escape, rural Mississippi)
  - 4: Raising Arizona (desert trailer parks, convenience store robbery, quirky domesticity)
  - 5: Miller's Crossing (1920s gangster, forest execution scene, fedoras and Tommy guns)
  - 6: Barton Fink (1940s Hollywood, creepy hotel hallways, writing desperation)
  - 7: The Man Who Wasn't There (1940s noir, barbershop, black and white existentialism)
  - 8: A Serious Man (1960s suburban Jewish community, uncertainty and Job-like suffering)
  - 9: True Grit (Western frontier, courtroom, wilderness pursuit)
  - 10: Inside Llewyn Davis (1960s folk music scene, Greenwich Village, struggling artist)
  - 11: Burn After Reading (gym settings, CIA paranoia, D.C. absurdism)
  - 12: The Hudsucker Proxy (1950s corporate skyscraper, art deco office)
  - 13: Intolerable Cruelty (courtroom, mansion, stylized romantic comedy)
  - 14: The Ballad of Buster Scruggs (Western anthology, frontier towns, gallows humor)

Use their distinctive visual style: perfectly composed symmetrical framing, absurdist dark comedy situations, eccentric character styling, and deadpan cinematography. Show the subject as a quirky character in an oddball situation - perhaps caught in circumstances beyond their control with a bewildered or stoic expression. Include Coen Brothers elements from the selected film: retro Americana settings, vintage cars, small-town locations, period-specific costumes and props. Use their characteristic lighting - naturalistic but carefully composed, often featuring golden hour warmth or harsh fluorescent interiors. Capture their blend of dark humor and existential dread - situations that are simultaneously funny and unsettling. Make it look like a frame from the selected film with that unique Coen Brothers tone with the subject and additional characters from that film integrated seamlessly into the world.

name: COINED
message: Take a picture and transform the subject's portrait onto the face of a coin. The subject's head should appear in profile or three-quarter view as embossed relief on the coin's surface, rendered in metallic texture - gold, silver, bronze, or copper. Show the portrait raised from the coin surface with dimensional depth and shadow, as if minted or stamped into metal. Surround the portrait with coin text elements around the rim. If master prompt text is provided, incorporate that text as the inscription on the coin - either around the rim, below the portrait, or as the motto. If no master prompt text is provided, use traditional coin phrases like denomination, year, country name, or Latin phrases ('E PLURIBUS UNUM', 'IN GOD WE TRUST'). Include decorative borders, stars, or laurel wreaths. The coin style can vary from ancient Roman/Greek coins with profile emperors, to medieval coins with crowned monarchs, to modern presidential coins with contemporary styling. Include authentic numismatic details: edge ridges (reeding), metallic patina or tarnish, slight wear showing age, that characteristic coin relief depth. The entire composition should be circular showing the full coin face. Use realistic metal textures - reflective highlights on raised surfaces, shadows in recessed areas, authentic metallic sheen. Make it look like an actual photographed commemorative or currency coin with the subject immortalized as the featured portrait, whether ancient artifact or modern minting.

name: COINS
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a real coin from a country around the world, with the subject's face replacing the historical figure on the coin.

COIN SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a coin or country, USE THAT COIN
• If no coin is provided, SELECT EXACTLY ONE coin using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 50:
  - 0: United States Quarter (Washington profile)
  - 1: United States Penny (Lincoln profile)
  - 2: United States Nickel (Jefferson profile)
  - 3: United States Dime (Roosevelt profile)
  - 4: United States Half Dollar (Kennedy profile)
  - 5: Canadian Dollar Coin - Loonie (loon on one side, Queen on other)
  - 6: Canadian Two Dollar Coin - Toonie (polar bear, Queen)
  - 7: British Pound Sterling (Queen Elizabeth II profile)
  - 8: British 50 Pence (Queen profile)
  - 9: Euro 1 Euro Coin (various national sides with portraits)
  - 10: Euro 2 Euro Coin (various national sides with portraits)
  - 11: Australian Dollar Coin (kangaroos, Queen profile)
  - 12: New Zealand Dollar Coin (kiwi bird, Queen profile)
  - 13: South African Rand (springbok, Nelson Mandela)
  - 14: Indian 10 Rupee Coin (Ashoka Lion emblem)
  - 15: Japanese 500 Yen Coin (paulownia flower, no portrait - adapt)
  - 16: Chinese 1 Yuan Coin (chrysanthemum, no portrait - adapt)
  - 17: Mexican 10 Peso Coin (Aztec calendar, Miguel Hidalgo)
  - 18: Brazilian 1 Real Coin (national arms)
  - 19: Swiss 5 Franc Coin (Helvetia profile)
  - 20: Swedish 10 Krona Coin (King Carl XVI Gustaf)
  - 21: Norwegian 20 Krone Coin (King Harald V)
  - 22: Danish 20 Krone Coin (Queen Margrethe II)
  - 23: Russian 10 Ruble Coin (Russian coat of arms)
  - 24: Polish 2 Zloty Coin (Polish eagle emblem)
  - 25: Turkish 1 Lira Coin (Mustafa Kemal Atatürk)
  - 26: Argentine 1 Peso Coin (Sun of May emblem)
  - 27: Chilean 100 Peso Coin (Bernardo O'Higgins profile)
  - 28: Thai 10 Baht Coin (King Rama IX)
  - 29: Singapore Dollar Coin (national arms, lion)
  - 30: Hong Kong 10 Dollar Coin (bauhinia flower)
  - 31: Israeli 10 Shekel Coin (ancient Jewish symbols)
  - 32: Egyptian 1 Pound Coin (Tutankhamun or Cleopatra)
  - 33: Saudi Arabian 2 Riyal Coin (crossed swords and palm tree)
  - 34: UAE 1 Dirham Coin (falcon and jug)
  - 35: South Korean 500 Won Coin (red-crowned crane)
  - 36: Philippine 10 Piso Coin (national heroes)
  - 37: Indonesian 1000 Rupiah Coin (Garuda bird emblem)
  - 38: Malaysian Ringgit Coin (hibiscus flower and Parliament)
  - 39: Pakistani 10 Rupee Coin (Quaid-e-Azam portrait)
  - 40: Bangladeshi 5 Taka Coin (national emblem)
  - 41: Nigerian 2 Naira Coin (coat of arms)
  - 42: Kenyan 20 Shilling Coin (Jomo Kenyatta profile)
  - 43: Moroccan 10 Dirham Coin (King Mohammed VI)
  - 44: Icelandic 100 Krona Coin (cod fish - adapt with portrait)
  - 45: Irish 1 Euro Coin (harp symbol - adapt)
  - 46: Greek 2 Euro Coin (Europa and bull)
  - 47: Italian 1 Euro Coin (Vitruvian Man by da Vinci)
  - 48: French 2 Euro Coin (tree of life)
  - 49: German 2 Euro Coin (Federal Eagle)

COIN AUTHENTICITY (CRITICAL):
• Exact recreation of the specified real coin
• BOTH sides of the coin must be accurate:
  - Obverse (heads): typically features portrait - REPLACE with subject
  - Reverse (tails): maintain exact original design
• The ONLY change is replacing the existing portrait with the subject's face
• All other elements remain identical to the genuine coin

OBVERSE (PORTRAIT SIDE) DESIGN:
• Subject's face replaces the historical figure's portrait
• Subject rendered in the SAME style as original coin portrait:
  - Profile view if original was profile (most common)
  - Three-quarter view if original was three-quarter
  - Same relief depth and detail level
  - Same engraving style and line work
• Subject's portrait faces the same direction as original
• Subject appears to be from the same era as the coin's design

PORTRAIT INTEGRATION:
• Subject's facial features clearly recognizable
• Portrait style matches coin's artistic period:
  - Classical/neoclassical for older coins
  - Modern/realistic for contemporary coins
  - Art deco for mid-20th century coins
• Relief depth authentic to actual coin minting:
  - High relief for some commemorative coins
  - Low relief for most circulating coins
  - Appropriate depth creates shadows and dimension
• Subject's hair, clothing, and accessories adapted to match original figure

COIN SPECIFICATIONS PRESERVED:
• Exact diameter of the actual coin
• Correct metal composition appearance:
  - Copper (pennies, some euros)
  - Nickel-copper (quarters, dimes)
  - Bronze (some international coins)
  - Brass (some dollars, international)
  - Bi-metallic (euros, some dollars)
  - Silver appearance (commemorative, some international)
  - Gold appearance (commemorative, some international)
• Proper edge design:
  - Reeded (ridged) edges on most coins
  - Smooth edges on some coins
  - Lettered edges on some pounds and commemoratives
• Correct thickness and weight appearance

TYPOGRAPHY AND TEXT:
• Country name exactly as on original coin
• Denomination value in original position and font
• Date/year on coin (can be current year or historical)
• National motto if present ("E PLURIBUS UNUM", "LIBERTY", "IN GOD WE TRUST", etc.)
• Mint mark if present (D, P, S for US, etc.)
• "QUARTER DOLLAR", "ONE CENT", "FIVE CENTS" etc. as original
• Text follows the curve of the coin precisely
• Font matches the official coin typography

REVERSE (TAILS SIDE) DESIGN:
• Completely unchanged from original coin
• National emblems, animals, or symbols preserved:
  - Eagle for US coins
  - Maple leaf for Canadian
  - National monuments or symbols
  - Commemorative designs if applicable
• All text, dates, and denominations exact
• Relief and detail match the genuine article

METAL FINISH AND PATINA:
• Appropriate finish for coin type:
  - Proof finish: mirror-like fields, frosted relief
  - Uncirculated: mint luster, no wear
  - Circulated: natural wear on high points
  - Aged: patina appropriate to metal and age
• Light interaction with metal:
  - Copper: reddish-brown or aged green patina
  - Silver: bright white or toned gray/gold
  - Gold: warm yellow or rose gold
  - Nickel: gray-white metallic
  - Brass: yellow-gold
• Realistic reflectivity and luster
• Slight variations in tone across surface

PHYSICAL PRESENTATION:
• Coin photographed to show dimension and relief
• Lighting creates shadows in recessed areas
• Highlights on raised relief elements
• Slight angle to show 3D depth
• Both obverse and reverse visible (shown separately or front/back)
• Natural metal texture and grain
• Edge visible showing reeding or smoothness
• Scale appropriate (show actual size or in context)

NUMISMATIC ACCURACY:
• Subject portrait integrated with professional engraving quality
• No anachronistic elements
• Subject's portrait in appropriate historical dress if coin is historical
• Modern portrait style if coin is contemporary
• Seamless integration—appears as original mint design
• Would pass casual inspection as an official variant

CONTEXT AND DISPLAY:
• Coin on neutral background or in collector display
• Proper photography showing mint quality
• Both sides shown clearly (dual image or separate)
• Slight rotation to show relief and dimension
• Professional numismatic presentation
• May include holder, case, or certification sleeve for realism

FINAL RESULT:
A photorealistic reproduction of an actual circulating or commemorative coin from a country around the world, where the subject's face has been expertly integrated into the portrait position, maintaining all official design elements, typography, national symbols, and numismatic standards. The coin appears authentic in every detail—correct metal composition, appropriate wear and patina, proper relief depth, and official typography—with only the portrait replaced by the subject's recognizable likeness rendered in the same engraving style as the original. Both obverse (portrait side with subject) and reverse (national symbol side) are accurately depicted, creating a convincing alternate-history coin that honors the subject as if they were the nation's commemorated leader or figure.

name: COLLAGE
message: Take a picture in the style of an artistic paper collage with visible cut edges and layered materials.

name: COLLECTIBLE TOY
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a collectible toy encased inside its original packaging. Adapt the packaging style to match the type of toy: for example, a car becomes a Matchbox or Hot Wheels package, an action figure or superhero becomes a classic action figure box, a person becomes a Barbie-style doll package, etc. Use the subject’s characteristics, clothing, and personality to inspire the toy design and accessories. Generate flavor text and captions on the packaging based on the subject’s appearance, traits, and surroundings, making it feel like an authentic collectible. Ensure the subject remains recognizable while fully integrated as a toy. Render the final image in high detail with realistic reflections, packaging materials, and lighting, so it looks like a real collectible ready for display.

name: COLOR BY NUMBERS
message: Take a picture and transform it into a color-by-numbers activity page. Convert the subject into outlined sections, each labeled with a number corresponding to a specific color. The image should be divided into geometric and organic shapes - similar colors grouped into numbered regions. Use thick black outlines defining each section clearly, with numbers printed inside each area indicating which color to use. Include a color key/legend at the bottom or side showing: '1 = Red', '2 = Blue', '3 = Yellow', etc., with 8-15 different colors total. Some sections should already be colored in (showing the activity partially completed), while other sections remain white with just the number visible. Use typical color-by-numbers aesthetic: simplified shapes, clear boundaries, numbers legible inside each section, varying section sizes from tiny details to large areas. Show the page with coloring supplies nearby - colored pencils, crayons, or markers, maybe a partially colored section demonstrating the process. The outlines should be clean and bold for easy following. Include typical activity book elements: page number in corner, title 'Color By Numbers', possibly difficulty rating or age recommendation. The subject should be recognizable through the outlined simplified shapes even before coloring. Make it look like an actual color-by-numbers activity page from a coloring book, either fresh and uncolored or partially completed with some sections filled in.

name: COMEDY CLASSIC
message:
Take a picture of the subject and place them into a scene from a cult comedy film.

FILM SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a cult comedy film, USE THAT FILM
• If no film is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE film using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 30:
  - 0: Ghostbusters (1984)
  - 1: Animal House (1978)
  - 2: Caddyshack (1980)
  - 3: Some Like It Hot (1959)
  - 4: Blazing Saddles (1974)
  - 5: Annie Hall (1977)
  - 6: Planes Trains and Automobiles (1987)
  - 7: The Hangover (2009)
  - 8: Coming to America (1988)
  - 9: Beverly Hills Cop (1984)
  - 10: Trading Places (1983)
  - 11: A Fish Called Wanda (1988)
  - 12: The Big Lebowski (1998)
  - 13: Dazed and Confused (1993)
  - 14: Wayne's World (1992)
  - 15: Monty Python and the Holy Grail (1975)
  - 16: This Is Spinal Tap (1984)
  - 17: The Princess Bride (1987)
  - 18: Young Frankenstein (1974)
  - 19: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
  - 20: Stripes (1981)
  - 21: Groundhog Day (1993)
  - 22: Happy Gilmore (1996)
  - 23: Dumb and Dumber (1994)
  - 24: Austin Powers (1997)
  - 25: Anchorman (2004)
  - 26: Superbad (2007)
  - 27: Step Brothers (2008)
  - 28: Zoolander (2001)
  - 29: Old School (2003)

The subject should be integrated as the central focus, interacting with the environment and versions of the scene's characters.

Props, costumes, and lighting should match the film style, making the scene look like a real movie still.

Optional flavor text from the master prompt can guide which gag or absurd twist is included (e.g., subject holding the proton pack upside-down, bowling in an exaggerated pose, or mimicking a famous line with a ridiculous expression).

The final image should be funny, cinematic, and instantly recognizable as a cult comedy film, with the subject as the star.

name: COMIC BOOK COVER
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into the star of a comic book cover.

FRANCHISE/HERO SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a franchise or hero, USE THAT FRANCHISE/HERO
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED

  - 0: Spider-Man (Marvel) - web-slinging, New York City

  - 6: Justice League (DC) - DC's premier team
  - 7: Iron Man (Marvel) - armored hero, arc reactor
  - 8: The Flash (DC) - speed force, lightning
  - 9: Hulk (Marvel) - green rage monster
  - 10: Captain America (Marvel) - star-spangled hero
  - 11: Green Lantern (DC) - power ring, constructs
  - 12: Thor (Marvel) - God of Thunder, Mjolnir
  - 13: Fantastic Four (Marvel) - First Family
  - 14: Teen Titans (DC) - young heroes

  - 22: Hawkeye (Marvel) - master archer
  - 23: Nightwing (DC) - acrobat, former Robin
  - 24: Punisher (Marvel) - skull logo, vigilante
  - 25: Catwoman (DC) - cat burglar
  - 26: Doctor Strange (Marvel) - sorcerer supreme

  - 28: Vision (Marvel) - synthezoid

  - 42: Constantine (DC/Vertigo) - occult detective

  - 54: Nightcrawler (Marvel) - teleportation
  - 55: Colossus (Marvel) - steel skin
  - 56: Hawkman (DC) - wings, mace
  - 57: Hawkgirl (DC) - wings, warrior
  - 58: Blue Beetle (DC) - scarab armor
  - 59: Booster Gold (DC) - time traveler

  - 102: Ghost (Dark Horse) - white female hero
  - 103: Barb Wire (Dark Horse) - bounty hunter
  - 104: The Goon (Dark Horse) - Depression-era tough guy
  - 105: Usagi Yojimbo (Dark Horse) - samurai rabbit
  - 106: Sin City (Dark Horse) - noir crime fighter
  - 107: 300 (Dark Horse) - Spartan warrior
  - 108: Nexus (Dark Horse) - cosmic executioner
  - 109: Aliens vs Predator (Dark Horse) - space marines

  - 112: Tarzan (Dark Horse) - jungle lord
  - 113: The Shadow (Dark Horse) - 1930s crime fighter
  - 114: Magnus Robot Fighter (Dark Horse/Valiant) - 4000 AD hero

  - 117: Harbinger (Valiant) - psiots with powers
  - 118: Bloodshot (Valiant) - nanite-powered soldier
  - 119: Archer & Armstrong (Valiant) - immortal and drunk

SUBJECT FACE COLOR TRANSFORMATION (CRITICAL):
• Subject's facial features MUST remain recognizable
• Subject's skin tone MUST change to match hero's characteristic color:
  — Hulk/She-Hulk: GREEN skin
  — Beast: BLUE fur-covered skin
  — Colossus: METALLIC STEEL silver skin
  — Vision: RED synthetic skin
  — Nightcrawler: DARK BLUE fuzzy skin
  — Martian Manhunter: GREEN Martian skin
  — Dr. Manhattan: GLOWING BLUE skin
  — Ghost Rider: FLAMING SKULL (face becomes skull on fire)
  — Hellboy: RED demon skin with filed horns
  — Swamp Thing: GREEN plant matter skin
  — The Mask: BRIGHT GREEN cartoon skin
  — Groot: BROWN wooden bark skin
  — Savage Dragon: GREEN with head fin
  — Gamora: GREEN alien skin
  — Drax: GRAY/GREEN tattooed skin
  — Starfire: ORANGE alien skin
  — Raven: GRAY/PURPLE skin
  — Beast Boy: GREEN shape-shifter skin
  — Concrete: GRAY STONE texture skin
  — The Tick: BRIGHT BLUE skin
  — TMNT: GREEN turtle skin
  — Normal human heroes (Superman, Batman, Spider-Man, etc.): Normal human skin tone
• Preserve eye shape, nose, mouth, facial structure — just change the COLOR
• Subject still looks like themselves, just in hero's skin color

MASK/HELMET VISIBILITY (CRITICAL):
• If hero wears FULL MASK or FULL HELMET (covering entire face), the mask/helmet MUST be:
  - Removed completely, OR
  - Partially removed (lifted up, pulled back), OR
  - Open/retracted (like Iron Man's faceplate opening)
