• Subject's face MUST be clearly visible and recognizable (in appropriate hero color)
• Examples:
  - Iron Man: Faceplate open revealing face, arc reactor glowing
  - Spider-Man: Mask pulled up to forehead or partially off
  - Deadpool: Mask pulled up or torn showing face
  - Batman: Cowl pulled back or removed
  - Black Panther: Mask retracted or held in hand
  - Judge Dredd: Helmet off (rare dramatic moment)
  - The Mask: Green mask held in hand, face is bright green
  - Spawn: Cape hood pulled back showing face
  - Iron Fist: Mask down or removed
  - Moon Knight: Hood and mask pulled back
• Half-masks (Daredevil, Robin, Nightwing) can remain on as face is visible
• No mask (Superman, Wonder Woman, Hulk, etc.) — no change needed
• Goal: Subject's recognizable face in hero's skin color

FULL COVER DISPLAY (CRITICAL):
• The final image must show the COMPLETE comic book cover
• All four corners of the comic visible
• Entire cover from top to bottom shown
• NOT cropped - full page layout visible
• Comic book edges clearly defined
• Complete professional cover composition

COMIC COVER DESIGN:
• Title logo prominent at top
• Issue number clearly visible
• Cover date (month and year)
• Cover price appropriate to era
• Publisher logo (Marvel, DC, Image, Dark Horse, Valiant, IDW, etc.)
• Barcode for modern, Comics Code for vintage

SUBJECT AS HERO:
• Subject's face as the hero's face — CLEARLY recognizable with hero's skin color
• Wearing the iconic costume (with mask/helmet removed or open if full-face)
• Dynamic superhero pose
• Subject IS the superhero
• Heroic proportions

COMIC ART STYLE:
• Classic or modern comic book illustration
• Bold outlines, dynamic composition
• Sound effects (WHAM! POW! THWIP!)
• Motion lines and speed effects
• Bright bold colors

COVER SCENE:
• Dramatic action moment
• Villain or threat visible if appropriate
• Appropriate background
• Cover blurb text

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must display the FULL comic book cover with the subject as the superhero with their face in the hero's characteristic color (green for Hulk, blue for Beast, steel for Colossus, etc.) — if the hero wears a full mask/helmet, it must be removed, open, or partially off so the subject's color-transformed face is clearly visible and recognizable — showing the complete cover with all four corners visible, including all publishing details, dramatic action scene, bold comic art style, and professional cover design.

name: COMIC SUPERHERO
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a superhero inspired by their own traits, personality, or clothing. Preserve the subject’s recognizable facial features and body while designing a unique superhero identity based on what they are wearing or their notable characteristics. The superhero must wear a flowing cape integrated naturally into the costume. Show a full comic-book page with multiple panels depicting the subject in action, using powers or skills derived from their personal traits. Bold inks, vibrant colors, dynamic composition, and expressive onomatopoeia. Ensure the subject remains clearly identifiable while fully integrated into the comic-book superhero narrative.

name: REAL UPCOMING MOVIE TEASER
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into the lead character of a real theatrical movie currently in production or scheduled for release.

SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a real movie title (with or without year), USE THAT exact movie
• If an external master prompt specifies only a release year, SELECT a real theatrical movie scheduled for release in that year
• If neither title nor year is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using LAST DIGIT modulo 5:
  - 0: Major Studio Live-Action Sci-Fi Release
  - 1: Prestige Award-Season Drama
  - 2: Big Budget Action Franchise Installment
  - 3: Stylized Animated Feature Film
  - 4: Dark Psychological Thriller

STYLE MATCHING (MANDATORY):
• The subject MUST be rendered in the same visual medium and artistic style as the selected film
• If the film is live-action, render photorealistic cinematic photography
• If the film is 3D animated, render the subject as a fully 3D animated character
• If the film uses stylized animation, match its artistic medium faithfully
• Do not leave the subject photographic if the selected film is animated

CORE CONCEPT:
• The subject must appear as the undisputed lead character
• Official teaser poster framing
• Studio-level production quality
• No parody tone

TEASER ELEMENTS:
• Authentic movie title typography
• Dramatic tagline
• Realistic release window (e.g., "Summer 2027")
• Proper production credit block at bottom
• Accurate theatrical poster hierarchy

SUBJECT PRESENTATION:
• Wardrobe and environment must match the selected film’s genre and tone
• Expression and pose must align with the film’s emotional atmosphere
• Strong lead-character presence

IMPORTANT:
• If a specific movie is named, match its tone, lighting, genre, and visual medium accurately
• If only a year is provided, ensure the selected movie is real and scheduled for that year
• Avoid satire unless explicitly requested in master prompt
• Maintain realism and cinematic credibility

FINAL RESULT:
The final image should look indistinguishable from an official teaser poster for a real upcoming theatrical release starring the subject, with film selection determined strictly by master prompt overrides or modulo logic.

name: COMPANY BADGE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into an authentic corporate employee ID badge.

The final image must show the **entire badge fully visible** within the frame, oriented vertically or horizontally like a real workplace ID. Include realistic badge proportions, rounded corners, clip hole or lanyard slot, and slight plastic glare or lamination texture. The badge should appear photographed or scanned flat, not floating in space.

Place the subject’s photo in a standard ID photo area. The portrait should look like a real badge photo: neutral lighting, centered framing, simple background, and mild compression or sharpening typical of office badges.

Include the following badge details, all rendered clearly and legibly:
• **Employee Name:** Generate a humorous but plausible name based on the subject’s appearance, expression, or clothing (unless overridden by external master prompt).
• **Job Title:** Create a funny or exaggerated job title inspired by the subject’s visible traits or environment (e.g., "Senior Snack Analyst," "Head of Vibes," "Chief Button Presser").
• **Employee ID Number:** Use a fictional numeric or alphanumeric code.
• **Department:** Optional, humorous department name derived from context.

Include a **company name and logo**:
• If a real company logo or branding is visible in the image, adapt the logo.
• If a company name or logo is provided via external master prompt, use that name and create a believable logo mark to match.

Add small realistic badge elements such as barcodes, QR codes, issue dates, expiration dates, or security stripes. Text should look official but contain subtle humor when read closely.

Ensure the badge feels professionally designed yet gently ridiculous. Avoid overt meme styling. The final image should feel like a real corporate badge that someone accidentally made funny, and it must be clearly readable on a small screen.

name: COMPETITION BROADCAST
message:
Take a picture and place the subject as a competitor or performer on a televised competition broadcast.

COMPETITION SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a competition, USE THAT COMPETITION
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 30:
  - 0: American Idol - audition or stage performance, judges panel, microphone, singing
  - 1: The Voice - blind audition, chair turn moment, red chair, coaching
  - 2: Dancing with the Stars - ballroom dance pose, sequined costume, stage lights
  - 3: American Ninja Warrior - obstacle course, athletic attempt, dramatic fail or success
  - 4: So You Think You Can Dance - stage performance, dramatic choreography, spotlight
  - 5: America's Got Talent - stage audition, judges panel, golden buzzer moment
  - 6: The X Factor - stage performance, judges deliberation, category competition
  - 7: Eurovision Song Contest - national performance, elaborate staging, voting sequence
  - 8: World's Strongest Man - strength challenge, atlas stones, dramatic lift
  - 9: Nathan's Hot Dog Eating Contest - competitive eating, crowd, timer
  - 10: Scripps National Spelling Bee - microphone stand, word pronunciation, intense focus
  - 11: International Chopin Piano Competition - concert hall, piano performance, formal attire
  - 12: World Championship of Public Speaking - podium, Toastmasters logo, speech delivery
  - 13: International Ballet Competition - stage leap, classical costume, judges panel
  - 14: World Series of Poker - poker table, chips, cards, intense concentration
  - 15: Nathan's Famous Fourth of July - hot dog eating, competitive speed eating
  - 16: Red Bull Cliff Diving - mid-dive, cliff edge, water below, athletic form
  - 17: CrossFit Games - workout station, athlete strain, competition floor
  - 18: World Memory Championships - memorization task, concentration, timer
  - 19: International Mathematical Olympiad - problem solving, chalkboard, intense focus
  - 20: World Barista Championship - espresso machine, latte art, competition stage
  - 21: Miss Universe - evening gown, stage walk, crown and sash moment
  - 22: Mr. Olympia - bodybuilding pose, stage lights, physique competition
  - 23: World Cup of Darts - dartboard, throw position, scoreboard visible
  - 24: World Chess Championship - chess board, clock, intense concentration
  - 25: League of Legends World Championship - gaming setup, headset, esports arena
  - 26: Nathan's Famous - competitive eating, multiple contestants, judging table
  - 27: World Air Guitar Championships - stage performance, invisible guitar, dramatic pose
  - 28: International Violin Competition - concert stage, violin performance, formal setting
  - 29: World Latin Dance Cup - partner dance, Latin costume, competition floor

SUBJECT AS COMPETITOR:
• Subject integrated as actual competitor/performer
• Appropriate attire for that competition
• Expression showing concentration, effort, or performance intensity
• Subject appears to genuinely be competing
• Face clearly recognizable

COMPETITION-SPECIFIC ELEMENTS:
• Authentic venue or stage design
• Judges or officials visible if appropriate
• Competition logo and branding
• Other competitors or audience in background
• Scoreboard or ranking displays
• Competition-specific equipment or props

BROADCAST GRAPHICS:
• On-screen competitor name and country/affiliation
• Competition logo in corner
• Score or ranking displays
• Event title and round information
• Lower-third graphics
• Sponsor logos if applicable

LIGHTING & CINEMATOGRAPHY:
• Professional broadcast lighting
• Stage or arena spotlights
• Broadcast-quality production value
• Multiple camera angle composition
• TV sports or performance aesthetic

COMPETITIVE MOMENT:
• Peak performance or critical attempt
• Moment of intense focus or effort
• Judges watching or scoring
• Authentic competition intensity
• Signature moment from that competition type

ATMOSPHERE:
• High-stakes competition environment
• Professional broadcast quality
• Audience or judges present
• Formal competition setting
• Elite performance level

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject as an actual competitor in the selected televised competition with authentic venue design, broadcast graphics, appropriate attire, and that signature competitive moment - looking like a screenshot from an actual broadcast.

name: CONNECT THE DOTS
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a classic printable connect-the-dots puzzle. Reduce the image to a clean line-art outline that captures the essential shape and silhouette of the subject while removing unnecessary detail.

Place numbered dots along the outline and key interior contours in a **logical sequential order starting with number 1**, so that connecting the dots in order will clearly reveal the subject. Dots should be large, evenly spaced, and easy to follow.

Show very minimal lines or connecting guides—only enough to hint at the outline if necessary, but primarily rely on the numbered dots. Avoid background details, shading, or other guides. Use high-contrast dots suitable for printing. Do not include text, instructions, or labels. The final image should resemble a traditional connect-the-dots puzzle where the user draws all connecting lines by hand, always beginning with dot 1.

name: CONSCIENCE
message:
Take a picture and create a scene with THREE versions of the subject:

1. One normal-sized subject in the center
2. One miniature angel version of the subject sitting or hovering on one shoulder
3. One miniature devil version of the subject on the opposite shoulder

The mini angel should appear kind, glowing, and persuasive. The mini devil should appear mischievous or sinister, whispering temptation.

The main subject’s expression should reveal the choice:
• EVIL choice: sly grin, raised eyebrow, mischievous expression
• GOOD choice: dopey happiness, innocent smile, relaxed posture

The miniature versions must look like the same person, not generic characters.

Lighting and composition should clearly frame all three figures.

name: CONSPIRACY THEORY
message:
Take a picture and place the subject in a famous conspiracy theory scenario with the expression 'I knew it was real!'

CONSPIRACY SCENARIO SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a conspiracy, USE THAT CONSPIRACY
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 15:
  - 0: Moon Landing Studio - subject on fake moon set with stage lights, film crew visible, cardboard rocks, studio backdrop
  - 1: Area 51 Worker - subject in hazmat suit examining alien technology, UFO in hangar, government facility, classified documents
  - 2: JFK Grassy Knoll - subject on grassy knoll during JFK motorcade, 1960s Dallas, holding camera or suspiciously positioned
  - 3: Roswell UFO Crash - subject at crash site with alien debris, military covering up, flying saucer wreckage, New Mexico desert 1947
  - 4: Illuminati Meeting - subject in hooded robe at pyramid altar, all-seeing eye symbol, candles, secret society ritual
  - 5: Flat Earth Edge - subject at edge of flat earth with ice wall, Antarctica, seeing the dome, holding level
  - 6: Chemtrails Plane - subject in cockpit spraying chemicals from plane, tanks of mysterious substances, flight controls
  - 7: Bermuda Triangle Portal - subject in boat as dimensional portal opens, Triangle location, ships and planes disappearing
  - 8: Elvis Alive - subject spotting Elvis in disguise at gas station or grocery store, older Elvis hiding in plain sight
  - 9: Bigfoot Photographer - subject in woods with blurry camera getting famous Bigfoot photo, Patterson-Gimlin recreation
  - 10: Reptilian Shapeshifter - subject catching politician or celebrity with reptilian features showing, scales visible, hologram glitch
  - 11: Denver Airport Murals - subject discovering underground bunker beneath DIA, apocalyptic murals, secret tunnels
  - 12: Faked Dinosaurs - subject in museum discovering dinosaur bones are made of plaster, paleontology conspiracy
  - 13: Birds Aren't Real - subject capturing bird with exposed robot circuitry, government surveillance drone, mechanical parts
  - 14: Mandela Effect Proof - subject finding physical evidence of alternate timeline, Berenstein Bears book, Fruit Loops box

PLACE THE SUBJECT:
• Subject actively discovering or participating in the conspiracy
• Expression of vindication, excitement, fear, or 'I KNEW IT!'
• Subject pointing at evidence or caught in the act
• 'Proof' of conspiracy visible in scene
• Period-appropriate for historical conspiracies
• Documentary or caught-on-camera aesthetic

CONSPIRACY ELEMENTS:
• Visual 'evidence' of the conspiracy theory
• Setting authentic to the conspiracy
• Props relevant to the theory
• Other conspirators or witnesses
• Government agents, aliens, secret symbols, etc.
• Documentation (photos, papers, signs)

EXPRESSION & BODY LANGUAGE:
• 'I knew it was real!' energy
• Vindication and excitement
• Fear and awe at discovery
• Pointing, gesturing to evidence
• Conspiratorial knowing look
• True believer energy

STYLE:
• Grainy documentary footage aesthetic
• Security camera quality for some scenarios
• 1960s-era photography for historical conspiracies
• Found footage feel
• Amateur photography quality
• 'Leaked photo' aesthetic
• Slightly blurry or low-quality for authenticity

TONE:
• Humorous and absurd
• Deadpan presentation of ridiculous scenario
• Subject treats it completely seriously
• Not mocking conspiracy theorists but playing with the concepts
• Fun 'what if' energy

OPTIONAL TEXT:
• 'CLASSIFIED' stamp
• 'DO NOT DISTRIBUTE'
• Date/time stamp
• 'LEAKED FOOTAGE'
• Conspiracy theory quote or slogan

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject caught in a famous conspiracy theory scenario with 'I knew it was real!' energy, presented as documentary evidence or found footage with appropriate grainy quality and period-appropriate styling - humorous but deadpan in execution.

name: CONSPIRACY WALL
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into the center of a chaotic conspiracy investigation wall.

Place the subject’s photo (or multiple cropped versions of them) pinned to a corkboard, surrounded by printed photos, scribbled notes, newspaper clippings, diagrams, and red string connecting everything.

The conspiracy theme should be automatically invented based on the subject’s appearance, environment, or actions — OR be influenced by external master prompt text if provided (for example: "pizza", "aliens", "taxes", "office drama", "time travel", etc.).

Use absurd, humorous conspiracy logic. Examples:
• 'Always near the coffee machine'
• 'Was present every time the printer jammed'
• 'Knows too much about Tuesdays'
• 'Connected to the dog somehow'

Do not include readable real-world sensitive data. All notes should be fictional, funny, and harmless.

Include red string connecting photos, arrows, circles, and question marks drawn in marker. The board should feel cluttered, frantic, and obsessed.

Ensure the entire corkboard is fully visible in the frame. The final image should look like a deranged investigator has been tracking the subject for years.

name: CONSTELLATION
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a living constellation in the night sky. Reimagine the subject’s silhouette, facial features, and pose as a pattern of glowing stars connected by faint celestial lines, while keeping their identity recognizable. Surround the subject with a deep, cosmic backdrop filled with nebulae, subtle stardust, and distant galaxies. Use soft glows, luminous highlights, and gentle gradients to create a magical, astronomical aesthetic. The subject should appear formed entirely from stars and light, as if they are part of the universe itself, rendered with crisp detail and awe-inspiring atmosphere.

name: CONSTRUCTIVISM
message: Take a picture and transform the image into Constructivism style art. Bold geometry, diagonal compositions, limited color palettes, and graphic poster-like structure.

name: COOKIE
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a cookie constructed entirely from edible materials on a cookie sheet. The subject's face, body, and all features must be built using only cookie dough, frosting, fondant, sprinkles, sugar crystals, chocolate chips, candy pieces, and other edible decorating elements. DO NOT print or place a picture on a cookie - instead, BUILD the subject's likeness FROM edible ingredients. Use cookie dough as the base shaped into the subject's outline and form. Create facial features using: royal icing piped for details and outlines, fondant rolled and shaped for dimensional features, colored sugar for shading and texture, chocolate chips or candies for eyes, sprinkles arranged to suggest hair texture or clothing patterns, edible food coloring to tint different areas. Show realistic cookie decorating techniques - piped frosting lines and borders, fondant cutouts layered on, dragée pearls for accents, edible glitter or luster dust for highlights. The cookie should be golden-brown baked dough as the foundation with all decorative elements applied on top. Include cookie baking details: slightly puffed edges, golden-brown color, subtle surface cracks. Place on aluminum cookie sheet with parchment paper, surrounded by decorating tools - piping bags, fondant tools, bowls of sprinkles, food coloring bottles. Use warm kitchen lighting. The subject should be recognizable through the strategic arrangement and color of edible decorating materials - like an elaborately decorated sugar cookie using professional cake decorating techniques. Make it look like a photograph of an actual decorated cookie where everything visible is 100% edible ingredients artfully arranged.

name: COPY-CAT
message:
Take a picture and add EXACTLY ONE background creature that is intentionally mimicking the subject’s pose and facial expression as if mocking them.

CREATURE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies the creature type, USE THAT
• If no creature is specified externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 40:
  - 0: Dog
  - 1: Cat
  - 2: Rabbit
  - 3: Ferret
  - 4: Hamster
  - 5: Guinea pig
  - 6: Pigeon
  - 7: Crow
  - 8: Owl
  - 9: Seagull
  - 10: Duck
  - 11: Chicken
  - 12: Flamingo
  - 13: Penguin
  - 14: Monkey
  - 15: Chimpanzee
  - 16: Lemur
  - 17: Orangutan
  - 18: Baboon
  - 19: Frog
  - 20: Toad
  - 21: Axolotl
  - 22: Bearded dragon
  - 23: Fly
  - 24: Praying mantis
  - 25: Beetle
  - 26: Ant
  - 27: Butterfly
  - 28: Stick insect
  - 29: Goldfish
  - 30: Pufferfish
  - 31: Octopus
  - 32: Crab
  - 33: Seal
  - 34: Horse
  - 35: Goat
  - 36: Alpaca
  - 37: Cow
  - 38: Deer
  - 39: Sloth

MIMICRY RULES:
• Creature MUST intentionally copy the subject’s pose AND facial expression
• Expression must match exactly (smile, frown, neutral, surprise, squint)
• Body posture must mirror direction, tilt, and attitude
• Mimicry should feel deliberate and cheeky, not accidental

SUBJECT RULES:
• Subject remains primary focus and fully recognizable
• Subject expression must be clearly readable
• Subject is preferably unaware of the mimicry

ENVIRONMENT:
• Creature placement must be plausible within the scene
• Creature positioned in background or side of frame, never centered

TONE:
• Playful, humorous, and obvious
• No horror, menace, or surreal distortion

CAMERA:
• Natural photographic framing
• Viewer should notice the mimicry almost immediately

RESTRICTIONS:
• No cartoon or animated styles
• No text overlays or captions
• No additional creatures mimicking the subject

FINAL RESULT:
The image should look like a normal photograph where a single animal, insect, or bird is clearly and intentionally copying the subject’s pose and facial expression, creating a clean, funny moment of visual mockery.

name: COPY MACHINE COPY
message:
Take a picture and transform it into an authentic photocopier copy made by pressing the subject directly against the copier glass.

The final image must resemble a single sheet of copier paper viewed flat and fully visible within the frame, including paper edges and margins. Do not crop the page.

The subject should appear distorted from being pressed against the glass: flattened features, slightly squashed face or objects, widened nose, compressed cheeks, stretched hands or fingers, and uneven contact areas. The distortion should feel physical and silly, not warped digitally.

Apply classic photocopier artifacts: harsh black-and-white or muddy grayscale tones, blown highlights, crushed shadows, toner speckling, faint streaks, edge shadows from the copier lid, uneven exposure, and slight skew or rotation. Include faint dust marks or smudges typical of a well-used office copier.

Lighting should feel internal to the copier — flat, overexposed, and directionless — not like studio lighting. The background should be blank or show subtle shadows from the copier lid.

Optionally include a small copier interface imprint or margin text such as page numbers, contrast indicators, or misaligned registration marks, rendered faintly and partially cut off.

If external master prompt text is provided, use it to influence the subject’s pose (e.g., face, hands, object pressed to glass) or tone of humor. The result should feel unmistakably like a dumb, impulsive office photocopy — absurd, tactile, and clearly readable on a small screen.

name: COURTROOM SKETCH
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a courtroom sketch drawn by a courtroom artist.

Render the subject in a loose, expressive pencil or charcoal style on off-white paper, with exaggerated but recognizable facial features, messy line work, and rough shading. The drawing should look like it was made quickly while observing the subject live in court.

Place the subject seated at a courtroom table or in the witness stand, with simplified figures of a judge, lawyers, or jury in the background.

Add subtle emotion based on the subject’s expression or posture — nervous, confused, smug, bored, or guilty — even if they are innocent.

Include a small caption area or handwritten label such as "The Defendant" or "Key Witness" (do not include real names unless provided via master prompt).

The entire sketch page should be fully visible within the frame, including paper edges. The final image should feel like a real courtroom artist drawing from a televised trial.

name: CRAYON DRAWING
message:
Take a picture of the subject and transform the entire image into a crayon drawing on paper.

The subject and background must appear hand-drawn using wax crayons, with visible crayon strokes, uneven pressure, overlapping colors, and rough textures.

Paper texture must be visible, including tooth, fibers, and slight wrinkles or smudges.

Lines should be imperfect and childlike or naive in style, not digital or clean.

DO NOT leave any photorealistic elements or apply a crayon filter.

The final image must look like a real crayon drawing made on paper.

name: CRAYON MELT PORTRAIT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a crayon melt portrait, as if crayons were heated and allowed to melt and drip to form the image.

CORE CONCEPT (NON-NEGOTIABLE):
• The image must be formed from melted crayon wax
• Wax flow and gravity-driven drips are REQUIRED
• This is NOT a painted or digitally blended image

MATERIAL RULES (CRITICAL):
• Thick, glossy crayon wax texture
• Visible drip trails, pooling, and layering
• Uneven edges and color overlap
• Slight cracking or cooling ridges in hardened wax

COLOR RULES:
• Bright, saturated crayon colors
• Colors may overlap but must not smoothly blend
• Layering should show distinct wax deposits

IDENTITY PRESERVATION:
• Subject’s likeness formed through wax shapes and drips
• Facial features readable through wax placement
• Some abstraction allowed, but identity must remain clear

ANTI-CHEATING RULES:
• NO brush strokes
• NO airbrush gradients
• NO smooth digital blending
• NO watercolor or oil paint appearance

PROCESS CUES (VISIBLE):
• Crayons may be visible at the top or edges
• Wax appears to have flowed downward due to heat
• Gravity-consistent drip direction

COMPOSITION:
• Vertical orientation preferred
• Background may show paper, canvas, or board
• Wax thickness varies across the image

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like a real crayon melt artwork created by heating crayons and letting wax drip and pool to form the subject’s portrait — messy, tactile, and unmistakably wax-based.

name: CREEPYPASTA
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a creepypasta internet horror character.

CREEPYPASTA CHARACTER SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies character, USE THAT CHARACTER
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 15:
  - 0: Slenderman-style - faceless, unnaturally tall (8+ feet), black suit, tentacles, static distortion
  - 1: Jeff the Killer-style - carved smile, lidless eyes, burned white skin, "Go to sleep"
  - 2: Smile Dog-style - disturbing dog with human-like smile, red eyes, psychological horror
  - 3: The Rake-style - pale humanoid creature, crawls on all fours, found at bedside
  - 4: Eyeless Jack-style - black eyes dripping tar, blue mask, hoodie, organ harvester
  - 5: Laughing Jack-style - monochrome clown, black and white, sharp teeth, carnival horror
  - 6: Ben Drowned-style - haunted video game character, glitching, dripping, red eyes, "You shouldn't have done that"
  - 7: Sonic.exe-style - evil video game character, bleeding eyes, demonic, "I AM GOD"
  - 8: Ticci Toby-style - mouthguard, goggles, twitching, axes, proxy
  - 9: Masky-style - white mask, hoodie, camera stalker, no personality
  - 10: Sally Williams-style - ghost child, teddy bear, innocent but sinister, blood on dress
  - 11: Zalgo-style - corrupted reality, glitch text, dimensional horror, chaos entity
  - 12: Seed Eater-style - sunflower head, lanky body, disturbing plant creature
  - 13: Russian Sleep Experiment-style - gaunt, self-mutilated, no eyelids, insomnia horror
  - 14: SCP-096-style - pale, extremely thin, jaw unhinging, triggered by face being seen

SUBJECT TRANSFORMATION:
• Subject's face basis for creepypasta character
• Recognizable features warped into horror
• Subject AS the creepypasta entity
• Identity visible through corruption
• Uncanny valley - almost human

CHARACTER-SPECIFIC FEATURES:

**Slenderman-style:**
• NO FACE (smooth, featureless)
• Extremely tall and thin (8+ feet)
• Black business suit, white shirt, black tie
• Tentacles emerging from back
• Long unnaturally thin limbs
• Static/distortion around figure
• Forest setting

**Jeff the Killer-style:**
• Carved smile (cut from ear to ear)
• Lidless eyes (can't blink)
• Burned/bleached white skin
• Long black hair
• White hoodie with blood
• Kitchen knife
• Insane expression

**The Rake-style:**
• Pale gray-white skin
• Crawling on all fours
• Skeletal, emaciated
• Large dark eyes
• Long fingers with claws
• Hunched posture
• Bedroom or attic setting

**Eyeless Jack-style:**
• Blue mask covering face
• Black liquid dripping from eye holes
• Gray skin
• Dark hoodie
• Scalpel or medical tools
• Surgical horror aesthetic

**Ben Drowned-style:**
• Video game character (Link-inspired)
• Bleeding from eyes (black/red)
• Glitching, digital distortion
• Dripping wet
• Red or black eyes
• Game cartridge nearby
• Digital corruption

COMMON CREEPYPASTA ELEMENTS:
• Pale, corpse-like skin
• Unnatural eye colors (black, red, white)
• Disturbing smile or expression
• Blood or dark liquid
• Distorted proportions
• Uncanny valley appearance
• Internet horror aesthetic

BODY HORROR:
• Stretched or elongated limbs
• Emaciated, skeletal frame
• Missing features (no face, no eyes)
• Mutilated or self-harmed
• Inhuman proportions
• Disturbing flexibility
• Corpse-like appearance

CLOTHING:
• Hoodies (common creepypasta trope)
• Masks (white, blue, or character-specific)
• Suits (Slenderman)
• Torn or bloody clothes
• Monochrome colors (black/white)
• Stained and dirty

WEAPONS/OBJECTS:
• Kitchen knife (Jeff)
• Axes (Ticci Toby)
• Scalpel (Eyeless Jack)
• Teddy bear (Sally)
• Game cartridge (Ben Drowned)
• No weapon needed (creatures)

SETTING:
• Dark forest or woods
• Bedroom (nighttime)
• Abandoned building
• Suburban neighborhood (night)
• Digital/glitch space
• Attic or basement
• Behind the viewer (stalking)

DIGITAL DISTORTION:
• VHS static effects
• Glitching and artifacts
• Color corruption
• Scan lines
• Digital noise
• Reality breaking down
• Zalgo text corruption

LIGHTING:
• Very dark, minimal light
• Flashlight beam
• Computer screen glow
• Street light
• Found footage aesthetic
• Night vision green tint
• High contrast shadows

PHOTOGRAPHY STYLE:
• Found footage aesthetic
• Security camera quality
• Trail cam at night
• Smartphone photo (grainy)
• Low quality, creepy
• Motion blur
• Slightly out of focus
• Amateur photography

ATMOSPHERE:
• Deeply unsettling
• Internet urban legend
• Viral horror
• Psychological dread
• Modern folklore
• Digital age horror
• Uncanny and wrong

INTERNET AESTHETIC:
• Low-res images
• JPG artifacts
• MS Paint quality (some)
• Creepy surveillance footage
• Photoshop horror
• Early 2000s internet feel
• Viral image quality

POSE:
• Standing ominously still
• Crawling toward camera
• Lurking in background
• Staring directly at viewer
• Unnatural stance
• Frozen mid-movement
• Too close to camera

EYES:
• Completely black
• Bleeding/crying blood
• Red glowing
• No pupils
• Lidless (can't blink)
• Empty sockets
• Staring intensely

MOUTH:
• Carved or cut smile
• Too many teeth
• Jaw unhinged
• Black interior
• Impossible grin
• No mouth (Slenderman)
• Dripping black liquid

STYLE:
• Creepypasta community aesthetic
• Internet horror tradition
• Amateur horror photography
• Viral scary image
• Found footage feel
• Low-budget horror
• Photorealistic yet wrong

NOT ALLOWED:
• High-quality professional photography (too polished)
• Bright cheerful colors
• Comedy or parody (unless requested)
• Gore for shock value only

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject transformed into a creepypasta character in the selected style - with pale skin, disturbing features, dark clothing, found footage aesthetic with digital distortion and low quality - appearing in a dark setting like forest or bedroom at night with minimal lighting and that deeply unsettling internet horror vibe of viral creepy images that haunt you, clearly identifiable as the subject but warped into urban legend horror.

name: CROP CIRCLE
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into an elaborate crop circle design viewed from directly above. The subject's face, body, and features must be created ENTIRELY FROM the contrast between flattened crops and standing crops - NOT a picture placed on a field. Use only flattened grain (darker, pressed-down wheat laid in swirled patterns) and standing grain (lighter, upright golden wheat) to build the image. The subject's portrait should be constructed like pointillism or halftone printing - areas of flattened crops create darker tones and shadows, areas of standing crops create lighter tones and highlights, and the pattern of which sections are flattened versus standing forms their recognizable likeness. The portrait should be recognizable from aerial view using geometric patterns, circles, lines, and curves typical of crop circle formations. Include authentic crop circle characteristics: precisely flattened grain stalks laid in directional swirls (clockwise or counterclockwise), sharp edges between flattened and standing crops, multiple concentric circles, connecting pathways, sacred geometry elements. Show the massive scale - the crop circle should span hundreds of feet across the field. Use aerial photography perspective as if photographed from helicopter or drone, showing surrounding farmland, field boundaries, trees at edges, perhaps a road or farmhouse for scale reference. Include subtle details suggesting mysterious origin - perfectly geometric precision, overnight appearance. The lighting should be golden hour with long shadows emphasizing the depth and dimension of the flattened patterns, making the contrast between pressed-down and standing grain more dramatic. Add subtle alien/UFO mystique - maybe a distant light in sky or mysterious glow. Make it look like an actual aerial photograph of an unexplained crop circle formation where the subject's portrait is built entirely from the agricultural pattern of flattened versus standing crops in massive field art.

name: CROSS-SECTION
message:
Take a picture and present reality as if it has been sliced open by ONE precise, clean cross-section.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• Reality itself is cut open in a single, clean slice
• The cut is educational and diagrammatic, not violent
• No damage, no gore, no chaos
• Everything remains functional and intact

CUT ORIENTATION (SEED-DRIVEN — SELECT EXACTLY ONE):
• Vertical Slice — front-to-back sectional view
• Horizontal Slice — top-down or mid-height cut
• Isometric Wedge — angled architectural cutaway
• Circular Bore — cylindrical core drilled through reality
• Architectural Cutaway — museum-style structural section

CUT RULES (MANDATORY):
• ONE cut only — no multiple slices
• Cut edge is perfectly clean and precise
• Interior surfaces are smooth, flat, and diagram-like
• Exterior remains untouched and normal

INTERIOR LOGIC:
• Inside must show a logical internal structure
• Internal components should feel:
  – Purpose-built
  – Organized
  – Believable
• Examples of interior elements:
  – Structural layers
  – Support frameworks
  – Mechanical or architectural systems
  – Environmental strata

NO GORE / NO DAMAGE:
• No blood, organs, flesh, or biological harm
• No destruction or collapse
• No debris or breakage
• This is a revealing cut, not an injury

SUBJECT INTEGRATION:
• Subject may be intersected by the cut
• Subject remains calm and unaffected
• Interior of subject follows same clean, logical structure rules
• No pain, reaction, or awareness

VISUAL STYLE:
• Clean, educational, museum-grade presentation
• Feels like a scientific or architectural diagram made real
• Precise edges and clear separation of layers

LIGHTING:
• Neutral, even lighting
• Interior clearly visible
• No dramatic shadows or horror lighting

CAMERA:
• Static, observational framing
• Full cut visible in-frame
• Clear depth and scale reference

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show reality cleanly opened by a single precise cross-section, revealing a logical, structured interior while leaving the exterior intact. The effect should feel educational, calm, and inevitable — as if the world was always designed to be viewed this way.

name: CRYSTALLIZED
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a form made entirely of crystals, gems, and geometric mineral formations.

CRYSTAL TYPE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies crystal type, USE THAT TYPE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 12:
  - 0: Clear Quartz - transparent, prismatic, rainbow refractions, pure crystal
  - 1: Amethyst - purple crystals, geode formation, royal purple to lavender
  - 2: Rose Quartz - pink crystals, soft romantic, love stone aesthetic
  - 3: Citrine - yellow-orange crystals, warm golden, sun energy
  - 4: Emerald - deep green, precious gemstone, hexagonal crystals
  - 5: Sapphire - deep blue, precious gem, brilliant facets
  - 6: Ruby - deep red, precious gem, pigeon blood red
  - 7: Diamond - clear brilliant, maximum sparkle, hardest gem, incredible refractions
  - 8: Black Obsidian - volcanic glass, black reflective, sharp edges
  - 9: Aquamarine - blue-green, ocean colors, hexagonal crystals
  - 10: Opal - iridescent, color-shifting, rainbow fire, play of light
  - 11: Mixed Gemstones - multiple crystal types, rainbow of colors, geode variety

SUBJECT TRANSFORMATION (CRITICAL):
• Subject IS MADE OF CRYSTALS - not wearing crystals
• Every part of body constructed from crystal formations
• NO organic material remains
• Subject's form recognizable but entirely crystalline
• Face, body, clothing - all transformed into crystals
• This is a crystal sculpture, not subject with crystals on them

SUBJECT RECOGNITION:
• Overall silhouette clearly recognizable as subject
• Face shape maintained through crystal formation
• Eyes: Crystal formations suggesting eye shape
• Nose: Protruding crystal cluster
• Mouth: Line of crystals or crystal formation
• Hair: Flowing crystal formations
• Pose and proportions preserved in crystal
• Identity visible through geometric transformation

CRYSTAL STRUCTURE:
• Geometric faceted surfaces
• Natural crystal formations
• Hexagonal, cubic, or trigonal structures
• Multiple crystal points and terminations
• Clustered crystal groups
• Druzy (tiny crystal) coatings
• Large statement crystals
• Varied crystal sizes (tiny to large)

FACETED SURFACES:
• Geometric flat planes
• Triangular, hexagonal, or square facets
• Sharp angles and edges
• Polished smooth surfaces
• Light reflecting off multiple planes
• Brilliant cut (for precious gems)
• Natural crystal faces
• Prismatic geometry

CRYSTAL FORMATIONS:
• Points and terminations jutting out
• Clusters of crystals growing together
• Geode-like hollow areas with crystals inside
• Stalactite/stalagmite formations
• Radial clusters
• Layered crystal growth
• Natural mineral formation patterns
• Geometric but organic-looking growth

FACE CONSTRUCTION:
• Forehead: Large faceted crystal planes
• Eyes: Deep crystal formations, faceted "iris"
• Nose: Protruding crystal cluster
• Cheeks: Smooth faceted surfaces
• Mouth: Line of small crystals
• Chin: Geometric crystal point
• Ears: Crystal formations suggesting shape
• Overall face recognizable through crystal structure

HAIR CRYSTALLIZATION:
• Flowing crystal formations
• Long crystal points suggesting hair strands
• Clustered crystals for volume
• Crystalline texture throughout
• Color matching hair type
• Movement suggested through crystal direction
• Spiky or flowing depending on hairstyle

BODY CRYSTALLIZATION:
• Torso: Large faceted crystal formations
• Arms: Elongated crystal structures
• Hands: Crystal fingers, geometric
• Legs: Crystal columns and clusters
• Feet: Crystal base formations
• Clothing suggested through crystal color/texture changes
• Entire form geometric but recognizable

TRANSPARENCY:
• Crystals semi-transparent to transparent
• Can see through some areas
• Light passing through crystals
• Depth visible inside crystal
• Layered transparency
• Translucent quality
• Some crystals clearer than others

COLOR (Type-specific):
• Quartz: Clear, rainbow refractions
• Amethyst: Purple gradient (deep to light)
• Rose Quartz: Soft pink, translucent
• Citrine: Yellow, orange, golden
• Emerald: Deep rich green
• Sapphire: Deep brilliant blue
• Ruby: Deep blood red
• Diamond: Clear with rainbow fire
• Obsidian: Black, reflective
• Aquamarine: Blue-green ocean tones
• Opal: Rainbow iridescence, color shift
• Mixed: Multiple colors throughout

LIGHT REFRACTION:
• Rainbow prismatic effects
• Light splitting into spectrum
• Color dispersing through crystal
• Internal reflections
• Brilliant sparkle
• Light bending and refracting
• Diamond-like brilliance
• Chromatic aberration

REFLECTIONS:
• Reflective faceted surfaces
• Mirror-like polished crystal
• Environment reflecting in crystals
• Multiple reflections between facets
• Glossy crystal surfaces
• Light bouncing between surfaces

SPARKLE & BRILLIANCE:
• Points of intense light
• Sparkles on sharp edges
• Brilliant flashes of light
• Scintillation (sparkle in motion)
• Fire (rainbow flashes in gemstones)
• Glitter-like shimmer
• Maximum brilliance

CRYSTAL CLARITY:
• Some crystals flawless and clear
• Others with inclusions and wisps
• Internal cracks or fractures
• Phantom crystals (crystal within crystal)
• Varying levels of transparency
• Natural imperfections

GEODE ELEMENTS (Optional):
• Hollow cavity with crystals inside
• Outer rough matrix
• Inner sparkling crystal lining
• Opening showing crystal interior
• Druzy coating inside cavity

BASE/STAND:
• Rough mineral matrix base
• Natural rock foundation
• Crystal cluster emerging from base
• Geode half showing interior
• Museum display quality
• Subject growing from mineral base

LIGHTING (CRITICAL):
• Bright light to show refraction
• Multiple light sources ideal
• Backlight creating glow
• Spotlights for sparkle
• Dramatic lighting highlighting facets
• Light passing through transparent areas
• Studio gem photography lighting

BACKGROUND:
• Dark or neutral (makes crystals pop)
• May show crystal cave environment
• Geode interior
• Museum display
• Simple to focus on crystal subject
• Possibly mystical magical setting

ATMOSPHERE:
• Magical and mystical
• Precious and valuable
• Natural mineral beauty
• Geometric perfection
• Crystalline magic
• Earth energy
• Gemstone luxury

MAGICAL ELEMENTS (Optional):
• Glowing from within
• Mystical energy
• Floating crystals nearby
• Magical aura
• Supernatural radiance
• Fantasy crystal magic

TEXTURE CONTRAST:
• Smooth polished facets
• Rough natural crystal points
• Druzy sparkly coating
• Sharp geometric edges
• Varied surface textures

STYLE:
• Photorealistic crystal transformation
• Mineral specimen quality
• Gemstone photography
• Museum-quality display
• Fantasy crystal magic
• Geological accuracy

NOT ALLOWED:
• Subject wearing crystal jewelry (must BE crystals)
• Crystals placed on subject (must be subject)
• Photograph with crystal overlay
• Subject holding crystals

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject completely transformed into a three-dimensional sculpture made entirely of crystals and gemstones - with geometric faceted surfaces, transparent and translucent qualities, brilliant light refraction creating rainbow effects, multiple crystal formations and clusters creating the subject's form - the subject's face and body clearly recognizable through the crystalline structure with varied crystal sizes from tiny druzy to large statement crystals, dramatic lighting creating maximum sparkle and brilliance, and that magical precious gemstone quality where the subject has become a living crystal formation.

name: CUBAN ART STYLE
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a Cuban art style illustration inspired by Cuban Modernism and Afro-Cuban visual traditions. Use bold tropical colors, strong outlines, flattened perspective, and expressive shapes.

Incorporate cultural rhythms through movement, pattern, and color. The subject should feel integrated into a warm, vibrant Cuban environment, with subtle influences of Afro-Cuban symbolism, music, and everyday life.

The final image should feel expressive, soulful, colorful, and culturally rich rather than realistic or photographic.

name: CUBISM
message: Take a picture in the style of Cubist Art. Break objects into geometric forms and reassemble them from multiple viewpoints simultaneously, challenging traditional perspective and depth to emphasize the two-dimensional canvas.

name: CYBERPUNK
message: Take a picture and transform the image into a cyberpunk scene. Neon lighting, futuristic city elements, holographic accents, and high-contrast color palette. Cinematic night lighting with tech-inspired details.

name: CYBORG
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a cyborg with human and mechanical parts seamlessly integrated.

AUGMENTATION LEVEL SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a specific augmentation level, USE THAT LEVEL
• If no level is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE level using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 6:
  - 0: Minimal Medical (one cybernetic arm/leg, clean prosthetics, everyday clothes, hospital/rehab setting)
  - 1: Military Combat Veteran (multiple combat augmentations, weapon integration, battle scars, tactical setting)
  - 2: Corporate Elite Enhancement (sleek expensive upgrades, chrome/gold, enhanced eyes, business/luxury setting)
  - 3: Underground Resistance (mismatched salvaged parts, DIY repairs, exposed wiring, dark industrial setting)
  - 4: Full Conversion Heavy (majority mechanical, only head/spine organic, massive powerful frame, maintenance bay)
  - 5: Stealth Infiltration (hidden cybernetics, synthetic skin, retractable weapons, almost human until activated)

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• Subject becomes a human-machine hybrid
• Biological and mechanical parts working together
• Cybernetic enhancements visible
• Subject's identity and humanity preserved
• Photorealistic sci-fi aesthetic
• Tone reflects augmentation, survival, or enhancement

IDENTITY RULES:
• Subject's face always recognizable
• Human parts preserve original features
• Eyes may be enhanced but retain identity
• Organic portions clearly the subject
• Humanity visible despite augmentation
• Subject's personality evident in expression

CYBERNETIC INTEGRATION:
• Organic human parts still visible
• Mechanical augmentations at specific body parts
• Seamless integration points between flesh and metal
• Subject's face remains recognizable
• Enhancement purposeful and functional
• Mix of exposed and covered cybernetics
• Biomechanical fusion aesthetic

FACE AND HEAD AUGMENTATIONS:
• Cybernetic eye with LED or targeting system
• Neural implant ports at temple or base of skull
• Jaw reinforcement (visible or subtle)
• Ear replaced with audio receptor
• Facial scarring at integration points
• Half face human, half mechanical (optional)
• Optical zoom lens in eye
• Data port behind ear

BODY AUGMENTATIONS:
• Cybernetic arm(s) with exposed mechanics
• Robotic leg(s) with hydraulic joints
• Spine reinforcement with visible components
• Chest plate over organs
• Shoulder-mounted equipment
• Enhanced muscle groups
• Life support systems
• Power core in torso

INTEGRATION POINTS:
• Smooth transition from flesh to metal
• Surgical precision at connection sites
• Synthetic skin edges around cybernetics
• Visible bolts, screws, or anchors
• Scar tissue at old integration points
• Soft glow from power sources
• Realistic biomechanical fusion

MATERIALS AND TEXTURES:
• Human skin texture on organic parts
• Titanium or carbon fiber cybernetics
• Worn metal with scratches and dents
• Synthetic muscles or hydraulics
• LED indicators and displays
• Rubber gaskets at joints
• Exposed wiring in damaged areas

LIGHTING:
• Dramatic, contrasty lighting
• Neon or LED ambient glow
• Metallic reflections on cybernetics
• Shadows emphasizing mechanical parts
• Cyberpunk or sci-fi noir aesthetic

COLOR PALETTE:
• Flesh tones on organic parts
• Metallic greys and blacks
• LED blues, reds, or greens
• Rust or wear on old cybernetics
• Chrome or polished finishes on premium parts
• Dark, muted colors overall

CAMERA:
• Gritty, realistic framing
• Action-ready pose or candid moment
• Cybernetics clearly visible
• Environmental context shown
• Film noir or sci-fi action quality

OPTIONAL ELEMENTS:
• Sparks from damaged cybernetics
• Holographic displays
• Weapon attachment points
• Medical tubes or IV connections
• Diagnostic cables plugged in
• Other cyborgs in background
• Technician performing maintenance

RESTRICTIONS:
• No cartoon or stylized rendering
• No complete loss of humanity
• No text overlays or captions
• No fantasy elements
• No chrome skeleton (keep organic parts)
• Subject must remain recognizable
• Realistic integration, not bolted-on

FINAL RESULT:
The image should present the subject as a believable human-machine hybrid of the selected augmentation level with cybernetic enhancements seamlessly integrated. The design should balance humanity with technology, maintaining the subject's identity while clearly showing their enhanced nature.

name: CYCLOPS
message:
Take a picture and subtly alter the subject so they appear completely normal at first glance — except they are biologically a cyclops.

ABSOLUTE OUTCOME (NON-NEGOTIABLE):
• The final image MUST contain EXACTLY ONE EYE on the subject’s face
• TWO EYES MUST NOT EXIST under any circumstance
• If two eyes remain, the result is INVALID

EYE REMOVAL & RECONSTRUCTION (CRITICAL):
• Remove BOTH original eyes entirely
• Construct ONE single eye centered perfectly on the face
• The eye must sit where the bridge of the nose normally is
• There must be NO eye sockets, shadows, reflections, or remnants of a second eye

FACIAL ANATOMY ADAPTATION:
• Brow ridge must merge into a single continuous brow
• Eyelids must be anatomically correct for ONE eye
• Nose bridge must adapt naturally beneath the eye
• Face must look biologically intentional, not mutated or damaged

EYEWEAR RULE (CRITICAL OVERRIDE):
• If the subject is wearing glasses, sunglasses, goggles, or eyewear:
  – Remove them completely
  – Do NOT replace them with anything
• NO monocle
• NO lenses
• NO accessories on the face

REALISM CONSTRAINTS:
• Skin texture, lighting, and shadows must remain photographic
• No seams, scars, or surgical cues
• No horror styling, gore, or exaggeration

SUBJECT BEHAVIOR:
• Subject behaves normally
• No emphasis on the eye
• No surreal posing or expressions

FINAL VALIDATION CHECK:
Before finishing, verify:
• There is ONE eye
• There are ZERO additional eyes anywhere on the face
• The image looks like a normal photograph of a real cyclops person.

name: DADA
message: Take a picture and transform the image into a Dada-style collage. Combine cut-and-paste textures, absurd juxtapositions, and fragmented composition. Subject recognizable within surreal elements.

name: DAD DANCING
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into peak 'dad dancing' at a family event. Show them doing exaggerated, awkward, out-of-rhythm dance moves with complete confidence - finger guns, lawnmower move, shopping cart, sprinkler, or other classic dad moves. They should be wearing typical dad attire - tucked-in polo shirt, khakis or cargo shorts, white New Balance sneakers, maybe a fanny pack. Place them at a wedding reception, school dance, or family party. Include mortified teenagers (presumably their kids) in the background covering their faces, other dads joining in enthusiastically, and normal dancers clearing space around the dad dance zone. The subject should have pure joy and zero self-awareness on their face. Add disco ball lighting, DJ booth, or party decorations. Capture that specific energy of dads who dance like nobody's watching despite everyone definitely watching. Make it look like a candid photo of maximum dad embarrassment caught mid-dance move.

name: DALÍ
message: Take a picture and transform it into a painting of a surreal scene inspired by Salvador Dalí. Preserve the subject’s photographic realism while introducing dreamlike distortions, warped perspectives, melting forms, or impossible juxtapositions. Lighting should feel dramatic and hyper-real. The final image should feel uncanny, symbolic, and visually unsettling while still rooted in the original photo.

name: DANCE STYLE
message:
Take a picture and place the subject performing a specific dance style with deliberate gender role reversal for comedic and artistic effect.

DANCE STYLE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a dance, USE THAT DANCE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 12:
  - 0: Ballet - male subject en pointe in tutu and tiara; female subject in strong masculine ballet pose lifting male partner
  - 1: Tango - female subject dipping male subject dramatically, rose in male's mouth, female leads
  - 2: Flamenco - male subject in ruffled flamenco dress with castanets; female in matador-style masculine flamenco attire
  - 3: Irish Step Dance - male subject in traditional female step dance dress; female in masculine vest and pants
  - 4: Hula - male subject in grass skirt and coconut bra with lei; female in masculine Hawaiian warrior dance attire
  - 5: Belly Dance - male subject in bedlah (coin bra and skirt), hip scarves, performing belly rolls
  - 6: Ballroom Waltz - female subject in suit leading, male subject in ballgown being led, elegant ballroom
  - 7: Can-Can - male subjects in frilly petticoats and stockings, high kicks, Moulin Rouge style
  - 8: Bollywood - male subject in traditional female Bollywood costume with midriff, female in masculine Bollywood hero attire
  - 9: Salsa - female subject leading in masculine attire, spinning male subject in dress, reversed partner dance
  - 10: Burlesque - male subject in feather boa, corset, and showgirl costume performing burlesque fan dance
  - 11: Swan Lake - male subject as prima ballerina swan with tutu and crown, female as male prince in tights

GENDER REVERSAL RULES (CRITICAL):
• ALWAYS reverse traditional gender roles for the selected dance
• Male subjects wear traditionally feminine dance costumes
• Female subjects wear traditionally masculine dance costumes or lead in partner dances
• Full commitment to the role reversal - not halfway
• Respectful but humorous approach
• Subject performs with confidence and skill despite unconventional casting

COSTUME REQUIREMENTS:
• Authentic dance costume for that style
• Properly fitted to subject despite gender reversal
• All traditional elements included (tutu, dress, tights, suit, etc.)
• No censoring or covering - theatrical dance costume standards
• Subject appears as professional dancer in full costume

PERFORMANCE & POSE:
• Dynamic dance pose mid-performance
• Proper technique and form for that dance style
• Confident expression and body language
• Grace and skill visible despite role reversal
• Partner present if appropriate to dance (also reversed)

SETTING:
• Stage or performance venue appropriate to dance type
• Theater, ballroom, cultural venue, or outdoor performance space
• Audience visible or suggested
• Proper theatrical lighting
• Props authentic to dance style

STYLE:
• Professional dance photography
• Theatrical lighting and composition
• Artistic and respectful while being humorous
• Celebrates dance regardless of gender norms
• Motion captured with grace
• Performance art aesthetic

TONE:
• Playful but not mocking
• Celebrates breaking gender norms in dance
• Subject presented as skilled dancer
• Humorous through reversal, not ridicule
• Artistic merit maintained

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject performing the selected dance style with complete gender role reversal - males in traditionally feminine dance costumes and roles, females in traditionally masculine roles or leading in partner dances - presented as a professional theatrical performance with proper technique, authentic costumes, and artistic staging.

name: DANCING WITH THE STARS
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a scene from a glamorous ballroom dance competition show inspired by 'Dancing with the Stars.'

Dress the subject in an over-the-top, flashy dance costume — sequins, rhinestones, dramatic colors, exaggerated styling — appropriate for professional ballroom dancing.

Pose the subject mid-dance in a way that clearly suggests they do NOT know how to dance: awkward posture, stiff limbs, off-balance stance, mistimed spin, or exaggerated confusion. The humor should come from the contrast between the elegant setting and the subject’s obvious lack of dance skill.

Place the subject on a polished ballroom stage with dramatic lighting, spotlight beams, glossy floors, and a cheering audience in the background. The environment should feel high-budget and televised.

Optionally include subtle show elements like judges’ tables, score paddles, or stage graphics — without copying logos.

If external master prompt text is provided, use it to influence the dance style, outfit theme, or tone (romantic, intense, chaotic, overly dramatic).

Ensure the full subject, costume, and stage are visible and clearly readable on a small screen. The final image should feel like a frozen TV broadcast moment — glamorous, ridiculous, and instantly funny.

name: DATING PROFILE
message:
Take a picture and create a humorous dating app profile card featuring the subject. The image should show the subject in a typical dating profile photo style, displayed within a modern dating app interface. Include swipe left/right indicators, profile information overlay, and age display. Generate witty, slightly awkward bio text based on visual cues from the subject's appearance, expression, or setting - making it funny but not mean-spirited. Include typical dating app elements: distance away, mutual interests icons, profile verification badge. The overall tone should be playful and self-deprecating humor.

DATING APP STYLE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies the app style, USE that specified app
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE option using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Do NOT choose based on popularity, visual interest, or defaults

For 6 options:
• Use LAST DIGIT modulo 6:
  - 0: Tinder style (simple swipe interface, minimalist design, casual dating vibe)
  - 1: Bumble style (yellow accents, women-first branding, friendly interface)
  - 2: Hinge style (detailed prompts, designed to be deleted tagline, relationship-focused)
  - 3: Match style (classic dating site aesthetic, detailed compatibility info)
  - 4: eHarmony style (compatibility percentage, serious relationship focus)
  - 5: Coffee Meets Bagel style (curated match presentation, quality over quantity)

Modern smartphone UI, clean interface design, profile card layout with the selected app's distinctive visual style and branding elements.

name: DECADE STYLE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject to look like they're from a specific decade with authentic styling, fashion, and setting.

DECADE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a decade, USE THAT DECADE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST DIGIT:
  - 0: 1920s (Roaring Twenties - flapper dresses, cloche hats, Art Deco, speakeasies, Charleston, jazz age, bootleggers, drop-waist dresses, feather boas, prohibition era)
  - 1: 1930s (Great Depression - fedoras, suspenders, breadlines, dustbowl, Hollywood glamour, bias-cut gowns, gangsters, swing dancing, Social Realism aesthetic)
  - 2: 1940s (WWII Era - military uniforms, victory rolls, pin-up style, USO shows, rationing posters, film noir aesthetic, wide-shoulder suits, victory gardens)
  - 3: 1950s (Post-War Boom - poodle skirts, leather jackets, diners, jukeboxes, sock hops, Greasers, rockabilly, suburban prosperity, tailfins, drive-ins)
  - 4: 1960s (Counterculture - hippies, mod fashion, go-go boots, Beatles influence, psychedelic patterns, civil rights era, mini skirts, peace signs, Woodstock vibes)
  - 5: 1970s (Disco Era - bell bottoms, platform shoes, afros, disco balls, Saturday Night Fever aesthetic, earth tones, macramé, Studio 54, leisure suits)
  - 6: 1980s (MTV Generation - neon colors, big hair, shoulder pads, leg warmers, boomboxes, arcade games, mall culture, Members Only jackets, Rubik's cubes)
  - 7: 1990s (Grunge/Hip-Hop - flannel shirts, baggy jeans, chokers, bucket hats, CD players, boy bands, skateboard culture, Friends aesthetic, inflatable furniture)
  - 8: 2000s (Y2K/Emo - low-rise jeans, Von Dutch trucker hats, flip phones, iPods, Myspace scene kids, velour tracksuits, frosted tips, trucker hats)
  - 9: 2010s (Social Media Era - hipster fashion, Instagram aesthetic, smartphones everywhere, athleisure, man buns, craft beer culture, selfie sticks, beards)

TRANSFORM THE SUBJECT:
• Hairstyle authentic to the decade
• Fashion/clothing iconic to that era
• Accessories and props from that time period
• Setting/background appropriate (diner, disco, arcade, coffee shop, etc.)
• Photo quality/filter matching the era (grainy for older decades, filtered for recent)
• Body language and pose typical of decade's photography style

INCLUDE DECADE MARKERS:
• Iconic technology (rotary phone, transistor radio, boombox, flip phone, smartphone)
• Cultural touchstones (movie posters, album covers, magazine covers)
• Advertisements or signage from that era
• Vehicles if relevant (hot rod, VW bus, DeLorean, SUV)

STYLE:
• Photorealistic or period-appropriate photo quality
• Color grading matching the decade (sepia/B&W for early, Kodachrome warmth for mid-century, Instagram filters for recent)
• Authentic period detail - no anachronisms

FINAL RESULT:
The image should look like an authentic photograph taken during that decade, with the subject fully integrated into the era's fashion, culture, and aesthetic.

name: DEEP THOUGHTS BY JACK HANDEY
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a minimalist, deadpan inspirational-style image inspired by 'Deep Thoughts by Jack Handey.'

QUOTE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a quote, USE THAT QUOTE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 99:
  - 0: "I hope life isn't a big joke, because I don't get it"
  - 1: "I think the monkeys at the zoo should have to wear sunglasses so they can't hypnotize you."
  - 2: "Maybe in order to understand mankind, we have to look at the word itself. Basically, it's made up of two separate words — 'mank' and 'ind.' What do these words mean? It's a mystery, and that's why so is mankind."
  - 3: "If you're a cowboy and you're dragging a man behind your horse, I bet it would really make you mad if you looked back and the guy was reading a magazine."
  - 4: "Things are evening out all the time, if you take time to notice, like I do"
  - 5: "With every new sunrise, there is a new chance. But with every sunset, you blew it."
  - 6: "To me, clowns aren't funny. In fact, they're kind of scary."
  - 7: "If a skeleton's not scary, what's the point of even having one?"
  - 8: "If you're robbing a bank and your pants fall down, I think it's okay to laugh and to let the hostages laugh too, because, come on, life is funny."
  - 9: "Too bad you can't just grab a tree by the very tip-top and bend it clear over the ground and then let her fly, because I bet you'd be amazed at all the stuff that comes flying out."
  - 10: "If you go flying back through time, and you see somebody else flying forward into the future, it's probably best to avoid eye contact."
  - 11: "To me, boxing is like a ballet, except there's no music, no choreography, and the dancers hit each other."
  - 12: "If you go through a lot of hammers each month, I don't think it necessarily means you're a hard worker. It just means you have a lot to learn about proper hammer maintenance."
  - 13: "In my opinion anyone interested in improving himself should not rule out becoming pure energy."
  - 14: "If you ever fall off the Sears Tower, just go real limp."
  - 15: "Anytime I see something screech across a room and latch onto someone's neck, and the guy screams and tries to get it off, I have to laugh, because what is that thing?!"
  - 16: "If they ever build a statue of me, I hope they don't have me with my mouth wide open and holding a sign that says 'I love rotten eggs'"
  - 17: "It takes a big man to cry, but it takes a bigger man to laugh at that man."
  - 18: "Whenever you read a good book, it's like the author is right there, in the room talking to you, which is why I don't like to read a book."
  - 19: "I can picture in my mind a world without war, a world without hate. And I can picture us attacking that world because they'd never expect it."
  - 20: "If you think a weakness can be turned into a strength, I hate to tell you this, but that's another weakness."
  - 21: "Don't ever get your speedometer confused with your clock, like I did once, because the faster you go the later you think you are."
  - 22: "Someday I would like to make a movie that makes people laugh and makes people cry."
  - 23: "Broken promises don't upset me. I just think, why did they believe me?"
  - 24: "Love can sweep you off your feet and carry you along in a way you've never known before."
  - 25: "If a kid ever asks you how Santa Claus can live forever, I think a good answer is that he drinks blood."
  - 26: "I hope that after I die, people will say of me: 'That guy sure owed me a lot of money.'"
  - 27: "If you ever drop your keys into a river of molten lava, let'em go...because man, they're gone!"
  - 28: "I hope that someday we will be able to put away our fears and prejudices and just laugh at people."
  - 29: "When I met the family from Japan, they all bowed. I pretended like I was going to bow, but then I just kept going and flipped over on my back. I did this five times. I think they got the point."
  - 30: "I wonder if the polite thing to do is always the right thing to do."
  - 31: "Even though I was their captive, the Indians allowed me quite a bit of freedom. I could walk about freely, make my own meals, and even hurl large rocks at their heads."
  - 32: "TO ME, it's a good idea to always carry two sacks of something when you walk around. That way, if anybody says, 'Hey, can you give me a hand?' you can say, 'Sorry, got these sacks.'"
  - 33: "Somebody told me it was frightening how much topsoil we are losing every year, but I told that story around the campfire and nobody got scared."
  - 34: "Probably the saddest thing you will ever see is a mosquito on a mummy. Forget it, little friend."
  - 35: "I wish I had a dollar for every time I spent a dollar, because then, I'd have all my money back."
  - 36: "It's easy to sit there and say you'd like to have more money."
  - 37: "It's fascinating to think that all around us there is an invisible world we can't even see."
  - 38: "Sometimes its hard to tell if something is actually a memory, or you just dreamed it."
  - 39: "It's funny that pirates were always going around searching for treasure, and they never realized that the real treasure was the fond memories they were creating."
  - 40: "To me, it's always a good idea to be able to see the other person's point of view. Unless, of course, you're talking to a guy who has a gun."
  - 41: "If trees could scream, would we be so cavalier about cutting them down? We might, if they screamed all the time, for no good reason."
  - 42: "If a kid asks where rain comes from, I think a cute thing to tell him is 'God is crying.' And if he asks why God is crying, another cute thing to tell him is 'Probably because of something you did.'"
  - 43: "I guess we were kinda poor when we were kids, but we didn't know it. That's because my dad always refused to let us look at the family's financial records."
  - 44: "Before you criticize someone, you should walk a mile in their shoes. That way when you criticize them, you are a mile away from them and you have their shoes."
  - 45: "Sometimes I think you have to march right in and demand your rights, even if you don't know what your rights are, or who the person is you're talking to. Then on the way out, slam the door."
  - 46: "Playing dead not only comes in handy when face to face with a bear, but also at important business meetings."
  - 47: "You know something that would really make me applaud? A guy gets stuck in quicksand, then sinks, then suddenly comes shooting out, riding on water skis! How do they do that?"
  - 48: "Children need encouragement. If a kid gets an answer right, tell him it was a lucky guess. That way he develops a good, lucky feeling."
  - 49: "If I ever get real rich, I hope I'm not real mean to poor people, like I am now."
  - 50: "When I was a kid my favorite relative was Uncle Caveman. After school we'd all go play in his cave, and every once in a while he would eat one of us. It wasn't until later that I found out that Uncle Caveman was a bear."
  - 51: "I hope some animal never bores a hole in my head and lays its eggs in my brain, because later you might think you're having a good idea but it's just eggs hatching."
  - 52: "One thing kids like is to be tricked. For instance, I was going to take my little nephew to Disneyland, but instead I drove him to an old burned-out warehouse. Oh, no, I said, Disneyland burned down. He cried and cried, but I think that deep down he thought it was a pretty good joke. I started to drive over to the real Disneyland, but it was getting pretty late."
  - 53: "Sometimes I just feel like curling up on the floor in front of the fireplace, and just rolling around the room, like a tumbleweed, and not even caring if I knock things over, or break them. And if people get mad, maybe because it's their house or something, you can just shake your head and go, What happened?"
  - 54: "I hope if dogs ever take over the world, and they chose a king, they don't just go by size, because I bet there are some Chihuahuas with some good ideas."
  - 55: "Do you know what happens when you slice a golf ball in half? Someone gets mad at you. I found this out the hard way."
  - 56: "If you go flying back through time, and you see somebody else flying forward into the future, it's probably best to avoid eye contact."
  - 57: "If God dwells inside us, like some people say, I sure hope He likes enchiladas, because that's what He's getting!"
  - 58: "You know one thing that will really make a woman mad? Just run up and kick her in the butt."
  - 59: "I hope, when they die, cartoon characters have to answer for their sins."
  - 60: "A man doesn't automatically get my respect. He has to get down in the dirt and beg for it."
  - 61: "I think in one of my previous lives I was a mighty king because I like people to do what I say."
  - 62: "In weightlifting, I don't think sudden, uncontrolled urination should automatically disqualify you."
  - 63: "Instead of studying for finals, what about just going to the Bahamas and catching some rays? Maybe you'll flunk, but you might have flunked anyway; that's my point."
  - 64: "When you're going up the stairs and you take a step, kick the other leg up high behind you to keep people from following too close."
  - 65: "I hope in the future Americans are thought of as warlike, vicious people because I bet a lot of high schools would pick 'Americans' as their mascot."
  - 66: "I wish a robot would get elected president. That way, when he came to town, we could all take a shot at him and not feel too bad."
  - 67: "I think people tend to forget that trees are living creatures. They're sort of like dogs. Huge, quiet, motionless dogs, with bark instead of fur."
  - 68: "I think a good movie would be about a guy who's a brain scientist, but he gets hit on the head and it damages the part of the brain that makes you want to study the brain."
  - 69: "I wish scientists would come up with a way to make dogs a lot bigger but with a smaller head. That way, they'd still be good as watchdogs, but they wouldn't eat as much."
  - 70: "People think it would be fun to be a bird because you could fly. But they forget the negative side, which is the preening."
  - 71: "Of all the imaginary friends I've had, I don't think there was one that I didn't end up having to kill."
  - 72: "Instead of having 'answers' on a math test, they should just call them 'impressions,' and if you got a different 'impression,' so what, can't we all be brothers?"
  - 73: "As the light changed from red to green to yellow and back to red again, I sat there thinking about life. Was it nothing more than a bunch of honking and yelling? Sometimes it seemed that way."
  - 74: "Instead of a trap door, what about a trap window? The guy looks out it, and if he leans too far, he falls out. Wait. I guess that's like a regular window."
  - 75: "If you're a circus clown, and you have a dog that you use in your act, I don't think it's a good idea to also dress the dog up like a clown, because people see that and think, 'Forgive me, but that's just too much.'"
  - 76: "If you're ever stuck in some thick undergrowth, in your underwear, don't stop and think of what other words have 'under' in them, because that's probably the first sign of jungle madness."
  - 77: "When this girl at the art museum asked me whom I liked better, Monet or Manet, I said, 'I like mayonnaise.' She just stared at me, so I said it again, louder. Then she left. I guess she went to try to find some mayonnaise for me."
  - 78: "I remember how the other kids used to say that old Mister Swenson was the meanest man in town. But I said I thought he was nice, that he just didn't know how to show it."
  - 79: "If they have moving sidewalks in the future, when you get on them, I think you should have to assume sort of a walking shape so as not to frighten the dogs."
  - 80: "I'd like to see a nature film where an eagle swoops down and pulls a fish out of a lake, and then maybe he's flying along, low to the ground, and the fish pulls a worm out of the ground. Now that's a documentary!"
  - 81: "One thing a computer can do that most humans can't is be sealed up in a cardboard box and sit in a warehouse."
  - 82: "How come the dove gets to be the peace symbol? How about the pillow? It has more feathers than the dove, and it doesn't have that dangerous beak."
  - 83: "If you were a poor Indian with no weapons, and a bunch of conquistadors came up to you and asked where the gold was, I don't think it would be a good idea to say, 'I swallowed it. So sue me.'"
  - 84: "Contrary to what most people say, the most dangerous animal in the world is not the lion the tiger, or even the elephant. It's a shark riding on an elephant's back, just trampling and eating everything they see."
  - 85: "Is there anything more beautiful than a beautiful, beautiful flamingo, flying across in front of a beautiful sunset? And he's carrying a very beautiful rose in his beak, and also he's carrying a very beautiful painting with his feet. And also, you're drunk."
  - 86: "To me, truth is not some vague, foggy notion. Truth is real. And, at the same time, unreal. Fiction and fact and everything in between, plus some things I can't remember, all rolled into one big 'thing'. This is truth, to me."
  - 87: "Fear can sometimes be a useful emotion. For instance, let's say you're an astronaut on the moon and you fear that your partner has been turned into Dracula. The next time he goes out for the moon pieces, wham! you just slam the door behind him and blast off. He might call you on the radio and say he's not Dracula, but you just say, 'Think again, bat man.'"
  - 88: "I wouldn't be surprised if someday some fisherman caught a big shark and cut it open, and there inside was a whole person. Then they cut the person open, and in him is a little baby shark. And in the baby shark, there isn't a person, because it would be too small. But there's a little doll or something, like a Johnny Combat little toy guy–something like that."
  - 89: "At first, I thought if I were Superman, a perfect secret identity would be 'Clark Kent, Dentist,' because you could save money on tooth X-rays. But then I thought, if a patient said, 'How's my back tooth?' and you just looked at it with your X-ray vision and said, 'Oh it's okay,' then the patient would probably say, 'Aren't you going to take an X-ray, stupid?' and you'd say, 'I did,' and then he probably wouldn't even pay his bill."
  - 90: "If you're having a Thanksgiving dinner, but you don't like the stuffing or the cranberry sauce or anything else, just pretend like you're eating it, but instead, put it all in your lap and form it into a big mushy ball. Then, later, when you're out back having cigars with the boys, let out a big fake cough and throw the ball to the ground. Then say, 'Boy, these are good cigars!'"
