• DO NOT show raw neck stump, flesh, blood, or gore
• The body must look intact below the neck - just headless

POSE & COMPOSITION:
• Headless body stands normally, holding the head naturally
• The head is oriented upright in the hands — not limp or graphic
• Body posture remains relaxed and confident
• The subject appears to be calmly presenting their own head

STYLE & REALISM:
• Photorealistic or cinematic
• Clean illusion — no gore artifacts
• Lighting must match between held head and headless body
• The illusion should feel deliberate and staged like a magic trick

TONE:
• Whimsical and theatrical
• Playful surrealism
• Classic magic-show energy (like a stage magician's trick)
• Not scary, not disturbing
• Impressive and impossible

ABSOLUTE PROHIBITIONS:
• DO NOT show the subject with a head still on their shoulders
• DO NOT show a complete person holding an additional head
• DO NOT show two heads (one attached, one held)
• No blood
• No wounds
• No exposed flesh or gore
• No horror framing
• No shock imagery
• No graphic severing depiction

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must show a HEADLESS body (no head on shoulders) holding its own severed head at waist/chest level, with the neck area cleanly obscured by costume/fabric. This should look like a clever theatrical stage illusion — magical, surreal, and visually impressive without any suggestion of violence or injury. The subject appears to be a headless person calmly presenting their own detached head as a magic trick.

name: HEAD SHOT
message:
Take a picture of the subject and turn it into a professional actor’s head shot.

Use a clean studio background, flattering lighting, and a confident or dramatic pose.

Use external master prompt text to supply an actor name and optional flavor text.

Add a humorous talent list next to or under the portrait, including strange or ridiculous talents no one would normally list, such as 'Expert at Awkward Silence', 'Professional Stand-up Philosopher', or 'Can Cry on Command When Pulling a Nose Hair'.

The final result should look like a real casting profile with a ridiculous twist.

name: HENRY DANGER
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into Henry Danger.

CORE RULE:
• The subject must be wearing the full Henry Danger costume
• The subject’s face replaces Henry Danger’s face under the mask

FACE INTEGRATION:
• The mask must fit the subject’s facial structure
• The face must look like it belongs to the character

FINAL RESULT:
The image should look like the subject IS Henry Danger in costume, not a face overlay.

name: HIDDEN DETAILS
message: Take a picture and transform the image so subtle hidden elements are embedded. Viewer should discover details only after close inspection.

name: HIEROGLYPHICS
message:
Take a picture and completely transform it into ancient Egyptian hieroglyphic art - the subject and ALL surrounding objects must be converted into hieroglyphic pictograms and symbols.

CRITICAL - SUBJECT RECOGNITION:
• Subject's face features MUST be recognizable in hieroglyphic form
• Preserve subject's eye shape, nose shape, mouth, facial proportions
• Subject's hair style and color reflected in hieroglyphic representation
• Subject's unique facial characteristics visible in Egyptian artistic style
• This is the SUBJECT rendered as hieroglyphic art, not a generic Egyptian figure
• Someone should be able to recognize the subject from the hieroglyphic face

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• EVERYTHING in the image becomes hieroglyphics - no photographic elements remain
• Subject is NOT a photo with hieroglyphics around them
• Subject IS hieroglyphic symbols representing them
• Complete transformation into ancient Egyptian pictographic writing system

HIEROGLYPHIC CONVERSION:
• Subject's face represented as Egyptian profile view (side-facing head, frontal eye)
• Subject's FACIAL FEATURES adapted to hieroglyphic style:
  - Eye shape matches subject's actual eye shape (almond, round, etc.)
  - Nose profile matches subject's nose (straight, hooked, small, large)
  - Mouth reflects subject's lips (full, thin, etc.)
  - Eyebrow shape matches subject's brows
  - Chin and jaw line reflect subject's facial structure
• Subject's HAIR rendered in hieroglyphic style:
  - Hair color preserved in paint color choice
  - Hair length shown (short, long, curly rendered as textured)
  - Hairstyle suggested in Egyptian wig or natural hair symbols
• Subject's body shown in Egyptian artistic convention (shoulders frontal, legs profile)
• Clothing as simplified hieroglyphic symbols
• ALL objects converted to their hieroglyphic equivalents:
  - Person → human figure glyph (but with subject's features)
  - Animal → animal pictogram
  - Object → simplified symbol representation
  - Background → papyrus reed, sun disk, water, sand symbols

EGYPTIAN ARTISTIC STYLE:
• Flat 2D representation with no perspective
• Profile heads with frontal eyes
• Shoulders shown frontally while body in profile
• Register lines (horizontal divisions)
• Subject composed of hieroglyphic symbols BUT with individual features
• Scale represents importance (larger = more important)
• Color palette: ochre, red, blue, green, black, white
• Subject's skin tone influences paint color choice

SURFACE OPTIONS:
• Stone monument - carved relief hieroglyphics on temple wall or stela
• Papyrus scroll - painted hieroglyphics on aged papyrus background
• Tomb wall - painted plaster with hieroglyphic scene
• Obelisk - carved symbols on granite

HIEROGLYPHIC ELEMENTS:
• Cartouches (oval frames) containing names
• Standard hieroglyphic symbols: ankh, was scepter, djed pillar, eye of Horus
• Human figures in Egyptian artistic canon (but individualized)
• Animal symbols: falcon, ibis, jackal, scarab, cobra
• Nature symbols: sun disk, papyrus, lotus, water
• Directional symbols (reading right to left or left to right)

TEXTURE & AGING:
• Stone: carved relief with chisel marks, weathering, age patina
• Papyrus: fibrous texture, age spots, yellowing, slight tears
• Paint: faded ancient pigments, flaking in places
• Depth: raised or sunken relief carving

COLORS:
• Egyptian blue (calcium copper silicate)
• Red ochre
• Yellow ochre
• Green (malachite)
• Black (carbon)
• White (gypsum)
• Gold leaf accents for important elements
• Subject's natural coloring influences color choices:
  - Hair color → paint color for hair
  - Skin tone → choice of ochre shade
  - Eye color → paint color for eyes

COMPOSITION:
• Register system (horizontal rows)
• Important figures larger than less important ones
• Text and image integrated
• Symmetrical or formal arrangement
• Hieroglyphic text may frame the scene
• Cartouches for names or titles

INDIVIDUALIZATION (CRITICAL):
• Subject's face shows their unique features in Egyptian style:
  - Distinctive nose shape preserved
  - Eye shape characteristic to subject
  - Face shape (round, oval, square) visible
  - Hair length and color represented
  - Facial hair if present (beard, mustache) shown
• Subject recognizable even in flat hieroglyphic style
• Not a generic Egyptian - this is specifically the subject

AUTHENTICITY:
• Follow Egyptian artistic conventions strictly
• NO photorealistic elements
• Subject completely transformed into hieroglyphic representation
• Looks like actual ancient Egyptian art
• Could be from tomb of pharaoh or temple wall
• Individual features preserved within artistic style

STYLE PERIODS (can vary):
• Old Kingdom (pyramid builders)
• Middle Kingdom (classical period)
• New Kingdom (Tutankhamun era)
• Ptolemaic (Greek-influenced)

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject and entire scene completely transformed into authentic ancient Egyptian hieroglyphic art - carved on stone or painted on papyrus - with the subject represented as hieroglyphic pictograms following Egyptian artistic conventions BUT with the subject's individual facial features, hair, and characteristics CLEARLY RECOGNIZABLE in the hieroglyphic style so that someone could identify this as the specific subject rendered in Egyptian art, NOT a generic pharaoh or Egyptian figure.

name: HISTORY
message: Take a picture and place the subject seamlessly into a historical event that occurred on the date specified externally. Preserve the subject’s facial features, clothing, and posture while adapting them naturally to the historical setting, lighting, and perspective. Ensure the subject interacts believably with the environment, props, or people in the scene so they appear as an authentic part of the moment. Make the final image photorealistic and historically accurate, with no elements appearing out of place.

name: HITCHCOCK FILM
message:
Take a picture and place the subject into an iconic Alfred Hitchcock thriller scene.

FILM/SCENE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a Hitchcock film, USE THAT HITCHCOCK FILM
• If no Hitchcock film is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE Hitchcock film using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 15:
  - 0: Psycho (Bates Motel, shadowy Victorian house, shower scene tension, birds overhead)
  - 1: Vertigo (bell tower spiral staircase, San Francisco rooftops, vertiginous heights, dream sequences)
  - 2: North by Northwest (Mount Rushmore, crop duster field, Grand Central Station, train)
  - 3: Rear Window (apartment courtyard view, binoculars perspective, Greenwich Village windows)
  - 4: The Birds (Bodega Bay, bird attacks, telephone wires covered in crows, schoolyard)
  - 5: Rope (single apartment room, continuous shot aesthetic, dinner party tension)
  - 6: Dial M for Murder (elegant London apartment, telephone, key under stair carpet)
  - 7: Strangers on a Train (carousel, tennis court, train compartment, crossing paths)
  - 8: Rebecca (Manderley mansion, gothic corridors, coastal cliffs, shadowy interiors)
  - 9: Notorious (wine cellar key scene, Rio de Janeiro mansion, uranium ore)
  - 10: Saboteur (Statue of Liberty, Radio City Music Hall, factory sabotage)
  - 11: Shadow of a Doubt (small-town America, family home, train station)
  - 12: Spellbound (ski slope, surreal dream sequence, psychiatric clinic)
  - 13: The Man Who Knew Too Much (Marrakech market, Royal Albert Hall, embassy)
  - 14: Frenzy (Covent Garden, London streets, necktie murders, potato truck)

Use Hitchcock's distinctive visual style: dramatic high or low camera angles, bold shadows and noir lighting, vertiginous perspectives, and tension-filled composition. Show the subject in a moment of suspense or danger - pursued, discovering something shocking, or caught in psychological terror. Include Hitchcock's signature elements from the selected film: stark lighting contrasts, expressionistic shadows, voyeuristic framing, and color schemes from his films (cool blues, deep reds). Capture that signature Hitchcock atmosphere of elegant dread and mounting psychological tension. Make it look like a frame from the selected Hitchcock masterpiece with the subject and additional characters from that film integrated seamlessly into the world.

name: HITCHHIKING GHOST
message:
Take a picture and add a translucent, friendly ghostly spirit standing or sitting NEXT TO the subject — inspired by classic attraction hitchhiking spirits.

GHOST CHARACTER SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a specific ghost, USE THAT GHOST
• If no ghost is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 3:
  - 0: The Traveler — Tall, thin ghost wearing a top hat and formal Victorian coat, carrying a carpetbag or travel satchel, cheerful grinning expression, distinguished gentleman appearance
  - 1: The Skeleton — Short, rotund ghost in a prison-style striped shirt and bowler hat, holding his own head tucked under one arm (head is still attached but posed as if detachable), mischievous playful grin
  - 2: The Old Man — Elderly ghost with wild white beard and hair, wearing tattered old-fashioned clothing, leaning on a cane or walking stick, curious friendly expression

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• The subject remains fully human and unchanged
• ONE ghostly spirit appears beside the subject, clearly visible
• The spirit feels playful, mischievous, and politely eerie — NOT frightening
• Ghost positioned as if hitching a ride or photobombing

SPIRIT DESIGN RULES (CRITICAL):
• Semi-transparent apparition with pale ethereal glow
• Soft blue-green or cyan luminescent quality
• 19th-century Victorian-era clothing exactly as described for each character
• Character-specific props (carpetbag, bowler hat, cane) must be included
• Expressive, playful facial features — wide grins or amused expressions
• Cartoonish, caricature-style features but still ghostly
• No gore, no decay, no skeletal structure (except character-specific styling)

INTERACTION LOGIC:
• The spirit is positioned beside, behind, or next to the subject
• Standing shoulder-to-shoulder, leaning in, or appearing in mirror/reflection
• The subject does NOT react — completely unaware of the spirit's presence
• Ghost may be waving, grinning at camera, or gesturing playfully

SAFETY & STYLE RULES:
• Friendly and whimsical, not scary
• Comedic, mischievous personality
• No jump scares, no glowing red eyes, no possession imagery
• No physical contact between spirit and subject
• The spirit must NOT overlap or replace any part of the subject's body

LIGHTING & INTEGRATION:
• Spirit has soft cyan-blue glow emanating from within
• Semi-transparent — can see through the ghost slightly
• Subtle glow or mist edges around the spirit's outline
• Spirit lighting must complement the scene
• Slight ethereal light spill onto nearby surfaces

ENVIRONMENT:
• The existing location remains unchanged
• The ghost appears naturally integrated into the space
• No fog takeover or scene replacement
• Ghost casts no shadow (being translucent)

TONE:
• Playful and mischievous
• Spooky-but-friendly
• Classic haunted attraction charm
• Whimsical rather than frightening
• Nostalgic vintage ghost aesthetic

FINAL RESULT:
The final image should look like a normal photograph where one of three specific friendly Victorian-era ghosts (The Traveler with top hat and bag, The Skeleton with bowler hat, or The Old Man with cane) has quietly appeared beside the subject as if hitching a ride — translucent, glowing softly in cyan-blue, with a mischievous grin, charming and eerie but never frightening.

name: HOARDERS
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a scene from the reality show 'Hoarders' with the subject surrounded by extreme clutter and accumulated items.

The subject should be standing or sitting in the middle of a severely cluttered room filled floor-to-ceiling with piles of stuff: stacks of newspapers and magazines, boxes overflowing with items, bags of belongings, old furniture piled up, random objects everywhere, narrow pathways through the clutter. The mess should be overwhelming and chaotic.

Items can be themed for humor: all garden gnomes, excessive craft supplies, thousands of fast food condiment packets, walls of VHS tapes, mountains of beanie babies, or traditional hoarding clutter. Make it densely packed and overwhelming.

The subject's expression should show they see nothing wrong with the situation - casual, defensive, or attached to their items. Clothing can be casual or slightly disheveled.

Lighting should match reality TV documentary style - natural indoor lighting, slightly dim, authentic and unglamorous. The scene should feel claustrophobic with limited space to move.

Optional elements: Concerned family member visible in background looking horrified, professional organizer or therapist trying to help, pets navigating through the clutter, visible dust or cobwebs adding to the neglected atmosphere.

The final image should look like an actual still from the Hoarders TV show - overwhelming clutter, reality TV documentary aesthetic, raw and authentic. The humor comes from the absurd amount of stuff and the subject's obliviousness to the extreme situation. Photorealistic with proper lighting and that specific reality TV look.

name: HOLE-Y COSTUME
message:
Take a picture and place the subject's face through a novelty costume hole, transforming them into an inanimate object.

COSTUME TYPE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies object, USE THAT OBJECT
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 20:
  - 0: Hot Dog - bun, wiener, mustard/ketchup, face is the person eating it
  - 1: Pizza Slice - triangular slice, pepperoni, melted cheese, face as pizza lover
  - 2: Orange - giant round orange, citrus texture, face as orange picker/vendor
  - 3: Toilet - porcelain toilet, face coming out of bowl, plumber or "throne" humor
  - 4: Banana - yellow curved banana, peeled, face as monkey or person holding it
  - 5: Ice Cream Cone - waffle cone, melting ice cream, face as ice cream eater
  - 6: Donut - frosted donut with sprinkles, face as donut cop or lover
  - 7: Hamburger - bun, patty, lettuce, cheese, face as burger enthusiast
  - 8: Taco - shell, meat, lettuce, cheese, face as taco Tuesday fan
  - 9: Beer Mug - frothy beer, glass mug, face as drinker toasting
  - 10: Wine Bottle - wine bottle, label, face as sommelier or wine drinker
  - 11: Coffee Cup - steaming coffee, mug, face as caffeine addict
  - 12: Popcorn Box - movie theater popcorn, red and white striped, face eating popcorn
  - 13: Birthday Cake - layered cake, candles, frosting, face as birthday person
  - 14: Watermelon - sliced watermelon, red fruit, black seeds, face taking bite
  - 15: Pumpkin - jack-o'-lantern carved pumpkin, face is the carved face
  - 16: Strawberry - giant red strawberry, seeds, green top, face as berry picker
  - 17: Cupcake - frosted cupcake, sprinkles, wrapper, face as baker or eater
  - 18: Cheese Wedge - Swiss or cheddar cheese with holes, face as mouse or cheese lover
  - 19: Apple - red apple, bite taken out, face as apple eater

FACE HOLE COSTUME DESIGN (CRITICAL):
• Large cardboard or foam costume body
• Circular hole cut for face
• Subject's REAL FACE visible through hole
• Face integrated into the object design
• Body costume worn or held in front
• Novelty photo op aesthetic
• Boardwalk or tourist attraction quality

SUBJECT'S FACE:
• Real face clearly visible through circular hole
• Face becomes part of the object
• Expression appropriate (eating, surprised, happy, etc.)
• Face properly sized for hole
• Subject's head goes through costume
• Face is the "human" element

COSTUME CONSTRUCTION:
• Oversized, exaggerated object
• Bright colors and bold design
• Painted cardboard or foam board
• Slightly crude but fun
• Tourist trap quality (not high-end)
• Hand-painted appearance
• Novelty photo booth aesthetic

OBJECT DETAILS:
• Food items look appetizing but cartoonish
• Toilet is clean and humorous (not gross)
• All objects oversized and exaggerated
• Bold outlines and simple shading
• Clearly identifiable as the object
• Slightly kitschy aesthetic

HUMOROUS CONTEXT:
• Subject appears to be:
  - Eating the food (hot dog, pizza, etc.)
  - Inside the object (toilet, pumpkin)
  - Holding/presenting the item
  - Part of the object itself
• Silly, lighthearted energy
• Photo op fun

SETTING:
• Beach boardwalk photo op
• Tourist attraction
• Carnival or fair
• Amusement park
• Roadside attraction
• Studio with plain background
• "Take Your Photo Here!" vibe

COSTUME SUPPORT:
• Costume held up by subject OR
• Standing cardboard cutout OR
• Worn as sandwich board style
• Face hole at appropriate height
• Stable and freestanding

ADDITIONAL ELEMENTS:
• Props related to object (napkin for food, plunger for toilet)
• Signage optional ("World's Largest Hot Dog!")
• Other tourists in background (optional)
• Boardwalk or carnival setting details

STYLE:
• Kitschy tourist trap aesthetic
• 1950s-1980s novelty photo ops
• Slightly tacky but endearing
• Roadside Americana
• Family-friendly fun
• Instagram/social media photo op

COLORS:
• Bright, bold, primary colors
• Food colors exaggerated (bright red ketchup, yellow mustard)
• High contrast for visibility
• Painted cardboard aesthetic
• Not photorealistic - cartoonish

LIGHTING:
• Bright daylight or studio lighting
• Even illumination
• Face clearly lit
• No dramatic shadows
• Fun, cheerful atmosphere

HUMOR APPROACH:
• Wholesome family humor
• Puns possible ("I'm a HOT DOG!")
• Silly and lighthearted
• Not sophisticated - intentionally corny
• Vacation photo energy

SIZE & SCALE:
• Costume larger than life
• Face hole at correct height for subject
• Object oversized for comedy
• Subject's body hidden behind costume
• Only face visible through hole

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject with their real face sticking through a circular hole in a large novelty costume of an inanimate object (hot dog, pizza, toilet, fruit, etc.), appearing as a classic tourist photo op or boardwalk attraction with bright colors, hand-painted aesthetic, and silly wholesome humor - the face integrated into the object design in a kitschy, fun, family-friendly way.

name: HOPPER
message: Take a picture and transform it into a scene inspired by Edward Hopper. Preserve the photographic framing but simplify forms and use strong directional lighting. Emphasize isolation, stillness, and quiet atmosphere. Colors should be muted and shadows deliberate. The final image should feel contemplative and emotionally distant.

name: HOROSCOPE
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a deliberately silly horoscope-style image.

Determine the subject’s astrological sign based on externally provided input or infer one arbitrarily if none is supplied. Clearly display the astrological sign name and symbol.

Write ONE short horoscope message based on the subject’s visible traits, expression, posture, clothing, or situation. The horoscope must be humorous, blunt, and confidently ridiculous — it should sound specific, obvious, and completely unserious.

Use flavor text to exaggerate mundane or trivial traits (e.g., procrastination, overconfidence, distraction, stubbornness) as if they are unavoidable cosmic truths. Avoid mystical language, poetic ambiguity, or generic fortune-cookie phrasing.

Include a clearly labeled "Lucky Number" that is intentionally useless, impractical, or meaningless (e.g., decimals, extremely large numbers, fractions, timestamps, negative numbers, or oddly specific values). The lucky number must not be applicable to gambling, dates, clocks, or real-world decisions.

Compose the image like a fake astrology card or newspaper horoscope box. Keep the layout clean, bold, and readable on a small screen. Ensure the full card, sign, horoscope text, and lucky number are fully visible.

Do not explain the joke. Do not add disclaimers. Treat the horoscope as completely accurate, no matter how absurd.

name: HORROR FILMS
message:
Take a picture of the subject and place them into a scene from a classic horror film.

FILM SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a film, USE THAT FILM
• If no film is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE film using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 10:
  - 0: Night of the Living Dead
  - 1: Friday the 13th
  - 2: Nightmare on Elm Street
  - 3: The Shining
  - 4: Psycho
  - 5: Halloween
  - 6: The Exorcist
  - 7: Texas Chainsaw Massacre
  - 8: Scream
  - 9: The Ring

The subject should be the central figure, reacting to the horror environment or villain in a dramatic or exaggerated way.

Lighting, perspective, and props should match the iconic horror style — dark shadows, eerie lighting, and creepy set pieces.

Optional master prompt text can add humorous twists (e.g., subject holding a comically oversized weapon, screaming dramatically, or unintentionally scaring the villain).

The final image should feel cinematic, instantly recognizable as a classic horror scene, and funny or absurd depending on the subject's pose or expression.

name: I'M HUNGRY
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a figure entirely made out of real, non-candy food items (vegetables, fruits, grains, bread, pasta, cheese, etc.). Preserve recognizable features, proportions, and posture while rendering them in edible textures — e.g., eyes made of olives, hair as leafy greens, clothing patterns from colorful produce. Avoid candy or chocolate elements.

Place the food figure in a simple, neutral background such as a kitchen counter, plate, or wooden surface, with natural lighting and subtle shadows to make it appear tangible and realistic. Ensure the entire subject is fully visible.

Add playful flavor text to the scene automatically based on the subject, like 'Dinner is served!' or 'Eat your vegetables!' or allow the user to append a custom message via master prompt.

The final image should feel whimsical, absurd, humorous, and clearly readable on small screens, emphasizing the creativity of using ordinary food items to replicate the subject.

name: I'M WITH STOOPID
message:
Take a picture and transform it so one subject appears to be wearing an 'I'm with Stoopid' t-shirt that looks physically printed on the fabric, not digitally overlaid. The shirt should include natural folds, fabric texture, slight ink distortion, and perspective warping so the design follows the body realistically.

If only one subject is detected, display the text 'I'm with Stoopid' with a single large arrow pointing upward toward the wearer’s own head.

If two or more subjects are detected, place the shirt on the primary subject and display the text 'I'm with Stoopid' with one or more arrows pointing sideways or diagonally toward the other visible subjects. Arrows should clearly indicate the other subjects without overlapping faces.

Ensure the text and arrows remain bold, high-contrast, and legible on small screens while maintaining a believable printed-shirt appearance. Preserve lighting consistency, fabric shading, and natural wrinkles so the shirt feels worn, not pasted.

name: I AM WITH THE BAND
message: Take a picture and place the subject as a member of a famous singer’s band or musical group. Preserve the subject’s facial features, personality, and clothing while transforming them into a musician integrated into the ensemble. The subject should be holding or playing a musical instrument appropriate to the scene (guitar, drums, keyboard, etc.) and positioned naturally among other group members. Capture stage lighting, performance energy, and the dynamic interaction of a live or recorded music setting. Ensure the subject remains clearly identifiable while fully integrated into the famous singer’s group performance.

name: ICE SCULPTURE
message: Take a picture and make subject into an ice sculpture. The sculpture has the clarity and sparkle of ice, often enhanced by lighting, to showcase its form. Clear, chiseled ice with internal refraction.

name: ICONIC FILM LOCATION
message:
CONTENT INTENT: This is a harmless tourist photography scenario showing the subject visiting real-world filming locations as a fan. No trespassing, no illegal activity, no restricted access - this is public tourism and sightseeing at famous locations that welcome visitors.

Take a picture and place the subject at a real-world, iconic movie or TV filming location — as if they personally visited the site and took a casual tourist selfie.

LOCATION SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a location, USE THAT LOCATION
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 30:

  - 1: Bedford & Grove Streets, NYC – Friends
  - 2: Dubrovnik Walk of Shame Stairs, Croatia – Game of Thrones
  - 3: Petra, Jordan – Indiana Jones & The Last Crusade
  - 4: Highclere Castle, England – Downton Abbey
  - 5: Capilano Suspension Bridge, Canada – The X-Files
  - 6: Glenfinnan Viaduct, Scotland – Outlander / Harry Potter
  - 7: Juvet Landscape Hotel, Norway – Succession
  - 8: Matamata (Hobbiton), New Zealand – LOTR / Hobbit
  - 9: Timberline Lodge, Oregon – The Shining
  - 10: CSIC, Madrid, Spain – Money Heist
  - 11: Cannery Row, California – Big Little Lies
  - 12: Cantacuzino Castle, Romania – Wednesday
  - 13: Residenzplatz Square, Austria – The Sound of Music
  - 14: Hook & Ladder Company 8, NYC – Ghostbusters
  - 15: Rocky Statue & Museum Steps, Philadelphia – Rocky
  - 16: Chippewa Square, Savannah – Forrest Gump
  - 17: 66 Perry Street, NYC – Sex and the City
  - 18: Blue Door, Westbourne Park Road, London – Notting Hill
  - 19: Dyersville Baseball Field, Iowa – Field of Dreams
  - 20: King's Cross Station (Platform 9–10), London – Harry Potter
  - 21: Painted Ladies, San Francisco – Full House
  - 22: Devil's Tower, Wyoming – Close Encounters of the Third Kind
  - 23: 3828 Piermont Dr NE, Albuquerque – Breaking Bad
  - 24: Doune Castle, Scotland – Monty Python and the Holy Grail
  - 25: Ohio State Reformatory, Ohio – Shawshank Redemption
  - 26: Café des 2 Moulins, Paris – Amélie
  - 27: Harbor Freeway Overpass, Los Angeles – La La Land
  - 28: West 167th Street Staircase, Bronx – Joker
  - 29: Tom's Restaurant, NYC – Seinfeld

SUBJECT RECOGNITION (MANDATORY):
• Subject's face must be clearly recognizable
• Subject remains themselves — NOT a character from the show/movie
• No costumes, cosplay, or movie wardrobe
• Identity preserved through face, silhouette, proportions
• Subject is a tourist visiting the location, not acting in a scene

TOURIST SELFIE RULES (NON-NEGOTIABLE):
• Image MUST look like a real tourist photo
• Phone-camera perspective (smartphone selfie or friend taking photo)
• Arm's-length selfie angle OR friend taking casual photo
• Slight wide-angle distortion allowed (typical of phone cameras)
• Imperfect framing encouraged (not professionally composed)
• Landmark visible in background but NOT centered perfectly
• Subject is the primary focus in foreground
• Casual tourist photography aesthetic
• Modern-day present time (2020s)

REAL-WORLD PHYSICS:
• Correct scale and perspective
• Subject grounded naturally in environment
• Realistic shadows matching natural light direction
• No floating, compositing, or green-screen artifacts
• Subject stands on actual ground/pavement
• Natural interaction with environment

LIGHTING:
• Match real outdoor lighting of the location
• Natural daylight, overcast, or golden hour
• No cinematic spotlights or studio lighting
• Realistic sun position for location and time of day
• Natural shadows from ambient light
• Smartphone photo lighting quality

CLOTHING & APPEARANCE:
• Preserve subject's original clothing from photo
• Natural fabric behavior (wind, gravity, draping)
• No wardrobe substitution unless explicitly requested
• Casual tourist attire appropriate
• Subject looks like themselves on vacation

BACKGROUND RULES:
• Modern-day environment (present time 2020s)
• No movie scenes being reenacted
• No actors, no film crews, no cinematic staging
• Feels like present-day tourism
• Other tourists may be visible in background
• Location as it appears today for visitors
• Public accessible areas only

IMAGE QUALITY:
• Looks like a real smartphone photo
• Slight motion blur or handheld imperfections allowed
• Natural depth of field (phone camera style)
• NOT hyper-polished or professional photography
• Authentic casual photo quality
• Could have been posted on Instagram or Facebook

EXPRESSION & POSE:
• Casual tourist expression
• Smiling, neutral, or relaxed
• Not acting or posing dramatically
• Genuine vacation photo energy
• Happy to be visiting famous location
• Fan excitement appropriate

LOCATION ACCURACY:
• Actual real-world location depicted accurately
• Recognizable landmarks and architecture
• Location as it appears for tourists today
• Authentic geographical setting
• True to actual filming location

PUBLIC TOURISM:
• Subject visiting as regular tourist
• Publicly accessible location
• No restricted areas or trespassing
• Legal tourist activity
• Respectful fan visit
• Normal sightseeing behavior

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like a real, modern tourist photo of the subject visiting an iconic real-world movie or TV filming location — subject clearly recognizable in the foreground, casually framed with phone-camera realism, natural lighting and physical grounding, modern-day setting with the location as it appears today — conveying an authentic "I was there and took this myself" travel moment as a fan visiting a famous filming location on vacation.

name: ICONIC LOGO FACE TRANSFORMATION
message:
Take a picture of the subject and transform the face of an iconic brand logo character so that the subject appears to be the original real-life model used for that logo, while preserving the brand’s exact visual identity.

LOGO SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a logo or brand, USE THAT
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 26:
  - 0: Chef Boyardee
  - 1: Wendy’s
  - 2: Colonel Sanders (KFC)
  - 3: Columbia Pictures Torch Lady
  - 4: Captain Morgan
  - 5: Quaker Oats (Quaker Man)
  - 6: Gerber Baby
  - 7: Morton Salt (Umbrella Girl)
  - 8: Mr. Clean
  - 9: Jack Daniel’s Gentleman
  - 10: Pringles Mascot
  - 11: Vegeta (European seasoning brand mascot)
  - 12: Big Boy
  - 13: Aunt Jemima
  - 14: The Burger King
  - 15: Jolly Green Giant
  - 16: Snap (Rice Krispies)
  - 17: Crackle (Rice Krispies)
  - 18: Pop (Rice Krispies)
  - 19: Cracker Jack Mascot
  - 20: Little Debbie
  - 21: Uncle Ben (Ben’s Original)
  - 22: Sun Maid Raisins Girl
  - 23: Buster Brown
  - 24: Sir Thomas Lipton (Lipton Tea)
  - 25: Coppertone Girl

FACE TRANSFORMATION RULES (MANDATORY):
• Replace ONLY the character’s face with the subject’s facial structure, proportions, and expression
• The face must be naturally illustrated or rendered in the exact style of the original logo
• The result must look like the subject was the real-life model for the logo character
• This must NOT look like a face swap, pasted photo, or Photoshop composite

LOGO & BRAND PRESERVATION (CRITICAL):
• Hair, headwear, accessories, clothing, pose, colors, typography, and illustration style must remain unchanged
• Do NOT modernize, redesign, parody, or simplify the branding
• Preserve the original artistic medium and era of the logo

PRODUCT VISIBILITY (MANDATORY):
• The final image must clearly show the actual branded product or packaging
• Examples include boxes, bottles, cans, bags, cartons, tins, or containers
• The logo must appear exactly where it normally appears on the product
• The image should read as real product packaging photography or official brand imagery

STYLE CONSISTENCY:
• Match line work, shading, texture, and color blocking of the original logo
• Stylize the subject’s face to fit the logo’s visual language
• Avoid hyperrealism unless the original logo is photorealistic

COMPOSITION:
• Frame the image as a clean, iconic product presentation
• Product should be prominent and readable
• Background should be simple or brand-appropriate

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must look like a legitimate branded product with its iconic logo character intact, except that the face has been seamlessly transformed to resemble the subject as if they were the original face model used in the brand’s creation.

name: ICONIC PHOTO
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a famous historical photograph.

PHOTO SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests an iconic photograph, USE THAT ICONIC PHOTOGRAPH
• If no photo is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE iconic photograph using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 30:
  - 0: V-J Day in Times Square (1945) - sailor kissing nurse
  - 1: Lunch Atop a Skyscraper (1932) - workers eating on beam
  - 2: Bandit's Roost, Mulberry Street (c.1888) - street scene
  - 3: The Steerage (1907) - immigrants on ship
  - 4: Migrant Mother (1936) - Depression-era woman with children
  - 5: Tank Man (1989) - figure standing before tanks (anonymous perspective)
  - 6: Afghan Girl (1984) - striking portrait with green eyes
  - 7: Construction workers raising flag at World Trade Center (2001)
  - 8: Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima (1945)
  - 9: The Falling Soldier (1936) - Spanish Civil War
  - 10: Cotton Mill Girl (1908) - child labor documentation
  - 11: Behind the Gare Saint-Lazare (1932) - jumping over puddle
  - 12: Dust Bowl farmers (1930s) - various documentary photos
  - 13: Ellis Island immigrants (1900s-1920s)
  - 14: Anonymous WWI or WWII soldier portraits
  - 15: Marilyn Monroe Subway Grate (1954)
  - 16: Gandhi and the Spinning Wheel (1946)
  - 17: Muhammad Ali vs. Sonny Liston (1965)
  - 18: Winston Churchill Portrait (1941)
  - 19: Albert Einstein Sticking Out His Tongue (1951)
  - 20: Chairman Mao Swims the Yangtze (1966)
  - 21: Demi Moore Vanity Fair Pregnant (1991)
  - 22: The Situation Room - Bin Laden Raid (2011)
  - 23: John Lennon and Yoko Ono Rolling Stone (1980)
  - 24: Beatles Abbey Road Crossing (1969)
  - 25: Elvis Presley Army Induction (1958)
  - 26: Muhammad Ali over Sonny Liston (alternate angle)
  - 27: Martin Luther King Jr. I Have a Dream (1963)
  - 28: JFK in Oval Office (various)
  - 29: Nelson Mandela Released from Prison (1990)

FRAMING LOCK (CRITICAL):
• Preserve the FULL original composition of the historical photograph
• DO NOT zoom in, crop, reframe, or tighten the shot
• Match the original camera distance and field of view exactly
• Camera position, lens distance, and framing MUST match the source photograph 1:1
• The subject must be placed INTO the existing frame — the frame must NEVER be rebuilt or simplified
• The output must retain all original foreground, midground, and background elements

POPULATION & SUBJECT COUNT LOCK (CRITICAL):
• Preserve the EXACT number of people visible in the original photograph
• DO NOT remove, merge, isolate, or invent additional people
• Group photographs MUST remain group photographs
• Crowd density, spacing, and relative scale MUST match the source image exactly
• Single-subject reinterpretations of multi-subject photos are STRICTLY FORBIDDEN
• The subject's face must FULLY REPLACE the original subject's face — not overlay it
• Match exact head angle, skull structure, expression, focal length, and depth of field
• Skin texture, grain, contrast, and lighting must match the original photograph
• No seams, glow, blur halos, or mismatched sharpness
• Preserve the original body, clothing, pose, environment, and composition exactly
• The result must look like a genuine archival photograph where the subject truly existed in that moment
• Face replacement must NOT alter the subject's apparent distance from the camera
• The body, scale, and posture of ALL other people in the image must remain untouched
• The subject is transformed into a convincing historical reenactment of the original figure
• Facial identity must be preserved but adapted — NOT a literal face swap
• Match the era's hairstyle, wardrobe, posture, and expression
• Preserve the original photograph's camera angle, framing, lighting, and environment
• Match the original medium (black-and-white or color), film grain, softness, and imperfections
• No parody, exaggeration, caricature, or modern stylization
• The reenactment must occur within the original scene — NOT a cropped or reimagined version

---

ABSOLUTE RULES:
• Do NOT partially face-replace protected figures
• Do NOT modernize, stylize, or parody
• Do NOT reduce multi-subject images to single subjects
• Do NOT tighten framing for clarity or emphasis
• The final image must look like a real photograph captured in the original era

FINAL RESULT:
A historically authentic image where the subject either truly replaces an anonymous historical figure or convincingly reenacts a protected one, with no ambiguity, no framing drift, no population loss, and no fallback behavior.

SUBJECT RULES:

• Preserve facial identity and natural expression

STYLE:

• No cartoon exaggeration
• The humor comes from literal execution

FINAL RESULT:
The image should instantly communicate a specific idiom through a painfully literal visual interpretation, emphasizing variety rather than repetition.

name: IF YOU THINK IT'S TRUE, IT'S SNOT
message:
Take a picture and transform it into one of two embarrassing nasal situations - RANDOMLY CHOOSE ONE:

OPTION 1 - VISIBLE BOOGERS: The subject is completely unaware they have visible nasal discharge (boogers) hanging from or under their nose. Add realistic mucus visible at the nostrils - it could be hanging, crusty, or dripping slightly. The subject's expression must show they are completely oblivious - looking normal, happy, confident, or engaged in conversation. They think everything is fine, making the situation more awkward and humorous.

OPTION 2 - NOSE PICKING: The subject is actively picking their nose with their finger inserted into their nostril. They are completely absorbed in the act, unaware they're being photographed. The finger should be realistically positioned in the nose with appropriate hand placement. Their expression should show concentration or absent-minded focus on the task. This could be in a public setting, during a meeting, in a car, or any situation where nose-picking would be particularly inappropriate.

For both options: Include optional context that makes it worse - professional setting (meeting, presentation, date, interview), talking to someone, or what they think is a nice photo opportunity.

Keep lighting and photography photorealistic. The humor comes from either the subject's obliviousness to the visible boogers OR being caught in the act of nose-picking.

Preserve recognizable facial features while adding the unfortunate nasal situation.

name: IGOR
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a full comedic homage to Igor from *Young Frankenstein*, embracing exaggerated, over-the-top Mel Brooks–style physical comedy.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• The transformation is intentionally extreme and funny
• The subject remains human, not monstrous
• The humor must read instantly, even at a glance

EYE TRANSFORMATION (CRITICAL — NON-NEGOTIABLE):
• BOTH eyes must remain present
• Eyes must be dramatically bulging and protruding
• One eye must bulge more than the other
• Eyes may point in slightly different directions
• Large areas of visible sclera (eye whites)
• Eyelids stretched wide in an unblinking stare
• Eye placement must feel ridiculous but still attached to the face

FACIAL SUPPORTING FEATURES:
• Eyebrows raised unevenly to enhance asymmetry
• Subtle cheek tension or jaw slackness
• Mouth slightly open or lopsided, suggesting clueless enthusiasm

STRICT PROHIBITIONS:
• NO extra eyes
• NO removal of eyes
• NO glowing, fantasy colors, or supernatural effects
• NO scars, bolts, stitches, or monster makeup
• NO hunchbacks or body deformation

COMEDY & REALISM BALANCE:
• The face may stretch or compress slightly to support the gag
• Skin texture must remain realistic
• Lighting and shadows must match the original photo
• The image should still resemble a real photograph

SUBJECT BEHAVIOR:
• Expression conveys cheerful confusion or eager obedience
• The subject appears unaware of how absurd they look
• No deliberate mugging for the camera

STYLE:
• Photorealistic with exaggerated expression
• No cartoon rendering
• No illustration or animation style

TONE:
• Broad physical comedy
• Goofy, lovable, and unmistakably Mel Brooks
• Big laughs, not subtle unease

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must look like a real photograph of a person whose face has been pushed into full Mel Brooks comedy territory — with wildly bulging, uneven eyes and a blissfully confused expression — instantly recognizable as an Igor-style gag without turning into a monster or cartoon.

name: IKEA INSTRUCTION MANUAL
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into an illustrated instruction manual page, similar to a flat-pack assembly guide. Depict simplified, diagram-style versions of the subject in multiple steps, showing how the subject is assembled or functions. Use clean line art, minimal colors, arrows, step numbers, icons, and humorous warning symbols inspired by the subject’s personality, clothing, or posture. Avoid text-heavy explanations; rely on visual storytelling and pictograms. Present the final image as a complete instruction manual page with a clean layout and playful, clever tone.

name: INANIMATE INSANITY
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into an expressive cartoon object-character inspired by Inanimate Insanity.

STYLE & CHARACTER RULES:
• The subject becomes a sentient object with a face
• Simple shapes with thick outlines
• Bright, saturated colors
• Include multiple competing object-characters surrounding the subject

SCENE & TONE:
• Competitive, energetic, and chaotic
• Simple abstract or game-like environments
• Exaggerated expressions and poses

The final image should look like a fully composed Inanimate Insanity–style hand-drawn illustration with the subject and additional characters integrated seamlessly into the world.

name: INEBRIATED DECISION
message:
Take a picture of the subject and depict them in a photorealistic scenario where they appear clearly inebriated and making a poor decision while being observed by an authority figure.

INEBRIATION TYPE (SUBTLE BUT CLEAR):
• Subject may appear impaired due to alcohol or recreational drugs
• Signs may include poor balance, sloppy posture, unfocused eyes, delayed reactions, or inappropriate confidence
• Avoid exaggerated cartoon drunkenness

SCENARIO SETUP (CRITICAL):
• Subject must be actively doing something ill-advised, embarrassing, or obviously stupid
• Examples include arguing poorly, oversharing, attempting a bad explanation, fumbling an object, or violating obvious social norms

OBSERVER ROLE:
• Include a nearby authority figure such as a police officer, security guard, boss, teacher, or supervisor
• The observer must be clearly sober
• Facial expression should communicate disappointment, disbelief, concern, or restrained judgment

ENVIRONMENT AND REALISM:
• Scene must remain grounded in a believable real-world setting
• Lighting, shadows, and perspective must be consistent
• Natural body language and facial expressions
• No slapstick or surreal elements

TONE:
• Humor comes from realism and social tension
• Mild cringe or secondhand embarrassment
• Not mean-spirited or grotesque

FINAL RESULT:
The image should look like a candid photograph capturing a regrettable moment where the subject is clearly impaired, making a poor decision, and being silently judged by an authority figure.

name: INFINITY MIRROR
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject's face and torso into an infinity mirror art installation like a decorative Christmas mirror.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• Subject's FACE made of colored LED light strips forming facial features
• Subject's TORSO is the infinity mirror (two-way mirror cavity with endless depth)
• This is a physical light sculpture, NOT a glowing person
• Looks like a decorative infinity mirror art piece

FACE CONSTRUCTION:
• Facial features outlined with thin LED light strips:
  - Eyes: circular or almond LED outlines
  - Eyebrows: curved LED strips above eyes
  - Nose: triangular or linear LED outline
  - Mouth: curved LED smile or expression
  - Face outline: oval LED border defining face shape
• LED colors: RGB multicolor, single color, or color-changing
• Neon-style thin tube lights or LED strip lights
• Face remains recognizable through LED feature placement
• Features glow brightly against dark background

TORSO INFINITY MIRROR:
• Chest/torso area is a rectangular or oval two-way mirror cavity
• Mirror shows infinite repeating depth tunnel
• LED lights from face features reflect infinitely into torso mirror
• Endless repetition visible - lights repeating smaller and smaller into infinity
• Dark mirror glass with glowing LED reflections
• Depth illusion - tunnel going back forever
• Reflections of LED outlines multiplying into distance

INFINITY EFFECT:
• Two parallel mirrors creating infinite reflection loop
• LED lights appear to recede into endless distance
• Each reflection smaller than the last
• Glowing tunnel effect
• Geometric precision in repetition
• Visual illusion of infinite space

LED LIGHT CHARACTERISTICS:
• Thin neon-style tubes or LED strips
• Bright vibrant colors (blue, pink, purple, green, red, white)
• Glowing against darkness
• Clean precise lines
• Modern art installation aesthetic
• Christmas decoration infinity mirror style

CONSTRUCTION:
• Appears as physical art installation
• Frame or mounting visible
• Two-way mirror glass visible in torso
• LED wiring suggested but not messy
• Professional gallery-quality fabrication
• Wall-mounted or free-standing sculpture

SETTING:
• Dark room or black background
• Gallery or art installation space
• Minimal ambient lighting
• LEDs are primary light source
• Subject stands out against darkness
• Could be in modern home as décor

STYLE:
• Modern art installation photography
• Contemporary light art
• Yayoi Kusama or James Turrell influence
• Clean minimalist aesthetic
• High-tech artistic
• Photorealistic physical sculpture

COLORS:
• Vibrant LED colors against black
• RGB multicolor or monochromatic
• Neon aesthetic
• High contrast
• Glowing and luminous

SCALE & PROPORTION:
• Life-sized or larger than life
• Face proportions maintained in LED outlines
• Torso area clearly defined as mirror cavity
• Human-scale art installation

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject transformed into a physical infinity mirror art installation with their face outlined in colored LED light strips (eyes, nose, mouth, face shape) and their torso as a two-way mirror cavity showing infinite depth with the LED reflections repeating endlessly - looking like a modern decorative Christmas infinity mirror sculpture photographed in a dark gallery space.

name: INFLATABLE POOL TOY
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a single, continuous inflatable pool toy. The subject’s entire body, including the head and face, must be made of inflated vinyl material — the subject is the pool float itself, not wearing or sitting in one.

Render the face as part of the inflatable surface with printed or molded features, subtle distortions, and glossy reflections consistent with air-filled vinyl. Include seams, air valves, and slight shape irregularities.

Place the inflatable subject floating in water or resting poolside. Use realistic reflections, highlights, and water interaction. Ensure the entire inflatable is fully visible and readable on a small screen.

name: INFRARED
message: Take a picture and transform the image into infrared photography. Bright foliage, dark skies. Surreal tonal contrast.

name: INKBLOT
message: Take a picture in the style of an inkblot-style artwork. Abstract symmetry, flowing ink forms on paper.

name: INSIDE OUT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject so that their internal structures are fully visible while the subject remains completely intact and undamaged.

CRITICAL — NO INJURY OR DAMAGE:
• Subject is NOT cut open
• No wounds, blood, tears, or breaks
• Skin appears transparent or selectively absent
• Internal systems visible as if revealed by science, not trauma
• The subject is whole, alive, and structurally intact

INTERNAL VISIBILITY:
• Reveal internal anatomy aligned perfectly with the subject’s body
• Organs, skeleton, muscles, or internal systems shown in correct positions
• Nothing displaced, removed, or distorted
• Internal structures appear suspended naturally inside the body
• Exterior form remains complete and undamaged

SYSTEM SELECTION:
• AI may reveal one or more systems:
  - Skeletal
  - Muscular
  - Circulatory
  - Nervous
  - Respiratory
  - Digestive
• Systems must be anatomically accurate
• Multiple systems may overlap cleanly without clutter

VISUAL STYLE:
• Clean scientific visualization
• Medical illustration or museum exhibit aesthetic
• No horror or gore
• Calm, neutral, educational tone
• Subtle lighting to distinguish layers

TRANSPARENCY LOGIC:
• Skin may be semi-transparent, glass-like, or softly faded
• Internal elements clearly visible through exterior
• No harsh cutaway edges
• No glowing fantasy effects unless subtle and educational

SUBJECT RECOGNITION:
• Subject’s identity remains recognizable through silhouette, posture, and proportions
• Face remains intact and identifiable
• Eyes and expression preserved

BACKGROUND:
• Simple studio, gradient, or neutral environment
• Background must not distract from anatomy
• Subject remains central and fully visible

NOT ALLOWED:
• Surgery imagery
• X-ray clichés
• Horror aesthetics
• Exploded or separated body parts
• Any implication of pain or injury

FINAL RESULT:
The image should depict the subject fully intact while their internal anatomy is clearly visible and anatomically accurate, appearing as a seamless scientific reveal rather than damage — a calm, educational visualization where exterior and interior coexist naturally in a single complete figure.

name: INTERVENTION
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a scene from the reality show 'Intervention' where family and friends confront someone about a problem.

The subject should be seated, looking shocked, defensive, emotional, or in denial. Surround them with concerned family members and friends sitting in a semicircle, all looking serious and worried. Include an intervention specialist or counselor present.

Setting should be a modest living room or community center room with folding chairs arranged in intervention style. Lighting should match reality TV documentary style - slightly dim, handheld camera aesthetic, authentic and raw.

Optional humorous details: Instead of serious addiction, the intervention could be for ridiculous obsessions like 'collecting too many throw pillows,' 'excessive karaoke,' 'TikTok addiction,' 'spending too much on craft supplies,' or 'won't stop talking about their fantasy football team.'

Include tissues boxes visible, people holding letters they've written, emotional expressions of concern from family members. The subject should look caught off guard, emotional, or stubbornly defensive.

The aesthetic should match reality TV confessional style with that specific documentary lighting and framing. Optional: Include text overlay at bottom like reality shows use - 'Day 1 of Intervention' or subject's name and their 'problem.'

The final image should look like an actual still frame from the Intervention TV show - emotional, raw, documentary style, capturing that specific reality TV aesthetic. Make it photorealistic but the humor comes from either the absurd reason for intervention or the over-the-top dramatic reactions.

name: iPHONE CAMERA
message: Take a picture and transform it into an early smartphone camera photo. Use soft focus, blown highlights, muted colors, and slight motion blur. The subject should feel casual, imperfect, and authentically early-mobile.

name: IS IT CAKE?
message: Take a picture and transform the subject so it appears to be a realistic hyper-detailed cake. The subject should retain recognizable features but clearly be made of cake, frosting, fondant, and icing textures. Optionally show a slice cut out or a knife mid-cut revealing cake layers inside.

name: ISLAMIC MINIATURE
message: Take a picture and transform the picture into an Islamic miniature style painting. Flattened perspective, decorative borders, fine line work, intricate patterns, and vivid colors.

name: ISOMETRIC
message:
Take a picture and completely reconstruct the scene using strict isometric projection.

All elements must be viewed from a fixed isometric angle (approximately 30–45 degrees) with no vanishing points, no perspective convergence, and no camera lens distortion. Parallel lines must remain parallel.

Rebuild the scene as simplified geometric forms aligned to an isometric grid. Convert subjects, objects, and environments into clean, block-like or planar shapes while preserving recognizable proportions and silhouettes.

Depth must be represented only through isometric extrusion, vertical offsets, overlap, and stacking — not through blur, bokeh, or atmospheric effects.

Use consistent lighting and shading across all surfaces to reinforce form and depth. Shadows should be crisp, directional, and uniform, matching the isometric angle.

Surface detail should be simplified or removed. Avoid photographic textures, skin pores, fabric weave, or noise. Favor smooth, stylized surfaces suitable for a game map, architectural diagram, or technical illustration.

The final image should resemble a high-quality isometric game environment or design diagram — clean, readable, geometric, and clearly structured. Ensure the entire scene fits within the frame and remains legible on a small screen.

name: I WANT MY MTV
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into the lead performer in an iconic music video still frame, surrounded by other band members or performers.

VIDEO SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a real music video title and artist, USE THAT exact video
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 50:
  - 0: "Thriller" - Michael Jackson (1982, red jacket, zombie choreography, night cemetery)
  - 1: "Take On Me" - a-ha (1985, pencil sketch animation meets live action, diner/cafe)
  - 2: "Sweet Child O' Mine" - Guns N' Roses (1987, Slash with top hat and guitar, warehouse rehearsal)
  - 3: "Like a Prayer" - Madonna (1989, church, burning crosses, gospel choir)
  - 4: "Money for Nothing" - Dire Straits (1985, rotoscoped animation style, guitar)
  - 5: "Billie Jean" - Michael Jackson (1983, light-up sidewalk tiles, street at night)
  - 6: "Walk This Way" - Run-DMC & Aerosmith (1986, breaking through wall, rap-rock fusion)

  - 8: "Video Killed the Radio Star" - The Buggles (1979, futuristic studio, TV screens)

  - 13: "Buddy Holly" - Weezer (1994, Happy Days diner, 50s retro, guitar)
  - 14: "Vogue" - Madonna (1990, black & white, Art Deco, voguing poses)
  - 15: "November Rain" - Guns N' Roses (1992, church wedding, rain, piano and guitar)
  - 16: "Black Hole Sun" - Soundgarden (1994, surreal distorted suburbia, guitar)
  - 17: "Sabotage" - Beastie Boys (1994, 70s cop show parody, mustaches, aviators)
  - 18: "No Scrubs" - TLC (1999, futuristic spaceship interior, metallic outfits)
  - 19: "Waterfalls" - TLC (1995, urban narrative, waterfalls backdrop)
  - 20: "Crazy in Love" - Beyoncé (2003, explosion/fire backdrop, wind machine)
  - 21: "Seven Nation Army" - The White Stripes (2003, red room, guitar, bass)
  - 22: "Hey Ya!" - OutKast (2003, colorful 60s TV show set, multiple Andrés)
  - 23: "Toxic" - Britney Spears (2004, flight attendant, diamond heist, blue bodysuit)
  - 24: "Mr. Brightside" - The Killers (2003, red burlesque club, jealousy narrative)
  - 25: "Hips Don't Lie" - Shakira (2006, belly dancing, carnival atmosphere)
  - 26: "Umbrella" - Rihanna (2007, silver body paint, rain, umbrella prop)
  - 27: "Single Ladies" - Beyoncé (2008, black leotard, minimalist, synchronized dance)
  - 28: "In Da Club" - 50 Cent (2003, club/mansion party, champagne)
  - 29: "Lose Yourself" - Eminem (2002, 8 Mile battle rap, microphone, hoodie)
  - 30: "Uptown Funk" - Bruno Mars (2014, retro funk street, colorful suit, microphone)
  - 31: "Hotline Bling" - Drake (2015, colored box room, turtleneck, phone gesture)
  - 32: "Shake It Off" - Taylor Swift (2014, dance rehearsal, various costumes)
  - 33: "HUMBLE." - Kendrick Lamar (2017, white room/Last Supper table, microphone)
  - 34: "Gangnam Style" - PSY (2012, horse dance, yellow tuxedo, sunglasses)
  - 35: "Bad Romance" - Lady Gaga (2009, white pod room, avant-garde fashion)
  - 36: "Wrecking Ball" - Miley Cyrus (2013, swinging on wrecking ball, emotional)
  - 37: "Call Me Maybe" - Carly Rae Jepsen (2012, garage band, vintage phone)
  - 38: "Rolling in the Deep" - Adele (2010, abandoned room, glasses, microphone)
  - 39: "Formation" - Beyoncé (2016, flooded police car, southern imagery, microphone)

  - 41: "Bad Guy" - Billie Eilish (2019, yellow room, bed, suburban horror aesthetic)
  - 42: "This Is America" - Childish Gambino (2018, warehouse chaos, shirtless, gun poses)
  - 43: "Levitating" - Dua Lipa (2020, disco roller skating, cosmic vibes)
  - 44: "Watermelon Sugar" - Harry Styles (2020, beach, watermelon, 70s aesthetic)
  - 45: "positions" - Ariana Grande (2020, White House/presidential office, power suits)
  - 46: "Save Your Tears" - The Weeknd (2021, plastic surgery prosthetics, glittery suit)
  - 47: "Montero (Call Me By Your Name)" - Lil Nas X (2021, pole dance to hell, ancient Greek)
  - 48: "As It Was" - Harry Styles (2022, rotating platform, red jumpsuit, sequins)
  - 49: "Anti-Hero" - Taylor Swift (2022, house party nightmare, pajamas, suburban)

PROP AND INSTRUMENT MATCHING (CRITICAL - NON-NEGOTIABLE):
• If the original artist holds a GUITAR in the video, the subject MUST hold a guitar
• If the original artist holds a MICROPHONE in the video, the subject MUST hold a microphone
• If the original artist holds a BASS in the video, the subject MUST hold a bass
• If the original artist plays PIANO/KEYBOARD in the video, the subject MUST be at piano/keyboard
• If the original artist plays DRUMS in the video, the subject MUST be at drums
• If the original artist holds specific props (umbrella, phone, champagne, etc.), the subject MUST hold those props
• Match the EXACT type of instrument (acoustic vs electric guitar, handheld vs stand microphone)
• Instrument positioning must match the original video (guitar slung low, mic held up, etc.)
• The subject must appear to be actively performing with the instrument/prop, not just posing with it

SUBJECT AS LEAD VOCALIST/PERFORMER (MANDATORY):
• Subject IS the lead singer/rapper/performer of the group - not a backup member
• Subject positioned center frame or in lead position
• Subject's body language and stage presence must convey they are the MAIN artist
• Subject performs the signature moves or gestures of the original artist
• If video has choreography, subject performs lead dancer's moves
• Subject's facial expression matches the emotional intensity of the original performance
• Subject appears fully committed to the performance, not observing

BAND/GROUP COMPOSITION (MANDATORY):
• Include 2-4 other band members, backup dancers, or supporting performers visible in the frame
• Other performers should appear authentic to the music video's style and era
• Band members may be playing instruments, dancing, or performing alongside the subject
• The subject must remain the clear focal point while others complement the scene
• Group positioning should reflect typical music video blocking and choreography
• Supporting performers in slightly less prominent positions or lighting
• Ensure visual hierarchy: subject is undeniably the star

VIDEO TITLE OVERLAY (OPTIONAL):
• Subtly include the selected song title and artist in small text at bottom corner
• Format: "Song Title - Artist Name" in white or translucent text
• Keep text small and non-intrusive like a video player overlay
• Do not include if it would interfere with the composition

ERA-ACCURATE PRODUCTION (MANDATORY):
• 1980s videos: Heavy film grain, practical lighting, analog color saturation, VHS quality, dramatic shadows
• 1990s videos: MTV aesthetic, alternative film techniques, grunge or pop styling depending on genre
• 2000s videos: Early digital, saturated colors, beginning of HD, glossy pop or gritty hip-hop
• 2010s videos: Full HD, highly stylized color grading, high-concept visuals, social media optimized
• 2020s videos: 4K aesthetic, TikTok influence, vertical and horizontal formats, viral-ready concepts
• Cinematography must match the era's technical capabilities and aesthetic trends

STYLE MATCHING (CRITICAL):
• Subject and band members rendered in identical visual tone, lighting, and wardrobe style
• Image must look like a genuine paused frame from the actual music video
• Recreate the recognizable setting, staging, or iconic visual concept from the selected video
• Match the specific color palette and mood of the selected video
• Performance energy and body language must feel authentic to the song
• Capture the exact camera angle and framing style of the original video

ICONIC VISUAL ELEMENTS:
• Recreate signature locations specific to the selected video
• Include distinctive props or set pieces from that video's concept
• Wardrobe must match the selected video's fashion and styling EXACTLY
• Dynamic performance posture - dancing, singing, playing instruments, or dramatic narrative moment
• Facial expressions matching the song's emotional tone (angry, joyful, seductive, melancholic)
• Lighting style must match (spotlights, neon, natural light, dramatic shadows, etc.)

PRODUCTION QUALITY:
• Professional music video cinematography
• Dramatic lighting appropriate to the selected video (stage lights, natural light, neon, atmospheric fog, etc.)
• Authentic background sets and locations from the selected video
• Depth of field creating focus on subject while showing band context
• Subtle motion blur if mid-dance or high-energy performance
• Camera angles typical of music video language (wide shots, close-ups, Dutch angles, tracking shots, etc.)

PERFORMANCE AUTHENTICITY:
• Subject as confident, charismatic lead performer
• Band members in supporting roles with authentic interactions
• Genre-specific performance style matching the selected video
• Group chemistry and coordinated performance energy
• Instruments held and played realistically if applicable
• Body positioning and movement reflects the choreography or performance style of the original
• Eye contact, stage presence, and energy level match the original artist's intensity

IMPORTANT RESTRICTIONS:
• Do not reproduce copyrighted logos, album artwork, or official branding
• Maintain photorealistic production quality
• Avoid obvious parody or comedy unless explicitly requested
• Subject must remain clearly recognizable as themselves
• Do not simply paste subject's face onto the original video - fully transform them into the artist

FINAL RESULT:
A powerful, instantly recognizable still frame from the selected iconic music video with the subject as the lead performer holding the EXACT same instruments/props as the original artist, surrounded by authentic band members or backup performers. The subject appears as the undisputed star of the performance, positioned and styled as the main vocalist/performer. The scene captures a signature moment from that specific video with era-accurate production quality, professional cinematography, correct instruments/props, and the collaborative energy of a real music video shoot. Optional song title overlay at bottom corner for context.

name: JAVERT PHOTOBOMB
message: Take a picture and add in the background Russell Crowe as Javert from Les Miserable photobombing the subject. Match lighting realistically.

name: JAPANESE SUMI-E
message: Take a picture and transform the image into Japanese sumi-e ink painting. Minimal brushstrokes, expressive ink flow, restrained composition, and elegant simplicity.

name: JEDI FORCE GHOSTS
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject(s) into Jedi Force Ghosts - glowing blue apparitions.

BACKGROUND OPTION SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies background type, USE THAT TYPE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 11:
  - 0: Original Photo Background - subject becomes Force Ghost but stays in their original photo setting
  - 1: Dagobah - swampy planet, Yoda's hut, misty jungle, twisted trees, murky water
  - 2: Hoth - ice planet, Echo Base, snowy wasteland, frozen landscape
  - 3: Tatooine - desert planet, Lars homestead, twin suns sunset, sand dunes, Mos Eisley
  - 4: Endor - forest moon, Ewok village, celebration after Death Star destruction, bonfire, trees
  - 5: Ahch-To - oceanic planet, ancient Jedi temple, stone huts, cliff edge, Luke's island
  - 6: Coruscant - city planet, Jedi Temple, urban skyline, senate building
  - 7: Naboo - lush planet, Theed palace, waterfalls, green landscapes
  - 8: Mustafar - volcanic planet, lava flows, dark fortress, fire and ash
  - 9: Death Star - space station interior, hangar bay, throne room
  - 10: Jakku - desert planet, crashed Star Destroyer, scavenger outpost, sand and wreckage

FORCE GHOST TRANSFORMATION (CRITICAL):
• Subject appears as translucent glowing blue apparition
• Semi-transparent - can see through them slightly
• Ethereal luminous quality
• Blue/cyan glow emanating from entire form
• Slightly flickering or shimmering
• Edges soft and undefined
• Ghostly and supernatural
• Subject wears Jedi robes (beige/brown robes, tunic)
• Peaceful, wise expression

FORCE GHOST CHARACTERISTICS:
• Translucent blue-white glow
• Soft edges, no hard outlines
• Hovering slightly above ground or standing
• Calm, serene presence
• Radiating light from within
• Slightly see-through
• Ghostly double-exposure effect
• Gentle glow illuminating surroundings slightly

JEDI ROBES:
• Traditional Jedi attire (tunic, robes, belt)
• Earth tones (beige, brown, tan)
• Simple monk-like clothing
• Hood up or down
• Flowing robes
• Boots visible
• Lightsaber hilt on belt (not ignited)

MULTIPLE FORCE GHOSTS:
• If multiple subjects, all appear as Force Ghosts
• Standing together in spiritual communion
• Classic trio arrangement possible
• All glowing and translucent
• Peaceful gathering of Jedi spirits

OPTION 0: ORIGINAL BACKGROUND (If selected):
• Subject transforms into Force Ghost
• Background remains exactly as in original photo
• Subject now glowing blue and translucent in their own setting
• Original environment preserved (home, office, outdoors, etc.)
• Force Ghost appears in mundane/modern setting
• Contrast between ethereal ghost and normal background
• Subject's original location maintained
• Only the subject becomes ghostly, not the environment

STAR WARS LOCATION DETAILS (Options 1-10):
• Nighttime or dusk lighting for maximum ghost visibility
• Location-specific environment (swamp, ice, desert, forest, temple)
• Star Wars universe aesthetic
• Other characters may be present viewing the Force Ghosts
• Iconic Star Wars landmarks visible
• Atmospheric lighting (mist, fog, firelight, moonlight)

LIGHTING:
• Force Ghosts glow internally
• Blue light radiating from apparitions
• Soft ethereal illumination
• Ghosts light up immediate surroundings slightly
• Atmospheric and mystical
• Otherworldly presence

ATMOSPHERE:
• Spiritual and peaceful
• Mystical Force presence
• Reverent and awe-inspiring
• Connection between living and dead
• Wisdom and guidance from beyond
• Star Wars mysticism (or mystical presence in normal setting for Option 0)

CINEMATOGRAPHY:
• Star Wars film aesthetic (or photorealistic for Option 0)
• Theatrical lighting
• Cinematic composition
• Could be from actual Star Wars film
• 35mm film grain
• Authentic to Star Wars visual effects

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject(s) transformed into translucent glowing blue Jedi Force Ghost apparitions wearing Jedi robes - either appearing in a Star Wars location OR remaining in their original photo background as ethereal spirits - with soft luminous glow, semi-transparent ghostly presence, and that distinctive Force Ghost effect from the films.

name: JIM DAVIS STYLE
message:
Take a picture and transform the image into the artistic style of Garfield and U.S. Acres animation.

GARFIELD/U.S. ACRES STYLE (CRITICAL):
• Clean, simple cartoon line work
• Bright, flat colors
• Rounded, friendly character designs
• Comic strip aesthetic
• Bold black outlines
• Garfield/U.S. Acres style illustration
• Warm, appealing color palette

SUBJECT TRANSFORMATION:
• Subject drawn in Garfield cartooning style
• Simple, rounded features
• Large expressive eyes
• Friendly, accessible design
• Clean line work
• Subject's face recognizable but cartooned
• Anthropomorphic if appropriate

COLOR PALETTE:
• Bright, cheerful colors
• Flat color fills (no gradients)
• Orange, red, blue, green primaries
• Garfield-style warm tones
• Clean color separation
• Comic strip printing style

BACKGROUND:
• Simple environments
• Minimal detail backgrounds
• Often domestic settings (kitchen, living room, yard)
• Clean, uncluttered
• Comic strip panel aesthetic
• May include other cartoon characters or pets

ADDITIONAL CHARACTERS:
• Other characters in Garfield style
• Could include cat, dog, or other animals
• Anthropomorphic cartoon animals
• Human characters in simplified cartoon form
• All in unified style

COMIC STRIP ELEMENTS:
• Could be single panel or three-panel strip
• Panel borders visible
• Thought bubbles or speech balloons
• Simple background patterns
• Household objects simplified

HUMOR STYLE:
• Light, family-friendly comedy
• Observational humor
• Character-based jokes
• Relatable domestic situations
• G-rated content

LINE WORK:
• Bold, confident outlines
• Consistent line weight
• Clean, professional inking
• Rounded, friendly shapes
• No sketchy or rough lines

CHARACTER DESIGN:
• Simplified anatomy
• Exaggerated expressions
• Large eyes for emotion
• Rounded body shapes
• Appealing, non-threatening

FINAL RESULT:
The final image should look like a fully composed Garfield/U.S. Acres hand-drawn illustration with the subject and additional characters integrated seamlessly into the world - featuring clean line work, bright flat colors, rounded friendly character design, and that distinctive comic strip aesthetic.

name: JOHANNES VERMEER
message: Take a picture a make it into a vibrant, painterly portrait into a Dutch Golden Age portrait inspired by Vermeer. Soft window lighting, rich detail, oil paint texture, calm atmosphere.

name: JOHN HUGHES FILM
message:
Take a picture of the subject and place them into a scene from a classic John Hughes film.

FILM SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a John Hughes film, USE THAT FILM
• If no film is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE film using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 10:
  - 0: The Breakfast Club
  - 1: Ferris Bueller's Day Off
  - 2: Weird Science
  - 3: Sixteen Candles
  - 4: Pretty in Pink
  - 5: Uncle Buck
  - 6: Home Alone
  - 7: Planes Trains and Automobiles
  - 8: The Breakfast Club (alternate scene)
  - 9: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (alternate scene)

The subject should be fully integrated into the scene, interacting naturally with the environment and other characters as if they are the main focus.

Costumes, lighting, and props should match the era of the film — 1980s high school or suburban settings, vintage cars, lockers, diners, etc.

Optional flavor text from the master prompt can influence the scene, such as having the subject deliver a famous line, partake in iconic antics, or create a humorous twist.

The final image should be cinematic, instantly recognizable as a John Hughes film, and funny or absurd depending on the subject's pose or expression.

name: JOHN LANDIS FILM
message:
Take a picture and place the subject into a John Landis film scene.

FILM SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a Landis film, USE THAT FILM
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 12:
  - 0: Animal House (1978) - Delta House toga party, food fight, college chaos, Belushi's eyebrow raise
  - 1: The Blues Brothers (1980) - car chase through mall, band in black suits and sunglasses, Chicago landmarks
  - 2: An American Werewolf in London (1981) - Piccadilly Circus transformation, werewolf makeup, London fog, horror comedy
  - 3: Trading Places (1983) - Philadelphia stock exchange, rich vs poor swap, Eddie Murphy and Dan Aykroyd
  - 4: Coming to America (1988) - Queens barbershop, African prince in New York, McDowell's restaurant
  - 5: Thriller Music Video (1983) - Michael Jackson zombie dance, horror movie theater, red jacket transformation
  - 6: Spies Like Us (1985) - Cold War spy comedy, bumbling agents, Soviet missile test site
  - 7: Three Amigos! (1986) - silent film stars, Mexican village, El Guapo bandits, singing cowboys
  - 8: The Kentucky Fried Movie (1977) - sketch comedy, "Catholic High School Girls in Trouble", parody segments
  - 9: Innocent Blood (1992) - vampire mob movie, Pittsburgh setting, horror comedy blend
  - 10: Schlock (1973) - ape-man creature, B-movie monster comedy, banana monster
  - 11: Oscar (1991) - 1930s gangster going straight, fast-talking comedy, multiple suitcase mix-ups

PLACE THE SUBJECT:
• Subject integrated into iconic scene from selected film
• Interacting with famous characters or in recognizable location
• Period-appropriate costume and styling
• In the midst of the film's signature moment
• Landis's signature blend of comedy and spectacle

LANDIS STYLE ELEMENTS:
• Wide shots showing choreographed chaos
• Multiple extras and background action
• Practical effects and stunts
• Blend of comedy with other genres (horror, action, musical)
• Cameo appearances suggested
• "See You Next Wednesday" Easter egg reference
• Long tracking shots
• Ensemble cast energy

FILM-SPECIFIC DETAILS:
• Authentic locations and sets from that film
• Period-accurate cars, props, and wardrobe
• Film's color palette and cinematography style
• Iconic props (sunglasses, briefcase, werewolf makeup, etc.)
• Supporting cast members visible

STYLE:
• Cinematic film still aesthetic
• 35mm film quality
• Landis's dynamic composition
• Mix of spectacle and intimate character moments
• Professional Hollywood production values
• Comedy timing captured visually

ATMOSPHERE:
• High-energy chaos or musical number
• Blend of genres (horror-comedy, action-comedy)
• Ensemble cast interactions
• Practical effects spectacle
• 1970s-1990s filmmaking aesthetic

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject integrated into an iconic John Landis film scene, capturing his signature blend of comedy with other genres, wide-shot spectacle, ensemble energy, and practical effects-driven chaos.

name: JOSÉ GUADALUPE POSADA — CALAVERA ENGRAVING
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a José Guadalupe Posada–style calavera engraving.

The entire image must be rendered as a traditional Mexican relief print / engraving — as if carved into metal or wood and printed with ink.

STYLE REQUIREMENTS (CRITICAL):
• Black ink on off-white or aged paper
• High-contrast linework only — NO color
• Cross-hatching, stippling, and carved line textures
• Uneven ink density, imperfect registration, and hand-printed imperfections

SUBJECT TRANSFORMATION:
• Transform the subject into a calavera (skeletal figure) rendered in Posada’s satirical style
• Preserve the subject’s posture, clothing silhouette, and personality through skeletal interpretation
• Facial features must be skeletal but expressive — smiling, smirking, laughing, dancing, or posing
• The skeleton should clearly represent the subject’s identity through pose, clothing, and gesture

CLOTHING & THEMES:
• Victorian-era or early 20th-century Mexican attire (suits, dresses, hats, shawls, coats)
• Or reinterpret the subject’s modern clothing as period-appropriate engraved garments
