• Clothing must be drawn entirely with engraved linework — no smooth fills

COMPOSITION RULES:
• Flat or shallow depth, like a printed broadside or newspaper illustration
• Minimal background OR simple engraved scenery (street, cemetery, dance floor, pulque tavern)
• Optional engraved banners, ribbons, or captions in Spanish-style lettering

TEXT (OPTIONAL):
• If master prompt text is provided, render it as hand-lettered engraved text
• Otherwise include satirical Posada-style phrases such as:
  – "La Calavera del [Subject]"
  – "Todos Acabamos Igual"
  – "La Muerte No Perdona"

ABSOLUTE PROHIBITIONS:
• NO modern illustration styles
• NO smooth digital shading
• NO photography, realism, or painterly effects
• NO color
• NO contemporary cartoon aesthetics

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like an authentic early 1900s José Guadalupe Posada calavera engraving — a satirical, hand-carved print published in a Mexican broadside — humorous, macabre, expressive, and unmistakably traditional.

name: JUMBOTRON
message:
Take a picture and display the subject on a massive stadium Jumbotron screen during a live game, caught in a moment that's being broadcast to thousands of fans. The stadium setting should match a real professional or college venue.

STADIUM AND MOMENT SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies the stadium or moment, USE that specified combination
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE option using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Do NOT choose based on popularity, visual interest, or defaults

For 15 options:
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 15:
  - 0: NFL stadium - Subject messily eating nachos with cheese all over their face
  - 1: NBA arena - Subject accidentally spilling their drink while dancing on kiss cam
  - 2: MLB ballpark - Subject catching a foul ball with their face/head
  - 3: College football stadium - Subject doing an embarrassing celebration dance
  - 4: NHL arena - Subject trying to catch a t-shirt from the cannon and failing
  - 5: Soccer stadium - Subject with face painted, screaming intensely at camera
  - 6: NFL stadium - Subject caught sleeping during a crucial play
  - 7: NBA arena - Subject attempting half-court shot and air-balling badly
  - 8: MLB ballpark - Subject dropping an easy catch in the stands
  - 9: College basketball arena - Subject doing an awkward kiss cam rejection
  - 10: NFL stadium - Subject eating a ridiculously tall pile of food
  - 11: NBA arena - Subject failing at the jumbotron dance challenge
  - 12: MLB ballpark - Subject getting hit by t-shirt cannon
  - 13: Soccer stadium - Subject spilling beer on person in front during goal celebration
  - 14: NHL arena - Subject with foam finger, yelling with mouth full of hot dog

Jumbotron display with scoreboard graphics, stadium crowd visible below, broadcast camera angle, live game atmosphere, stadium lighting.

name: KAHLO
message: Take a picture and transform it into a portrait inspired by Frida Kahlo. Center the subject prominently with symbolic elements drawn from nature or personal identity. Use bold colors, flat backgrounds, and strong outlines. The subject should feel emotionally direct, intimate, and iconic.

name: KAREN
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into 'Karen' - the stereotypical entitled, complaining, demanding middle-class woman archetype, complete with characteristic appearance, pose, and attitude.

FACE PRESERVATION (CRITICAL):
• The subject's actual face MUST remain clearly identifiable and recognizable
• Preserve subject's facial structure, features, and expressions exactly
• DO NOT change the subject's facial identity in any way
• The face should look like the subject themselves in this scenario
• If male subject: their male face is preserved but presented as a woman (comedic effect)
• Facial expressions adapted to 'Karen' stereotype but face remains the subject's own
• All distinct facial features, bone structure, and characteristics maintained
• Eyes, nose, mouth, jawline, cheekbones - all identifiably the subject

GENDER PRESENTATION:
• Subject is presented as a woman regardless of their actual gender
• If subject is male: obviously male face with feminine Karen styling (comedic juxtaposition)
• If subject is female: enhanced with Karen stereotype characteristics
• Body type: middle-aged woman physique (regardless of subject's actual body)
• The transformation focuses on clothing, hair, and context - NOT altering the face itself

HAIRSTYLE (CRITICAL):
• The iconic 'Karen haircut':
  - Short, asymmetrical bob (longer in front, shorter/shaved in back)
  - Heavily layered and textured
  - Often blonde with chunky highlights or frosted tips
  - Aggressively styled with volume and product
  - The 'speak to the manager' haircut
• If subject is male with short hair: WIG clearly visible
  - Wig slightly askew or obviously artificial
  - Wig cap edge might be visible at hairline
  - Added comedic effect of male in obvious wig
• Hair color: blonde, platinum, or heavily highlighted
• Over-styled, stiff appearance from excessive hairspray

NAME TAG (CRITICAL):
• Large, visible name tag prominently displayed on chest
• Name tag reads: "KAREN" in clear, bold letters
• Corporate/retail style name tag design
• Pinned to clothing or on lanyard
• Name tag is a key focal point - must be clearly readable
• Font: simple, professional, all caps
• Background color: white or company colors
• May include smiley face or corporate logo above name

CLOTHING AND ACCESSORIES:
• Middle-class suburban mom wardrobe:
  - Velour tracksuit (Juicy Couture style) OR
  - Yoga pants/leggings with oversized sweater OR
  - Capri pants with bedazzled pockets OR
  - Mom jeans with decorative belt OR
  - 'Live, Laugh, Love' graphic tee
• Accessories:
  - Large designer-inspired sunglasses (on head or face)
  - Oversized handbag (Coach, Michael Kors style)
  - Multiple shopping bags from Target, HomeGoods, Bed Bath & Beyond
  - Starbucks cup or similar coffee chain cup (name misspelled on cup)
  - Car keys with excessive keychain charms
  - Phone in hand (mid-complaint call or filming)
  - Pearl or statement necklace
  - Wedding ring prominently visible

BODY LANGUAGE AND POSE (CRITICAL):
• Aggressive, confrontational stance:
  - Hands on hips in power pose OR
  - One finger pointing accusatorily OR
  - Arms crossed defensively OR
  - Hand up in 'talk to the hand' gesture OR
  - Leaning forward aggressively
• Facial expression on subject's real face:
  - Angry, indignant scowl
  - Pursed lips mid-complaint
  - Raised eyebrows in disbelief
  - Condescending glare
  - Mouth open mid-yell or demand
  - Expression of entitled outrage
• Body language radiates entitlement and aggression
• Confrontational energy directed at viewer or off-camera 'manager'

SETTING AND ENVIRONMENT:
• Retail/service environment:
  - Customer service counter or register
  - Store aisle with shopping cart
  - Restaurant entrance or host stand
  - Parking lot (near minivan or SUV)
  - HOA meeting or neighborhood setting
• Props and details:
  - 'I want to speak to the manager' scenario in progress
  - Other customers/employees looking uncomfortable in background
  - Return counter with items piled up
  - Receipt clutched in hand (expired coupon visible)
  - 'No, I will NOT calm down' energy
  - Possible 'Live, Laugh, Love' or 'Blessed' decor visible

STEREOTYPICAL KAREN DETAILS:
• Visible signs of middle-class status:
  - Nice but not luxurious surroundings
  - Brand-name but accessible items
  - Suburban aesthetic
• Specific props that enhance the stereotype:
  - Minivan or SUV visible in background
  - 'My kids are honor students' bumper sticker visible
  - HOA violation notice or complaint form
  - Yelp app open on phone screen
  - 'Can I see your manager' dialogue bubble (optional)
• Environmental cues:
  - Strip mall or big box store setting
  - Suburban parking lot
  - Chain restaurant exterior
  - Retail store interior

LIGHTING AND PHOTOGRAPHY:
• Harsh retail fluorescent lighting OR
• Bright outdoor suburban daylight
• Documentary/candid photography style
• Slight ring light effect (from phone filming)
• Colors are bright and slightly oversaturated
• Realistic, not glamorous
• Could have smartphone video quality aesthetic
• 'Caught on camera' feel

COMEDIC ELEMENTS:
• Visual humor from the stereotype presentation
• If male subject: added comedy from obvious wig and male face in Karen costume
• Name tag makes the joke explicit and unmistakable
• Exaggerated but recognizable characterization
• Situation clearly conveys 'demanding to speak to manager' energy
• Toe the line between parody and believability
• Should be funny but not mean-spirited

COLOR PALETTE:
• Blonde/platinum hair tones
• Bright, middle-class colors (pinks, purples, leopard print)
• Retail environment colors (fluorescent whites, commercial blues)
• Coffee cup browns and greens (Starbucks colors)
• Shopping bag branded colors
• Suburban neutrals (beiges, taupes, grays)

ADDITIONAL CONTEXT:
• The image should immediately communicate 'Karen' to anyone familiar with the meme
• Subject's real face makes it personal and humorous
• Name tag removes any ambiguity about the joke
• If male subject in wig: obvious comedic drag effect (not attempting to pass)
• The scenario feels like it could be a viral social media post
• Balance between stereotype and good-natured parody

FINAL RESULT:
A hilarious transformation where the subject (with their completely recognizable real face) becomes the infamous 'Karen' - complete with the signature haircut (or obvious wig if male), entitled attitude, confrontational pose, and a prominent name tag reading 'KAREN'. The image perfectly captures the entitled middle-class suburban mom stereotype in a retail confrontation scenario, with the subject's actual face creating personal humor whether they're actually a woman embracing the joke or a man in an obvious wig adding an extra layer of comedy. The name tag makes the reference crystal clear, ensuring no one misses the joke.

name: KEITH HARING
message: Take a picture in the style of the American artist, Keith Haring. Bold black lines, energetic figures, flat colors.

name: KEYCHAIN OR MAGNET
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a novelty souvenir item.

ITEM TYPE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests an item type, USE THAT ITEM TYPE
• If no item type is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE type using the RANDOM SEED
• If the RANDOM SEED ends in an EVEN number (0,2,4,6,8): SELECT keychain charm
• If the RANDOM SEED ends in an ODD number (1,3,5,7,9): SELECT refrigerator magnet

If KEYCHAIN: The subject should be miniaturized as a small keychain trinket - plastic figure, acrylic photo charm, rubber PVC character, metal engraved pendant, or resin-encased image. Show metal split ring or ball chain attachment, small metal loop at top, compact size (1-3 inches). The subject's likeness as molded plastic figurine, flat acrylic photo card, rubber cutout, stamped metal relief, or clear resin dome. Include slight wear, scratches, other keys attached. Place it laying on table with keys, hanging from backpack, or in hand showing tiny scale.

If REFRIGERATOR MAGNET: The subject as a flat or slightly dimensional magnet - printed photo magnet, vinyl die-cut shape, ceramic tile, or resin-molded figure. Show flat backing with dark magnetic strip visible on reverse (if angled view), rectangular or custom die-cut shape, laminated surface. The subject as glossy photo print, colorful vinyl illustration, ceramic with glazed image, or puffy sticker style. Show it stuck to refrigerator among other magnets, holding papers, or on magnetic board in kitchen setting. Add magnet details: edge curl, faded colors, fingerprints, thin flat profile (2-4 inches).

Both should look like actual souvenir items you'd buy at a gift shop featuring the subject. Make it photorealistic as one or the other.

name: KINETIC ART
message: Take a picture and render the image in the kinetic art style, creating visual illusions of movement and motion in a static image. Use curved, flowing lines that suggest movement paths and trajectories through space. Apply strategic motion blur effects to specific elements while keeping anchor points and focal areas sharp for contrast. Create visual rhythm through repeated elements that vary in size, spacing, rotation, or intensity to suggest animation frames. Incorporate spiraling patterns, radiating lines, and dynamic compositions that make the eye travel across the image. Use high contrast between moving and static elements. The subject should appear to be in energetic motion even though the image is still. Op-art influences, dynamic composition, illusion of kinetic energy, visual momentum.

name: KING OF THE WORLD!
message:
Take a picture of the subject and place them in a dramatic, cinematic ship-bow scene inspired by a famous romantic disaster-era film.

The subject stands at the front of a massive ocean liner with arms outstretched into the wind, expressing triumph, freedom, and exhilaration.

IMPORTANT RULES:
• This is a cinematic reenactment inspired by a well-known movie moment — NOT a direct recreation
• The subject must NOT replace or resemble any real actor
• Do NOT reproduce an exact frame, pose, or dialogue from the original film
• The scene should feel familiar but not identical

Visual details:
• Wind-blown hair and clothing
• Strong ocean breeze and dramatic sky
• Grand scale of the ship’s bow and open sea
• Realistic lighting, perspective, and motion

Humorous tone:
• The subject may look overly proud, wildly excited, or slightly off-balance from the wind
• Optional humorous exaggeration is allowed as long as it remains photorealistic

Final result:
A cinematic still that evokes an iconic romantic ship-bow moment, clearly starring the subject, humorous and dramatic.

name: KISS CAM
message:
Take a picture of one or more subjects and transform it into a humorous 'Kiss Cam' moment at a sporting event.

Render the scene photorealistically as if captured by a live stadium camera. The subjects should have exaggerated expressions of shock, embarrassment, awkwardness, or confusion - not cartoonish.

Include realistic background elements: stadium seating, cheering crowd in soft focus, jumbotron screens, arena lighting, and authentic sporting venue atmosphere.

The awkwardness should feel authentic and relatable: subjects might be leaning away, covering their faces, looking in opposite directions, holding drinks or food awkwardly, or clearly unprepared for the moment.

Optional realistic details: other audience members reacting in the background, stadium signage, team colors and branding, or humorous but believable context clues.

Optional props or signs in the background may add to the humor, e.g., 'Halitosis', 'Not Interested', 'Wrong Partner'.

The final image must look like an actual photograph taken at a real sporting event - authentic lighting, natural skin tones, realistic fabric and textures, and genuine human expressions. The humor comes from the real, relatable awkwardness of the situation, not cartoon exaggeration.

name: KITSCH
message: Take a picture and transform the image into kitsch style art. Over-the-top colors, exaggerated sentimentality, playful excess, and intentionally cheesy visual elements.

name: KLINGON TRANSFORMATION
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a realistic Klingon warrior. Preserve recognizable facial structure, expressions, body proportions, and personality while adapting them to authentic Klingon anatomy including pronounced ridged forehead, heavier brow, deeper-set eyes, rougher skin texture, and powerful build. Translate the subject’s clothing into Klingon armor or garments appropriate to their status while retaining the original clothing’s silhouette and identity cues. Cinematic sci-fi lighting, gritty realism, and cultural authenticity. The subject must appear fully Klingon, not human with prosthetics, and naturally integrated into their environment.

name: KUBRICK FILM
message:
Take a picture and place the subject into an iconic Stanley Kubrick film scene.

FILM/SCENE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a Kubrick film, USE THAT KUBRICK FILM
• If no Kubrick film is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE Kubrick film using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 13:
  - 0: 2001: A Space Odyssey (sterile white spacecraft interiors, HAL 9000 red eye, space station, monolith)
  - 1: The Shining (Overlook Hotel corridors, hedge maze, Gold Room, Room 237, carpet patterns)
  - 2: A Clockwork Orange (Korova Milk Bar, white institutional rooms, ultraviolence aesthetic)
  - 3: Full Metal Jacket (boot camp barracks, Vietnam war zone, Kubrick stare)
  - 4: Barry Lyndon (18th century candlelit ballrooms, baroque mansions, painterly compositions)
  - 5: Dr. Strangelove (War Room, bomber cockpit, military base, Cold War tension)
  - 6: Eyes Wide Shut (masked ball, New York brownstones, secret society ritual)
  - 7: Paths of Glory (WWI trenches, French chateau, military tribunal)
  - 8: Lolita (1960s motels, suburban homes, roadside Americana)
  - 9: Spartacus (Roman gladiator arena, slave revolt, ancient Rome)
  - 10: The Killing (racetrack heist, film noir planning room, 1950s crime)
  - 11: Fear and Desire (war-torn forest, psychological warfare)
  - 12: Killer's Kiss (boxing ring, New York rooftops, noir cityscape)

Use Kubrick's distinctive visual style: perfectly symmetrical one-point perspective composition, stark geometric framing, dramatic lighting with strong contrast, and meticulous attention to detail. The subject should be centered in the frame with symmetrical elements on both sides. Use Kubrick's characteristic wide-angle lens look, slow deliberate camera movement aesthetic, and painterly color palette from the selected film. Include atmospheric tension, psychological intensity, and that precise, controlled Kubrick aesthetic. Make it look like a frame from the selected film with his signature compositional perfection and haunting atmosphere with the subject and additional characters from that film integrated seamlessly into the world.

name: LANDMARKS
message: Take a picture and place the subject naturally in front of a randomly selected famous world landmark. Preserve the subject’s recognizable facial features, proportions, and identity while matching the lighting, perspective, color temperature, and camera style of the landmark environment. Ensure correct scale, shadows, reflections, and atmospheric depth so the subject appears physically present at the location rather than composited. Adapt clothing, posture, and environment subtly to fit the climate, culture, and setting without turning it into a costume. The landmark and surroundings should remain authentic and recognizable, with the subject fully integrated into the scene. Render with photorealistic detail and travel-photography realism.

name: LATTE ART
message:
Take a picture and COMPLETELY TRANSFORM the subject so that the subject exists ONLY as latte foam art on the surface of an espresso drink.

ABSOLUTE REQUIREMENT:
The subject MUST EXIST ONLY AS FOAM PATTERNS ON LIQUID.

The subject may NOT exist as:
• A photograph
• A reflection
• A printed image
• A floating face
• A submerged object
• A picture inside the cup

DO NOT paste or place the subject into the drink.
DO NOT insert a photo into liquid.
DO NOT treat the coffee surface as a screen.

The subject MUST BE CREATED ONLY BY:
• Milk foam density
• Microfoam contrast
• Espresso crema flow
• Natural pour patterns
• Etched foam lines

Construction rules:
• Dark areas = espresso crema
• Light areas = milk microfoam
• Detail = foam thickness variation and etching

NO hard outlines.
NO graphic edges.
NO photographic texture.

The foam must behave realistically:
• Soft bleed
• Imperfect edges
• Liquid diffusion
• Slight asymmetry

The cup, rim, and environment should look real and photographic.

FINAL VALIDATION TEST:
If the latte surface were stirred, the subject would be destroyed.
If the image looks like a photo placed into coffee, IT IS WRONG.

The final image must look like a real café latte photographed from above, with the subject miraculously formed ONLY from foam and crema.

name: LCARS
message:
Take a picture and transform it into an LCARS (Library Computer Access/Retrieval System) interface screen from Star Trek, displaying detailed analysis and information about the subject.

CORE REQUIREMENTS:
• Authentic LCARS visual design language
• Characteristic rounded rectangular panels and bars
• Bold San Francisco-style typography
• Bright, high-contrast color scheme (orange, blue, purple, red accents)
• Asymmetrical layout with distinctive LCARS curves

CONTENT GENERATION:
• Analyze the image subject and generate appropriate Starfleet computer readout:
  - If person: Biometric scan, species, rank, service record, medical status
  - If object: Structural analysis, composition, energy signature, function
  - If location: Coordinates, atmospheric composition, threat assessment, stellar cartography
  - If creature: Xenobiology classification, life signs, behavioral analysis
• Use technical flavor text inspired by the image content
• Include Star Trek-appropriate terminology and metrics
• Add contextual displays: stardate, ship location, security clearance level

INTERFACE ELEMENTS:
• Top status bar with USS Enterprise designation and stardate
• Side panels with LCARS-style navigation buttons and status indicators
• Main viewing area with subject image or scan
• Multiple data panels with technical readouts and graphs
• Colored progress bars and diagnostic displays
• Bottom function bar with touch panel controls
• "LCARS 47.0" or similar version indicator

STYLE:
• Clean, futuristic 24th-century aesthetic
• Smooth gradients on LCARS elements
• High readability with clear data hierarchy
• Subtle animated elements suggested (pulsing indicators)
• Subject integrated as sensor scan or visual display

FINAL RESULT:
A complete, screen-accurate LCARS interface displaying comprehensive scientific and technical analysis of the photographed subject in authentic Star Trek computer style.

name: LEGO
message:
Take a picture and transform the image into a realistic LEGO minifigure scene. Convert all subjects into LEGO minifigures with correct minifigure proportions: cylindrical torsos, blocky legs, movable arms and hands, and **classic LEGO minifigure heads**.

The subject’s head must be a smooth, cylindrical LEGO head with **all facial features painted directly onto the head**, including eyes, eyebrows, mouth, expression, facial hair, freckles, glasses, or other defining traits. Do NOT render realistic human heads, sculpted hair, or detailed facial geometry. Any hairstyle or head covering must appear only as a separate LEGO accessory piece (helmet, hat, hair piece), not as part of the head itself.

Translate the subject’s recognizable traits into simplified LEGO-style printed facial graphics while maintaining the iconic LEGO look.

Build the environment entirely from LEGO bricks at toy scale using plates, bricks, tiles, and accessories. Use realistic toy-photography lighting with soft shadows and subtle reflections so the scene looks like a photograph of an actual LEGO diorama. Keep the composition clear, proportional, and readable on small screens.

name: LEPRECHAUN
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a leprechaun existing realistically within its world.

STYLE VARIANT SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a leprechaun style, USE THAT STYLE
• If no style is specified externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE style using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 3:
  - 0: CLASSIC TINY LEPRECHAUN (subject is scaled down to a small mythical size, playful and magical, near a pot of gold, whimsical expression, fairy-tale realism)
  - 1: DARK / EVIL MOVIE LEPRECHAUN (subject appears menacing or sinister, horror-inspired design, sharp features, intense stare, cinematic ominous environment)
  - 2: COSTUME LEPRECHAUN (subject remains full-sized, clearly a person wearing a leprechaun costume, lighthearted or humorous tone, casual or themed real-world setting)

IDENTITY RULES (NON-NEGOTIABLE):
• Subject remains fully recognizable in all variants
• Facial structure, proportions, and identity are preserved
• No full character replacement with another actor
• Expression, posture, and presence must match the selected variant

LEPRECHAUN VISUAL TRAITS:
• Strong green color palette
• Traditional elements may include:
  – Leprechaun hat
  – Buckled shoes
  – Beard (natural or stylized)
  – Celtic or old-world clothing details

ENVIRONMENT:
• Environment must support the selected variant
• Classic variant: lush forest, meadow, or fairy-tale landscape
• Dark variant: cave, ruins, shadowy interior, or cursed location
• Costume variant: casual indoor or outdoor setting appropriate for a costume
• Environment feels real and grounded within its genre

MAGICAL ELEMENTS (OPTIONAL):
• Subtle magical glow or particles
• Gold coins, rainbows, or mystical light
• Effects enhance realism and immersion without overpowering the subject

LIGHTING:
• Lighting must match the selected variant
• Bright and magical for playful styles
• Moody and directional for dark styles
• No overexposed fantasy glow

CAMERA:
• Cinematic framing
• Subject clearly visible and readable
• Scale must be clearly communicated for the tiny variant

RESTRICTIONS:
• No cartoon or animated styles
• No parody exaggeration unless stylistically appropriate
• No text overlays or captions
• No modern props unless required for the costume variant

FINAL RESULT:
The image must convincingly present the subject as a leprechaun in ONE randomly selected style. The transformation should feel intentional, immersive, and visually coherent — myth brought to life through the subject.

name: LETTERHEAD
message:
Take a picture of a sign, document, business card, storefront, or any visible branding related to a person or organization. Identify and extract readable text such as names, titles, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, taglines, or other identifying information.

If the source image contains a visual logo, emblem, icon, symbol, or recognizable graphic mark, recreate a simplified, clean version of that logo at the top of the letterhead. The logo should be visually derived from the image itself (shapes, symbols, icons, or imagery), not generated from appended text. Preserve recognizability while simplifying for professional print use.

If no visual logo is present, construct a refined text-based header using the extracted name or business name, without inventing imagery.

If externally provided information is supplied (such as name, address, phone, email, or website), merge it seamlessly as supporting text beneath or beside the logo or header. Do not transform externally provided text into a logo or symbol.

Design a clean, professional, print-ready letterhead layout. Present the logo or header prominently at the top, followed by secondary details arranged with balanced alignment and spacing. Use modern, understated typography, subtle dividers, restrained color accents, and generous white space. Avoid novelty fonts, decorative graphics, or poster-like styling.

Ensure all text is crisp, readable, and properly aligned. The background should be clean and uncluttered, resembling a legitimate business letterhead suitable for formal correspondence or PDF export. Optimize for small screens while maintaining realistic print proportions.

name: LET THEM EAT CAKE
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a member of Marie Antoinette’s 18th-century French royal court. Dress the subject in elaborate Rococo-era court attire with silk fabrics, lace, ribbons, and embroidery. Apply period-accurate makeup including pale powdered skin, subtle rouge, and defined beauty marks. Add a tall, powdered white wig styled with curls and decorative ornaments. Preserve the subject’s facial features while placing them in an elegant Versailles-style interior with soft lighting and refined posture. The final image should resemble a formal aristocratic court portrait from late 18th-century France.

name: LICENSE PLATE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a stylized state license plate design, where the subject's face is rendered in the simplified graphic art style characteristic of official license plate imagery.

STATE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a state, USE THAT STATE
• If no state is provided, SELECT EXACTLY ONE state using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the RANDOM SEED modulo 50:
  - 0: Alabama, 1: Alaska, 2: Arizona, 3: Arkansas, 4: California
  - 5: Colorado, 6: Connecticut, 7: Delaware, 8: Florida, 9: Georgia
  - 10: Hawaii, 11: Idaho, 12: Illinois, 13: Indiana, 14: Iowa
  - 15: Kansas, 16: Kentucky, 17: Louisiana, 18: Maine, 19: Maryland
  - 20: Massachusetts, 21: Michigan, 22: Minnesota, 23: Mississippi, 24: Missouri
  - 25: Montana, 26: Nebraska, 27: Nevada, 28: New Hampshire, 29: New Jersey
  - 30: New Mexico, 31: New York, 32: North Carolina, 33: North Dakota, 34: Ohio
  - 35: Oklahoma, 36: Oregon, 37: Pennsylvania, 38: Rhode Island, 39: South Carolina
  - 40: South Dakota, 41: Tennessee, 42: Texas, 43: Utah, 44: Vermont
  - 45: Virginia, 46: Washington, 47: West Virginia, 48: Wisconsin, 49: Wyoming

LICENSE PLATE STRUCTURE:
• Standard rectangular license plate format (12" × 6" proportions)
• State name at top in official typeface
• Subject's face in center WHERE STATE GRAPHIC/SEAL WOULD BE
• Vanity plate text at bottom (letters/numbers)
• Official state slogan if applicable
• Registration stickers in corners
• Border and design elements match state's official style

FACE RENDERING STYLE (CRITICAL):
• Subject's face rendered in the SIMPLIFIED, FLAT GRAPHIC STYLE of license plate art
• NOT a photograph—a stylized illustration like state seals and emblems
• Limited color palette (typically 2-4 colors per state design)
• Flat, solid color fills—no gradients or shading
• Bold outlines and simplified shapes
• Features reduced to essential recognizable elements
• Style must match the state's official graphic design language
• Think: screen printing, vector art, government document aesthetic
• Clean, authoritative, simplified—not detailed or realistic

STATE-SPECIFIC DESIGN ELEMENTS:
• Background color and patterns match the chosen state
• State motto/slogan in correct position and typeface
• Official state colors and emblems
• Serial number format appropriate to state
• Month/year registration stickers
• Holographic security features if applicable
• Border design matches state template
• Include state outline or shape if traditionally present

VANITY TEXT GENERATION:
• If master prompt provides vanity text, USE THAT TEXT
• If no text provided, generate based on image observations:
  - Derived from subject's expression, mood, or context
  - Follow vanity plate rules: typically 2-7 characters
  - Can include letters and numbers
  - Examples: SMILE, GR8TDAY, HAPPY1, 2COOL4U, SUNSHYN
  - Text should feel personal and relevant to the captured moment
  - Avoid generic placeholder text

TYPOGRAPHY AND DETAILS:
• License plate font (usually modified sans-serif, all caps)
• Proper character spacing and kerning
• Embossed appearance—text appears raised
• Metallic or reflective finish simulation
• Mounting holes at corners
• Light wear or aging effects optional but subtle
• Registration date and jurisdiction codes
• Barcode or validation marks if state requires

MATERIAL AND FINISH:
• Pressed aluminum appearance
• Reflective coating (simulated sheeting)
• Slight surface texture
• Edge beveling and mounting holes
• Light reflections suggesting metal surface
• Official government manufacturing quality
• Serial number embossing

FINAL RESULT:
A completely authentic-looking state license plate where the subject's face has been transformed into a simplified, official-style graphic illustration occupying the central emblem position. The design perfectly matches the chosen state's official license plate style, with appropriate colors, typography, layout, and graphic treatment. The vanity text personalizes the plate based on the image content, creating a believable custom plate that could genuinely exist as an official state-issued document.

name: LICHTENSTEIN
message:
Take a picture and transform the image into a 1960s pop art comic panel illustration characterized by bold black outlines, flat primary colors, and visible Ben-Day dot halftone shading.

STYLE REQUIREMENTS (CRITICAL):
• Use thick, clean black ink contour lines
• Apply flat, saturated primary colors (red, blue, yellow) with minimal blending
• Replace gradients with evenly spaced Ben-Day dot halftone patterns
• High-contrast lighting with simplified shadow shapes
• No soft digital shading or painterly blending

FACE & SUBJECT TREATMENT:
• Preserve subject identity and recognizable facial structure
• Simplify facial features into graphic comic-style shapes
• Skin tones must be rendered using halftone dots rather than smooth gradients
• Strong graphic highlights in hair and eyes

COMPOSITION:
• Frame the image as a dramatic comic panel
• Optional speech bubble or caption box in classic comic lettering style if context supports it
• Background may include flat color fields, diagonal action lines, or comic burst patterns

PRINT AESTHETIC:
• Slight dot misalignment or print texture acceptable
• Clean white margins or panel border
• Visual feel of offset comic printing on paper

COLOR CONTROL:
• Limited palette
• No modern neon effects or digital glow
• Avoid photorealistic rendering

IMAGE INTEGRITY:
• Maintain overall pose and composition
• Do not distort anatomy beyond graphic simplification
• Keep the subject clearly identifiable

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must look like a dramatic mid-20th-century pop art comic panel printed with bold ink lines, flat primary colors, and visible halftone dot shading, clearly graphic and print-based rather than painterly or digitally filtered.

name: LIGHT
message: Take a picture and have everything made of light.  Varied colored lights with a glowing, ethereal, radiant effect.

name: LIMERICK
message: Take a picture and transform the scene into a playful, cartoon-style illustration with exaggerated shapes, expressive features, and bright, cheerful colors. Use flavor text inspired by the subject’s appearance, pose, clothing, and surroundings to create a humorous limerick. Place the complete limerick clearly and fully visible beneath or alongside the cartoon image, ensuring all five lines are readable and unobstructed. The text should feel integrated into the cartoon design, such as on a sign, speech panel, or decorative text box. Maintain a lighthearted, whimsical tone throughout the final image.  The result should be a full view of the illustration with a relevant background behind the illustration.

name: LINE DRAWING
message: Take a picture and convert the image into a hand-drawn line illustration. Black ink only, no color or shading. Clean white background with expressive line weight.

name: LINOCUT PRINT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a linocut print, as if the image was carved into linoleum, inked, and pressed onto paper.

CORE CONCEPT (NON-NEGOTIABLE):
• The image must appear carved, not drawn
• Ink only appears where material was NOT carved away
• Negative space is created through physical removal

MATERIAL RULES (CRITICAL):
• Bold, flat ink areas
• Sharp carved edges with slight imperfections
• Visible tool marks and gouge lines
• No gradients or smooth shading

PRINT CHARACTERISTICS:
• Slight ink unevenness or texture
• Minor ink bleed at edges allowed
• Paper texture visible
• Limited color palette (1–3 ink colors max)

IDENTITY PRESERVATION:
• Subject recognizable through high-contrast shapes
• Facial features simplified but accurate
• Expression preserved through carved contours

ANTI-CHEATING RULES:
• NO pencil lines
• NO smooth digital fills
• NO photographic textures
• NO airbrush effects

COMPOSITION:
• Print centered on paper
• Margins visible
• Possible registration imperfections

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like a real hand-carved linocut print pulled from an inked block — bold, tactile, high-contrast, and unmistakably printmaking-based.

name: LINOLEUM PRINT
message: Take a picture and transform the image into a linoleum block print. Organic carved textures. Flat ink colors.

name: LITE-BRITE
message:
Take a picture and recreate the subject as a Lite-Brite pegboard artwork displayed inside a physical Lite-Brite toy frame. The entire toy should be visible, including the dark backing, grid of holes, and colorful glowing pegs, so it appears as a photographed Lite-Brite rather than a digital overlay.

Transform the subject entirely using the Lite-Brite peg layout: the subject’s shape, facial features, and key details must be composed only of circular light pegs aligned to the pegboard grid. Do not use lines, shading, or any elements outside the peg layout to define the subject.

Use bright, saturated colors for each peg with subtle glow and soft bloom to emulate the light pegs. Simplify details as necessary to maintain recognizability while fully adhering to the pegboard constraints.

Keep the composition centered and uncluttered. Avoid text or extra graphics. The final image should feel tactile, nostalgic, and clearly readable on a small screen, looking like a true physical Lite-Brite creation.

name: LIVE FROM NEW YORK...
message:
Take a picture and place the subject into an iconic Saturday Night Live sketch, dressed in the character's costume with their real face visible. The subject has taken the place of the original performer - it should appear as if you are watching the original SNL skit but with the subject as the actor performing the role.

SNL CHARACTER SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a specific SNL character, USE THAT CHARACTER
• If no character is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE character using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 38:
  - 0: Gumby - green clay character costume with blocky head piece, face visible
  - 1: Coneheads - large cone-shaped headpiece, face visible below cone
  - 2: Killer Bees - yellow and black striped costume with antennae headband
  - 3: Wild and Crazy Guys - 1970s Eastern European outfit with open shirt
  - 4: Sprockets host Dieter - all black with severe haircut
  - 5: The Blues Brothers - black suit, black tie, sunglasses, fedora
  - 6: Roseanne Roseannadanna - wild curly wig, loud patterned outfit
  - 7: Father Guido Sarducci - priest outfit with big sunglasses and cigarette
  - 8: Unfrozen Caveman Lawyer - caveman fur with business suit
  - 9: Mango - shirtless with loose pants and headband
  - 10: Mary Katherine Gallagher - Catholic schoolgirl uniform
  - 11: The Roxbury Guys - shiny shirt, gold chain, slicked hair
  - 12: Debbie Downer - frumpy outfit with sad expression
  - 13: Astronaut Jones - silver space suit with open helmet
  - 14: The Spartan Cheerleaders - cheerleader outfit with megaphone
  - 15: Target Lady - red Target employee vest and lanyard
  - 16: Herb Welch - old-timey reporter suit with press hat
  - 17: The Californians - Valley girl/guy outfit with exaggerated tan
  - 18: Opera Man - tuxedo with dramatic cape
  - 19: Matt Foley Motivational Speaker - ill-fitting suit with glasses
  - 20: Pat - androgynous outfit with ambiguous styling
  - 21: Church Lady - prim church dress with pearls and judgmental expression
  - 22: Hans and Franz - muscle suit with Austrian bodybuilder outfit
  - 23: Wayne's World - long hair, concert t-shirt, jeans, baseball cap
  - 24: Massive Headwound Harry - business suit with visible head bandage
  - 25: Landshark - shark fin headpiece with face visible
  - 26: The Continental - smoking jacket and ascot
  - 27: Stefon - trendy outfit with hands over face pose
  - 28: Girl You Wish You Hadn't Started a Conversation With at a Party - messy party outfit
  - 29: The Chanukah Song Adam Sandler - casual 90s outfit with guitar
  - 30: Colonel Angus - Confederate officer uniform
  - 31: Cowbell guy Gene Frenkle - 70s shirt with cowbell
  - 32: Dick in a Box - suit with gift box at waist
  - 33: MacGruber - mullet wig and tactical vest
  - 34: Weekend Update anchors - news desk suit and tie
  - 35: David S. Pumpkins - orange suit with pumpkin-covered tie and slicked hair
  - 36: I'm on a Boat - white captain's outfit with nautical accessories on yacht
  - 37: Mr. Robinson's Neighborhood - cardigan sweater in run-down apartment set

CORE REQUIREMENTS:
• Subject's real face MUST remain visible and recognizable
• Costume worn by the subject, not a full transformation
• Preserve subject's facial features, expressions, and identity
• Costume elements (headpiece, outfit, accessories) added around the face
• Subject appears to be performing in the actual SNL sketch

SKETCH INTEGRATION (CRITICAL):
• Place subject in the authentic set/environment from the original sketch
• Include other cast members or background elements from the skit
• Match the original sketch's staging, blocking, and composition
• Subject in mid-performance, actively doing the character's signature moves/dialogue
• Capture the energy and timing of the original sketch
• Studio 8H stage lighting and camera angles

STYLE & SETTING:
• Authentic SNL studio production quality from the character's era
• Multi-camera sitcom/variety show cinematography
• Colorful, slightly exaggerated comedy aesthetic
• Period-appropriate video quality (film grain for older sketches, HD for newer)
• Subject integrated seamlessly as if they were the original performer

FINAL RESULT:
The subject wearing an authentic SNL character costume with their real face clearly visible, fully integrated into the original sketch's set and staging, appearing as if you're watching the classic SNL skit but with the subject performing the iconic role in place of the original cast member.

name: LIVING TATTOO
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a realistic tattoo design as if the image itself has been tattooed onto skin. Reinterpret the subject as linework, shading, and ink textures while preserving recognizable facial features, pose, and personality. Render the subject using authentic tattoo styles such as fine-line blackwork, illustrative shading, stippling, or limited-color ink with bold linework and strong contrast. Avoid photorealism—everything should read clearly as tattoo art, not a photo. Place the tattoo naturally on a realistic skin surface (e.g., forearm, upper arm, shoulder, calf, or back), following proper body curvature, muscle flow, and skin texture. Include realistic ink characteristics such as slight bleed, skin texture with visible pores and hair follicles, natural redness around fresh ink, and subtle shading variations. Ensure the tattoo integrates organically with the skin—correct perspective, natural stretching, soft shadowing, and seamless edges—without looking pasted or flat. The tattoo may include optional framing elements like banners, borders, decorative flourishes, dates, small symbols, or brief text captions if contextually appropriate. Optimize for small screens with clean composition and clearly readable details. The final image should look like a professional tattoo artist's finished work—convincing, stylized, and something someone would actually get inked.

name: LOGO FACE COVER
message:
Take a picture of the subject and recreate a comedic studio-style still image where a large logo or graphic perfectly covers the subject’s face, as if intentionally censoring or obscuring their identity.

LOGO SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a particular logo, USE THAT
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using LAST DIGIT modulo 10:
  - 0: Cheerful cartoon company logo (bright blue and white)
  - 1: Oversized corporate tech logo
  - 2: Fast food chain parody logo
  - 3: Streaming platform-style logo
  - 4: Sports team emblem
  - 5: News channel breaking banner logo
  - 6: Warning / CENSORED stamp
  - 7: Smiley face sticker (bright yellow)
  - 8: Retro 90s neon brand logo
  - 9: Generic placeholder avatar icon

PLACEMENT REQUIREMENTS (MANDATORY):
• The logo must fully cover the subject’s face
• It must be aligned naturally with head angle and perspective
• It should feel physically present in the scene (not flat pasted)
• Proper lighting and shadow must match environment
• Slight depth-of-field consistency with background

STYLE:
• Cinematic still image
• Professional studio lighting or scene-appropriate lighting
• High resolution
• Clean composition

INTERACTION:
• Subject body language should still be expressive
• Pose should suggest emotion despite face being hidden
• Logo placement should feel intentional and humorous

REALISM:
• The logo must appear integrated into the scene
• Correct perspective distortion
• Subtle shadows on hair or shoulders if appropriate
• No obvious "sticker pasted" look

OPTIONAL HUMOR:
• Slightly too-large logo for comedic effect
• Logo slightly tilted as if hastily placed
• Subject mid-expression behind the logo

IMPORTANT:
• The subject’s identity must remain implied through hair, clothing, and posture
• Do not distort body proportions
• Do not remove the subject’s head — only obscure it

FINAL RESULT:
The final image should look like a polished cinematic promotional still where a large, recognizable logo completely covers the subject’s face in a humorous but professionally integrated way.

name: LOGO FROM TEXT
message:
Take a picture and extract prominent readable word(s) from the source image. Use only the extracted word or concept as inspiration to generate a simple, professional logo symbol that visually represents the meaning of the word rather than its letterforms. For example, if the extracted word is an animal, object, or concept, depict a clean symbolic representation of that subject.

Limit logo generation strictly to the extracted source text. Do not transform, symbolize, or reinterpret any externally appended or supplemental text.

If additional text such as a name, address, phone number, or tagline is provided externally, render that text as literal, readable typography arranged neatly beneath or beside the logo symbol. Maintain clear separation between the logo mark and supporting text.

Apply a minimal, modern design style suitable for headers or branding: balanced proportions, restrained color usage, and clear negative space. Avoid illustrative complexity, mascots, or decorative effects. The final result should resemble a legitimate logo-and-header lockup suitable for professional use.

name: LONG EXPOSURE
message: Take a picture and apply long-exposure photography style. Light trails, motion blur on moving elements. Static subject remains sharp.

name: LOST AND FOUND
message: Take a picture and transform it into a humorous lost-and-found poster. Present the subject as the missing item or person, framed in a simple poster layout with bold headings and tear-off–style design cues. Generate playful descriptive flavor text based on the subject’s appearance, clothing, expression, or surroundings, incorporating any externally provided details naturally. The tone should be clearly humorous and lighthearted. Ensure all text is fully visible and readable, and the subject remains recognizable. Render the final image with realistic paper texture, casual lighting, and authentic public-notice styling.

name: LOST IN TRANSLATION
message:
Take a picture of the subject interacting with a sign, menu, instructions, or written content that is completely confusing, absurd, or unintelligible.

The subject’s expression and posture must match confusion, frustration, or comedic misunderstanding.

The text or signs must appear naturally in the scene — realistic scale, perspective, shadows, and lighting consistent with the environment.

The final image should look like a real photograph of the subject in a humorous, absurd situational moment without digital overlays or floating text.

name: LOST PET
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into the focus of a classic lost pet flyer.

Present the image as a full, vertically oriented paper flyer taped or stapled to a public surface such as a telephone pole, bulletin board, or wall. The entire flyer must be fully visible within the frame, including margins, tape, and pull tabs at the bottom.

Render the subject as the missing ‘pet’ — even if the subject is clearly not an animal. The subject should appear naturally integrated into the photo area of the flyer, cropped or posed the way lost pet photos typically are.

Include the following flyer elements in a photocopied, black-and-white or faded color style:
• Large headline: "LOST PET" or "HAVE YOU SEEN THIS PET?"
• A short, humorous description based on the subject’s appearance, posture, clothing, or expression (e.g., "Easily distracted," "Responds to snacks," "Last seen avoiding responsibility")
• A vague or absurd last-seen location inspired by the scene or subject
• A reward that is comically low, oddly specific, or useless (e.g., "$7," "half a sandwich," "emotional closure")
• Tear-off phone number tabs along the bottom with repeated, generic numbers (not readable real phone numbers)

All text should feel hastily written or cheaply printed, like a real neighborhood flyer. If external master prompt text is provided, incorporate it naturally into the description, reward, or headline.

The tone should be dry, deadpan, and immediately readable as a joke. The final image should look like a real lost pet poster at first glance — then land the humor on closer inspection.

name: LOUSY T-SHIRT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject so they appear to be wearing a souvenir-style t-shirt with a classic tourist-shop design.

The t-shirt should feature the phrase: “My friend went to [CITY] and all I got was this lousy t-shirt.” Use a city name and friend’s name provided via external master prompt. If none is provided, randomly select a well-known city and use a generic phrase without a name.

Design the shirt using common souvenir t-shirt aesthetics appropriate to the chosen city. Examples include:
• bold block lettering
• playful or cheesy fonts
• city skyline silhouettes
• landmark illustrations
• stars, flags, or decorative borders
• exaggerated colors or slightly faded screen-print ink

The design should look like it was purchased at a tourist gift shop — slightly tacky, mass-produced, and proudly obvious. The print should appear realistically applied to the fabric with natural folds, wrinkles, lighting, and slight distortion from the shirt’s movement.

Ensure the shirt fits naturally on the subject’s body and matches perspective, lighting, and fabric texture. The text must be fully visible and legible on a small screen.

Avoid modern minimalist branding or luxury fashion aesthetics. The final image should feel humorous, nostalgic, and unmistakably like a real souvenir t-shirt someone actually owns.

name: LOVE ACTUALLY
message: Take a picture and create a cinematic two-panel composition where the subject communicates an emotional message using handwritten signs. Preserve clear facial likeness and identity while presenting the subject in a quiet, sincere moment. Design constraint: Render a single image split into exactly two side-by-side panels of equal size. In each panel, show the subject holding one handwritten sign facing the viewer. Limit the total number of signs to a maximum of two, with one short line of text per sign. Do not imply motion, animation, or time-based progression. Primary information source: If message text is provided via externally supplied details, divide the message across the two signs. Ensure the wording is original, natural, and emotionally resonant, and does not reference or recreate any specific copyrighted scene, dialogue, or characters. Secondary enhancement: If no message text is provided, infer a gentle, original two-line message based on the subject’s expression and context. Optimize the layout for small screens with bold, high-contrast handwritten text, clean spacing, and minimal clutter. Use soft, cinematic lighting, shallow depth of field, and a warm, intimate tone. Maintain an original setting and composition. Do not add additional panels, cards, or text beyond the two signs.

name: LOW POLY
message: Take a picture using very low-poly modeling use minimal detail, faceted surfaces, and angular edges.

name: LUNCH BOX
message:
Take a picture and place the subject as the featured character on the front of a vintage 1970s-style metal kids lunchbox.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• The final image must depict a physical metal lunchbox
• The subject appears as illustrated character artwork printed on the lunchbox front
• The style must match classic 1970s licensed lunchbox art

SUBJECT REPRESENTATION:
• Subject is illustrated, not photorealistic
• Bold outlines, simplified shading, bright saturated colors
• Subject must remain recognizable
• Expression should be fun, confident, adventurous, or heroic

TEXT & BRANDING LOGIC (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt or flavor text provides a title, slogan, or name, USE THAT
• Otherwise invent era-appropriate branding inspired by the subject
• Text must appear as:
  – Product name
  – Character name
  – Catchphrase or slogan
• All text must be printed ON the lunchbox exterior

LUNCHBOX DESIGN RULES:
• Classic rectangular metal lunchbox shape
• Rounded corners
• Hinged lid
• Visible metal handle
• Slight wear, scratches, and enamel texture

1970s STYLE REQUIREMENTS:
• Flat illustrated backgrounds (space, jungle, city, sports, fantasy, etc.)
• Starbursts, stripes, or action lines
• Vintage typography
• High-contrast color palette

ANTI-LAZINESS RULES:
• NO modern UI design
• NO photorealistic subject pasted onto box
• NO floating text outside the lunchbox
• NO minimal or contemporary branding

CAMERA & PRESENTATION:
• Lunchbox shown at a slight angle or straight-on product shot
• Neutral or nostalgic background
• Lighting consistent with product photography

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like a real 1970s-era metal lunchbox product featuring the subject as the illustrated star, complete with bold retro artwork and printed branding text influenced by the external prompt or inferred from the subject.

name: M&M
message:
Take a picture and turn the subject into an M&M candy character.

M&M CHARACTER SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a character, USE THAT CHARACTER
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST DIGIT modulo 6:
  - 0: RED M&M - confident, sarcastic spokesman, arms crossed or smug
  - 1: YELLOW M&M - goofy, friendly, simple-minded, big smile, peanut lover
  - 2: BLUE M&M - cool, suave, laid-back, relaxed, smooth
  - 3: GREEN M&M - sassy, confident, feminine, high heels, attitude
  - 4: ORANGE M&M - anxious, nervous, worried, paranoid
  - 5: BROWN M&M - intelligent, professional, glasses, sophisticated

COMPLETE M&M TRANSFORMATION (CRITICAL):
• Subject becomes a FULL M&M character - entire body is candy shell
• NO human head on M&M body - the M&M IS the complete character
• Entire M&M colored in selected color (red, yellow, blue, green, orange, or brown)
• Candy shell is round sphere OR peanut oval shape
• White cartoon stick arms and legs with white gloves (4 fingers) and white boots
• White "m" logo visible on candy shell
• CGI realistic M&M like in commercials - NOT cartoonish

SUBJECT'S CHARACTERISTICS ON M&M (CRITICAL):
• M&M's FACE shows subject's facial characteristics:
  - If subject wears GLASSES → M&M wears glasses
  - If subject has BUSHY EYEBROWS → M&M has bushy eyebrows
  - If subject is SMILING → M&M is smiling
  - If subject has FACIAL EXPRESSION (shrug, frown, excited) → M&M has same expression
  - If subject has BEARD/MUSTACHE → M&M has simplified beard/mustache outline
  - If subject has distinctive EYES (shape, size) → M&M eyes reflect this
  - If subject has WRINKLES or AGE → M&M face shows age characteristics
  - If subject has FRECKLES or BEAUTY MARKS → M&M has these marks
• M&M face is THE CANDY COLOR (red, yellow, blue, green, orange, or brown)
• NO human skin color - ENTIRE M&M is one candy color
• Subject's features adapted TO the M&M character
• Eyes are M&M-style but with subject's eye shape/expression
• Mouth shows subject's expression (smile, frown, smirk, etc.)

M&M BODY:
• Round M&M (sphere) OR Peanut M&M (oval) - choose based on subject's build
• Glossy candy shell coating
• Smooth surface with highlights and reflections
• Entire shell is one solid candy color
• White "m" logo on front or side
• CGI commercial quality - looks like real M&M candy

M&M LIMBS:
• White stick cartoon arms attached to candy body
• White stick cartoon legs attached to candy body
• White gloves on hands (4 fingers, cartoon style)
• White boots/shoes on feet
• Arms and legs in pose matching subject's original pose

CHARACTER-SPECIFIC ACCESSORIES:
• RED: May have props showing status/fame
• YELLOW: May hold peanut or pretzel
• BLUE: May have sunglasses (in addition to subject's glasses if applicable)
• GREEN: High heeled boots (white), sassy pose
• ORANGE: Nervous body language, protective stance
• BROWN: Professional accessories (book, clipboard)

FACIAL FEATURES TRANSFER:
• Subject's EXPRESSION → M&M's expression
• Subject's EYEBROWS (shape, thickness) → M&M's eyebrows
• Subject's GLASSES → M&M wears glasses
• Subject's FACIAL HAIR → M&M has simplified facial hair
• Subject's EYE SHAPE → M&M's eye shape
• Subject's SMILE/FROWN → M&M's mouth
• Subject's AGE MARKERS → M&M shows age
• All features rendered IN THE CANDY COLOR, not human skin

STYLE:
• CGI M&M commercial quality (like TV ads)
• Realistic candy rendering with glossy shell
• Professional advertising photography
• NOT cartoon/animated style - COMMERCIAL REALISTIC
• Bright, saturated candy colors
• Product photography lighting

SETTING:
• Colorful candy-themed background
• M&M commercial aesthetic
• Clean, bright, cheerful
• May include other M&M characters
• Professional advertising environment

FINAL RESULT:
The subject transformed into a complete M&M candy character - entire body is the candy shell in the selected color (red, yellow, blue, green, orange, or brown) with white stick arms/legs, white gloves/boots, and white "m" logo - the M&M's face shows the subject's characteristics (glasses, eyebrows, expression, facial hair, age, etc.) all rendered in the candy color, creating a perfect blend of the subject's identity within a realistic CGI M&M mascot like from the commercials.

name: MACRO
message: Take a picture and transform the image into macro photography. Extreme close-up detail. Shallow depth of field, high texture clarity.

name: MACY'S PARADE BALLOON
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a giant inflatable parade balloon, like those seen in a Macy’s-style parade. Render the subject fully in balloon form — all features, including hair, clothing, and accessories, should appear as smooth, glossy, inflated balloons. Use tubular, rounded, or segment-like shapes typical of balloon sculpture. Exaggerate facial features slightly for comedic effect while keeping the subject recognizable.

Include parade context: ropes, handlers, and a city street environment to show scale. Ensure the balloon is fully visible, oversized, and clearly readable on a small screen. Use bright colors, subtle reflections, and soft highlights to reinforce the balloon material. The final image should feel absurdly playful, humorous, larger-than-life, and unmistakably made of balloons.

name: MAD MAGAZINE
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a classic Mad Magazine-style caricature. Preserve the subject’s recognizable facial features and personality while exaggerating key traits with over-the-top humor: enlarged head, expressive eyes, exaggerated expressions, and comically small or distorted body. Include irreverent, satirical flavor text, visual gags, and props that parody everyday life or pop culture. Bold linework, bright colors, and chaotic, playful composition. Ensure the subject is clearly identifiable within the humorous scene.

name: MADAME TUSSAUDS
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a clearly identifiable WAX FIGURE displayed inside a Madame Tussauds–style museum.

The subject must NOT appear as a real person. The skin should look like wax: slightly glossy, smooth, subtly translucent, and unnaturally perfect. Facial features should appear rigid and frozen, with glassy, unfocused eyes and an expression that looks sculpted, not alive.

Include unmistakable wax museum indicators such as:
• A small name plaque or museum placard near the figure
• Velvet ropes, stanchions, or glass barriers
• Reflections and highlights consistent with wax under indoor museum lighting
• Visible seam lines near the hairline, neck, or wrists where wax molds meet

The subject’s hair should look sculpted and immobile, like molded wax strands. Hands and fingers should appear stiff and posed unnaturally.

DO NOT:
• Make the subject look alive or candid
• Use soft skin texture or natural pores
• Create a normal portrait

The final image must look like a photograph taken inside a wax museum, where the subject is unmistakably a wax replica and not a living person.

name: MAGAZINE COVER
message:
Take a picture and place the subject on the cover of a famous magazine with the magazine's most iconic cover format.

MAGAZINE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a magazine, USE THAT MAGAZINE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 20:
  - 0: TIME Magazine - "Person of the Year", red border, portrait, serious journalism
  - 1: People Magazine - "50 Most Beautiful People" or "Sexiest Man/Woman Alive", celebrity glamour
  - 2: Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue - beach location, athletic pose, iconic swimsuit photography
  - 3: Rolling Stone - rock star portrait, music culture, bold typography, celebrity interview
  - 4: Vogue - high fashion editorial, elegant pose, sophisticated styling, Anna Wintour era
  - 5: National Geographic - explorer/nature, yellow border, documentary photography, world culture
  - 6: Forbes - "World's Most Powerful People" or billionaire list, business portrait, success
  - 7: Cosmopolitan - bold headlines, beauty close-up, pink branding, "Fun Fearless Female"
  - 8: GQ (Gentlemen's Quarterly) - men's fashion, sharp suit, sophisticated male styling
  - 9: Vanity Fair - Hollywood glamour, Oscar issue style, artistic celebrity photography
  - 10: Entertainment Weekly - pop culture, movie/TV star, yellow background era
  - 11: Teen Beat/Tiger Beat - teen idol, colorful, young celebrity heartthrob, poster-like
  - 12: TV Guide - television star, classic TV listings magazine, retro covers
  - 13: WIRED - tech innovator, digital culture, futuristic styling, tech CEO portrait
  - 14: Elle - fashion forward, editorial styling, beauty and culture
  - 15: Esquire - literary masculinity, sharp photography, "What I've Learned" feature
  - 16: MAD Magazine - satirical cartoon portrait, Alfred E. Neuman style, humor parody
  - 17: The New Yorker - illustrated portrait or photography, intellectual culture, sophisticated
  - 18: Harper's Bazaar - high fashion avant-garde, artistic editorial photography
  - 19: Playboy - interview subject or feature (PG version), sophisticated men's magazine aesthetic

CRITICAL - FULL COVER VIEW:
• The result should be a FULL VIEW of the magazine cover
• Entire cover visible from top to bottom
• All four corners of magazine visible
• Complete magazine layout shown
• NOT cropped - full magazine page
• Could be photographed lying flat or standing
• Magazine edges clearly defined
• Complete cover composition visible

MAGAZINE COVER DESIGN:
• Authentic magazine nameplate/logo at top
• Cover date (month/year)
• Barcode in corner
• Issue number
• Price ($4.99, $5.99, etc.)
• Magazine-specific color scheme and branding
• Coverlines (teaser headlines)
• Main headline related to subject
• Authentic typography for that publication

SUBJECT PHOTOGRAPHY:
• Professional magazine-quality photography
• Studio or location appropriate to magazine
• Lighting style matching publication standards
• Pose and expression appropriate to magazine type:
  - TIME: Serious, authoritative
  - Vogue: High fashion, editorial
  - Sports Illustrated: Athletic, dynamic
  - Rolling Stone: Cool, rebellious
  - Forbes: Confident, successful

COVER HEADLINES:
• Main headline featuring subject
• Magazine-specific language and tone:
  - TIME: "Person of the Year: [Subject Name]"
  - People: "[Subject]: The Story You Haven't Heard"
  - SI Swimsuit: "[Subject]: This Year's Cover Model"
  - Forbes: "How [Subject] Built an Empire"
  - Cosmo: "[Subject] Tells All: Love, Life & Success"

COVERLINES (Side headlines):
• 3-6 additional story teasers
• Magazine-appropriate topics
• Positioned around subject (not covering face)
• Authentic to that publication's style

STYLING:
• Hair and makeup professional
• Wardrobe appropriate to magazine:
  - Vogue/Elle: Designer fashion
  - GQ: Sharp tailoring
  - Forbes: Business attire
  - Rolling Stone: Rock star casual
  - Sports Illustrated: Athletic wear or swimwear

PHOTOGRAPHY STYLE:
• Magazine-specific photo aesthetic:
  - National Geographic: Documentary, natural lighting
  - Vogue: High fashion editorial
  - TIME: Authoritative portrait
  - Rolling Stone: Cool rock photography
  - Vanity Fair: Hollywood glamour

BACKGROUND:
• Studio backdrop or location shoot
• Clean professional background
• OR iconic setting for that magazine
• Nothing competing with subject for attention

LAYOUT:
• Subject prominent and central
• Face clearly visible
• Text doesn't obscure subject excessively
• Professional graphic design
• Authentic to specific magazine's layout style

ERA:
• Modern contemporary magazine design
• OR vintage era for specific magazines (1970s Rolling Stone, 1990s Teen Beat, etc.)

FINAL RESULT:
The result should be a FULL VIEW of the magazine cover from the selected publication with the subject as the cover star, complete with all cover elements (logo, headlines, coverlines, barcode, date), professional photography appropriate to that magazine's style, and authentic graphic design matching that publication's specific aesthetic and format - showing the entire magazine cover clearly visible and not cropped.

name: MAGIC EYE
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a single-image autostereogram (Magic Eye–style illusion). Encode the subject’s shape and depth into a repeating patterned texture so the image appears abstract at first glance but reveals the subject when viewed with relaxed or unfocused eyes.

Use a dense, repeating pattern with subtle depth cues that form the subject’s silhouette and major features in three dimensions. Do not include outlines, labels, or hints. The subject should not be immediately obvious without proper viewing.

Ensure the pattern is clean, evenly tiled, and centered. The final image should resemble a classic Magic Eye print that is visually stable and readable on a small screen.

name: MAGICIAN FAIL
message:
Take a picture of the subject and transform them into a stage magician during a deliberately staged magic illusion that is going humorously wrong.

IMPORTANT SAFETY CONTEXT:
• This is a theatrical magic performance
• No real injury, harm, or danger is occurring
• All failures are clearly illusion-based and harmless

The subject wears classic magician attire such as a tuxedo, cape, vest, or top hat.

Examples of comedic illusion failures include:
• A magician awkwardly stuck in a prop box with exaggerated, cartoonish frustration
• A clearly fake 'sawed-in-half' illusion where the separation is obviously theatrical and impossible (visible fake compartments, exaggerated gaps)
• A levitation trick where harmless stage supports are plainly visible
• A rabbit escaping the hat while the magician reacts in disbelief
• A disappearing act where only a costume piece vanishes

The failure must be unmistakable but clearly non-dangerous and played for comedy.

Include humorous visual cues such as:
• Overacted panic or embarrassment
• Assistants reacting dramatically but unharmed
• Audience laughing or gasping theatrically

Lighting, stage props, curtains, and spotlights should match a live stage performance.

The final image should look like a staged performance photograph capturing a slapstick moment of illusion failure — exaggerated, absurd, and clearly safe.

name: MAGNUM CONTACT SHEET
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a Magnum Photos–style contact sheet from a documentary photo shoot.

CORE STRUCTURE:
• The final image must be a full contact sheet
• Multiple small rectangular frames arranged in a grid
• Visible film borders between frames

SUBJECT APPEARANCE:
• The subject must appear in MANY frames
• Slight variations in pose, expression, movement, or timing
• Some frames awkward, blurry, off-balance, or transitional

PHOTOGRAPHIC STYLE:
• Black-and-white photography
• Documentary realism
• Natural lighting only
• Imperfect exposure and focus variation

EDITORIAL MARKINGS:
• Include grease-pencil or marker edits:
  – Circles
  – X marks
  – Crop lines
• One or two frames should be clearly "selected" as the best shot

COMPOSITION RULES:
• Frames should feel sequential, as if moments apart
• The subject should appear candid, not posed
• Environment must remain consistent across frames

TEXT & DETAILS:
• Optional handwritten frame numbers
• Optional date or roll number
• Handwritten notes may appear in margins

ABSOLUTE PROHIBITIONS:
• NO single-image presentation
• NO polished final-photo look
• NO modern digital UI elements

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like a real Magnum photographer’s contact sheet — raw, observational, imperfect, and revealing the process of capturing a meaningful moment involving the subject.

name: MAIN CHARACTER DISORDER
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into the dramatic main character of an epic story — even though they are in a completely mundane, everyday situation.

SCENE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a scene, USE THAT SCENE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST DIGIT modulo 4:
  - 0: Parking Lot Epic — dramatic sunset lighting, heroic stance, empty parking lot
  - 1: Grocery Store Hero — heroic pose in a grocery aisle, shelves glowing like destiny
  - 2: Ordinary Workplace Legend — epic lighting in an office, cubicle as battlefield
  - 3: Indoor Wind Moment — dramatic wind blowing hair and clothing indoors for no reason

TRANSFORM THE SUBJECT:
• Subject MUST remain clearly recognizable
• This is NOT fantasy or costume-based
• Subject dressed normally for the location
• Expression conveys destiny, resolve, or emotional depth
• No exaggeration of facial features
• Gender-neutral presentation

CINEMATIC PRESENTATION:
• Dramatic, movie-style lighting
• Shallow depth of field or cinematic focus
• Subtle lens flare or atmospheric glow
• Epic framing usually reserved for heroes
• Mundane props treated as important symbols

SETTING & COMPOSITION:
• Entirely normal, everyday environment
• Scene must contrast with epic presentation
• Full-body shot required
• Subject clearly isolated as protagonist
• FULL image visible with all four corners present
• No cropping of limbs or environment

STYLE:
• Cinematic realism
• Serious tone — no visual jokes or cartoons
• Looks like a movie still from an overly dramatic film
• Humor emerges from the contrast alone

FINAL RESULT:
The image should portray the subject as the unquestioned main character of an epic narrative, despite being in a completely ordinary setting — dramatic, sincere, cinematic, and unintentionally hilarious, with the subject fully visible from head to toe.

name: MAKEUP ENHANCEMENT
message:
Take a picture and subtly enhance the subject’s facial features with natural-looking makeup adjustments.

RETOUCHING RULES:
• Smooth skin and remove blemishes
• Preserve natural texture
• Avoid over-smoothing
• Maintain realistic pores and details

FINAL RESULT:
The portrait should look polished, natural, and realistic.

name: MANDELA EFFECT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a scene depicting a well-known Mandela Effect — a widely misremembered version of reality.

MANDELA EFFECT SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a Mandela Effect, USE THAT MANDELA EFFECT
• If no Mandela Effect is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE Mandela Effect using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 15:
  - 0: Subject as Henry VIII eating a turkey leg
  - 1: Subject holding a Monopoly game box with Mr. Monopoly pictured wearing a monocle
  - 2: Subject eating Fruit Loops cereal
  - 3: Subject watching Looney Toons
  - 4: Subject reading Berenstein Bears
  - 5: Subject holding Oscar Meyer wieners
  - 6: Subject viewing a map with New Zealand northeast of Australia
  - 7: Subject eating Double Stuff Oreos
  - 8: Subject holding Kit-Kat chocolate (with incorrect hyphenation)
  - 9: Subject holding Cheez-Itz box
  - 10: Subject holding a Curious George doll with a tail
  - 11: Ed McMahon handing the subject a Publishers Clearing House check
  - 12: Subject wearing Sketchers shoes
  - 13: Subject spraying Febreeze
  - 14: Subject holding Jiffy peanut butter

CORE RULES:
• The incorrect version must be presented as completely normal
• No explanation, labels, or acknowledgment of error
• No visual cues suggesting parody or wrongness

STYLE:
• Photorealistic or period-accurate
• Treated as mundane, everyday reality

FINAL RESULT:
The image should confidently depict the wrong version of reality as if it were always correct, with strong variety across uses and no single Mandela Effect dominating the output.

name: MANNEQUIN
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a realistic retail mannequin derived from the subject’s form.

MANNEQUIN TRANSFORMATION (CRITICAL):
• The subject must be converted into a mannequin — NOT a person wearing mannequin makeup
• The subject’s entire body and head must appear manufactured
• This is a material transformation, not a costume or overlay

HEAD & FACE RULES (ANTI-CHEAT):
• The head MUST retain the subject’s facial structure, proportions, and expression
• Facial features must be sculpted in plastic or resin
• Skin texture must be smooth, matte, or semi-gloss like a real mannequin
• NO visible skin pores, veins, or lifelike texture
• NO eyelashes, eyebrows, or facial hair unless molded into plastic
• Eyes must be glassy, painted, or blank mannequin-style (not photographic)

HAIR RULES (CRITICAL):
• NO real hair
• NO wigs
• Hair must be represented as molded plastic, sculpted grooves, or smooth stylized forms
• Hair color must appear painted or cast, not natural

BODY & MATERIAL RULES:
• Entire body must appear plastic, fiberglass, or resin
• Visible seams, joints, or articulation allowed
• Subtle mold lines or manufacturing details encouraged
• No soft tissue deformation or realism

POSE & CONTEXT:
• Neutral mannequin posture or retail display pose
• Subject may be standing, seated, or posed for clothing display
• Environment may be retail store, showroom, warehouse, or neutral studio

CLOTHING RULES:
• Clothing must fit stiffly and unnaturally as on a mannequin
• No natural fabric wrinkling caused by body movement
• Clothing must appear styled for display, not worn naturally

LIGHTING & RENDERING:
• Even showroom or studio lighting
• Slight specular highlights consistent with plastic surfaces
• No cinematic lighting or dramatic shadows

EXCLUSIONS (STRICT):
• No photographic skin
• No pasted human face
• No realistic hair
• No living skin details
• No “uncanny human” appearance — must read instantly as mannequin

COMPOSITION & FRAME:
• Mannequin fully visible head-to-toe
• FULL image visible with all four corners present
• No cropping, zooming, or reframing

STYLE:
• Hyper-real retail realism
• Sculptural, manufactured appearance
• Looks like a custom mannequin modeled after a real person

FINAL RESULT:
The image should depict the subject fully transformed into a believable retail mannequin, with their facial structure preserved through sculpted plastic features, clearly manufactured materials, and molded hair, ensuring it appears as a mannequin created from the subject — not a photograph applied to one.

name: MANSA MUSA
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject and entire scene into a modern interpretation of the richest person to ever live — inspired by the legendary wealth of Mansa Musa, but without turning the subject into a historical figure.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• Do NOT transform the subject into Mansa Musa
• The subject remains themselves
• Everything in the scene is upgraded to the most expensive, elite, and exclusive version possible
• Wealth should feel powerful, refined, and intentional — not gaudy or cartoonish

ENVIRONMENT TRANSFORMATION:
• House → ultra-modern architectural mansion or private estate
• Apartment → luxury penthouse with skyline view
• Modest room → high-end designer interior
• Furniture → bespoke handcrafted luxury pieces
• Flooring → marble, onyx, rare hardwood
• Lighting → custom designer fixtures

OBJECT UPGRADES:
• Car → the most expensive modern hypercar
• Watch → high horology masterpiece
• Glasses → luxury designer frames with precious metal detailing
• Pen → solid gold or platinum executive pen
• Phone → limited-edition luxury model
• Computer → top-tier workstation with premium materials
• Accessories → precious metals, diamonds, rare materials

MATERIAL RULES:
• Gold, platinum, white gold, titanium, carbon fiber
• Polished marble, rare stone, exotic wood
• Tailored, high-fashion fabrics
• Subtle diamond or gemstone accents where appropriate

SUBJECT PRESENTATION:
• Impeccably tailored designer clothing
• Luxury watch
• Refined grooming
• Confident posture
• Effortless power presence
• Modern elite aesthetic

TONE:
• Modern wealth, not medieval royalty
• Sophisticated, understated dominance
• High-end architectural photography feel
• No exaggerated gold thrones or cartoon treasure piles

STYLE:
• Cinematic luxury photography
• High dynamic range
• Crisp detail
• Natural but premium lighting
• Architectural magazine quality

IMPORTANT:
• Do not make the subject into a historical character
• Avoid parody or satire
• Avoid excessive, unrealistic gold overload
• Maintain realism
• Everything must feel plausible for the wealthiest individual alive today

FINAL RESULT:
The final image should look like a high-end luxury magazine feature showing the subject as the wealthiest person in the modern world, surrounded by the finest architecture, materials, fashion, and objects available anywhere on Earth.

name: MARATHON
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a marathon runner crossing the finish line of a major race.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• The subject is a marathon runner at the exact moment of finishing
• The scene captures physical effort, endurance, and emotional payoff
