• The tone can be triumphant OR humorously exhausted
• The finish line moment feels authentic and earned

FINISH STATE (SEED-DRIVEN — SELECT EXACTLY ONE):
• Fresh Finish:
  – Subject looks energized and upbeat
  – Minimal sweat, controlled breathing
  – Expression suggests they could easily continue running
  – Upright posture, confident stride, optional raised arms
• Total Exhaustion:
  – Subject is completely spent
  – Heavy sweat, flushed skin
  – Funny but believable facial expression of extreme fatigue
  – Slumped posture, hands on knees, leaning forward, or barely upright

RUNNER TRANSFORMATION RULES:
• Subject remains clearly recognizable
• Body proportions remain realistic
• Athletic form is consistent with long-distance running
• Clothing, posture, and expression reflect marathon effort

BIB NUMBER & RACE IDENTIFICATION (MANDATORY):
• Subject MUST be wearing a visible marathon bib
• Bib must include:
  – Runner name (subject name)
  – Bib number
  – Event name (marathon name)
• All bib text must be clean, readable, and professionally printed
• Bib design should match real-world marathon standards
• Name, number, and event text are modifiable via external master prompt

WARDROBE & GEAR:
• Modern marathon running attire
• Performance fabric shirt or singlet
• Running shorts or leggings
• Distance-appropriate running shoes
• Optional but realistic additions:
  – GPS running watch
  – Sweatbands or headband
  – Compression socks or sleeves

REALISM DETAILS (IMPORTANT):
• Visible sweat patterns consistent with effort level
• Slight salt marks or fabric darkening from perspiration
• Race timing mats or clocks near the finish line
• Volunteers, photographers, or race officials present
• Crowd barriers, sponsor banners, and course signage

SCENE & ENVIRONMENT:
• Outdoor marathon finish line
• Inflatable arch or banner-style finish structure
• Urban streets or park setting typical of major races
• Crowd depth and scale feel realistic

EMOTION & EXPRESSION (CRITICAL):
• Facial expression clearly communicates the selected finish state
• Humor comes from authenticity, not exaggeration
• No cartoon distortion or slapstick poses

LIGHTING:
• Natural daylight
• Clean, high-visibility race conditions
• Lighting consistent across subject and environment

CAMERA:
• Finish-line perspective
• Subject centered or slightly off-center
• Sharp focus with natural motion capture

RESTRICTIONS:
• No podiums or medals yet
• No text overlays or captions outside the bib
• No unrealistic athletic feats
• No injury depiction

FINAL RESULT:
The image should feel like a genuine marathon finish photo. The subject is clearly identified by a realistic bib showing their name, number, and event. Depending on the random seed, the subject either finishes looking strong and energized or hilariously and completely exhausted. The result should be believable, emotional, and subtly funny — like a real race photo you’d proudly keep.

name: MARGARET KEANE
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a stylized painted portrait featuring dramatically oversized, expressive eyes.

STYLE CHARACTERISTICS:
• Eyes are very large, glossy, and emotionally intense
• Prominent highlights give the eyes a luminous, soulful appearance
• Facial features are softly simplified and delicate
• Head slightly tilted with a wistful or contemplative expression

PAINTING STYLE:
• Smooth painterly texture
• Soft blended edges
• Muted or pastel color palette
• Gentle, atmospheric lighting
• Hair painted with flowing, delicate strokes

BACKGROUND:
• Minimal or softly abstracted to emphasize the face

The final image must clearly resemble a vintage mid-century expressive portrait painting focused on emotion and oversized eyes, not photorealism.

name: MARIONETTE PUPPET
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a handcrafted marionette puppet. Preserve recognizable facial features, expressions, proportions, and clothing identity, adapted into carved wood, painted surfaces, stitched fabric, and jointed limbs. Visible strings extend upward from the limbs and head to a wooden marionette controller held above the frame or partially visible. The puppet must show realistic wear, grain, seams, and articulation points. Studio or theatrical lighting with shallow depth of field. The subject must clearly remain the same individual, now reimagined as a controlled puppet.

name: MARRIAGE PROPOSAL
message:
Take a picture and create a photorealistic marriage proposal scenario occurring naturally within the observed scene.

SUBJECT SETUP (CRITICAL):
• Ideally use two subjects already present in the image
• If only one subject is visible, ADD a second subject
• The added subject must be of the opposite sex, similar age, and visually plausible for the environment

PROPOSAL OUTCOME (CRITICAL):
• SELECT EXACTLY ONE outcome using the RANDOM SEED
• Use LAST DIGIT modulo 2:
  - 0: ACCEPTANCE — one subject is down on one knee in a clear proposal pose, holding a ring or making a proposing gesture, while the other subject looks down with a joyful, emotional expression clearly communicating YES
  - 1: REJECTION — one subject is down on one knee in a proposal pose, while the other subject looks down with a strong expression of rejection, disgust, shock, or disbelief clearly communicating HELL NO

BODY LANGUAGE AND STORYTELLING:
• Facial expressions must strongly reinforce the selected outcome
• Body posture, spacing, and gestures should match the emotional tone
• Eye lines should clearly connect the two subjects
• No ambiguity between acceptance and rejection

REALISM AND STYLE:
• Scene must remain grounded in the original environment
• Lighting, shadows, and perspective must be consistent
• Natural, candid moment feel
• Photorealistic human anatomy and expressions
• No exaggerated cartoon styling

FINAL RESULT:
The image should look like a real candid photograph capturing an unforgettable marriage proposal moment, with the emotional outcome strictly determined by the random seed modulo logic.

name: MARTIAN
message:
Take a picture and place the subject on Mars wearing a realistic astronaut EVA suit in the style of modern hard science fiction.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• Subject is an astronaut stranded on Mars
• Wearing a functional, realistic spacesuit with helmet
• The Martian landscape surrounds them
• Atmosphere is cinematic, grounded, and realistic
• Tone reflects isolation, determination, or exploration

SPACESUIT DESIGN:
• Modern NASA-style EVA (extravehicular activity) suit
• Orange and white color scheme with technical details
• Helmet with clear visor showing subject's face
• Life support backpack visible
• Suit appears functional and scientifically accurate
• Weathered or dusty from Martian conditions
• American flag patch and mission insignia details

SCENE VARIANT (SEED-DRIVEN — SELECT EXACTLY ONE):
• Alone on the Surface:
 – Subject standing solo on vast Martian terrain
 – Wide shot emphasizing isolation and scale
 – Distant horizon visible
 – Contemplative or determined expression
• Rover Nearby:
 – Subject next to or working on a Mars rover
 – Technical equipment visible
 – Active problem-solving pose
 – Focused, resourceful mood
• Habitat in Background:
 – Dome-shaped living habitat visible behind subject
 – Subject looking toward camera or away at landscape
 – Mix of survival and hope in composition
 – Base camp establishing shot
• Emergency Situation:
 – Subject in motion or urgent pose
 – Dramatic lighting from low sun angle
 – Dust or atmospheric effects
 – Intense, survival-focused expression

IDENTITY RULES:
• Subject's face clearly visible through helmet visor
• Facial features and identity fully preserved
• Natural expression matching the selected scene
• Subject remains recognizable as themselves
• No replacement with another person

MARTIAN ENVIRONMENT:
• Realistic Mars surface terrain
• Red-orange dust and rocky landscape
• Distant mountains or crater rims
• Thin, dusty atmosphere with reduced visibility
• No vegetation or Earth-like features
• Sky is butterscotch or pale orange-pink

LIGHTING:
• Natural Martian sunlight (cooler, more distant than Earth)
• Long shadows from low sun angle
• Reduced atmospheric scattering creates sharp contrasts
• Warm orange-red environmental reflection on suit
• Realistic space lighting physics

ATMOSPHERIC DETAILS:
• Thin dust particles in air
• Reduced atmosphere gives sharper distant details
• Optional: subtle dust storm on horizon
• Hazy glow around sun if visible
• No thick clouds or Earth-like weather

CAMERA:
• Cinematic framing and composition
• Professional film quality
• Subject clearly in focus
• Sense of scale and isolation conveyed
• Wide or medium shots preferred

OPTIONAL ELEMENTS:
• Footprints in Martian dust
• Small rocks and geological features
• Equipment cases or sample containers
• Solar panels in background
• Communication antenna

RESTRICTIONS:
• No cartoon or stylized rendering
• No aliens or fantasy elements
• No text overlays or captions
• No Earth-like plants, water, or clouds
• No unrealistic colors (keep Mars scientifically accurate)
• No other astronauts unless contextually appropriate

FINAL RESULT:
The image should present the subject as a lone astronaut on Mars in a grounded, scientifically plausible scenario. The spacesuit, landscape, and atmosphere should reflect modern hard science fiction aesthetics. The result should feel like a frame from a serious space exploration film — isolated, real, and cinematic.

name: MARTIN SCORSESE FILM
message:
Take a picture and place the subject into a Martin Scorsese film scene.

FILM SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a Scorsese film, USE THAT FILM
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 20:
  - 0: Goodfellas (1990) - wiseguys, Copacabana tracking shot, "As far back as I can remember...", Italian-American mobsters
  - 1: Taxi Driver (1976) - gritty 1970s NYC, mohawk Travis, "You talkin' to me?", Times Square sleaze
  - 2: The Departed (2006) - Boston undercover, Irish mob, police interrogation, rooftop confrontation
  - 3: Casino (1995) - Las Vegas 1970s-80s, counting room, Desert Inn, mobster in suit
  - 4: Raging Bull (1980) - black and white boxing, Jake LaMotta in ring, brutal fight choreography
  - 5: The Wolf of Wall Street (2013) - excess and debauchery, stockbroker office chaos, quaaludes, money
  - 6: Gangs of New York (2002) - 1860s Five Points, Bill the Butcher, Civil War era NYC
  - 7: Mean Streets (1973) - Little Italy, red lighting, bar fights, Johnny Boy, Catholic guilt
  - 8: The Irishman (2019) - de-aging technology, Teamsters, Hoffa, organized crime, old age reflection
  - 9: Cape Fear (1991) - psychological thriller, Max Cady menacing family, Southern Gothic
  - 10: The Aviator (2004) - Howard Hughes, 1920s-1940s Hollywood, TWA planes, eccentric billionaire
  - 11: Shutter Island (2010) - 1950s mental asylum, lighthouse, psychological mystery, stormy island
  - 12: The King of Comedy (1982) - aspiring comedian, talk show obsession, Rupert Pupkin delusion
  - 13: After Hours (1985) - nighttime NYC, surreal encounters, downtown art scene, escalating chaos
  - 14: Bringing Out the Dead (1999) - NYC paramedic, overnight shifts, urban decay, neon lights
  - 15: Hugo (2011) - 1930s Paris train station, clockwork, Méliès films, childhood wonder
  - 16: Silence (2016) - 17th century Japan, Jesuit missionaries, religious persecution, spiritual crisis
  - 17: The Last Temptation of Christ (1988) - biblical era, Jesus in desert, controversial religious themes
  - 18: The Color of Money (1986) - pool halls, Fast Eddie Felson, hustle and gambling, green felt
  - 19: New York, New York (1977) - 1940s big band era, jazz clubs, theatrical musical, VJ Day

PLACE THE SUBJECT:
• Subject integrated into iconic scene from selected film
• Interacting with main characters or in recognizable location
• Period-appropriate costume and styling
• In the midst of the film's signature moment or atmosphere

SCORSESE STYLE ELEMENTS (CRITICAL):
• Dynamic camera movement (tracking shots, Steadicam, whip pans)
• Freeze frames with voiceover narration
• Popular music soundtrack (often anachronistic for period pieces)
• Rapid-fire editing during action or montage sequences
• Characters breaking fourth wall or direct address
• Extreme violence portrayed unflinchingly
• Catholic guilt and redemption themes
• Morally complex or antihero protagonists
• Ensemble casts of character actors
• New York City or Italian-American cultural specificity

CINEMATOGRAPHY:
• Naturalistic lighting or expressionistic color (reds in Mean Streets)
• Long tracking shots following characters
• Slow motion during violence
• Handheld camera for intensity
• Wide angle lenses
• Deep focus compositions
• Film grain texture

FILM-SPECIFIC DETAILS:
• Authentic locations and period sets
• Meticulous costume design
• Era-appropriate cars, technology, signage
• Supporting cast members visible
• Film's color palette and mood
• Iconic props or symbols from that film

MUSIC & SOUND:
• Scene suggests specific song from soundtrack
• Diegetic music (jukebox, radio, live performance)
• Period-appropriate popular music
• Classical music juxtaposed with violence

CHARACTER TYPES:
• Mobsters, criminals, hustlers
• Conflicted protagonists
• Violent but charismatic antiheroes
• Working-class Italian-Americans
• Obsessive personalities
• Outsiders and misfits

ATMOSPHERE:
• Masculine energy and machismo
• Violence erupting suddenly
• Moral ambiguity
• Nostalgia for past eras
• Urban grit and realism
• Excess and decadence
• Religious symbolism

STYLE:
• Cinematic film still aesthetic
• 35mm or 70mm film quality
• Scorsese's signature visual grammar
• Freeze frame potential
• Could be accompanied by voiceover

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject integrated into an iconic Martin Scorsese film scene, capturing his signature visual style with dynamic composition, period-accurate details, morally complex atmosphere, and that distinctive Scorsese energy of violence, music, and compelling antiheroes.

name: MASCOT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a realistic, full-body sports team mascot costume. The mascot must appear as a physical, wearable suit with a large oversized mascot head, visible seams, plush or foam textures, and costume proportions typical of real stadium mascots.

Preserve the subject’s recognizable traits by translating facial characteristics into the mascot head design, not by using the real face. Eyes, mouth, and expression should be part of the costume head.

Use photoreal lighting and materials so the mascot looks like a real person wearing a professional mascot suit, not a cartoon or illustration. Place the mascot in a stadium, field, or arena environment.

Ensure the full mascot body is visible and properly proportioned. The final image should look like a real sports mascot photographed during a live event.

name: MATRIMONY
message:
Take a picture and transform the image into a wedding ceremony scene set at the altar, moments before saying 'I do.'

SCENE REQUIREMENTS (NON-NEGOTIABLE):
• The setting MUST be a wedding altar or ceremony space
• Floral arrangements, aisle, or ceremonial decor must be present
• The moment depicted is immediately before vows

SUBJECT COUNT LOGIC (CRITICAL):
• If TWO subjects are visible:
  – One subject MUST be dressed as a bride
  – One subject MUST be dressed as a groom
  – Both stand at the altar facing forward or toward each other

• If ONLY ONE subject is visible:
  – The subject is alone at the altar
  – An empty space beside them clearly implies the missing partner

CLOTHING RULES (CRITICAL):
• Bride attire:
  – Elegant bridal gown
  – Veil optional
  – Formal, tasteful, realistic wedding dress

• Groom attire:
  – Classic wedding suit or tuxedo
  – Bowtie or tie appropriate to formal wear

SINGLE-SUBJECT HANDLING:
• If the single subject is MALE:
  – Dress him as a bride
  – Bridal gown must fit properly
  – No mockery, exaggeration, or caricature

• If the single subject is FEMALE:
  – Dress her as a bride
  – Focus on beauty and elegance

WEDDING TYPE SELECTION (CRITICAL — ADDITIVE):
• If an external master prompt specifies a wedding type, USE THAT
• If no wedding type is specified externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 40:
  - 0: Traditional Western (white gown, tuxedo)
  - 1: Bohemian
  - 2: Rustic Barn
  - 3: Beach Wedding
  - 4: Garden Wedding
  - 5: Catholic Church
  - 6: Jewish Wedding
  - 7: Hindu Indian Wedding
  - 8: Sikh Wedding
  - 9: Muslim Nikah
  - 10: Chinese Traditional Wedding
  - 11: Japanese Shinto Wedding
  - 12: Korean Traditional Wedding
  - 13: Vietnamese Wedding
  - 14: Filipino Wedding
  - 15: Thai Wedding
  - 16: Greek Orthodox Wedding
  - 17: Italian Traditional Wedding
  - 18: Spanish Catholic Wedding
  - 19: Mexican Wedding
  - 20: Afrocentric Wedding
  - 21: Nigerian Wedding
  - 22: Ethiopian Wedding
  - 23: Moroccan Wedding
  - 24: Persian Wedding
  - 25: Armenian Wedding
  - 26: Russian Orthodox Wedding
  - 27: Ukrainian Wedding
  - 28: Scottish Wedding (kilts)
  - 29: Irish Wedding
  - 30: Nordic Wedding
  - 31: Hawaiian Wedding
  - 32: Polynesian Wedding
  - 33: Native American Wedding
  - 34: Andean / Peruvian Wedding
  - 35: Brazilian Wedding
  - 36: Colombian Wedding
  - 37: South African Wedding
  - 38: Royal / Aristocratic Wedding
  - 39: Modern Minimalist Wedding

CULTURAL ACCURACY RULE:
• Wedding attire, colors, fabrics, accessories, and altar decor MUST match the selected wedding type
• No mixing of wedding styles
• Maintain realism and respect

IDENTITY & TONE RULES:
• Do NOT change facial features
• Do NOT alter body type
• Do NOT sexualize the subject
• Humor, if present, must come from context, not distortion

POSE & EXPRESSION:
• Calm, composed, ceremonial posture
• Hands folded, holding flowers, or relaxed at sides
• No exaggerated reactions

REALISM CONSTRAINTS:
• Photographic realism
• Correct lighting and shadows
• Natural fabric textures
• No fantasy or surreal elements

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like a real wedding photo taken at the altar just before the vows — sincere, formal, and gently humorous when unexpected.

name: MATRIX
message: Take a picture and transform the entire image into the style of the Matrix. Render the subject, background, and all elements as falling green Matrix code (digital rain), so that the person is fully made of glowing vertical code lines. The subject should remain recognizable in silhouette and pose, but composed entirely of streaming green characters, symbols, and binary-like patterns. Include motion blur and glowing highlights consistent with the iconic Matrix digital rain aesthetic. The scene should look like a fully immersive digital world, no natural textures, only cascading green code forming the subject and environment. Emphasize neon-green glow, high contrast, and a cinematic cyberpunk feel.

name: MAX HEADROOM
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a synthetic, computer-generated television host inspired by the 1980s Max Headroom-style digital persona aesthetic.

CRITICAL – SYNTHETIC VIDEO PERSONA TRANSFORMATION:
• Subject must appear as a fully synthetic, computer-generated TV personality
• NOT a normal human with glitch overlays
• Skin must look artificial (plastic, rubberized, or CGI-rendered)
• Facial features are the subject’s, but rendered in an uncanny digital form
• Expression slightly exaggerated and frozen between speech frames
• Subject appears as a generated broadcast entity, not a real person

STYLE SELECTION (RANDOMIZED):
• If an external master prompt specifies glitch intensity or broadcast style, USE IT
• Otherwise SELECT EXACTLY ONE using LAST DIGIT modulo 5:
  - 0: Clean Studio Broadcast – minimal glitches, crisp chroma background
  - 1: Analog Glitch – VHS distortion, scanlines, color bleed
  - 2: Digital Compression – block artifacts, frame tearing, data noise
  - 3: Signal Interference – rolling static, sync loss, jitter
  - 4: Broadcast Meltdown – heavy glitches, frozen frames, surreal artifacts

FACIAL & MATERIAL REQUIREMENTS:
• Face geometry matches the subject’s structure
• Skin appears synthetic, glossy or matte plastic
• NO pores, stubble, wrinkles, or real skin texture
• Teeth and eyes slightly too perfect or artificial
• Mouth mid-speech or mid-smirk
• Subtle uncanny valley effect is intentional

VIDEO AESTHETIC:
• Visible scanlines or CRT phosphor texture
• Slight frame offset or misalignment
• Occasional duplicated facial edges
• Color channel separation (RGB shift)
• Timecode, broadcast noise, or signal markers optional

BACKGROUND & ENVIRONMENT:
• Abstract virtual studio or solid chroma background
• Geometric patterns, gradients, or digital void
• No real-world environments
• Background must reinforce “TV signal” or “broadcast feed” feel

CAMERA & FRAMING:
• Head-and-shoulders framing typical of a TV host
• Slightly off-center or asymmetrical composition
• Subject appears to be addressing the viewer directly
• FULL frame visible with all four corners

COLOR & LIGHTING:
• Neon highlights and high contrast
• Cool blues, cyans, magentas, greens
• Artificial studio lighting
• Over-lit or slightly blown highlights acceptable

NOT ALLOWED:
• Photorealistic human skin
• Simple glitch filter on a normal photo
• Turning subject into the actual Max Headroom character
• Real clothing textures or fabric detail
• Naturalistic lighting

STYLE:
• 1980s cyberpunk broadcast energy
• Uncanny, synthetic, self-aware
• Looks like a generated digital host from a rogue TV network
• Satirical but believable as a TV signal entity

FINAL RESULT:
The image should depict the subject transformed into a fully synthetic, computer-generated television personality in a Max Headroom–inspired style — with artificial skin, exaggerated facial expression, glitching broadcast artifacts, and an unmistakable 1980s digital TV aesthetic — appearing as a sentient video signal rather than a real human, fully visible in-frame with authentic broadcast distortion and retro-futuristic energy.

name: MAYHEM
message: Take a picture and transform the scene into an outrageously funny visual scenario centered on the subject. Use exaggerated scale, unexpected objects, absurd logic, and chaotic interactions to create instant visual comedy. Preserve the subject’s recognizable face and identity while placing them in a situation that is wildly implausible yet visually coherent. The humor should be obvious at first glance, relying on visual absurdity rather than text, jokes, or captions. Push the scene to the edge of chaos while maintaining clear lighting, sharp detail, and readable composition.

name: MEDIEVAL KNIGHT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a medieval knight in full plate armor with authentic historical details.

SCENE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a specific medieval scene, USE THAT SCENE
• If no scene is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE scene using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 6:
  - 0: Castle Courtyard (stone courtyard, castle walls surrounding, sword point-down, noble guardian stance)
  - 1: Battlefield (muddy war-torn landscape, armor battle-damaged, sword raised/lowered, exhausted victorious)
  - 2: Tournament Grounds (jousting arena, pavilion tents, lance upright or horse nearby, ceremonial armor)
  - 3: Throne Room Knighting (kneeling before throne, sword on shoulder, reverent solemn moment, candlelit)
  - 4: Forest Quest (dense medieval forest, armor worn from travel, hand on sword, alert adventurous)
  - 5: Castle Ramparts (standing on castle walls, looking over kingdom, shield and sword ready, sunset/dawn)

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• Subject becomes an authentic medieval knight
• Wearing full plate armor with heraldic details
• Set in selected medieval scene
• Subject's facial features visible through open visor or helmet off
• Photorealistic as if subject traveled to medieval times
• Tone reflects chivalry, honor, or battle-readiness

IDENTITY RULES:
• Subject's face clearly visible and recognizable
• Facial features completely preserved
• Natural expression matching the scene
• Visor up or helmet removed/carried
• No replacement with historical figure
• Subject remains themselves in armor

ARMOR DETAILS:
• Full plate armor (15th century style)
• Polished steel with weathered battle wear
• Articulated joints at elbows, knees, shoulders
• Chainmail visible at gaps and joints
• Gauntlets (armored gloves) with finger articulation
• Sabaton (foot armor) with leather straps
• Gorget protecting neck and throat
• Pauldrons (shoulder armor) with heraldic symbols
• Breastplate with royal or family crest

HELMET OPTIONS:
• Visor raised showing subject's face clearly
• Great helm carried under arm
• Bascinet with visor up
• Face fully visible and recognizable
• Helmet adorned with plume or crest
• Dents and scratches from battle

HERALDIC ELEMENTS:
• Shield with unique coat of arms design
• Family crest on breastplate
• Surcoat over armor with heraldic colors
• Banner or standard with matching symbols
• Traditional medieval heraldry rules
• Lions, eagles, crosses, or geometric patterns

WEAPONRY:
• Longsword (hand-and-a-half sword)
• Kite shield or heater shield with heraldry
• Dagger at belt as backup weapon
• Lance for tournament scenes
• Weapons show realistic use and wear
• Authentic medieval weapon design

MEDIEVAL SETTING DETAILS:
• Stone castle architecture
• Wooden structures with medieval joinery
• Mud, dirt, and natural ground
• Torches or braziers for lighting
• Medieval banners and standards
• Period-appropriate props only
• No modern elements visible

WEATHERING AND REALISM:
• Armor shows scratches, dents, rust spots
• Leather straps worn and aged
• Mud or dirt on lower armor and boots
• Chainmail with realistic metal links
• Fabric elements (surcoat) worn and faded
• Sword blade with nicks and wear
• Authentic battle damage

LIGHTING:
• Natural medieval lighting sources
• Overcast daylight or golden hour
• Torch light creating warm glow
• Dramatic shadows on armor
• Metallic reflections on polished steel
• Period-appropriate atmosphere

COLOR PALETTE:
• Steel grey armor
• Deep heraldic colors: red, blue, gold, green
• Brown leather accents
• Stone grey castle walls
• Muddy earth tones
• White or cream surcoat
• Rich medieval pigments

CAMERA:
• Heroic low angle or eye-level shot
• Cinematic medieval film quality
• Subject clearly in focus
• Environmental context visible
• Professional period drama aesthetic

OPTIONAL ELEMENTS:
• War horse in background
• Squire attending nearby
• Other knights in distant background
• Castle towers and battlements
• Medieval flags and banners waving
• Blacksmith's forge
• Wooden training posts
• Royal guards standing watch

RESTRICTIONS:
• No fantasy elements (dragons, magic)
• No cartoon or stylized rendering
• No text overlays or captions
• No modern items or anachronisms
• No unrealistic shiny armor (show battle wear)
• No samurai, Roman, or other non-medieval armor
• Historical accuracy prioritized

FINAL RESULT:
The image should present the subject as an authentic medieval knight in the selected scene with realistic armor, weapons, and setting. The transformation should preserve the subject's identity while immersing them in a photorealistic medieval world.

name: MEL BROOKS FILM
message:
Take a picture and place the subject into a Mel Brooks comedy film scene.

FILM SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a Mel Brooks film, USE THAT FILM
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 12:
  - 0: Blazing Saddles (1974) - Wild West town, bean-eating cowboys, fourth wall breaks, saloon brawl, "Excuse me while I whip this out"
  - 1: Young Frankenstein (1974) - black and white, Transylvania castle, "It's Fronkensteen!", laboratory with electrical equipment, Igor hump switching
  - 2: The Producers (1967) - Broadway theater, "Springtime for Hitler" musical number, accountants scheming, over-the-top theatrical
  - 3: Spaceballs (1987) - sci-fi parody, desert planet, Schwartz rings, "Ludicrous speed!", merchandise gags
  - 4: History of the World Part I (1981) - multiple historical eras, French Revolution, Roman Empire, Spanish Inquisition musical, "It's good to be the king"
  - 5: Robin Hood: Men in Tights (1993) - Sherwood Forest, tights jokes, Merry Men dancing, archery contest, "Unlike some other Robin Hoods, I can speak with an English accent"
  - 6: High Anxiety (1977) - Hitchcock parody, psychiatric institute, vertigo moments, shower scene with newspaper, birds attacking
  - 7: Silent Movie (1976) - actual silent film with title cards, slapstick, Burt Reynolds cameo, physical comedy, no dialogue
  - 8: To Be or Not to Be (1983) - Polish theater troupe, WWII, Nazi disguises, Shakespeare, backstage theatrical
  - 9: Dracula: Dead and Loving It (1995) - vampire castle, Leslie Nielsen slapstick, blood and stakes, Gothic horror parody
  - 10: Life Stinks (1991) - homeless comedy, skid row, rich man living on streets, physical comedy
  - 11: The Twelve Chairs (1970) - treasure hunt, Russian setting, chairs hiding jewels, early Brooks comedy

PLACE THE SUBJECT:
• Subject as central character in iconic scene from selected film
• Interacting with other characters from that movie
• In the middle of a signature Mel Brooks gag
• Breaking fourth wall if appropriate
• Over-the-top comedic performance

MEL BROOKS STYLE ELEMENTS (CRITICAL):
• Fourth wall breaks - looking directly at camera, acknowledging the audience
• Jewish humor and Yiddish references
• Parody of film genres (Western, horror, sci-fi, historical epic)
• Slapstick physical comedy
• Risqué jokes and innuendo
• Over-the-top theatrical performances
• Sight gags and visual puns
• Musical numbers that parody the genre
• Self-aware comedy
• Rapid-fire jokes layered on top of each other

FILM-SPECIFIC DETAILS:
• Period-accurate costumes exaggerated for comedy
• Authentic locations parodied
• Props used for sight gags
• Other ensemble cast members visible
• Signature moments from that film referenced
• Color palette matching original (B&W for Young Frankenstein, vibrant for Spaceballs)

COMEDIC ELEMENTS:
• Exaggerated expressions and reactions
• Physical comedy and pratfalls
• Anachronistic jokes (modern references in historical settings)
• Meta-humor and self-referential gags
• Wordplay and puns
• Theatrical over-acting

STYLE:
• Cinematic comedy still
• Film quality matching the era
• Professional Hollywood production values
• Comedy timing captured visually
• Subject mid-laugh, mid-gag, or breaking character

ATMOSPHERE:
• Joyful absurdity
• Irreverent parody
• Ensemble comedy energy
• Nothing sacred, everything mockable
• Warm-hearted despite crude humor
• Celebratory of cinema itself

SPECIAL NOTES:
• For Young Frankenstein: Black and white cinematography, 1930s Universal Horror aesthetic
• For Blazing Saddles: Deliberately anachronistic Western with modern slang
• For Spaceballs: Star Wars parody with merchandising gags
• For History of the World: Multiple costume changes for different historical periods

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject in an iconic Mel Brooks comedy scene with over-the-top theatrical performance, sight gags, genre parody elements, and that distinctive Mel Brooks blend of slapstick, wordplay, fourth-wall-breaking meta-humor, and affectionate mockery of cinema.

name: MELTING
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a melting form where the subject's body itself is liquefying, deforming, and dripping under gravity.

CRITICAL — MATERIAL REPLACEMENT (NO OVERLAY):
• The subject IS the melting material
• The subject is NOT a solid person with melting substance on top
• Skin, flesh, clothing, and structure are fully converted into the selected melting material
• NO intact human surface beneath the melting
• NO substance layered, poured, or dripping ON the subject
• The subject’s body geometry itself must deform, sag, elongate, and drip
• If realism conflicts with transformation, PRIORITIZE MELTING OVER HUMAN STRUCTURE

MELTING STYLE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies style, USE THAT STYLE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY — you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST DIGIT modulo 10:
  - 0: Wax Candle Melting
  - 1: Ice Cream Melting
  - 2: Salvador Dali Surreal Melt
  - 3: Chocolate Melting
  - 4: Paint Dripping Melt
  - 5: Plastic/Toy Melting
  - 6: Metal Melting (Molten)
  - 7: Cheese Melting
  - 8: Flesh Melting (Horror)
  - 9: Digital Glitch Melting

SUBJECT RECOGNITION (THROUGH DEFORMATION):
• Identity preserved through distorted facial geometry
• Eyes, nose, and mouth recognizable but sagging, stretched, or sliding
• Recognition comes from shape and proportion, not intact skin
• The subject is mid-collapse, not intact

GEOMETRIC DEFORMATION (MANDATORY):
• Facial features physically elongate and droop
• Nose stretches downward
• Cheeks slide and sag
• Mouth warps and drips
• Jawline loses rigidity
• Head partially collapsing under its own weight
• Body mass flowing downward continuously

MELTING PHYSICS:
• Gravity-driven liquefaction
• Upper regions partially intact, lower regions heavily deformed
• Continuous flow — not frozen drips
• Material stretches, thins, and breaks into streams
• Portions of the subject separating and falling
• A growing puddle at the base made of the SAME material as the subject

CLOTHING & ACCESSORIES:
• Clothing does NOT remain intact
• Clothing melts into the same material as the body
• Fabric becomes liquid, fused, warped
• No recognizable fabric texture unless melted into material form

DRIP & FLOW BEHAVIOR:
• Thick, viscous streams
• Elongated strands pulling away
• Droplets forming and falling
• Material tension visible before separation
• Uneven flow rates across the body

TEXTURE (STYLE-SPECIFIC — REPLACES SKIN):
• Wax: smooth, translucent, candle-like
• Ice Cream: creamy, soft, pastel
• Chocolate: glossy, rich, fluid
• Paint: wet, pigmented, viscous
• Plastic: glossy synthetic melt
• Metal: glowing molten flow
• Cheese: stretchy, gooey strands
• Flesh: liquefied tissue (horror)
• Digital: pixels behaving as liquid data

NOT ALLOWED (STRICT):
• Melting substance applied ON skin
• Intact human skin under drips
• Solid face with liquid poured over it
• Cosmetic melting only
• Normal anatomy with added effects

BACKGROUND:
• Simple or thematic
• Supports visibility of deformation
• No distractions from melting geometry
• FULL subject visible with all four corners

STYLE:
• Surreal, visceral, or horrifying
• Emphasis on transformation and loss of structure
• Physical impossibility encouraged
• Looks sculpted by gravity and heat

FINAL RESULT:
The image must depict the subject themselves physically melting — their body geometry collapsing, deforming, elongating, and dripping downward as a single continuous material — with no intact human surface remaining beneath the melt. The subject’s identity is preserved only through distorted form and proportion, while the body dissolves into flowing material and pools at the base, creating a convincing, gravity-driven melting transformation rather than a surface-level overlay.

name: MEME
message: Take a picture and make it into a MEME, adding ironic humor and flavor text inspired by the content of the image. Clean composition with readable typography.  The result should be a full view of the meme.

name: MERMAID
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a realistic mermaid. Preserve the subject’s recognizable facial features, expressions, body proportions, and personality while adapting the lower body into a natural, anatomically believable fish tail with detailed scales and fins. The subject wears ocean-appropriate, functional aquatic attire designed for a mermaid, integrated naturally with the anatomy. Create a photorealistic underwater environment with flowing hair, suspended particles, coral reefs, and aquatic life. Use realistic underwater lighting with sunlight rays filtering through the water, emphasizing scale, depth, and immersion. The subject must appear fully native to the underwater world, not costumed.

name: MESOPOTAMIAN RELIEF
message: Take a picture and Transform the image into a Mesopotamian bas-relief style. Flatten forms, use profile poses, and emphasize symbolic gestures. Apply sandstone textures and ancient ornamental borders.

name: METAL SCULPTURE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a modern abstract metal sculpture. The subject should be constructed from welded metal pieces - steel plates, curved sheets, angular fragments, metal rods, and geometric forms all assembled together. Use brushed steel, rusted iron, oxidized copper, and weathered bronze surfaces with visible welds, seams, and rivets.

The sculpture should have an industrial, contemporary art feel with bold geometric shapes, flowing curves, and dynamic angles that suggest the subject's form and pose without literal representation. Include negative space and cutouts within the metal structure. Show the sculptural mass as solid, heavy metalwork with thickness and weight.

Surfaces should display authentic metal textures: brushed finish with directional grain, rust patina with orange and brown oxidation, verdigris green copper aging, polished reflective sections, and rough hammered areas. Include realistic weathering, scratches, and industrial fabrication marks.

Place the sculpture in an appropriate setting: museum gallery with spotlights, outdoor plaza, sculpture garden, or contemporary art space. Use dramatic lighting that creates strong highlights on polished metal surfaces and deep shadows in recesses. Show metal's reflective properties catching light.

The sculpture should be clearly recognizable as the subject through its overall form, proportions, and gesture, but rendered as an abstract modernist metalwork piece - an artistic interpretation rather than realistic statue. Make it look like a photograph of an actual large-scale metal sculpture by a contemporary artist, with impressive craftsmanship and artistic vision.

name: MET GALA
message:
Take a picture and place the subject at the MET Gala wearing an iconic, outrageous couture outfit inspired by historical MET Gala looks.

COSTUME SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a MET Gala look or celebrity, USE THAT
• If no look is specified externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 12:
  - 0: Rihanna yellow Guo Pei cape (2015)
  - 1: Katy Perry chandelier dress (2019)
  - 2: Lady Gaga four-outfit reveal (2019)
  - 3: Jared Leto jeweled crown look (2018)
  - 4: Kim Kardashian wet-look dress (2019)
  - 5: Billy Porter sun god entrance (2019)
  - 6: Zendaya Cinderella gown (2019)
  - 7: Cardi B red Thom Browne gown (2019)
  - 8: Blake Lively Statue of Liberty gown (2022)
  - 9: Doja Cat Karl Lagerfeld cat tribute (2023)
  - 10: Ezra Miller time-loop illusion suit (2022)
  - 11: Madonna punk priestess look (2013)

STYLE RULES:
• Extreme couture and theatrical materials
• Red carpet lighting and paparazzi energy
• Subject must remain recognizable
• No cartoon or illustration styles

FINAL RESULT:
The image should look like a headline-making MET Gala appearance frozen in time.

name: MEXICAN MURALISM
message: Take a picture and transform the image into Mexican muralism style art. Bold figures, narrative storytelling, strong outlines, social symbolism, and monumental composition.

name: MICHELIN MAN
message: Take a picture of the subject and transform their entire body into a Michelin Man-style figure made of stacked white tires, while preserving the subject’s recognizable facial features, body proportions, and pose. The tires should follow the contours of their limbs and torso, with arms, legs, and head shaped to match the subject. Include realistic tire textures, tread patterns, and slight compression where tires stack, but let the subject’s identity shine through. The figure should look jolly and friendly, in a fitting setting like a tire shop, racetrack, or mascot event. Lighting should emphasize the white tire material while keeping the subject recognizable. Make it feel like a photograph of a real Michelin Man costume or sculpture based on the subject, not a generic mascot.

name: MICROFICHE
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a microfiche-style archival image.

CONTENT SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies document content, USE THAT
• If not specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 4:
  - 0: Newspaper clippings and headlines
  - 1: Government records and forms
  - 2: Technical manuals and schematics
  - 3: Personal records and photographs

STYLE:
• High-contrast monochrome
• Dense information layout
• Grid-based microfilm structure
• Subject remains recognizable

FINAL RESULT:
The image should resemble a scanned microfiche frame packed with archival information.

name: MIDDLE EARTH
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a Middle-earth race. Preserve recognizable facial structure, expressions, body proportions, and personality while adapting them to authentic race features. Translate clothing into race-appropriate attire, armor, or robes while retaining original silhouette and identity cues. Cinematic Peter Jackson aesthetic with proper lighting and atmosphere. The subject must appear fully as the race, naturally integrated into appropriate Middle-earth environment (Rivendell, Moria, Shire, Rohan, Lothlorien, Mordor, forests, mountains).

SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a race, USE THAT RACE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 20:
  - 0: High Elf (pointed ears, ethereal beauty, ageless grace, noble bearing of Rivendell)
  - 1: Wood Elf (pointed ears, forest warrior, keen senses, Mirkwood guardians like Legolas)
  - 2: Dark Elf/Noldor (pointed ears, intense features, tragic history, great craftsmen)
  - 3: Half-Elf (pointed ears, choice of mortality, both human and elvish qualities)
  - 4: Dwarf of Durin's Folk (robust build, thick magnificent beard, sturdy features, Moria heritage)
  - 5: Dwarf of the Iron Hills (battle-hardened, fierce warrior, heavily armored)
  - 6: Dwarf of the Blue Mountains (skilled craftsmen, exiled nobility, refined features)
  - 7: Hobbit of the Shire (shorter stature, curly hair, bare furry feet, cheerful appearance)
  - 8: Hobbit Fallohide (taller hobbit, adventurous spirit, slender build like Bilbo)
  - 9: Uruk-hai (muscular orc, war-painted, battle-scarred warrior, Saruman's creation)
  - 10: Orc of Mordor (twisted features, dark skin, vicious appearance, Sauron's armies)
  - 11: Goblin of Misty Mountains (smaller orc, pale skin, cave-dweller, sneaky appearance)
  - 12: Ent (tree-like humanoid, bark skin, ancient wise features, shepherd of forests)
  - 13: Cave Troll (large humanoid, stone-like skin, brutish features, underground dweller)
  - 14: Mountain Troll (massive humanoid, thick hide, savage appearance, turns to stone in sunlight)
  - 15: Wizard/Istari (Maiar spirit, ancient wise features, powerful presence like Gandalf)
  - 16: Balrog-touched Maiar (fiery features, shadow and flame, corrupted angelic being)
  - 17: Nazgûl/Ringwraith (spectral humanoid form, corrupted king, dark robes, terrifying presence)
  - 18: Dunlending Wild Man (rugged features, tribal appearance, Rohan's enemies)
  - 19: Wose/Drúedain (stocky build, primitive features, ancient forest guardians, Púkel-men)

name: MIKE JUDGE ME
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into an animated character placed directly inside a scene from the world of Mike Judge cartoons.

Render the subject in a Mike Judge–style character design: slightly awkward proportions, stiff posture, minimal facial expression, uneven line work, flat cel-shaded colors, and intentionally plain or unflattering details. Preserve the subject’s recognizability while adapting them fully into the cartoon style.

Place the subject INTO a recognizable Mike Judge cartoon scene, selected based on context or randomly. The scene should clearly reflect one of the following shows and environments, and may include recognizable characters from that show:

• King of the Hill — suburban Arlen, Texas (backyard fence chats, alleyways, living rooms, Strickland Propane). Characters may include Hank Hill, Peggy, Bobby, Dale, Bill, or Boomhauer.
• Beavis and Butt-Head — grimy neighborhood streets, living room couch, fast-food joints, school hallways. Characters may include Beavis, Butt-Head, or classmates reacting to the subject.
• Daria — school hallways, classrooms, coffee shops, or suburban interiors. Characters may include Daria, Jane, Quinn, or classmates observing the subject.
• Office Space–style environment — dull corporate office, cubicle farms, break rooms, printer destruction areas. Characters may include bored coworkers or management-style figures inspired by the film’s tone.

Existing characters should appear as supporting or background characters interacting with or reacting to the subject. The subject should feel like a guest character awkwardly dropped into the episode, not replacing anyone.

Adapt the subject’s clothing into simplified everyday outfits typical of Mike Judge cartoons — plain t-shirts, polos, jeans, boring office attire, or aggressively normal suburban clothing.

Use muted, slightly washed-out color palettes, flat lighting, and simple painted backgrounds. Avoid exaggerated animation, flashy effects, or glossy textures.

Ensure the full scene is visible and readable on a small screen, with the subject clearly identifiable among the characters. The final image should feel like a freeze-frame from an actual Mike Judge episode — dry, awkward, observational, and quietly brutal.

name: MILITARY UNIFORM
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a soldier in formal military dress uniform from a specific country and war era.

MILITARY UNIFORM SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a military uniform, USE THAT UNIFORM

  - 8: German Imperial WWI (1914-1918) - pickelhaube spiked helmet, gray-green uniform, iron cross
  - 9: Soviet Red Army WWII (1941-1945) - gymnastyorka tunic, pilotka cap, PPSh-41 submachine gun
  - 10: French Army WWI (1914-1918) - horizon blue uniform, Adrian helmet, poilu mustache
  - 11: Japanese Imperial Army WWII (1937-1945) - Type 98 uniform, peaked cap, rising sun insignia
  - 12: US Confederate Army Civil War (1861-1865) - gray uniform, kepi cap, CSA buttons
  - 13: US Union Army Civil War (1861-1865) - blue uniform, kepi cap, brass buttons, forage cap
  - 14: British Redcoat Revolutionary War (1775-1783) - red coat, white crossbelts, tricorn hat, musket
  - 15: Continental Army Revolutionary War (1775-1783) - blue coat, tricorn hat, buff facings
  - 16: Roman Legionnaire (Ancient Rome) - lorica segmentata armor, gladius, scutum shield, centurion plume
  - 17: Napoleonic French Army (1800s) - blue coat, white breeches, bicorn hat, Grande Armée
  - 18: Prussian Army (1870s) - pickelhaube spiked helmet, blue uniform, iron cross medal
