  - 27: Samurai Warrior (Feudal Japan) - full samurai armor, katana, helmet with horns
  - 28: Spartan Hoplite (Ancient Greece) - bronze armor, red cloak, lambda shield, spear
  - 29: Viking Warrior (800-1000 AD) - chainmail, round shield, axe, horned or winged helmet
  - 30: Medieval Knight (1200s-1400s) - full plate armor, surcoat with heraldry, longsword
  - 31: Zulu Warrior (1800s) - cowhide shield, assegai spear, ceremonial headdress
  - 32: Cuban Army Spanish-American War (1898) - independence fighter, white uniform, machete, Cuban flag
  - 33: Italian Army WWII (1940-1945) - grayish-green uniform, alpine hat, Fascist insignia (historical)
  - 34: Italian Bersaglieri (1800s-present) - distinctive plumed hat, running riflemen
  - 35: Spanish Nationalist Army Civil War (1936-1939) - khaki uniform, Legion insignia
  - 36: Spanish Republican Army Civil War (1936-1939) - mixed uniforms, International Brigades
  - 37: Spanish Tercios (1500s-1600s) - morion helmet, pike, conquistador era
  - 38: Polish Army WWII (1939-1945) - khaki uniform, rogatywka cap, eagle insignia
  - 39: Finnish Army Winter War (1939-1940) - white winter camo, ski troops, against Soviets
  - 40: Dutch Army WWII (1940) - khaki uniform, Netherlands insignia, German invasion
  - 41: Belgian Army WWI (1914-1918) - horizon blue, Adrian helmet, King Albert's army
  - 42: Greek Army WWII (1940-1941) - khaki uniform, fighting Italians and Germans
  - 43: Yugoslav Partisans WWII (1941-1945) - mixed uniforms, red star, Tito's forces
  - 44: North Vietnamese Army (1960s-1970s) - pith helmet, tan uniform, AK-47
  - 45: South Vietnamese Army (1960s-1970s) - US-style uniform, ARVN insignia
  - 46: Chinese People's Liberation Army (1940s-present) - Mao suit style, red star
  - 47: North Korean People's Army (1950s-present) - Soviet-style uniform, large peaked cap
  - 48: East German NVA (1956-1990) - gray-green uniform, Communist insignia
  - 49: West German Bundeswehr (1955-present) - modern NATO uniform, Iron Cross (modern version)
  - 50: Mexican Army Revolutionary Era (1910-1920) - sombrero, bandoliers, Villa/Zapata forces
  - 51: Mexican Army Modern (1990s-present) - olive green uniform, Mexican eagle insignia
  - 52: Chinese Imperial Army Qing Dynasty (1644-1912) - traditional armor, queue hairstyle, spear
  - 53: Chinese Nationalist Army (1920s-1940s) - blue-gray uniform, sun insignia, Republican era

TRANSFORM THE SUBJECT:
• Subject in full authentic military dress uniform
• Medals, ribbons, and decorations appropriate to rank and era
• Proper insignia, patches, and unit identifiers
• Period-appropriate grooming standards (clean shaven, mustache styles, etc.)
• Formal military bearing and posture
• Rank insignia visible (private, sergeant, lieutenant, captain, etc.)

UNIFORM DETAILS:
• Authentic colors and materials for the era
• Correct buttons, belts, and accessories
• Headgear appropriate to service and era
• Footwear (boots, shoes, sandals) period-accurate
• Weapons if appropriate (rifle, sword, sidearm)
• All insignia historically accurate

SETTING:
• Formal military portrait background
• OR battlefield/wartime setting appropriate to conflict
• OR military base/barracks
• OR parade ground
• National flag visible if appropriate
• Other soldiers in background

PHOTOGRAPHY STYLE:
• Formal military portrait photography
• Period-appropriate photo quality:
  - Ancient/Medieval: Painted portrait style
  - 1800s-early 1900s: Sepia or black and white photography
  - WWII-Vietnam: Black and white or early color
  - Modern: Professional color photography
• Studio lighting or natural outdoor lighting
• Dignified and respectful presentation

BODY LANGUAGE:
• Standing at attention or parade rest
• Confident military bearing
• Proud and dignified
• Professional military demeanor
• Era-appropriate formal pose

HISTORICAL ACCURACY:
• Uniforms accurate to specific time period and nation
• Medals and decorations historically appropriate
• No anachronisms
• Respectful portrayal of military service
• Period-appropriate photography techniques

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject in authentic military dress uniform from the selected country and war era, with historically accurate details, medals, insignia, and formal military portrait presentation appropriate to that time period and military service.

name: MILK CARTON
message: Take a picture and place the subject on the side of a classic milk carton as a missing person feature. Design the carton with realistic packaging details, typography, and layout. Generate humorous descriptive flavor text for the missing person section based on the subject’s appearance, clothing, expression, or personality, incorporating any externally provided details naturally. Keep the tone playful and clearly fictional. Ensure the subject’s image is integrated naturally into the carton design and remains recognizable. Render the final image photorealistically with believable lighting, carton texture, and packaging realism.

name: MIME
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a classic French mime performer. Apply full mime makeup - white face paint covering entire face and neck, black outlined eyes with exaggerated eyebrows drawn high on forehead, red or black lips painted in dramatic expression, beauty mark optional. Dress them in traditional mime costume: black and white horizontal striped shirt (marinière), black pants, black suspenders, white gloves, black beret. Show the subject frozen in an exaggerated mime pose - pretending to be trapped in an invisible box with hands pressed against imaginary glass walls, pulling an invisible rope, walking against invisible wind, or climbing invisible stairs. Their facial expression should be theatrical and over-dramatic. Place them in a street performance setting - cobblestone plaza, Parisian street scene, or park with small crowd watching. Include mime props if appropriate - invisible wall, trapped in box gesture, leaning on nothing. Use dramatic lighting and slight vignette for theatrical effect. The performance should be clearly pantomime with exaggerated physical comedy frozen mid-gesture. Make it look like a photograph of an actual street mime performance with that classic Marcel Marceau aesthetic and silent theatrical energy.

name: MINECRAFT
message:
Take a picture and completely transform it into the Minecraft game world with blocky voxel geometry and pixelated textures.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• EVERYTHING becomes Minecraft blocks - no smooth surfaces
• Subject transformed into blocky Minecraft character model
• Environment completely built from Minecraft blocks
• 16x16 pixel texture resolution
• Perfect cubic voxel geometry

SUBJECT TRANSFORMATION:
• Subject as Minecraft player character (Steve/Alex model)
• Blocky rectangular head (8x8x8 block)
• Rectangular body and limbs
• No curves - all right angles
• Pixelated skin texture (16x16 resolution)
• Subject's features simplified to pixel art on block face
• Standing in Minecraft pose (arms straight out or at sides)

MINECRAFT CHARACTER FEATURES:
• Blocky cubic head
• Rectangular torso
• Rectangular arms and legs
• No joints - limbs are solid blocks
• Pixelated clothing/skin texture
• Face is flat pixel art on front of head cube
• Subject's likeness rendered in limited pixel resolution

ENVIRONMENT:
• Entire world made of 1-meter cubes
• Minecraft biome (plains, forest, desert, mountains, cave, etc.)
• Recognizable Minecraft blocks:
  - Grass blocks (green top, dirt sides)
  - Stone, cobblestone
  - Wood planks, logs
  - Dirt, sand, gravel
  - Ores (diamond, iron, gold, redstone)
  - Water (translucent blue blocks)
  - Trees made of log and leaf blocks

TEXTURE STYLE:
• 16x16 pixel textures on every surface
• Pixelated and grainy
• Limited color palette per texture
• No texture filtering - hard pixel edges
• Authentic Minecraft texture pack aesthetic
• Visible pixels and grid pattern

GEOMETRY:
• Everything is perfect cubes or rectangular prisms
• 90-degree angles only
• Blocky voxel construction
• Minecraft's 1-meter block scale
• No curves or organic shapes
• Stepped terrain (not smooth slopes)

LIGHTING:
• Minecraft's lighting engine style
• Blocky shadows
• Ambient occlusion in corners
• Torch light if present (warm orange glow)
• Sunlight (bright directional light)
• Smooth lighting or classic Minecraft lighting

MINECRAFT ELEMENTS:
• Crafting table, furnace, or chest visible
• Tools in hand (pickaxe, sword, shovel - all blocky)
• Minecraft animals (blocky pigs, cows, sheep, chickens)
• Minecraft mobs (creepers, zombies, skeletons - if appropriate)
• Items as floating rotating cubes

STYLE:
• In-game screenshot aesthetic
• First-person or third-person Minecraft camera view
• Minecraft's art style exactly
• Looks like actual Minecraft gameplay
• Could be from Minecraft Java or Bedrock edition

COLORS:
• Vibrant but limited palette
• Minecraft's characteristic bright colors
• Grass green, sky blue, stone gray
• Block-based color distribution

SETTING OPTIONS:
• Overworld surface (plains, forest, mountains)
• Cave or mine interior
• Village with blocky houses
• Nether (red netherrack, lava, fortress)
• The End (purple void, endstone)

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject completely transformed into a blocky Minecraft character with pixelated textures, standing in a fully Minecraft world made entirely of cubic blocks with 16x16 pixel textures - looking exactly like an in-game Minecraft screenshot with perfect voxel geometry and no smooth surfaces.

name: MINIATURE SET
message:
Take a picture and transform the entire scene into a handcrafted miniature diorama. Scale all subjects and objects to match the proportions of a physical miniature set, so they appear small and in proportion to each other. Render surfaces with handcrafted textures such as clay, painted wood, cardboard, fabric, or tiny props, giving the scene a realistic, tactile feel.

Use shallow depth of field, soft studio lighting, and subtle shadows to emulate macro photography of a real miniature model. Ensure the composition reads clearly, maintains visual depth, and feels like a meticulously constructed miniature set. Keep subjects and environment clearly recognizable and readable on small screens, with a handcrafted, physical toy-like aesthetic.

name: MINIMALISM
message: Take a picture and transform the image into the Minimalism style. Simplify shapes, reduce color palette, and remove extraneous detail while keeping subject identifiable.

name: MINION MODE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a small, yellow, gibberish-speaking cartoon minion.

Adapt the subject’s facial structure, expression, and personality into a simplified, rounded, toy-like character with yellow skin, large expressive eyes behind goggles, and a compact body. Preserve recognizable traits such as smile shape, eyebrow energy, or posture.

Dress the character in classic minion-style overalls or a similar worker outfit. Proportions should be exaggerated and playful, not realistic.

The environment should be simplified and colorful to match an animated comedy world. Lighting should be bright and cheerful.

Do not include text. The final image should feel mischievous, energetic, and immediately recognizable as a minion-style parody while remaining readable on a small screen.

name: MIRROR WORLD
message: Take a picture and create a mirrored reality where reflection differs from reality. Subtle narrative differences.

name: MISPLACED SCALE
message:
Take a picture and transform it so ONE object in the scene is hilariously the wrong size, while everything else remains realistic and grounded.

SCALE TARGET SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies which object is mis-scaled, USE THAT
• If no object is specified externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 6:
  - 0: Everyday small object made absurdly large (coin, key, fork, phone, pencil)
  - 1: Normally large object made comically small (car, chair, door, trash can)
  - 2: Furniture scaled incorrectly (tiny couch or massive table)
  - 3: Food item wildly mis-scaled (giant grape, tiny pizza slice)
  - 4: Tool or appliance mis-scaled (huge remote, tiny ladder)
  - 5: Environmental object mis-scaled (oversized mailbox, miniature tree)

SCALE RULES:
• EXACTLY ONE object may have incorrect scale
• The object must remain realistic in material and detail
• No cartoon exaggeration or stylization
• Perspective must support the illusion

SUBJECT RULES:
• Subject remains normal-sized and recognizable
• Subject may be interacting naturally with the mis-scaled object
• Subject reaction should feel casual or mildly confused, not shocked

TONE:
• Lighthearted, playful, and visually obvious
• The humor should register instantly

ENVIRONMENT:
• Environment remains realistic and coherent
• Lighting and shadows must match the altered scale

CAMERA:
• Natural photographic framing
• No forced wide-angle distortion unless needed for realism

RESTRICTIONS:
• No text overlays or captions
• No additional scale changes elsewhere in the image
• No surreal or abstract styles

FINAL RESULT:
The image should look like a normal photograph at first glance, except for one unmistakably wrong-scale object that creates a clean, humorous visual gag.

name: MONA LISA
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into the Mona Lisa painting.

Replace the Mona Lisa’s face with the subject, carefully adapting their facial features, expression, and posture to match the iconic pose, angle, and calm demeanor of the original artwork. The subject should feel painted into the scene, not pasted on.

Render the image in a classical Renaissance oil painting style with soft brushwork, subtle gradients, muted earth tones, and realistic canvas texture. Preserve the iconic background landscape, atmospheric depth, and lighting.

Gently adapt the subject’s hair or accessories into period-appropriate forms while maintaining recognizable traits (for example, modern glasses subtly reinterpreted as period-style frames).

Ensure the full painting is visible within the frame, including the subject, background, and edges of the artwork. The final image should feel like a museum-worthy reinterpretation — respectful, believable, and quietly humorous through contrast.

name: MONDRIAN
message: Take a picture and reinterpret it in the style of Piet Mondrian. Reduce the scene into a grid of bold black lines and flat blocks of primary colors with white space. Abstract the subject while maintaining a clear structural reference to the original composition. The final image should feel balanced, geometric, and modernist.

name: MONOCHROME PHOTOGRAPHY (BLACK AND WHITE)
message:
Take a picture and convert the image into a professional monochrome black and white photograph.

CONVERSION RULES (CRITICAL):
• Remove all color information completely
• Use a full tonal range from deep blacks to bright whites
• Preserve strong midtone detail and subtle grayscale transitions

PHOTOGRAPHIC QUALITY:
• Maintain sharp focus and realistic lighting
• Emphasize contrast, texture, shadow depth, and highlight control
• Avoid flat gray washes or desaturated color appearance
• Ensure the image reads as intentionally shot in black and white, not merely color removed

STYLE OPTIONS:
• High-contrast dramatic lighting or soft documentary realism
• Film-like tonal response similar to professional black and white film stocks
• Natural grain if appropriate, but not excessive

IMAGE INTEGRITY:
• Do NOT alter composition, objects, or facial features
• Preserve original framing and perspective
• No artistic filters beyond monochrome tonal control

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must look like a professionally shot black and white photograph with rich tonal depth, clean grayscale separation, and strong photographic realism.

name: MONOCHROME PHOTOGRAPHY (COLOR)
message:
Take a picture and convert the image into a professional monochrome photograph using a single selected color tone.

COLOR SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a color, USE THAT COLOR
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 12:
  - 0: Sepia (Warm Brown)
  - 1: Cyan
  - 2: Deep Blue
  - 3: Teal
  - 4: Emerald Green
  - 5: Crimson Red
  - 6: Magenta
  - 7: Purple
  - 8: Amber
  - 9: Gold
  - 10: Rose
  - 11: Slate Gray-Blue

CONVERSION RULES (CRITICAL):
• Convert the image to shades of the selected color only
• Preserve full tonal range from darkest shade of the chosen color to its lightest tint
• No secondary hues or color contamination
• This is not a color filter — it must be a true monochrome tonal conversion

PHOTOGRAPHIC QUALITY:
• Maintain realistic lighting and shadow detail
• Strong contrast and smooth tonal transitions
• Professional fine-art or cinematic photography aesthetic

IMAGE INTEGRITY:
• Do NOT alter composition, objects, or facial features
• Preserve original framing and perspective
• No additional artistic stylization beyond monochrome conversion

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must look like a professionally shot monochrome photograph rendered entirely in the selected color tone, with rich depth, clean tonal separation, and high photographic realism.

name: MONSTER
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a cinematic monster while preserving the subject’s recognizable facial structure, body proportions, and identity. Reimagine the subject with exaggerated, otherworldly features such as altered skin texture, enhanced musculature, claws, horns, scales, or glowing eyes, inspired by the subject’s original traits. Place the subject naturally into a dark, immersive environment that complements the creature’s design. Use dramatic lighting, shadows, and environmental interaction to ensure the monster appears physically present in the scene. Render in photorealistic detail with a powerful, intimidating atmosphere.

name: MONTY PYTHON STYLE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into the distinctive Monty Python graphic design and animation style.

STYLE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a Python element, USE THAT ELEMENT
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST DIGIT:
  - 0: Terry Gilliam Cutout Animation - subject as Victorian-era cutout figure in surreal collage landscape
  - 1: Flying Circus Title Card - subject in ornate vintage illustration style with decorative typography
  - 2: Medieval Manuscript Parody - subject as illuminated manuscript illustration with gold leaf and Latin text
  - 3: Giant Foot Absurdity - subject being approached by or interacting with the giant crushing foot
  - 4: Victorian Photo Collage - subject's head on Victorian body in impossible surreal scenario
  - 5: Gilliam Animated Landscape - subject in psychedelic cutout animation with bizarre architecture
  - 6: Period Engraving Style - subject as detailed 18th/19th century engraving with cross-hatching
  - 7: Surreal Body Transformation - subject with absurd mixed-media body parts (clouds, buildings, animals)
  - 8: Renaissance Painting Parody - subject inserted into classical art with anachronistic elements
  - 9: Collage Chaos - subject fragmented and reassembled with Victorian clip art elements

TERRY GILLIAM ANIMATION STYLE (CORE AESTHETIC):
• Cutout animation aesthetic - flat 2D paper cutout appearance
• Victorian and Edwardian illustration sources
• Surreal juxtapositions and impossible scenarios
• Vintage engraving and etching texture
• Sepia tones, aged paper background
• Decorative borders and frames
• Absurdist combinations
• Stop-motion collage feel

VISUAL ELEMENTS:
• Subject appears as Victorian-era illustration or photograph
• Aged paper texture background (yellowed, stained)
• Other vintage cutout elements (cherubs, clouds, buildings, body parts)
• Ornate Victorian typography
• Decorative flourishes and borders
• Cross-hatching and engraving line work
• Sepia, aged color palette

SURREAL PYTHON ELEMENTS:
• Impossible architecture (floating, upside-down buildings)
• Mixed-scale objects (giant feet, tiny castles)
• Disconnected body parts with faces
• Clouds with faces or expressions
• Victorian figures in absurd situations
• Anarchic juxtapositions
• Nonsensical combinations presented matter-of-factly

COLLAGE TECHNIQUE:
• Obvious cut-and-paste aesthetic (not seamless)
• Slightly rough edges on cutouts
• Layered depth with shadow effects
• Elements from different sources combined
• Varying illustration styles within one image
• Stop-motion animation still feel

TYPOGRAPHY & TEXT:
• Ornate Victorian fonts
• Decorative title cards
• Latin or pseudo-Latin text
• "And Now For Something Completely Different" style announcements
• British spelling and phrasing
• Absurdist labels and captions

COLOR PALETTE:
• Sepia and aged paper tones
• Faded colors like old hand-tinted photographs
• Yellowed parchment backgrounds
• Muted earth tones
• Occasional vibrant psychedelic accent colors
• Ink stains and aging marks

PYTHON SIGNATURE ELEMENTS:
• The giant Cupid's foot (for crushing/stomping gags)
• Clouds with cherub faces
• Victorian women in impossible scenarios
• Disconnected hands gesturing
• Ornate picture frames
• Classical statuary
• British landmarks absurdly placed

TEXTURE & AGING:
• Paper grain visible
• Foxing and age spots
• Creases and fold marks
• Slight yellowing
• Vintage print quality
• Woodcut or engraving texture

SURREAL SCENARIOS:
• Subject floating in clouds
• Subject emerging from impossible architecture
• Subject with mechanical or anatomical additions
• Subject in Victorian formal wear doing absurd things
• Subject surrounded by disconnected Victorian clip art
• Subject at impossible scale (tiny or giant)

STYLE:
• Flat 2D cutout appearance
• Animation cel aesthetic
• Victorian illustration collage
• Surrealist art movement influence
• Terry Gilliam's distinctive vision
• Deliberately artificial and theatrical

ATMOSPHERE:
• Absurdist British humor
• Anarchic and nonsensical
• Intellectual meets silly
• Stream-of-consciousness visual jokes
• Subversive and irreverent
• Playfully surreal

FINAL RESULT:
The image should transform the subject into Terry Gilliam's distinctive Monty Python cutout animation style - appearing as a Victorian-era illustration or photograph integrated into a surreal collage with aged paper textures, ornate typography, impossible juxtapositions, and that flat 2D stop-motion aesthetic that defined Python's visual identity.

name: MOON
message: Take a picture and place subject on the moon. Subject is wearing an astronaut suit. Subject face is visible through the helmet visor. The Earth is in the background. Make it photorealistic. Make it 8k resolution.

name: MORNING TALK SHOW
message:
Take a picture and place the subject on a trashy 1980s-90s daytime talk show set as the victim or central figure in a sensationalist episode.

SHOW SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a show, USE THAT SHOW
• If no show is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE show using the RANDOM SEED
• If the RANDOM SEED ends in 0,1,2: SELECT MAURY POVICH (paternity test reveals, 'You ARE/ARE NOT the father!' graphics, women running backstage crying, Maury holding DNA results)
• If the RANDOM SEED ends in 3,4: SELECT MORTON DOWNEY JR. (confrontational 80s set, chain-smoking host, audience shouting matches, in-your-face aggressive style)
• If the RANDOM SEED ends in 5,6: SELECT GERALDO (chair-throwing brawls, nose-breaking fights, security rushing in, Geraldo in the middle of chaos)
• If the RANDOM SEED ends in 7,8,9: SELECT JERRY SPRINGER (chanting audience 'JER-RY! JER-RY!', blonde security guard Steve breaking up fights, chair throwing, love triangles, surprise reveals)

Show the subject sitting in the guest chair looking shocked, crying, angry, or dramatically emotional while the scandal unfolds. The set should match the chosen show's aesthetic: bright primary color blocking on walls, geometric patterns, cheap modular furniture, studio audience visible in tiered seating going wild - pointing, gasping, booing, cheering, chanting. Include the specific host with their signature style. Add on-screen graphics matching that show's style with sensationalist text. Include other guests in 90s fashion all in dramatic confrontation. Use harsh studio lighting, multiple cameras visible. Make it look like a freeze-frame from an actual episode of that specific show with maximum drama and chaos.

name: MOSAIC
message: Take a picture in the style of a glass Mosaic. Small tiles, reflective surfaces.

name: MOTION TRAIL
message:
Take a picture and transform it to show the subject at the tail end of extreme movement, enhanced with energetic photon trails.

MOTION TYPE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a motion type, USE THAT
• If no motion type is specified externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 2:
  - 0: Super-speed ground movement (subject running or dashing at extreme speed, Flash-like energy)
  - 1: High-speed aerial movement (subject flying or launching through the air, Superman-like motion)

TRAIL RULES (FULL):
• Subject is duplicated multiple times along the motion path forming a continuous trail
• Earlier duplicates are progressively more transparent or motion-blurred
• Photon trails appear **additionally** alongside the duplicates as streaks of light/color following the path
• The photon trails **do not replace duplicates**; they are an additive effect
• Final, foremost subject is fully solid, sharp, and dominant
• The image captures the exact moment **after** the movement has completed

IDENTITY RULES:
• Subject remains fully recognizable in the final position
• Facial structure and proportions preserved across all duplicates
• Trail duplicates represent the same subject, not separate characters

VISUAL STYLE:
• Photorealistic or cinematic realism
• Motion conveyed through both spatial duplication and colored photon streaks
• No cartoon or comic-style exaggeration

ENVIRONMENT:
• Environment subtly reacts to the movement (displaced debris, motion wake)
• Background remains coherent and grounded

CAMERA:
• Dynamic framing emphasizing direction and speed
• Clear sense of origin point and end point

RESTRICTIONS:
• No text overlays or captions
• No comic-book panels or stylized speed lines
• No exaggerated energy effects unless externally specified

FINAL RESULT:
The image should look like a frozen instant immediately after extreme motion, with the subject fully arrived, the path of movement clearly visible behind them, and energetic photon trails enhancing the sense of speed and motion without altering the subject duplicates.

name: MOTIVATIONAL CAT POSTER
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a cat hanging from a tree branch for a motivational poster parody. Replace the subject's body with a cute kitten's body while preserving their face, show them gripping a branch with tiny paws, and include the classic 'HANG IN THERE!' text at the bottom.

FACE BLENDING (CRITICAL):
• Subject's face must be SEAMLESSLY integrated onto the kitten - no visible edges or masking
• Blend subject's face naturally with kitten's fur around edges
• Match lighting, shadows, and color temperature between face and kitten body
• Add subtle fur texture at hairline and edges where face meets kitten fur
• Adjust face size to fit naturally on kitten head proportions
• Subject's skin tone should blend with kitten's coloring
• No sharp cutout lines - use soft feathered edges
• Face should look like it naturally belongs on the kitten body
• NOT a flat photo pasted on - the face must have dimension matching the kitten's head shape
• Lighting direction must match between face and body

HAIR MATCHING (CRITICAL):
• Kitten's fur color MUST match subject's hair color
• If subject has brown hair → brown/tan kitten fur
• If subject has black hair → black kitten fur
• If subject has blonde hair → light orange/cream kitten fur
• If subject has red hair → orange/ginger kitten fur
• If subject has gray/white hair → gray/white kitten fur
• Fur color transition from subject's hair should be seamless
• Hair and fur blend together naturally at the edges
• Subject's hair appears to continue as kitten fur

Use that distinctive 1980s motivational poster aesthetic with gradient background, inspirational font, and slightly faded photo quality as if it's been hanging in an office for decades.

name: MOUNT RUSHMORE
message: Take a picture and make the subject face a carved head placed on Mount Rushmore. Make it photorealistic.

name: MOVIE MONSTER
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a classic movie monster while retaining recognizable facial characteristics.

MONSTER SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a monster, USE THAT MONSTER
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 15:
  - 0: Frankenstein's Monster - flat-top head, neck bolts, green skin, stitched scars, lumbering pose, laboratory setting
  - 1: Dracula - slicked hair, high collar cape, pale skin, fangs, Transylvania castle, elegant gothic horror
  - 2: The Mummy - wrapped bandages, ancient Egyptian tomb, sarcophagus, hieroglyphics, shuffling walk, decayed but preserved
  - 3: Werewolf - full moon transformation, fur, claws, torn clothing, fangs, beast-man hybrid, forest setting
  - 4: Creature from the Black Lagoon - gill-man, scales, webbed hands, underwater swamp, amphibious monster
  - 5: Godzilla - giant radioactive lizard, atomic breath, destroying cityscape, towering over buildings, dorsal spines
  - 6: King Kong - giant ape, atop Empire State Building or jungle setting, roaring, protective of beauty
  - 7: Alien Xenomorph - H.R. Giger biomechanical design, elongated head, inner jaw, acidic drool, dark spaceship corridor
  - 8: The Blob - amorphous gelatinous mass, absorbing victims, 1950s small town, oozing through streets
  - 9: Swamp Thing - humanoid plant creature, moss and vines, swamp environment, tragic monster, algae-covered
  - 10: The Fly - human-fly hybrid, compound eyes, insect features, teleportation pod, body horror transformation
  - 11: Invisible Man - wrapped bandages on invisible body, sunglasses, hat, trench coat, Victorian laboratory
  - 12: Zombie - rotting flesh, tattered clothes, shuffling gait, graveyard or apocalypse setting, undead pallor
  - 13: Phantom of the Opera - half-masked face, elegant cape, underground lair, chandelier, tragic romantic monster
  - 14: Jekyll and Hyde - transformation between gentleman and beast, Victorian London, split personality horror

TRANSFORM THE SUBJECT:
• Subject's facial features MUST remain recognizable despite monster transformation
• Facial structure, eyes, nose, mouth proportions preserved but monstrous
• NOT a generic monster - this is the subject AS that monster
• Monster characteristics applied TO the subject's face, not replacing it
• Subject's unique features (jawline, cheekbones, facial shape) visible through monster makeup/transformation

MONSTER FEATURES:
• Authentic classic movie monster design from 1930s-1980s era
• Practical effects aesthetic (makeup, prosthetics) not CGI
• Monster-specific characteristics (bolts, fangs, scales, fur, bandages, etc.)
• Appropriate coloring (green for Frankenstein, pale for Dracula, grey for Mummy)
• Costume and props authentic to that monster

SETTING:
• Classic horror movie environment appropriate to monster
• Black and white or muted color palette for vintage monsters
• Dramatic horror lighting (shadows, fog, moonlight)
• Period-appropriate sets (Gothic castle, laboratory, swamp, tomb)
• Background elements that tell the monster's story

STYLE:
• Classic Universal Monsters or Hammer Horror aesthetic
• 1930s-1980s practical effects look
• Dramatic theatrical lighting and poses
• Film grain or aged footage quality
• Photorealistic but with vintage horror movie feel

POSE & EXPRESSION:
• Monster-appropriate pose (lumbering, threatening, tragic, etc.)
• Expression fitting the monster's character
• Dramatic monster movie moment captured

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject transformed into a classic movie monster with their facial features still clearly recognizable - not a generic monster, but specifically the subject as that creature, with authentic practical effects aesthetic from classic horror cinema.

name: MOVIE POSTER
message:
Take a picture and replace ONE iconic character in a famous movie poster with the subject.

RECAST RULES (CRITICAL):
• ONLY the face is replaced
• Clothing, pose, body, props, and poster layout remain unchanged
• The subject's facial expression MUST match the original character's expression exactly
• Skin tone, lighting, and grain must match the original poster
• Must NOT look pasted or artificial

name: MOVIE SCENE INSERT
message: Take a picture and place the subject inside a cinematic movie scene as if they were an original character in the film. Preserve the subject’s recognizable facial features, body proportions, clothing identity, and personality. Match the exact cinematography of the chosen movie including lens type, depth of field, film grain, color grading, lighting direction, production design, and era-accurate costuming if required. The subject must appear physically present in the scene with correct scale, shadows, reflections, and environmental interaction. The background, props, and atmosphere must be authentic to the movie’s world, making the subject indistinguishable from the original cast and fully integrated into the scene.

name: MOVIE SET REALITY
message: Take a picture and create the scene as a movie set rather than real life. The subject remains realistic and unchanged, but the environment is exposed as a film production: buildings are partially constructed facades, walls end abruptly, lighting rigs, boom mics, cameras, and crew are subtly visible. The sky is a painted or printed backdrop held by scaffolding, scenery is mounted on trusses, and distant landscapes are clearly artificial. Floor markings, cables, and set props are visible. Cinematic lighting, behind-the-scenes realism, playful but believable illusion.

name: MR. POTATO HEAD
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a Mr. Potato Head–style toy.

Convert the subject into a smooth, potato-shaped plastic body with a slightly shiny, molded toy texture. The subject’s original human facial anatomy MUST NOT remain visible. All facial features (eyes, nose, mouth, ears, eyebrows) must be represented ONLY as removable Mr. Potato Head–style toy parts.

Important facial replacement rules:
• REMOVE the subject’s real nose, mouth, eyes, and ears entirely
• REPLACE them with toy-style plug-in parts mounted directly onto the potato surface
• Do NOT allow any human facial features to appear behind or beneath the toy parts
• Ensure correct positioning: the toy nose must sit centered above the toy mouth, with clear separation between parts

Arrange classic Mr. Potato Head components — eyes, eyebrows, nose, mouth, ears, arms, and optional accessories (hat, glasses, mustache) — snapped into visible peg holes or implied mounting points. Parts should feel modular, slightly misaligned, and intentionally toy-like, but never overlapping or duplicated.

Preserve the subject’s identity through:
• eye shape or spacing translated into toy eyes
• mouth expression adapted into a toy mouth
• accessories inspired by the subject (glasses, hat, etc.)

Maintain realistic toy scale, lighting, and soft shadows so the figure appears as a real physical plastic toy photographed in the real world.

Avoid cartoon drawing styles or painterly rendering. This must look like a tangible Mr. Potato Head toy, not an illustration.

Keep the composition clean and centered. Ensure the full toy is visible and clearly readable on small screens. The final image should feel nostalgic, playful, and unmistakably a Mr. Potato Head version of the subject — with no anatomical confusion.

name: MUG SHOT
message:
Take a picture of the subject and transform it into a realistic police-style booking photo (mugshot) without implying any real criminal behavior.

Background and framing: Place the subject against a height measurement wall with clear horizontal lines and markers. Use a neutral institutional backdrop. Camera angle should be straight-on with the subject facing forward in standard mugshot style.

Placard details: The subject holds a board displaying a whimsical ID number and date. Generate humorous or descriptive fictional text inspired by the subject's expression, clothing, or personality (examples: 'Stand-up Philosopher', 'Professional Procrastinator', 'Serial Cereal Eater'). Incorporate any externally provided master prompt text naturally.

Subject appearance: Hair, clothing, and expression may show slight comedic dishevelment or exaggerated personality traits. Expressions can be deadpan, silly, smirking, or exaggeratedly dramatic.

Lighting and quality: Use flat, institutional-style lighting typical of official ID photos, emphasizing facial features and photorealistic depth. Subtle imperfections (slight shadows, mild unevenness) may be included for realism.

The final image should look exactly like a genuine police-style booking photograph, preserving the subject's recognizable face, pose, and expression, but entirely safe, humorous, and fictional.

name: MULTIPLE MATERIALS
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject so that different parts of their body appear as distinct materials.

MATERIAL SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies materials, USE THAT
• If no materials specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE MATERIAL SET using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 5:
  - 0: Head as porcelain, torso as metal, limbs as glass
  - 1: Skin as wood, hair as water, clothing as stone
  - 2: Face as ice, arms as clay, legs as fabric
  - 3: Upper body as leather, lower body as crystal, hands as liquid metal
  - 4: Random combination of natural and artificial materials preserving realistic lighting

IDENTITY RULES:
• Subject remains fully recognizable
• Facial structure and key features preserved
• Material transformation affects only surfaces and textures, not body shape

VISUAL STYLE:
• Photorealistic rendering
• Lighting consistent across all materials
• Seamless integration of differing materials on one subject

FINAL RESULT:
The subject should appear composed of multiple distinct materials, each part realistic and coherent, yet fully recognizable and integrated into a single figure.

name: MULTIPLICITY
message:
Take a picture and transform the scene so the subject appears duplicated multiple times within the same frame.

Create several copies of the subject, each placed naturally into the environment with consistent lighting, scale, and perspective. The duplicates should feel like they coexist in the same moment rather than layered edits.

Each version of the subject should have a slightly different pose, expression, or attitude to suggest personality divergence — for example: confident, confused, bored, overexcited, distracted, or plotting.

Avoid obvious repetition. Vary posture, head tilt, facial expression, or interaction with the environment so each duplicate feels intentional.

Keep the composition readable on a small screen. Ensure no duplicate is cropped or partially hidden. The final image should feel funny, surreal, and immediately understandable — as if reality accidentally made too many copies of the same person.

name: MULTIVERSE
message: Take a picture and create a parallel version of the same subject in a different reality. Parallel version is subtly different in style, clothing, or environment.

name: MUPPET
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a Muppet-style puppet.

The subject must have felt skin, stitched seams, button or googly eyes, and exaggerated puppet proportions.

Include other recognizable Muppets or Sesame Street characters interacting naturally in the scene.

All characters must appear as physical puppets — not costumes or CGI characters.

Lighting should resemble a TV set or puppet stage.

The final image must look like a real behind-the-scenes Muppet production still.

name: MUSEUM EXHIBIT
message: Take a picture and present the subject as a museum exhibit on display. Place the subject behind glass or on a pedestal within a realistic museum gallery environment, with proper lighting, barriers, and signage. Generate an exhibit placard using descriptive or humorous flavor text inspired by the subject’s appearance, clothing, pose, or surroundings, incorporating any externally provided details naturally. The placard should include a title, short description, and optional faux historical or cultural context. Ensure the subject appears seamlessly integrated into the exhibit, with realistic scale, reflections, and museum ambiance. Render the final image photorealistically, as if photographed inside a real museum.

name: MUSICAL MOMENTS
message:
Take a picture of the subject and place them into a scene from a classic movie musical.

MUSICAL SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a musical, USE THAT MUSICAL
• If no musical is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE musical using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 10:
  - 0: Grease
  - 1: Footloose
  - 2: Singin' in the Rain
  - 3: The Sound of Music
  - 4: West Side Story
  - 5: Hairspray
  - 6: La La Land
  - 7: The Wizard of Oz
  - 8: Mary Poppins
  - 9: Chicago

The subject should be actively participating in the musical moment — dancing, singing, or dramatically posing — while fully integrated into the scene with background dancers, instruments, or choreography.

Costumes, props, lighting, and setting should match the original musical style and era.

Optional flavor text from the master prompt can influence the song, scene, or humorous twist (e.g., the subject missing a step, dramatically belting a line, or accidentally knocking over props).

The final image should look like a real movie still from the musical, cinematic, and humorous with the subject as the star.

name: MYSTICAL
message: Take a picture and transform it into a realistic, detailed mystical world, where trees have faces and bioluminescent plants and objects light up.

name: MYTHOLOGY
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a mythological creature while preserving their recognizable identity.

CREATURE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a specific mythological creature, USE THAT CREATURE
• If no creature is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE creature using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 50:
  - 0: Minotaur (human body, bull head/horns, labyrinth/arena, fierce bestial)
  - 1: Centaur (human torso, horse body, forest/plains, noble archer/warrior)
  - 2: Satyr (human upper, goat legs, small horns, forest, mischievous with pan flute)
  - 3: Medusa (human face, snake hair, stone statues nearby, mesmerizing dangerous gaze)
  - 4: Cyclops (giant humanoid, single central eye, massive muscular, cave/forge, imposing)
  - 5: Harpy (human face/torso, bird wings/talons, feathered lower body, mountain cliff, fierce)
  - 6: Siren (beautiful upper body, fish tail, rocks by sea, alluring dangerous)
  - 7: Chimera humanoid (human with lion/goat/serpent features, mixed characteristics, mythical landscape)
  - 8: Valkyrie (warrior woman with wings, Norse armor, battlefield/Valhalla, fierce divine)
  - 9: Dwarf (stout muscular, long beard, underground forge, master craftsman)
  - 10: Frost Giant (large humanoid, ice features, blue-white skin, frozen wasteland, powerful cold)
  - 11: Troll (large brutish, rocky/mossy skin, forest/mountain, primitive strong)
  - 12: Anubis (human body, jackal head, Egyptian garb, temple/tomb, solemn divine)
  - 13: Sphinx (human head, lion body, wings optional, desert pyramid, mysterious wise)
  - 14: Sekhmet (human body, lioness head, Egyptian goddess attire, temple, fierce protective)
  - 15: Sobek (human body, crocodile head, Egyptian priestly garb, Nile River, powerful ancient)
  - 16: Selkie (human with seal characteristics, seal skin nearby, rocky coast, mysterious dual-nature)
  - 17: Banshee (ghostly woman, ethereal features, spectral hair/robes, misty Irish landscape, mournful)
  - 18: Faun (goat legs, small horns, Celtic forest glade, playful nature-connected)
  - 19: Kitsune (human with fox ears/tail(s), Japanese robes, shrine/forest, mischievous intelligent)
  - 20: Tengu (human with bird features, red face, long nose/wings, mountain temple, fierce martial)
  - 21: Naga (human upper, serpent lower body, Southeast Asian jewelry/crown, temple/water, regal)
  - 22: Oni (humanoid demon with horns, red/blue skin, tusks/wild hair, fearsome warrior)
  - 23: Kappa (humanoid turtle-like, shell on back, water dish on head, river/pond, mischievous)
  - 24: Rakshasa (human with tiger/demon features, clawed hands/fangs, Indian palace/jungle, cunning)
  - 25: Garuda (human torso, eagle wings/features, golden plumage, sky/temple, noble powerful)
  - 26: Nagual (human-jaguar hybrid, Aztec warrior attire, jungle temple, fierce shamanic)
  - 27: Quetzalcoatl avatar (human with feathered serpent features, colorful plumage, pyramid temple, divine wise)
  - 28: Leshy (tree-like humanoid, bark skin/branch horns, deep forest, ancient guardian)
  - 29: Vodyanoy (humanoid water creature, aquatic features/green skin, river/swamp, ancient elemental)
  - 30: Djinn (human upper, smoke/mist lower, Arabian attire, desert/lamp, powerful magical)
  - 31: Lamassu (human head, winged bull body, Mesopotamian crown/beard, palace gate, guardian protective)
  - 32: Anansi humanoid (human with spider characteristics, multiple arms/web patterns, African village, clever trickster)
  - 33: Adze (human with firefly/vampire features, glowing elements, night setting, mysterious dangerous)
  - 34: Dryad (human merged with tree, bark skin/leaf hair, forest grove, peaceful nature-connected)
  - 35: Oread (human merged with mountain/stone, rocky features, mountain setting, strong enduring)
  - 36: Griffin humanoid (human with eagle/lion features, wings/talons/leonine, mountain peak, noble guardian)
  - 37: Manticore humanoid (human face, lion body features, scorpion tail, desert/ruins, dangerous exotic)
  - 38: Pegasus merged (human merged with winged horse, wings from back/equine legs, clouds, graceful divine)
  - 39: Cerberus aspect (human with three-headed/multi-headed canine features, underworld gate, guardian fierce)
  - 40: Hydra aspect (human with multiple serpent heads/necks, reptilian features, swamp, regenerative dangerous)
  - 41: Basilisk (human with serpent/rooster features, deadly gaze/reptilian skin, ruins, lethal regal)
  - 42: Phoenix humanoid (human with fiery bird features, flame wings/golden plumage, sky/pyre, rebirth eternal)
  - 43: Golem (human form made of clay/stone, Hebrew inscriptions on forehead, ancient city, powerful protective)
  - 44: Werewolf (human with wolf features, mid-transformation or full wolf form, forest, fierce primal)
  - 45: Dragon humanoid (human with dragon features, scales/wings/horns, mountain lair, powerful ancient)
  - 46: Unicorn humanoid (human with unicorn horn/equine features, magical forest, pure noble)
  - 47: Thunderbird humanoid (human with massive bird wings, Native American styling, storm sky, powerful elemental)
  - 48: Wendigo (human with skeletal/deer features, antlers/emaciated, winter forest, terrifying cursed)
  - 49: Yeti (large humanoid ape-like, white fur, Himalayan mountains, mysterious powerful)

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• Subject becomes selected mythological creature
• Human-creature hybrid or humanoid mythical being
• Subject's facial features and identity preserved
• Photorealistic, epic classical atmosphere
• Tone matches creature's mythology

IDENTITY RULES:
• Subject's face ALWAYS recognizable
• Facial structure and features preserved
• Eyes, nose, mouth clearly the subject's
• Expression matches creature's nature
• No complete replacement with another being
• Subject remains themselves as mythological version

TRANSFORMATION APPROACH:
• Seamless fusion of human and creature
• Creature features integrated naturally
• Maintains human intelligence and expression
• Recognizable as specific mythological being
• Anatomically believable hybrid
• Photorealistic execution

MYTHOLOGICAL SETTING:
• Environment matches creature's origin culture
• Classical or ancient atmosphere
• Epic, legendary mood
• Period-appropriate architecture or landscape
• Mystical or divine lighting
• Authentic cultural details

CLOTHING/ADORNMENTS:
• Matches creature's cultural origin
• Minimal or culturally appropriate
• Jewelry and accessories from mythology
• Armor or robes if appropriate
• Natural elements (fur, feathers, scales)
• Authentic to creature's lore

LIGHTING:
• Epic, dramatic lighting
• Golden hour or mystical glow
• Divine light sources
• Atmospheric, legendary quality
• Emphasizes creature features
• Classical painting inspiration

COLOR PALETTE:
• Rich, saturated classical colors
• Gold, bronze, deep jewel tones
• Natural creature colors
• Mythical atmosphere
• Epic, timeless palette

CAMERA:
• Heroic framing and angle
• Classical composition
• Subject prominently featured
• Environmental context visible
• Epic fantasy film quality

RESTRICTIONS:
• No cartoon or animated style
• No modern elements or anachronisms
• No text overlays or captions
• Subject must remain recognizable
• Respect cultural mythology authentically
• No mixing incompatible mythologies
• Photorealistic, not stylized

FINAL RESULT:
The image should transform the subject into the selected authentic mythological creature while maintaining their recognizable identity. The creature, setting, and atmosphere should reflect genuine mythological traditions from the appropriate culture.

name: N64 BLUR FILTER
message: Take a picture and transform it using a Nintendo 64–style blur and texture smoothing. Apply soft focus, smeared textures, and simplified geometry. Colors should feel slightly muddy but warm. The subject should look nostalgic and dreamlike, as if remembered from an old cartridge game.

name: NAPKIN DOODLE
message:
Take a picture of the subject and transform the scene into a pen doodle drawn on a paper napkin.

The napkin texture must be clearly visible, including folds, creases, embossed patterns, and uneven absorption of ink.

The subject should be drawn using simple, loose pen lines, stick-figure exaggeration, or quick caricature-style sketching.

Include casual doodle elements such as arrows, scribbles, crossed-out lines, coffee stains, or handwritten notes.

DO NOT create clean vector art or realistic shading.

The final image must look like a spontaneous doodle someone drew on a napkin at a restaurant.

name: NATURAL DISASTER
message:
Take a picture and place the subject experiencing a dramatic natural disaster with realistic environmental effects.

DISASTER SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a disaster, USE THAT DISASTER
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 12:
  - 0: Hurricane - violent winds, flying debris, torrential rain, palm trees bending horizontal, storm surge waters
  - 1: Tornado - massive funnel cloud approaching, swirling debris, dark green sky, subject bracing against wind
  - 2: Earthquake - ground splitting and cracking, buildings collapsing, subject losing balance, tilted perspective
  - 3: Tsunami - enormous wave wall approaching shore, subject running/fleeing, boats lifted, coastal destruction
  - 4: Volcano Eruption - lava flows, ash cloud, pyroclastic flow, glowing red magma, volcanic lightning, apocalyptic sky
  - 5: Wildfire - walls of flames, smoke-filled sky, orange glow, firefighting efforts, forest ablaze, embers flying
  - 6: Blizzard - complete whiteout, heavy snow, ice accumulation, subject bundled up, limited visibility, frozen landscape
  - 7: Flood - rising floodwaters, subject on roof or elevated area, submerged vehicles, rescue scenario
  - 8: Avalanche - cascading snow wall, mountain slope, subject attempting to escape, powder cloud, alpine setting
  - 9: Drought - severely cracked dry earth, dead vegetation, scorching sun, barren landscape, water desperation
  - 10: Lightning Storm - multiple lightning strikes, dramatic electrical arcs, storm clouds, subject caught in tempest
  - 11: Landslide - mud and debris flowing down slope, homes being swept away, geological collapse, destructive force

PLACE THE SUBJECT:
• Subject actively experiencing the disaster (not observing from safety)
• Realistic fear, determination, or survival expression
• Weather-appropriate clothing and condition (soaked, windswept, covered in ash/mud)
• Action pose (running, bracing, clinging, seeking shelter)
• Scale showing the enormity of the disaster
• Other people fleeing or responding in background

DISASTER EFFECTS:
• Realistic environmental destruction
• Dynamic weather effects (rain, wind, snow, fire)
• Debris flying or scattering
• Water, mud, lava, or snow in motion
• Atmospheric effects (dark clouds, smoke, ash, mist)
• Lighting appropriate to disaster (dark storm, orange fire glow, lightning flash)

SETTING:
• Environment appropriate to disaster type (coast, forest, mountain, city, plains)
• Buildings, vehicles, or structures being damaged
• Emergency response if appropriate (fire trucks, evacuation)
• Dramatic sky (storm clouds, ash plume, clear drought sky)
• Geographic authenticity

STYLE:
• Photorealistic disaster photography
• News/documentary aesthetic
• Dramatic action movie cinematography
• Natural lighting enhanced by disaster conditions
• Motion blur where appropriate
• Epic scale disaster movie feel

EXPRESSION & BODY LANGUAGE:
• Genuine fear or determination
• Survival instinct visible
• Physical struggle against elements
• Not posed - caught in authentic disaster moment

SAFETY NOTE:
• No actual harm depicted to subject
• Dramatic but not gratuitously violent
• Survival/escape scenario, not injury

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject caught in a dramatic natural disaster with realistic environmental effects, destruction, and atmospheric conditions, captured as if by a news photographer or disaster film cinematographer - intense, dynamic, and emphasizing the raw power of nature.

name: NAZCA LINES
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a massive Nazca Lines geoglyph in the Peruvian desert viewed from directly above. The subject's form should be recreated as an enormous ancient line drawing etched into the desert floor, visible only from aerial view. Use the characteristic Nazca Lines technique: shallow trenches carved into reddish-brown desert surface revealing lighter-colored ground beneath, creating bold continuous lines forming the subject's shape. The design should be simplified and stylized like authentic Nazca geoglyphs - geometric and recognizable but rendered in that distinctive ancient linear style with bold outlines and minimal interior detail. Show the massive scale - the geoglyph should span hundreds of feet across the arid desert plateau. Include authentic Nazca environment: reddish-brown desert soil, surrounding smaller geometric shapes and lines, trapezoids, spirals, and other mysterious markings nearby. Use aerial photography perspective as if photographed from aircraft, showing the Pan-American Highway cutting through the desert, surrounding barren landscape, distant mountains. The lines should appear ancient and weathered - slightly eroded edges, desert patina, centuries of age visible. Include the desert's characteristic patterns - wind-swept sand, sparse vegetation, rocky terrain. Show the mysterious precision of the lines - perfectly straight trenches, smooth curves, intentional design despite ground-level impossibility. Make it look like an actual aerial photograph of an ancient Nazca Lines geoglyph depicting the subject as a mysterious pre-Columbian ground drawing that has survived for over 1,500 years in the Peruvian desert.

name: NEGATIVE SPACE
message: Take a picture and use negative space to define the subject. Primary form emerges from absence rather than detail. Minimalist composition.

name: NEOCLASSICAL
message: Take a picture and transform the image into Neoclassical style painting. Strong lines, realistic proportions, muted colors, classical architecture or drapery elements, and dignified subject presentation.

name: NEOLITHIC CAVE PAINTING
message:
Take a picture and completely transform it into an authentic prehistoric cave painting - the subject and scene must be rendered as actual primitive art painted/drawn on a cave wall by ancient humans.

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• This is NOT a photo with cave painting effects applied
• The subject IS a cave painting - completely transformed into primitive art
• Hand-painted by prehistoric humans on rough stone surface
• Simplified abstracted forms in ochre, charcoal, and natural pigments
• Looks like Lascaux, Altamira, or Chauvet cave paintings

CAVE PAINTING STYLE:
• Subject rendered in simplified primitive style
• Abstracted shapes - not realistic proportions
• Profile view for humans and animals (side-facing)
• Stick figures or simplified body forms for humans
• Stylized animals with characteristic cave art appearance
• Minimal detail - essential forms only
• Flat 2D representation with no perspective
• Handprint stencils possible

PIGMENTS & COLORS:
• Red ochre (iron oxide)
• Yellow ochre
• Black (charcoal or manganese)
• White (kaolin clay or calcite)
• Brown (umber)
• Natural earth tones only
• Limited palette - 3-5 colors maximum
• Pigments appear hand-applied

CAVE WALL SURFACE:
• Rough limestone or sandstone texture
• Bumpy uneven surface
• Cracks and crevices in rock
• Natural stone color (tan, gray, beige) showing through
• Age: 10,000-40,000 years of weathering
• Mineral deposits and calcification
• Slight moisture or dampness suggested
• Torch soot marks possible

PAINTING TECHNIQUE:
• Hand-painted with fingers or primitive brushes
• Blown pigment (spray painting with mouth)
• Charcoal drawing
• Finger painting appearance
• Uneven paint application
• Drips or runs from wet pigment
• Handprints (negative or positive)
• Crude but expressive brushwork

SUBJECT REPRESENTATION:
• Humans as stick figures or simplified forms
• Animals in profile (bison, horses, deer, mammoths)
• Hunting scenes (humans with spears pursuing game)
• Ritual or shamanic imagery
• Geometric symbols (dots, lines, hand stencils)
• Abstract patterns
• No written language - pure pictorial

COMPOSITION:
• Scene painted across cave wall surface
• Multiple figures possible
• Overlapping images from different time periods
• No formal composition - organic placement
• Follows contours of rock surface
• May use natural rock features (bulges become animal bodies)

PREHISTORIC SUBJECTS:
• Paleolithic megafauna (woolly mammoth, cave bear, bison)
• Hunters with spears or atlatls
• Hand stencils (blown pigment around hand)
• Shamanic figures or spirits
• Abstract symbols and dots
• Daily life activities (hunting, gathering)

AGING & WEATHERING:
• Ancient appearance - millennia old
• Faded pigments
• Partial erosion of paint
• Mineral buildup over some areas
• Scratches and damage
• Authentic archaeological appearance

LIGHTING:
• Dim cave interior lighting
• Torch light or firelight (warm flickering)
• Shadows in crevices
• Natural cave darkness
• Pigments visible but muted in low light

AUTHENTICITY:
• Looks like actual prehistoric cave art
• Could be from Lascaux, Altamira, Chauvet caves
• Archaeological accuracy
• No modern elements
• Primitive human artistic expression
• 15,000-35,000 years old appearance

STYLE REFERENCES:
• Lascaux caves (France) - detailed animal paintings
• Altamira caves (Spain) - polychrome bison
• Chauvet Cave (France) - charcoal drawings
• Hands of Patagonia - hand stencils

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject completely transformed into authentic prehistoric cave art - painted in ochre, charcoal, and natural pigments on rough limestone cave wall surface with simplified primitive style, ancient weathering, and the appearance of being hand-painted by Paleolithic humans 20,000+ years ago.

name: NEON SIGN
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a glowing neon sign. Recreate the subject’s silhouette, facial features, and defining characteristics using luminous neon tubing and light trails, while keeping the subject clearly recognizable. Use vibrant neon colors with realistic glow, reflections, and light bleed against a dark or urban-inspired background such as brick, concrete, or night scenery. Arrange the neon lines as if they were hand-bent glass tubes, with subtle imperfections and mounting hardware for realism. Render the final image with crisp detail, strong contrast, and a striking nighttime atmosphere.

name: NESTING DOLLS
message: Take a picture of the subject or subjects and transform them into a set of Russian-style nesting dolls (matryoshka dolls). Each doll should be a carved and painted wooden figure, with the largest on the outside and smaller dolls nested inside. The subject’s facial features must be fully integrated as if hand-painted on the wooden surface — no photographic face overlays, no floating heads. Simplify features in traditional matryoshka style, with decorative clothing and patterns painted onto the wood. Show realistic wood grain, brush strokes, and glossy lacquer finish. Optionally depict dolls partially opened to reveal smaller dolls inside. The final image must look like an actual photograph of real wooden nesting dolls, with the subject’s likeness authentically rendered as painted decoration on the wood.

name: NEWSPAPER
message: Take a picture and Transform the image into a newspaper print. Halftone dots, grayscale ink. Newsprint texture. Include flavor text headline and story text inspired by the content of the image. The result should be a full view of the newspaper page with the newspaper header and date visible with a relevant background behind the newspaper.

name: NIFTY FIFTY
message:
Take a picture and place the subject in a major city representing one of the 50 United States.

STATE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a state, USE THAT STATE
• If no state is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE state using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 50:
  - 0: Alabama (Montgomery/Birmingham - cotton fields, Civil Rights Memorial, state bird: Yellowhammer)
  - 1: Alaska (Anchorage - glaciers, northern lights, grizzly bears, state bird: Willow Ptarmigan)
  - 2: Arizona (Phoenix - Grand Canyon, desert landscape, saguaro cactus, state bird: Cactus Wren)
  - 3: Arkansas (Little Rock - Hot Springs, diamonds, rice fields, state bird: Mockingbird)
  - 4: California (Los Angeles/San Francisco - Golden Gate Bridge, Hollywood sign, redwoods, state animal: Grizzly Bear)
  - 5: Colorado (Denver - Rocky Mountains, skiing, Pikes Peak, state animal: Rocky Mountain Bighorn Sheep)
  - 6: Connecticut (Hartford - Yale, maritime history, autumn leaves, state bird: American Robin)
  - 7: Delaware (Wilmington - First State monument, beaches, state bird: Blue Hen)
  - 8: Florida (Miami/Orlando - beaches, palm trees, Disney, alligators, state animal: Florida Panther)
  - 9: Georgia (Atlanta - peach orchards, Martin Luther King Jr. memorial, state bird: Brown Thrasher)
  - 10: Hawaii (Honolulu - volcanoes, surfing, lei flowers, state bird: Nene goose)
  - 11: Idaho (Boise - potatoes, mountains, skiing, state bird: Mountain Bluebird)
  - 12: Illinois (Chicago - skyscrapers, deep-dish pizza, state bird: Northern Cardinal)
  - 13: Indiana (Indianapolis - racing cars, Indianapolis 500, state bird: Northern Cardinal)
  - 14: Iowa (Des Moines - corn fields, covered bridges, state bird: Eastern Goldfinch)
  - 15: Kansas (Topeka - wheat fields, sunflowers, state bird: Western Meadowlark)
  - 16: Kentucky (Louisville - horse racing, Kentucky Derby, bourbon, state animal: Thoroughbred horse)
  - 17: Louisiana (New Orleans - jazz, Mardi Gras, bayou, state bird: Brown Pelican)
  - 18: Maine (Portland - lighthouses, lobsters, rocky coast, state animal: Moose)
  - 19: Maryland (Baltimore - blue crabs, Chesapeake Bay, state bird: Baltimore Oriole)
  - 20: Massachusetts (Boston - Freedom Trail, Harvard, Revolutionary history, state bird: Black-capped Chickadee)
  - 21: Michigan (Detroit - Great Lakes, automobiles, Mackinac Bridge, state bird: American Robin)
  - 22: Minnesota (Minneapolis - lakes, Vikings, Mall of America, state bird: Common Loon)
  - 23: Mississippi (Jackson - Mississippi River, cotton, blues music, state bird: Mockingbird)
  - 24: Missouri (St. Louis - Gateway Arch, BBQ, state bird: Eastern Bluebird)
  - 25: Montana (Helena - Big Sky, mountains, Glacier National Park, state animal: Grizzly Bear)
  - 26: Nebraska (Omaha - Chimney Rock, cornfields, state bird: Western Meadowlark)
  - 27: Nevada (Las Vegas - casinos, desert, Hoover Dam, state animal: Desert Bighorn Sheep)
  - 28: New Hampshire (Concord - White Mountains, fall foliage, state bird: Purple Finch)
  - 29: New Jersey (Trenton - Atlantic City boardwalk, state bird: Eastern Goldfinch)
  - 30: New Mexico (Santa Fe - adobe architecture, desert, hot air balloons, state bird: Greater Roadrunner)
  - 31: New York (NYC - Statue of Liberty, Empire State Building, Times Square, state bird: Eastern Bluebird)
  - 32: North Carolina (Raleigh - Blue Ridge Mountains, lighthouses, state bird: Northern Cardinal)
  - 33: North Dakota (Bismarck - prairies, Theodore Roosevelt National Park, state bird: Western Meadowlark)
  - 34: Ohio (Columbus - Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, state bird: Northern Cardinal)
  - 35: Oklahoma (Oklahoma City - oil derricks, Route 66, state bird: Scissor-tailed Flycatcher)
  - 36: Oregon (Portland - coast, mountains, Crater Lake, state animal: Beaver)
  - 37: Pennsylvania (Philadelphia - Liberty Bell, Amish country, state animal: White-tailed Deer)
  - 38: Rhode Island (Providence - Newport mansions, beaches, state bird: Rhode Island Red chicken)
  - 39: South Carolina (Charleston - plantations, beaches, Fort Sumter, state bird: Carolina Wren)
  - 40: South Dakota (Pierre - Mount Rushmore, Badlands, state bird: Ring-necked Pheasant)
  - 41: Tennessee (Nashville - country music, Grand Ole Opry, Great Smoky Mountains, state bird: Mockingbird)
  - 42: Texas (Houston/Dallas - cowboys, oil, Alamo, state animal: Longhorn)
  - 43: Utah (Salt Lake City - Mormon Temple, Arches, skiing, state bird: California Gull)
  - 44: Vermont (Montpelier - maple syrup, fall foliage, skiing, state animal: Morgan Horse)
  - 45: Virginia (Richmond - Colonial Williamsburg, Jamestown, state bird: Northern Cardinal)
  - 46: Washington (Seattle - Space Needle, Mount Rainier, coffee, state bird: Willow Goldfinch)
  - 47: West Virginia (Charleston - Appalachian Mountains, coal mining, state animal: Black Bear)
  - 48: Wisconsin (Madison - dairy farms, cheese, Great Lakes, state animal: Badger)
  - 49: Wyoming (Cheyenne - Yellowstone, cowboys, Grand Tetons, state animal: American Bison)

PLACE THE SUBJECT:
• In or near the major city/landmark associated with the selected state
• Doing an activity famous to that state (skiing, surfing, horse racing, etc.)
• Near or holding the state bird or animal (photorealistic, integrated naturally)
• With a famous state monument visible in background
• State flag prominently displayed nearby (on building, flagpole, or held)

STATE MOTTO:
• Add the state's official motto as a small banner/footer in the image
• Styled as vintage americana typography or state seal style
• Readable but not overwhelming the main image

STYLE:
• Photorealistic
• Americana aesthetic - patriotic, proud, celebratory
• Natural lighting appropriate to location
• Subject appears as enthusiastic tourist or proud resident

FINAL RESULT:
The image should look like a vintage travel postcard or state tourism advertisement featuring the subject celebrating that specific state's most iconic elements.

name: NIGHTHAWKS
message:
Take a picture and transform it into the style of Edward Hopper’s painting Nighthawks (1942).

CORE REQUIREMENT:
The subject must REPLACE one of the human figures inside the diner without removing or cropping the rest of the scene.

POSITION LOCK (CRITICAL FIX):
• The subject MUST be located INSIDE the diner interior, behind the glass
• The subject may NOT appear on the sidewalk, street, exterior reflection, or outside the diner
• The subject must occupy the exact spatial position of an original interior figure

SUBJECT INTEGRATION:
• The subject becomes one diner patron or the bartender.
• Preserve Hopper’s original body pose, posture, and placement for that figure.
• Replace only the face (and optionally subtle hands/arms if visible) with the subject’s likeness, adapted to Hopper’s painted anatomy.
• The subject must feel emotionally detached, distant, or introspective.
• Keep the subject naturally integrated, proportionally scaled, and visually coherent with the rest of the figures and environment.

SCENE PRESERVATION (CRITICAL):
• Maintain the full diner interior, including all other patrons, the bartender, furniture, counters, stools, and décor.
• Preserve the exterior street, sidewalk, and urban emptiness visible through the windows.
• Keep all original compositions, geometry, and placement of characters and objects.
• Do NOT remove, crop, or replace any other elements aside from the single figure chosen for substitution.

STYLE & MEDIUM:
• Oil painting on canvas.
• Smooth but visible brushwork.
• Muted, controlled color palette.
• No photographic realism.
• No cartoon stylization.

LIGHTING (CRITICAL):
• Strong interior fluorescent diner light.
• Exterior street remains dark, empty, and quiet.
• Sharp contrast between interior warmth and exterior isolation.

COMPOSITION RULES:
• Preserve the original Nighthawks layout:
 – Corner diner.
 – Large glass windows.
 – Empty street.
• No additional people.
• No modern objects.

EMOTIONAL TONE:
• Loneliness.
• Stillness.
• Urban isolation.
• Suspended time.

ABSOLUTE PROHIBITIONS:
• Do NOT modernize the scene.
• Do NOT add extra figures.
• Do NOT exaggerate expressions.
• Do NOT break Hopper’s geometry.

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like a faithful Hopper oil painting where the subject appears as if they were always part of Nighthawks — quiet, distant, and frozen in time — while the rest of the diner and exterior remain fully intact, unaltered, and visually consistent.

name: NIGHT VISION
message: Take a picture and transform the image into night vision style. Green monochrome, sensor noise.

name: NOT IT!
message:
Take a picture and transform the scene so it appears the subjects are playing the classic game of "Not It."

Analyze the number of visible subjects:
• If multiple subjects are present, show all but one touching their index finger to their nose in a synchronized, quick-reaction pose.
• One subject should clearly be "too late" — their finger either not yet touching their nose, hovering just short, or their hand still moving — making it obvious they are now "it."

Body language and facial expressions are critical:
• The non-it subjects should look relieved, smug, amused, or triumphant.
• The subject who is "it" should look surprised, annoyed, resigned, or caught off-guard.

Ensure everyone remains in the same moment in time, as if the action was frozen immediately after the call of "Not it!" No motion blur — clarity is more important than realism.

Do not add text, arrows, or labels. The concept must be communicated purely through pose, gesture, and expression.

Match lighting, perspective, and scale so the scene feels like a candid photo capturing a spontaneous social moment. Keep the composition readable on a small screen, with all hands and faces clearly visible.

name: NURSERY RHYME STORYBOOK
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into the main character of a classic nursery rhyme. Select the nursery rhyme based on the subject’s appearance, personality, posture, environment, or externally provided instructions.

Examples include, but are not limited to: Jack and Jill (subject as Jack or Jill), Little Miss Muffet (subject as Miss Muffet), Mary Had a Little Lamb (subject as Mary), Humpty Dumpty (subject fully transformed into Humpty), Old MacDonald Had a Farm (subject as Old MacDonald), Row Row Row Your Boat (subject rowing the boat), Jack Be Nimble (subject as Jack), Little Bo Peep (subject as Bo Peep), Little Boy Blue (subject as Little Boy Blue), or similar well-known rhymes.

Transform the subject accordingly so they appear fully integrated into the nursery rhyme world — not posing on top of it. Costumes, props, environment, and proportions should make the subject look like they belong inside the story.

Render the scene in a whimsical, illustrated storybook style with soft colors, painterly textures, gentle lighting, and classic children’s book charm. Avoid modern objects or settings unless intentionally playful.

Include the **title of the nursery rhyme** prominently and clearly at the top or bottom of the image. Display a **short, complete version of the nursery rhyme text** within the scene in large, legible lettering, styled like a storybook page. All text must be fully visible and readable.

The final image should resemble a single open illustrated page from a nursery rhyme book, with the subject and all text fully contained within the frame, suitable for viewing on a small screen. The tone should be magical, nostalgic, and immediately recognizable.

name: NUTCRACKER
message:
Take a picture of the subject and transform them into a classic wooden nutcracker figure.

The subject should appear as a rigid, carved wooden toy with jointed arms, a levered jaw, painted facial features, and a formal or military-style outfit.

Wood grain, paint wear, chips, and glossy varnish should be visible.

The mouth should appear hinged or mechanical, clearly identifying the figure as a nutcracker.

DO NOT make the subject look like a person in costume.

The final image must look like a real physical nutcracker figurine displayed upright.

name: O’KEEFFE
message: Take a picture and reinterpret it in the style of Georgia O’Keeffe. Simplify the subject into flowing organic forms with smooth gradients and soft transitions. Emphasize shape, color, and scale over detail. The final image should feel calm, intimate, and abstracted.

name: OBJECT MOSAIC
message: Take a picture and recreate the subject so that their entire face and body are constructed exclusively from hundreds or thousands of small physical objects such as coins, pennies, jellybeans, M&Ms, bottlecaps, beads, stones, buttons, or similar items. There must be NO visible skin, fabric, or underlying human form anywhere in the image. Every facial feature, contour, shadow, and body shape must be defined only by the placement, color, density, and orientation of the objects. From a distance, the subject must be clearly recognizable; up close, the image must resolve entirely into individual objects. Use realistic lighting, depth, and perspective so the objects cast shadows and feel physically present. Do not overlay or decorate a normal body — the objects themselves ARE the subject.

name: OBJECT WORLD
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a sentient anthropomorphic version of an inanimate object, while converting the entire world into that same type of object. First, determine what object best represents the subject based on their appearance, clothing, or context. The subject becomes that object while retaining their characteristics - their clothing colors/patterns become the object's colors and surface design, any text or logos on their outfit appear as labels or markings on the object, their facial expression translates to the object's 'face' (using natural features of that object type), their body proportions determine the object's shape and size. The entire environment must also be constructed from the same type of object - if subject becomes a car, the world is all cars; if a book, everything is books; if a bottle, all bottles; if furniture, all furniture pieces. Buildings, trees, ground, sky, other people - everything transforms into creative arrangements of that one object type. The objects should have personality and life while remaining recognizable as that object. Use photorealistic rendering with authentic material textures - metal, plastic, wood, glass, fabric depending on object type. Make it look like a parallel universe where this one object type has evolved into an entire functional ecosystem. Preserve the subject's identity through their object-form's unique colors, patterns, markings, and expressive features.

name: OFFSPRING
message:
Take a picture and transform the image into a realistic depiction of a child based on the visible subject(s).

SUBJECT COUNT LOGIC (CRITICAL):
• If TWO subjects are visible:
  – Create ONE child
  – The child’s facial features MUST be a blended combination of BOTH subjects
  – Blend bone structure, eye shape, nose, mouth, and skin tone naturally
  – The result should look like a believable biological child of the two subjects

• If ONLY ONE subject is visible:
  – Transform the subject into a child version of themselves
  – Randomize the child’s sex
  – Randomize the child’s race
  – The result must still feel genetically plausible and human

CHILD AGE RANGE:
• The child must appear between 4 and 8 years old
• Proportions must reflect a real child (larger eyes, softer facial features)

REALISM RULES (CRITICAL):
• Photographic realism
• No cartoon, anime, or stylized rendering
• Natural skin texture and lighting
• No exaggerated or fantasy traits

SAFETY & CONTENT RULES:
• The child must be fully clothed
• Clothing must be age-appropriate and neutral
• No adult themes, poses, or expressions
• Innocent, neutral, or gentle expression only

BACKGROUND HANDLING:
• If possible, keep the original background
• Otherwise, use a simple, realistic environment (studio or everyday setting)

IDENTITY RULES:
• Do NOT add accessories that were not already present unless necessary for realism
• Do NOT add makeup
• Do NOT sexualize or dramatize the subject

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must look like a real photograph of a child — either the believable offspring of two subjects, or a randomized child version of a single subject — natural, respectful, and emotionally neutral.

name: OLD MACDONALD HAD A FARM
message:
Take a picture of the subject and create a photorealistic farm animal whose ORIGINAL ANIMAL HEAD DOES NOT EXIST.

FARM ANIMAL SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a farm animal, USE THAT FARM ANIMAL
• If no farm animal is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE farm animal using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 10:
  - 0: horse
  - 1: pig
  - 2: cow
  - 3: sheep
  - 4: goat
  - 5: chicken
  - 6: rooster
  - 7: duck
  - 8: goose
  - 9: rabbit

COMPLETELY REMOVE THE ANIMAL'S HEAD AND SKULL. The animal's original face, snout, beak, eyes, and mouth must NOT be visible anywhere.
