TEXT REPLACEMENT:
• Detect ALL readable text in the image (signs, labels, packaging, screens, clothing text)
• Replace original text visually with the translated equivalent in the selected conlang
• Match font style, size, orientation, and placement as closely as possible
• Maintain realism — text must appear naturally embedded in the scene

FOOTER REQUIREMENT:
• Add a subtle footer overlay indicating the selected language
• Example: "Language: Klingon" / "Language: High Valyrian"
• Footer must be unobtrusive and professional

IMAGE INTEGRITY:
• Do NOT stylize, cartoon, or alter objects
• Preserve original lighting, perspective, and composition
• Annotations only — no artistic transformation

SETTING & COMPOSITION:
• Maintain original framing
• All labels and replaced text must remain within image bounds
• FULL image visible with all four corners present
• No cropping, zooming, or reframing

STYLE:
• Clean, educational, reference-quality
• Museum placard or fictional-language field guide aesthetic
• High readability with minimal visual clutter

FINAL RESULT:
The image should function as a precise visual translation guide rendered entirely in a fictional constructed language, accurately labeling visible objects and replacing all readable text while preserving the realism and full-frame integrity of the original photo.

name: TRICK OR TREAT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a playful Halloween trick-or-treater.

CORE CONCEPT:
• The subject's HEAD must be preserved and clearly recognizable
• The BODY must be scaled down to the size and proportions of a child
• This is a stylized, humorous proportion shift — NOT realism

SUBJECT TRANSFORMATION:
• Place the subject's head onto a child-sized body
• Head should be slightly oversized relative to the small body for a fun, cartoon-like effect
• Match lighting, angle, and perspective so the head looks naturally attached
• No floating heads or mismatched scale

COSTUME SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a specific costume, USE THAT COSTUME
• If no costume is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE classic Halloween costume using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 10:
  - 0: Witch
  - 1: Vampire
  - 2: Ghost
  - 3: Superhero
  - 4: Monster
  - 5: Zombie
  - 6: Pirate
  - 7: Mummy
  - 8: Skeleton
  - 9: Devil
• Costume must fully cover the child-sized body

COSTUME & PROPS:
• The subject must be holding an orange pumpkin candy pail (jack-o'-lantern style)
• The pose should clearly suggest asking for candy (pail held forward or at waist level)

SCENE & ENVIRONMENT:
• Halloween night setting
• Suburban neighborhood, front porch, or doorway
• Autumn decorations encouraged: pumpkins, porch lights, leaves, spooky décor
• Warm porch lighting or soft night lighting

STYLE & TONE:
• Wholesome, humorous, and playful
• No horror, fear, or menace
• No realism that implies an actual child — this is a stylized character transformation

COMPOSITION RULES:
• Keep the subject centered and clearly visible
• Preserve a full-body view of the child-sized figure
• No cropping that removes the pumpkin pail or costume details

FINAL RESULT:
A fun Halloween image where the subject appears as a trick-or-treater with their recognizable head on a child-sized costumed body, holding a pumpkin candy pail and joyfully asking for candy.

name: TRICORDER
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a Starfleet tricorder display screen showing real-time sensor analysis and data about the subject.

CORE REQUIREMENTS:
• Authentic tricorder interface from Star Trek (TNG/DS9/VOY era preferred)
• Small handheld device screen proportions
• Characteristic blue-green display with gold/orange accents
• Grid-based technical readout aesthetic
• Multiple small data panels and sensor readouts

CONTENT GENERATION:
• Analyze the image subject and generate appropriate tricorder scan data:
  - If person: Life signs, species, vital statistics, bioscan, health status
  - If object: Material composition, energy reading, mass, atomic structure
  - If location: Environmental scan, atmosphere, temperature, radiation, geological data
  - If creature: Xenobiology scan, DNA sequence, threat assessment, behavior patterns
• Use technical flavor text with Star Trek scientific terminology
• Include numeric readouts, waveforms, and scanning graphs
• Add contextual data: scan mode, range, signal strength, accuracy percentage

INTERFACE ELEMENTS:
• Top header with "TRICORDER" and Starfleet insignia
• Small central viewing window showing subject or sensor visualization
• Surrounding data panels with multi-colored status bars
• Waveform displays and oscilloscope-style readings
• Numeric data fields with labels (temperature, pressure, composition, etc.)
• Bottom status bar with scan mode and battery/power level
• Grid lines and technical overlay on subject image
• "SCANNING" or "ANALYSIS COMPLETE" status indicator

STYLE:
• Compact handheld device screen format
• Slightly curved display edges (matching tricorder hardware)
• Backlit blue-green screen with subtle glow
• High-tech but readable 24th-century design
• Small, efficient use of space like a real scanner device
• Subject visible through sensor overlay/scan grid

FINAL RESULT:
A complete, authentic tricorder display showing active sensor analysis of the photographed subject with technical data, vital readings, and Star Trek-appropriate scientific information in the classic handheld scanner format.

name: TROGLODYTE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into an early human ancestor species.

CRITICAL - FACE PRESERVATION:
• Subject's face MUST remain recognizable
• Preserve subject's facial structure, eyes, nose shape, mouth
• Subject's unique features visible through prehistoric transformation
• Hair color and skin tone from original subject maintained
• This is the SUBJECT as a prehistoric human, not a generic caveman
• Apply species features TO the subject's face, don't replace it

SPECIES SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a species, USE THAT SPECIES
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST DIGIT:
  - 0: Homo neanderthalensis - stocky build, prominent brow ridge, receding forehead, large nose, robust frame
  - 1: Homo habilis - smaller brain case, protruding face, ape-like features, early toolmaker
  - 2: Homo erectus - elongated skull, thick brow ridges, flat nose, muscular build, upright posture
  - 3: Homo heidelbergensis - large brow ridge, massive jaw, robust features, large-brained
  - 4: Homo floresiensis - very small stature 'hobbit' (3-4 feet tall), proportionally small brain
  - 5: Denisovans - broad face, large molars, robust features, cold-adapted
  - 6: Homo naledi - small brain, curved fingers, primitive and modern trait mix
  - 7: Australopithecus afarensis - Lucy species, ape-like face, small brain, bipedal
  - 8: Homo antecessor - mix of primitive and modern features, cannibalistic evidence
  - 9: Paranthropus boisei - massive jaw, huge molars, sagittal crest, 'Nutcracker Man'

GENDER-SPECIFIC FEATURES (CRITICAL):

FOR MALE SUBJECTS:
• More pronounced brow ridges (added to subject's existing brow)
• Larger, more robust jaw (subject's jaw made stronger)
• Broader, more muscular build
• Thicker neck and shoulders
• More pronounced facial features
• Heavier bone structure
• More body hair
• Larger hands and feet
• More rugged appearance
• Stronger sagittal crest (if species has one)

FOR FEMALE SUBJECTS:
• LIGHTER brow ridges (enhanced but still subject's brow)
• More DELICATE facial bone structure (subject's face made graceful)
• Smaller, more GRACEFUL jaw (still prehistoric but feminine)
• NARROWER shoulders and frame
• Less muscular build, more slender
• SOFTER facial features within species characteristics
• Less body hair than male counterparts
• Smaller hands and feet
• More FEMININE appearance while still clearly prehistoric
• GENTLER overall features
• Breasts appropriate to prehistoric human anatomy

IMPORTANT: Female prehistoric humans should look distinctly MORE DELICATE and FEMININE than males of the same species while still maintaining the species' characteristic features. The sexual dimorphism should be clearly visible.

TRANSFORMATION FEATURES (Applied TO subject, not replacing):
• ADD brow ridges to subject's existing forehead (heavy for males, lighter for females)
• MODIFY subject's jaw to be more robust (or delicate for females)
• ADJUST subject's nose to species characteristics
• ADD appropriate body hair to subject
• ENHANCE subject's build to be muscular/robust (or slender for females)
• Subject's eyes, eye color, facial proportions PRESERVED
• Subject's hair color maintained (just styled primitively)
• Subject's skin tone preserved (just weathered)
• Subject clearly recognizable as themselves transformed

PRIMITIVE CLOTHING:
• Animal hide wraps and pelts
• Fur clothing (bear, mammoth, deer)
• Leather straps and ties
• Bone ornaments and necklaces
• Shell or tooth jewelry
• Crude belt or waistband
• Minimal clothing appropriate to Stone Age
• Gender-appropriate primitive attire:
  - Males: Animal hide loincloth, fur shoulder wrap
  - Females: Animal hide dress or wrap, more decorative jewelry

PREHISTORIC SETTING:
• Cave entrance or rock shelter
• Rocky outcrop or cliff
• Savanna landscape
• Forest clearing
• Stone tool workshop area
• Campfire scene
• Near water source
• Open grassland

PERIOD ELEMENTS:
• Stone tools (hand axes, scrapers, points)
• Wooden spears or clubs
• Animal bones scattered
• Primitive shelter structure
• Cave paintings on walls in background
• Fire pit with stones
• Animal skins drying
• Primitive food preparation area

BODY CHARACTERISTICS:
• Species-appropriate hair coverage (on subject's body)
• Weathered, sun-exposed skin (subject's skin tone)
• Calloused hands and feet
• Muscular from physical lifestyle (males more so)
• Posture appropriate to species
• Bare feet or primitive footwear
• Natural, unkempt hair (subject's hair color)

LIGHTING:
• Natural outdoor lighting
• Firelight glow
• Dawn or dusk golden hour
• Cave shadows and torch light
• Harsh prehistoric sun
• Dramatic natural lighting

PHOTOGRAPHY STYLE:
• Photorealistic reconstruction
• Museum diorama quality
• Documentary/National Geographic aesthetic
• Scientific accuracy
• Paleoanthropological precision
• Could be from natural history exhibit

SCIENTIFIC LABEL:
• Text label at bottom of image
• Species name in italicized Latin (e.g., *Homo neanderthalensis*)
• Museum placard or documentary style
• Scientific nomenclature format
• Could include time period (e.g., "300,000-30,000 years ago")
• Location if relevant (e.g., "Europe and Western Asia")

ANTHROPOLOGICAL ACCURACY:
• Based on fossil evidence
• Scientifically accurate features
• Correct anatomical proportions for species
• Realistic prehistoric human appearance
• Paleoanthropology research-based
• Could be museum reconstruction

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject - CLEARLY RECOGNIZABLE with their own face, eyes, and features - transformed into a scientifically accurate early human ancestor with species-specific anatomical features added to their existing face and body, with CLEAR GENDER DIFFERENCES (males more robust, females more delicate), dressed in primitive Stone Age clothing, in a prehistoric setting with period-appropriate elements and natural lighting, complete with a scientific label - appearing as a photorealistic paleoanthropological reconstruction where you can definitively say 'that's [subject's name] as a Neanderthal.'

name: TRON
message: Take a picture and place the subject inside the digital world of Tron. Show them either riding a light cycle leaving glowing trails of neon light behind them as they race across the game grid, or participating in the disc battle game throwing and catching glowing identity discs. The subject should wear the iconic Tron suit with glowing circuit patterns - black suit with bright neon blue, orange, or white illuminated lines tracing across the body and helmet. The environment should be the dark geometric game grid with glowing floor lines, dramatic perspective, and that distinctive early CGI aesthetic. Use heavy contrast between deep blacks and vibrant neon colors. Include motion blur on light trails, reflective surfaces, and the surreal digital atmosphere of the Grid. Make it look like the subject is actually inside the Tron movie universe in an intense action moment.

name: TV DRAMA
message: Take a picture and place the subject into a famous dramatic television series scene. Preserve the subject’s facial features, expressions, and clothing while adapting them to the television drama style. Include cinematic lighting, moody atmosphere, and emotionally charged interactions with other characters or surroundings. The composition should convey tension, suspense, or deep narrative context, fully integrating the subject into the dramatic storyline of the show.

name: TV GAME SHOW
message: Take a picture and place the subject into a famous television game show set. Preserve the subject’s facial features, personality, and clothing while transforming them into a contestant or host in the game show style. Include colorful set design, bright stage lighting, game props, podiums, or audience elements. Convey excitement, engagement, and fun, fully integrating the subject into the lively, competitive environment of the television show.

name: TV SITCOM
message: Take a picture and place the subject into a famous television sitcom scene. Preserve the subject’s facial features, personality, and clothing while adapting them to the sitcom style. Include bright, cheerful lighting, a recognizable multi-camera set or typical sitcom living room, and humorous interactions with other characters or props. Ensure the scene conveys comedic timing, lightheartedness, and laugh-track energy, fully integrating the subject into the television comedy environment.

name: TWINS
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into realistic conjoined (Siamese) twins — two fully formed human heads and upper bodies joined together in a biologically plausible way.

CONJOINED TYPE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a conjoined type, USE THAT TYPE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY — you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST DIGIT modulo 4:
  - 0: Side-by-Side Torso — two heads and upper bodies sharing a single widened torso
  - 1: Shoulder Conjoined — twins joined at the shoulder and upper rib area
  - 2: Upper Torso Split — two distinct upper bodies merging into a shared lower body
  - 3: Chest Conjoined — twins joined at the chest with closely aligned shoulders

TRANSFORM THE SUBJECT:
• Both twins must clearly resemble the original subject
• Facial features should be nearly identical but not perfectly mirrored
• Subtle natural variation in expression, posture, or gaze
• No exaggerated symmetry
• Gender-neutral presentation
• No caricature or surreal distortion

BODY & ANATOMY REQUIREMENTS:
• Anatomically plausible human proportions
• Smooth, natural skin transitions at the point of connection
• No visible seams, stitching, or unnatural blending
• No exposed organs, blood, or graphic elements
• Realistic muscle, bone, and posture alignment

CLOTHING & STYLING (CRITICAL):
• Clothing must be realistically adapted for conjoined bodies
• Garments should appear custom-tailored or shared naturally
• Fabric must drape correctly across both bodies
• No duplicated or clipped clothing
• Patterns, seams, and folds must align naturally

STYLE & TONE:
• Photorealistic
• Serious, respectful presentation
• Subtle uncanny realism rather than shock
• Looks like a real photograph of conjoined twins
• No fantasy, horror, or cartoon styling

SETTING & COMPOSITION:
• Subject fully visible from top to bottom
• Entire conjoined form must fit within the frame
• FULL image visible with all four corners present
• No cropping of heads, limbs, or clothing
• Neutral or everyday environment preferred

IMAGE INTEGRITY:
• Lighting, shadows, and perspective must be consistent
• Skin tone and texture must match across both twins
• No obvious digital manipulation artifacts
• Transformation should feel physically possible

FINAL RESULT:
The image should convincingly depict the subject as realistic conjoined twins — anatomically plausible, respectfully presented, and visually seamless — with natural body integration, properly adapted clothing, and full-body framing that makes the transformation appear completely real.

name: TYPICAL TOURIST
message: Take a picture and place the subject in front of a randomly selected famous world landmark using classic forced-perspective tourist photography. The subject is intentionally interacting with the landmark through optical illusion—such as pinching it between their fingers, holding it up, pushing it, leaning against it, or framing it with their hands—while maintaining realistic scale and perspective from the camera’s point of view. Preserve the subject’s recognizable facial features, proportions, and identity. Carefully match camera angle, focal length, lighting direction, shadows, depth of field, and atmospheric perspective so the illusion feels natural and intentional rather than composited. The subject’s pose, hand placement, and eye line must align perfectly with the landmark to sell the visual trick. Capture the moment as if snapped at the exact perfect second. Render the final image with photorealistic travel-photo realism, playful humor, and precise forced-perspective accuracy.

name: UK POSTER ART 1930s
message: Take a picture and transform the image into a 1930s British travel poster style art. Simplified shapes, bold typography, stylized landscapes, and clean graphic composition.

name: UNCLE SAM
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into Uncle Sam as seen in a classic wartime recruitment poster.

CORE REQUIREMENT (CRITICAL):
• The subject must appear to be the original illustrated model for Uncle Sam
• The face must be fully redrawn in illustration form — not replaced or composited

ANTI-PHOTOSHOP RULE (CRITICAL):
• Do NOT paste or overlay the subject’s face onto an existing illustration
• Reconstruct Uncle Sam’s face from scratch using the subject’s facial structure
• The result must look hand-illustrated, not edited

HAIR & FACIAL HAIR INTEGRATION (CRITICAL):
• Uncle Sam’s hair and facial hair MUST inherit the subject’s natural hair color
• Do NOT default to white hair or beard unless the subject already has white or gray hair
• Hair texture and color must match the subject’s age and appearance
• Facial hair must be illustrated to match the subject, not the archetype

FACIAL INTEGRATION (CRITICAL):
• Translate the subject’s facial features into vintage poster illustration style
• Match original linework, shading, and ink density
• Skin must appear painted or lithographed
• No photographic lighting, pores, or smooth gradients

STYLE & MEDIUM:
• Early 20th-century illustration / lithograph
• Slightly aged paper texture
• Muted reds, blues, and off-whites
• Period-accurate ink imperfections

COMPOSITION & TEXT:
• Preserve the iconic pointing pose and gaze
• Preserve classic typography and layout
• No modern design elements

TONE:
• Serious, authoritative, and patriotic
• No parody or humor

FINAL RESULT:
A fully convincing wartime Uncle Sam poster where the subject clearly appears to have been illustrated as Uncle Sam from the beginning — including hair and facial hair that naturally match the subject rather than the archetype.

name: UNDER THE SEA
message: Take a picture and place the subject underwater in a natural ocean environment. The subject is wearing streamlined, sport-style swimwear suitable for ocean swimming, styled realistically for an underwater setting. Create a photorealistic underwater seascape capturing the beauty of the ocean depths. Include coral reefs, exotic fish, and aquatic plants, with sunlight filtering through the water to create dramatic lighting and rich color variation. Emphasize realism, scale, and natural movement in the water.

name: UNIFORMED
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into an employee wearing the distinctive uniform and attire of a specific company or brand.

COMPANY SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a company, USE THAT COMPANY
• If no company is provided, SELECT EXACTLY ONE company using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 35:
  - 0: McDonald's crew member (red/yellow polo, visor, name tag)
  - 1: Hooters waitress (orange shorts, white tank top, pantyhose, sneakers)
  - 2: UPS driver (brown uniform, shorts, brown cap, clipboard)
  - 3: FedEx courier (purple/orange uniform, cap, handheld scanner)
  - 4: Domino's Pizza delivery driver (blue/red polo, cap, pizza bag)
  - 5: Apple Store employee (blue shirt, lanyard, AirPods, tablet)
  - 6: Best Buy Geek Squad (black/white uniform, clip-on tie, badge)
  - 7: Starbucks barista (green apron, black shirt, visor, name tag)
  - 8: USPS mail carrier (blue uniform, pith helmet, mail bag)
  - 9: Burger King crew member (brown/beige uniform, crown logo cap)
  - 10: Foot Locker employee (black/white referee shirt, whistle, clipboard)
  - 11: Dunkin' Donuts worker (pink/orange uniform, visor, apron)
  - 12: Disney cast member (themed costume depending on park area, name tag)
  - 13: KFC employee (red/white striped uniform, colonel bow tie, cap)
  - 14: In-N-Out Burger associate (white uniform, red apron, paper hat)
  - 15: Target team member (red polo, khakis, name tag, walkie-talkie)
  - 16: Chick-fil-A team member (red polo, black pants, visor, apron)
  - 17: Costco employee (blue vest over polo, name tag, scanner gun)
  - 18: Sonic Drive-In carhop (retro uniform, roller skates, tray)
  - 19: Home Depot associate (orange apron, tool belt, name tag)
  - 20: Subway sandwich artist (green/yellow uniform, visor, gloves)
  - 21: Waffle House server (black uniform, yellow name tag, order pad)
  - 22: Buc-ee's team member (red shirt, khaki shorts, beaver logo cap)
  - 23: Wendy's crew member (black/red uniform, striped shirt, visor)
  - 24: Taco Bell employee (purple/black uniform, name tag, headset)
  - 25: AMC Theatres usher (red vest, black shirt, bow tie, flashlight)
  - 26: Panera Bread associate (green apron, black shirt, name tag)
  - 27: GameStop employee (black polo with logo, khakis, lanyard)
  - 28: CVS pharmacy technician (red smock, name tag, scanner)
  - 29: Jiffy Lube technician (blue coveralls, oil-stained, cap, rag)
  - 30: Pizza Hut server (red polo, black pants, Pizza Hut cap, order pad)
  - 31: Nando's Chicken employee (black shirt, red apron, Nando's logo, peri-peri bottle)
  - 32: Qantas flight attendant 1974 uniform (retro orange/red dress or suit, neck scarf, winged pin)
  - 33: Center Parcs staff (green polo, khaki pants, outdoor/resort setting)
  - 34: Progressive Insurance Flo (white apron, headband, red lipstick, name tag, retro style)

UNIFORM ACCURACY (CRITICAL):
• Research and match the EXACT current uniform design for the selected company
• Include all standard uniform components:
  - Shirts/polos with correct colors and logos
  - Pants/shorts in company-specified style and color
  - Hats, visors, or hair nets as required
  - Aprons if applicable
  - Name tags in correct position and style
  - Company-specific accessories (lanyards, badges, tools)
• Logo placement must be accurate (chest, shoulder, cap, etc.)
• Colors must match official brand guidelines precisely
• Fabric textures should be realistic (polyester, cotton, twill)
• Show appropriate wear and cleanliness for the job type

WORKPLACE CONTEXT:
• Place subject in appropriate work environment:
  - Fast food: behind counter, near register, holding food items
  - Retail: on sales floor, near products, helping customers
  - Delivery: next to vehicle, holding packages, at doorstep
  - Service: with appropriate tools and equipment for the role
  - Airlines: in aircraft cabin or airport terminal
  - Resort/hospitality: outdoor recreation or guest service areas
• Include relevant props and accessories:
  - Order pads, tablets, scanners, clipboards
  - Food items, products, or packages appropriate to company
  - Tools of the trade (mops, wrenches, measuring tapes)
  - Company-branded equipment (bags, boxes, carts)
  - Aviation items (meal cart, safety demonstration card)
  - Insurance/sales materials (brochures, rate cards)
• Background should show recognizable elements:
  - Store signage, logos, and branding
  - Product displays or service areas
  - Company vehicles if applicable
  - Interior design matching corporate aesthetic
  - Aircraft interior for flight crew
  - Insurance office setting with retro styling

BODY LANGUAGE AND POSE:
• Subject should appear as a genuine employee:
  - Natural work posture (standing at register, walking with purpose)
  - Appropriate facial expression (friendly customer service smile, focused concentration)
  - Hands engaged in relevant tasks (holding items, gesturing, working)
  - Confident but approachable demeanor
• Avoid overly posed or theatrical positioning
• Should look like a candid workplace photo or training material
• Employee should appear competent and professional

DETAIL AND AUTHENTICITY:
• Name tags should have realistic names (or blur/generic text)
• Uniforms should show realistic fit and draping
• Include minor details: pens in pockets, headset wires, stains if appropriate
• Shoes should match company requirements (non-slip, specific colors)
• Hair should be styled according to company standards (net, pulled back, etc.)
• Visible ID badges, security tags, or access cards if applicable
• Time clocks, schedules, or employee notices visible in background
• Other employees or customers may be present but blurred in background

LIGHTING AND PHOTOGRAPHY STYLE:
• Workplace fluorescent or LED lighting
• Slightly institutional feel but well-lit
• Colors should be accurate but not oversaturated
• Depth of field keeps focus on subject but shows environment
• Documentary or corporate photography aesthetic
• Not glamorous—realistic workplace conditions
• May include slight graininess or security camera quality if appropriate
• Exception: Qantas 1974 should have vintage film photography look
• Exception: Progressive Flo should have bright commercial advertising lighting

COMPANY-SPECIFIC DETAILS:
• McDonald's: golden arches visible, red and yellow everywhere, cleaning cloth in belt
• Hooters: classic orange and white, wings and beer in background
• UPS: brown everything, package cart nearby, delivery route sheet
• Apple: minimalist clean store, products on tables, other employees helping customers
• Geek Squad: black VW Beetle or tech bench in background, computer equipment
• Disney: specific land theming (Tomorrowland futuristic, Frontierland western)
• Pizza Hut: red roof logo visible, pizza box in hand, dine-in restaurant setting
• Nando's: flame-grilled chicken visible, peri-peri sauce bottles, Portuguese-African decor
• Qantas 1974: retro aircraft interior, vintage grooming standards, winged badge pin
• Center Parcs: forest/woodland resort background, bikes or outdoor equipment
• Progressive Flo: retro name tag holder, white kiosk background, enthusiastic pose
• Fast food chains: menu boards, food warmers, drink dispensers visible
• Delivery services: vehicle with company logo, packages stacked, handheld device

FINAL RESULT:
A completely believable workplace photograph where the subject appears as a genuine employee of the specified company, wearing an accurate and detailed uniform in an authentic work environment. The image should look like it could be from employee training materials, a corporate website, or a realistic workplace documentary. Every detail—from uniform accuracy to environmental context—reinforces the subject's new identity as a working member of that company's team.

name: UNKEMPT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into someone who needs grooming, with visible (but not exaggerated) signs of neglected personal maintenance.

GENDER-SPECIFIC GROOMING ISSUES:

FOR MALE SUBJECTS:
• If clean-shaven: Add realistic stubble or 5 o'clock shadow (NOT a full beard, just visible unshaven growth)
• If bearded: Make existing beard scraggly, patchy, unkempt, uneven
• Nose hair: Visible protruding from nostrils (realistic length, not exaggerated cartoon style)
• Ear hair: Visible tufts growing from ear openings (realistic, not excessive)
• Eyebrows: Bushy and slightly unkempt, maybe some wild hairs, possibly starting to connect (mild unibrow)
• Head hair: Messy, needs a cut, possibly greasy or disheveled

FOR FEMALE SUBJECTS:
• Nose hair: Slightly visible (realistic, subtle)
• Eyebrows: Unkempt, not plucked/shaped, some stray hairs, natural growth
• Facial hair: Subtle upper lip or chin hair visible (realistic peach fuzz or light hair growth)
• Head hair: Messy, frizzy, greasy, needs washing and styling
• Makeup: Either badly applied (smudged, uneven, wrong colors) OR completely removed showing natural ungroomed appearance
• Focus on realistic unglamorous appearance without makeup

GROOMING ISSUES (CRITICAL - NOT EXAGGERATED):
• Hair growth VISIBLE but REALISTIC
• Nose hair: Few visible hairs, not giant tufts
• Ear hair: Some visible growth, not huge bushes
• Eyebrows: Bushy but believable
• Stubble: Realistic 1-3 day growth
• NO cartoon exaggeration
• NO comically oversized features
• Looks like actual person who skipped grooming

HAIR CHARACTERISTICS:
• Slightly oily or greasy appearance
• Messy, uncombed, disheveled
• Needs a trim or cut
• Possibly some dandruff visible
• Natural texture emphasized (frizz, cowlicks)
• Not styled or maintained

FACIAL APPEARANCE:
• Tired or disheveled look
• Possibly dark circles under eyes
• Skin may look slightly oily or dull
• Natural blemishes not concealed
• Un-groomed natural state

EXPRESSION OPTIONS:
• Neutral, unaware of grooming issues
• Tired, just woke up
• Casual, comfortable
• Could even look proud or confident (making the unkemptness more humorous)
• NOT embarrassed - that's what makes it funny

REALISM (CRITICAL):
• Photorealistic - must look like actual photograph
• NOT a cartoon or illustration
• Believable grooming neglect
• Could be someone you'd actually see
• Exaggeration is SUBTLE, not cartoonish
• Natural appearance, just unkempt

CLOTHING & OVERALL APPEARANCE:
• Clothing may be wrinkled or casual
• Overall slightly disheveled appearance
• Not homeless - just needs grooming
• Otherwise normal person with grooming neglect

HUMOR APPROACH:
• Funny because it's relatable and realistic
• NOT funny because it's grotesque
• Everyday grooming failures
• Natural human appearance without maintenance
• Subject appears oblivious or unconcerned

PRESERVE IDENTITY:
• Subject's face clearly recognizable
• Facial structure unchanged
• Only grooming elements altered
• Features remain proportional
• No distortion, just added realistic hair growth

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject with realistic visible signs of grooming neglect - subtle stubble (if male and clean-shaven), visible but not exaggerated nose/ear hair, bushy eyebrows, messy hair, and (for women) either bad makeup or natural unglamorous appearance with subtle facial hair - all photorealistic and believable, funny because it's relatable not because it's grotesque.

FINAL RESULT:
The image must look like a real travel photograph taken at a famous U.S. National Park landmark.

name: VACATION
message: Take a picture and have the subject standing in the middle of a CITY street somewhere in the world, with iconic and easily recognizable landmarks from that CITY in the background. The scene should capture the CITY life, detailed architecture, and natural lighting, with the person dressed in modern casual clothing, blending naturally into the environment. Make it photorealistic. 8k resolution.

name: VALENTINE
message: Take a picture and frame the subject inside a visually prominent heart shape. Create a romantic Valentine’s Day–themed scene with warm colors, soft lighting, and gentle decorative elements. Extract subtle flavor text and inspiration from the subject’s appearance, expression, clothing, and surroundings to generate a heartfelt Valentine’s Day poem. Display the complete poem clearly and fully within the image, ensuring all lines are legible and unobstructed. Integrate the poem naturally into the composition, such as on a decorative card, ribbon, or elegant text panel, while keeping the subject as the central focus. Render the final image with polished, high-quality detail.

name: VAMPIRE
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a realistic vampire while preserving the subject’s recognizable facial structure, body proportions, and identity. Subtly enhance features with pale, luminous skin, sharp yet refined fangs, intense eyes, and an elegant, supernatural presence. Adapt the subject’s clothing to a dark, timeless vampire aesthetic while maintaining their original style and personality. Place the subject naturally into a moody, atmospheric environment such as a gothic interior, moonlit street, or candlelit chamber. Use cinematic lighting, deep shadows, and rich textures to create a seductive, mysterious tone. Ensure the subject appears fully integrated into the scene and render the final image in photorealistic detail with depth, realism, and supernatural elegance.

name: VAN GOGH
message: Take a picture and transform it into a painted scene inspired by Vincent van Gogh. Preserve the photographic composition but reinterpret it using bold, swirling brushstrokes, thick paint texture, and expressive movement. Use vivid blues, yellows, and greens with visible directional strokes. The subject should remain clearly recognizable while the surrounding scene feels alive with motion and emotion.

name: VAPORWAVE
message: Take a picture and style it as if it were a retro-futuristic vaporwave album cover. Dreamy neon colors, glitchy textures, and retro-futuristic vibes. Inspired by 90s aesthetics and early internet culture, giving the photo a surreal, nostalgic feel, like a lost scene from an old VHS tape or a synthwave album cover.

name: VEGAS NEON SIGN
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a large, spectacular neon sign mounted on the side of a Las Vegas casino building.

The subject's image should be converted into glowing neon tubing and illuminated sign elements. Their facial features, silhouette, and recognizable characteristics should be rendered using bright neon tubes in classic Vegas colors - hot pink, electric blue, bright red, golden yellow, vibrant purple, lime green.

Sign construction details: The neon should have realistic glass tube appearance with visible glowing gas, support brackets and framework visible, bulb marquee borders surrounding the main image, animated chasing lights or blinking elements, possibly text above or below saying the subject's name in classic Vegas marquee lettering.

Mount the sign prominently on the side of an authentic Las Vegas casino building - art deco or mid-century modern architecture, visible in evening or night setting. Include surrounding Vegas context: other neon signs visible in background, palm trees, busy street below with car light trails, other casinos in distance.

Lighting and atmosphere: The scene should be photographed at dusk or night when neon is most vibrant. The sign should be the brightest element, casting colorful glow on the building facade. Include atmospheric haze or slight blur to enhance the neon glow effect. Light from the sign should reflect on surrounding surfaces.

Scale: The sign should be LARGE - multiple stories tall on the casino building, dominating the facade, visible from far away. The subject's neon portrait should be the centerpiece of an elaborate sign display.

The final image should look like an actual photograph of a real Las Vegas casino with this spectacular custom neon sign installation, capturing the over-the-top glitz, glamour, and bright electric energy of classic Vegas signage. Photorealistic rendering with authentic neon glow, proper scale, and vintage Vegas atmosphere.

name: VEHICLE TIME SHIFT
message: Take a picture and identify the vehicle in the image, then transform it to a different era version of the same make and model while keeping everything else identical. If the vehicle is modern, transform it to a classic vintage version from the 1950s-1970s. If the vehicle is vintage/classic, transform it to the modern current version. Examples: 2024 Ford Mustang becomes 1967 Ford Mustang; 1965 VW Beetle becomes 2024 VW Beetle; 1963 Corvette becomes 2024 Corvette; modern Porsche 911 becomes 1970s Porsche 911; classic Bronco becomes modern Bronco. CRITICAL: Preserve exactly the same color, license plate number, location, background, lighting, angle, and any damage or modifications - ONLY change the body style, design elements, and year-specific features of that vehicle model. Keep wheels/rims in period-appropriate style for the new era. Maintain any custom details like racing stripes, decals, or accessories but update them to match the era shift. The transformation should be seamless - same car in same spot with same paint, just from a different decade. Update headlights, grille, body lines, bumpers, and trim to match the target era's authentic factory design for that specific make and model. Make it photorealistic as if this exact car (same color, same plate, same location) is simply from a different generation of that vehicle line.

name: VENDING MACHINE ITEM R1
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a novelty vending machine product. The subject should appear as a toy, figurine, or packaged novelty item clearly designed to be sold.

Place the product inside a vending machine slot behind glass. Show spiral coils, price tags without readable text, glass reflections, and interior vending machine lighting. The subject should appear scaled appropriately to fit the slot as a product, not as a real person.

Ensure the scene reads as playful and humorous, like a novelty item for sale, with the vending machine fully visible and the product clearly displayed inside.

name: VENTRILOQUIST DUMMY
message:
Take a picture of the subject and transform them into a classic ventriloquist dummy.

The subject should look like a wooden puppet version of themselves, with a glossy painted face, carved features, and a hinged jaw line.

Give them slightly exaggerated eyes, a stiff posture, and a stylized puppet outfit such as a suit, bow tie, or dress.

The wood texture, joint seams, and mouth hinge should be clearly visible so it unmistakably looks like a ventriloquist dummy.

The final image should look like a lifelike puppet replica of the subject, humorous, eerie, and unmistakably artificial.

name: VHS 80s
message: Take a picture and transform the image into 1980s VHS footage. Soft focus, scanlines, color bleed, timestamp artifacts. Analog nostalgia aesthetic.

name: VICTORIA'S COMMON KNOWLEDGE RUNWAY
message: Take a picture of the subject and transform them into a glamorous runway model in an extravagant fashion show. The subject should be walking confidently down a runway wearing over-the-top, flamboyant outfits — dramatic capes, feathered costumes, oversized hats, sparkling accessories, or theatrical fashion pieces. Include dramatic runway lighting, photographers, flashing cameras, and a cheering audience. The subject’s pose, facial expression, and stride should be exaggerated and confident, capturing the flair and drama of a live fashion show. Optional flavor text from the master prompt can influence the costume style or theme. The final image should look like a high-fashion runway photo shoot — realistic lighting, shadows, and perspective — but humorous if desired by exaggerating poses, outfit size, or runway theatrics.

name: VICTORIAN ENGRAVING
message: Take a picture and transform the image into a Victorian engraving. Fine linework, cross-hatching, monochrome or sepia tones, and antique print texture.

name: VICTORIAN PHOTO
message: Take a picture in the style of a Vintage photo of a Victorian family. Sepia tones, period attire.

name: VIDEO GAME AVATAR
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into an iconic video game character while preserving recognizable features.

GAME CHARACTER SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a character, USE THAT CHARACTER
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST TWO DIGITS modulo 25:
  - 0: Mario - red cap with M, blue overalls, brown shoes, iconic mustache, Mushroom Kingdom background, jumping pose
  - 1: Sonic the Hedgehog - blue spiky hair, red shoes, white gloves, speed blur, Green Hill Zone, rings
  - 2: Lara Croft - dual pistols, tank top, shorts, holsters, tomb raiding, archaeological adventure
  - 3: Master Chief - full Spartan armor helmet and suit, visor, Halo ring background, futuristic military
  - 4: Pac-Man - round yellow shape with wedge mouth, dots, ghosts, maze, 8-bit aesthetic
  - 5: Link (Zelda) - green tunic, pointed hat, Master Sword, Hylian Shield, Triforce, Hyrule landscape
  - 6: Donkey Kong - brown gorilla, red tie, barrels, construction site, climbing girders
  - 7: Street Fighter Character - fighting stance, special move energy, vs. screen, health bar, martial arts attire
  - 8: Minecraft Steve - blocky cubic head and body, pixelated, holding pickaxe, cubic world
  - 9: Pikachu (Pokémon) - yellow electric mouse, red cheeks, lightning bolt tail, Poké Ball
  - 10: Mortal Kombat Fighter - martial arts costume, tournament stage, "FIGHT!" energy
  - 11: Samus Aran - Power Suit armor, arm cannon, Metroid atmosphere, space bounty hunter
  - 12: Mega Man - blue armor, arm cannon, robot aesthetic, Dr. Wily's fortress
  - 13: Solid Snake - stealth suit, bandana, cardboard box, Metal Gear, tactical espionage
  - 14: Crash Bandicoot - orange marsupial, spinning, Wumpa fruit, island adventure
  - 15: Spyro the Dragon - purple dragon, fire breath, gems, fantasy realm
  - 16: Kratos (God of War) - red war paint, Blades of Chaos, muscular, Greek mythology
  - 17: Ryu (Street Fighter) - white gi, red headband, hadouken pose, martial artist
  - 18: Chun-Li - blue qipao dress, spiked bracelets, ox horns hairstyle, powerful legs
  - 19: Sackboy (LittleBigPlanet) - burlap sack texture, button eyes, zipper mouth, craft aesthetic
  - 20: Kirby - pink round puffball, simple face, Dream Land, floating
  - 21: Fox McCloud (Star Fox) - pilot suit, Arwing cockpit, space combat
  - 22: Cloud Strife (FF7) - spiky blonde hair, Buster Sword, SOLDIER uniform
  - 23: Ratchet & Clank - lombax with wrench, robot companion, sci-fi weapons
  - 24: Nathan Drake (Uncharted) - treasure hunter, holster, climbing gear, adventurer

TRANSFORM THE SUBJECT:
• Subject's face MUST remain recognizable within the character design
• Match exact art style of the game (pixelated, cel-shaded, realistic, cartoon)
• Preserve subject's facial features adapted to game's art style
• Body transformed to character proportions but face stays identifiable
• Animation-ready pose characteristic of that character

GAME WORLD INTEGRATION:
• Setting authentic to that video game universe
• Background, props, effects match the game exactly
• UI elements if appropriate (health bar, score, HUD)
• Correct camera perspective for that game type
• Environmental interaction (standing on platform, in battle, exploring)

ART STYLE MATCHING:
• 8-bit pixel art for retro games (Pac-Man, early Mario)
• 16-bit sprite style for SNES era
• Polygonal for N64/PS1 era
• Cell-shaded for Wind Waker, Borderlands style
• Realistic for modern AAA titles
• Blocky for Minecraft
• Match lighting and rendering of original game

CHARACTER ELEMENTS:
• Signature costume/outfit
• Iconic weapons or items
• Character-specific pose or action
• Powers or abilities visualized
• Color palette accurate

STYLE:
• Subject looks NATIVELY integrated - not composited
• Correct proportions for game type
• Game's graphics quality (retro low-poly or modern high-fidelity)
• In-game screenshot aesthetic
• Character selection screen OR gameplay moment

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject transformed into the iconic video game character with their facial features recognizable but adapted to the game's art style, appearing as if they are genuinely that character rendered in that game's engine and world.

name: VIDEO GAME COVER ART
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into video game cover art, showing the complete retail packaging with the subject integrated into iconic cover artwork.

GAME SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a game, USE THAT GAME
• If no game is provided, SELECT EXACTLY ONE game using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 50:
  - 0: Super Mario Bros. (NES, 1985) - Mario jumping, brick background
  - 1: The Legend of Zelda (NES, 1986) - Link with sword and shield, gold cartridge
  - 2: Pac-Man (Atari 2600, 1982) - yellow Pac-Man and ghosts
  - 3: Donkey Kong (Arcade/NES, 1981) - Mario climbing, Donkey Kong at top
  - 4: Street Fighter II (SNES, 1992) - Ryu and fighters collage
  - 5: Mortal Kombat (Genesis, 1993) - fighting characters, dragon logo
  - 6: Sonic the Hedgehog (Genesis, 1991) - Sonic running, checkered background
  - 7: Final Fantasy VII (PS1, 1997) - Cloud with Buster Sword, Midgar
  - 8: Metal Gear Solid (PS1, 1998) - Solid Snake portrait
  - 9: Halo: Combat Evolved (Xbox, 2001) - Master Chief with assault rifle
  - 10: Grand Theft Auto: Vice City (PS2, 2002) - Miami Vice aesthetic, palm trees
  - 11: The Sims (PC, 2000) - plumbob diamond and character
  - 12: Resident Evil (PS1, 1996) - horror mansion, characters
  - 13: Tomb Raider (PS1, 1996) - Lara Croft with guns
  - 14: Mega Man 2 (NES, 1988) - Mega Man shooting, cityscape
  - 15: Castlevania (NES, 1987) - Simon Belmont, castle backdrop
  - 16: Metroid (NES, 1986) - Samus in power suit
  - 17: Tetris (Game Boy, 1989) - falling blocks, portable design
  - 18: Pokémon Red/Blue (Game Boy, 1996) - Charizard or starter Pokémon
  - 19: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (Xbox 360, 2007) - soldier with rifle
  - 20: Minecraft (PC/Multi, 2011) - blocky Steve, pixelated world
  - 21: World of Warcraft (PC, 2004) - fantasy characters, logo
  - 22: Half-Life 2 (PC, 2004) - Gordon Freeman with crowbar, lambda logo
  - 23: BioShock (Xbox 360, 2007) - Big Daddy diving suit
  - 24: Portal (PC/Xbox 360, 2007) - Chell and companion cube
  - 25: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim (Multi, 2011) - dragon logo, warrior
  - 26: Fallout 3 (Multi, 2008) - Vault Boy, post-apocalyptic
  - 27: Mass Effect (Xbox 360, 2007) - Commander Shepard, space
  - 28: Uncharted 2 (PS3, 2009) - Nathan Drake climbing, action
  - 29: The Last of Us (PS3, 2013) - Joel and Ellie, post-apocalyptic
  - 30: God of War (PS2, 2005) - Kratos with blades
  - 31: Devil May Cry (PS2, 2001) - Dante with sword and guns
  - 32: Kingdom Hearts (PS2, 2002) - Sora with keyblade, Disney characters
  - 33: Super Smash Bros. Melee (GameCube, 2001) - character collage
  - 34: Star Fox 64 (N64, 1997) - Fox McCloud in Arwing
  - 35: GoldenEye 007 (N64, 1997) - James Bond with gun
  - 36: Perfect Dark (N64, 2000) - Joanna Dark with pistol
  - 37: Banjo-Kazooie (N64, 1998) - bear and bird duo
  - 38: Crash Bandicoot (PS1, 1996) - Crash spinning
  - 39: Spyro the Dragon (PS1, 1998) - purple dragon breathing fire
  - 40: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2 (PS1, 2000) - Tony Hawk skating
  - 41: Guitar Hero (PS2, 2005) - guitar controller, rock aesthetic
  - 42: Dance Dance Revolution (PS1, 1999) - dancing figures, arrows
  - 43: Madden NFL (Various) - football player in action
  - 44: NBA Jam (Arcade/SNES, 1993) - basketball players dunking
  - 45: FIFA (Various) - soccer players, ball
  - 46: Doom (PC, 1993) - space marine with gun, demons
  - 47: Wolfenstein 3D (PC, 1992) - soldier with gun, Nazi imagery
  - 48: Civilization (PC, 1991) - world map, historical leaders
  - 49: SimCity (PC, 1989) - city skyline, building simulation

PACKAGING AUTHENTICITY (CRITICAL):
• Complete retail packaging shown, not just cover art
• Platform-specific box design:
  - NES: vertical box, black border, Nintendo seal
  - SNES: horizontal box, purple/gray design
  - Genesis: vertical box, black with red stripe
  - PS1: black long-box or jewel case
  - PS2/Xbox/GameCube: standard game cases
  - PC: large cardboard box or DVD case
  - Game Boy: small cardboard box with clear window
• Era-appropriate packaging materials and style
• Box shows proper dimensions and angles
• Slight wear appropriate to the game's age (optional)

COVER ART INTEGRATION (CRITICAL):
• Subject's face/body replaces the main character on the cover
• Subject rendered in the SAME art style as the original:
  - Pixel art for 8-bit/16-bit era games
  - Hand-painted illustration for classic games
  - Digital art for modern games
  - Photo-manipulation for sports games
  - 3D rendered for contemporary games
• Subject in the exact pose and position of original character
• Subject wears the character's iconic costume/outfit
• Subject wields the character's signature weapons or items
• Background and environment remain identical to original
• Art style consistency is critical—no style mixing

PLATFORM-SPECIFIC ELEMENTS:
• Console logo in correct position:
  - "Nintendo Entertainment System"
  - "Super Nintendo", "Sega Genesis"
  - PlayStation, PlayStation 2, Xbox, etc.
  - Platform-specific colors and fonts
• Rating system appropriate to era:
  - No rating for pre-1994 games
  - ESRB rating (E, T, M) for 1994+ US games
  - PEGI rating for European games
  - Age-appropriate rating placement and size
• Official seals and logos:
  - "Official Nintendo Seal of Quality"
  - "Sega" logo variations
  - PlayStation "PS" logos
  - Microsoft Xbox logos
• Barcode placement (usually on back or side)
• Copyright and developer/publisher information

TYPOGRAPHY AND BRANDING:
• Game title in exact original font and placement
• Logo treatment identical to original (metallic, 3D, stylized)
• Subtitle or tagline if present
• Developer/publisher logos (Nintendo, Capcom, EA, etc.)
• Franchise branding if applicable
• Legal text and copyright notices
• All text crisp and professionally laid out

ART STYLE MATCHING:
• 1980s games: hand-painted illustration, bold colors, fantasy art
• Early 1990s: anime influence, detailed sprites, action scenes
• Late 1990s: early 3D renders, photoshop effects
• 2000s: high-quality 3D renders, cinematic compositions
• 2010s+: photo-realistic characters, dramatic lighting
• Sports games: action photography style
• Retro games: pixel art or simplified illustrations

SUBJECT AS CHARACTER:
• Subject fully transformed into the game character:
  - Mario's mustache, hat, and overalls
  - Link's tunic, shield, and sword
  - Master Chief's armor and helmet
  - Lara Croft's outfit and dual pistols
  - Sonic's spikes and red shoes
• Subject's face recognizable within character design
• Clothing, weapons, and accessories accurate to game
• Pose dynamic and action-oriented as per original cover
• Background elements (explosions, enemies, environment) preserved

PHYSICAL PRESENTATION:
• Box photographed at slight angle to show 3D depth
• Proper lighting showing box construction
• Spine visible showing title and platform
• Slight reflections on glossy surfaces
• Cardboard texture for older games
• Plastic case shine for disc-based games
• May show shrink wrap for "new" condition
• Proper scale—recognizable as retail product

CONTEXT OPTIONS:
• Standalone product shot on white/neutral background
• On store shelf with other games (retro game store)
  Held in hands showing scale
• Multiple angles (front, back, spine) in one image
• Collectors display case or shelf
• Professional product photography style

COLOR AND PRINTING:
• Color saturation authentic to era:
  - Vibrant, sometimes oversaturated for 80s/90s
  - Balanced and sophisticated for modern games
• Printing quality appropriate to age:
  - Slight dot pattern for older offset printing
  - Sharp digital printing for modern games
• Box finish: glossy, matte, or textured as per original
• Age-appropriate yellowing or fading (optional)

BACK COVER ELEMENTS (if visible):
• Screenshots from the game (original game screens)
• Feature list or game description
• System requirements for PC games
• Publisher information and website
• Additional character art or logos
• Multiple language text for international releases

FINAL RESULT:
A photorealistic retail video game package from the specified platform and era, showing complete packaging with authentic platform branding, proper typography, and all official elements. The subject has been seamlessly integrated into the iconic cover artwork, replacing the original character while matching the exact art style, pose, costume, and composition of the original game cover. The package appears as a genuine retail product that could have existed in an alternate timeline, complete with appropriate wear, proper dimensions, platform logos, rating information, and all the nostalgic details that make classic game packaging instantly recognizable to collectors and gamers.

name: VILLAGE PEOPLE
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into one of the iconic Village People characters from YMCA.

CHARACTER SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a specific Village People character, USE THAT CHARACTER
• If no character is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE character using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 6:
  - 0: The Cop (dark blue police uniform, police cap with badge, aviator sunglasses, mustache, authoritative pose, urban street)
  - 1: The Native American (feathered headdress, fringed leather vest, beaded accessories, face paint, proud pose, Southwestern setting)
  - 2: The Sailor (white sailor uniform, dixie cup hat, navy neckerchief, bell-bottoms, saluting pose, harbor/ship deck)
  - 3: The Biker (black leather vest, no shirt, leather pants/chaps, studded accessories, thick mustache, tough pose, motorcycle/garage)
  - 4: The Construction Worker (yellow hard hat, orange safety vest, tool belt, flannel shirt, work boots, strong pose, construction site)
  - 5: The Cowboy (large cowboy hat, leather vest with fringe, bandana, jeans, cowboy boots, swagger pose, Western saloon/ranch)

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• Subject becomes selected Village People persona
• Authentic 1970s costume and styling
• Subject's face and identity clearly preserved
• Photorealistic costume transformation, not cartoon
• Disco era atmosphere and energy
• Fun, campy, celebratory tone

GROUP COMPOSITION (CRITICAL FIX):
• ALL SIX Village People characters must appear in the image
• The subject is ONE member of the group, not alone
• The remaining characters must be clearly visible and fully costumed
• Group should appear performing, posing, or promoting together
• No single-character isolation

IDENTITY RULES:
• Subject's face completely recognizable
• Facial features and structure preserved exactly
• Natural expression showing personality
• Subject remains themselves in costume
• No replacement with original Village People members
• Keep subject's natural skin tone and features

COSTUME AUTHENTICITY:
• Accurate to 1970s Village People aesthetic
• Slight exaggeration and camp styling
• Bright, bold colors where appropriate
• Well-fitted, costume-quality outfits
• Theatrical presentation
• Disco-era fashion details
• Professional costume quality

1970s STYLING:
• Feathered hair or period-appropriate hairstyle
• Mustaches (prominent 70s style)
• Sideburns if appropriate
• Disco-era grooming
• Bold masculine presentation
• Confident, theatrical posing

SETTING:
• Disco dance floor or stage
• YMCA-style performance environment
• 1970s aesthetic environment
• Colorful, vibrant atmosphere
• Promotional photo or performance still

FINAL RESULT:
The image should depict the subject as one member of the Village People, fully costumed and recognizable, performing or posing together with the other five characters in an authentic, energetic 1970s disco scene.

name: VINTAGE POSTER
message: Take a picture in the style of a vintage movie poster. The poster uses lithography for printing on lightweight paper, and includes hand-painted illustrations. Add flavor text to the film title, director, and actor names inspired by the content of the image.

name: VIRTUOSO
message:
Take a picture of the subject and transform them into a solo musical virtuoso performing on stage.

The subject should be playing a single instrument such as a piano, violin, cello, guitar, trumpet, or another orchestral instrument.

Behind the subject, show a full orchestra performing along with them in a grand concert hall.

Spotlight the subject as the star of the performance while the orchestra supports them.

The scene should look dramatic, cinematic, and impressive, like a world-class concert starring the subject.

name: VISUAL POETRY
message: Take a picture and transform the image into visual poetry. Metaphor-driven imagery with emotional rhythm.

name: VITRUVIAN MAN
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a Renaissance-style geometric figure inspired by Leonardo da Vinci.

STYLE:
• Hand-drawn ink sketch
• Sepia or brown ink
• Aged parchment background

GEOMETRIC COMPOSITION:
• Show the subject in two overlapping poses
• One pose fits inside a square
• One pose fits inside a circle
• Both poses share the same center point

FIGURE PRESENTATION:
• Subject is represented using abstract linework.

ANNOTATIONS:
• Handwritten mirror-style notes
• Pseudo-Latin or Renaissance-style text

The final image must resemble a Renaissance notebook page focused on proportion and geometry, not anatomy.

name: VULCAN TRANSFORMATION
message: Take a picture and transform the subject into a realistic Vulcan. Preserve the subject’s recognizable facial features, bone structure, body proportions, and personality while adapting them to authentic Vulcan traits including pointed ears, subtle brow structure, calm expression, and controlled posture. Maintain the subject’s clothing identity translated into Vulcan-appropriate garments or Starfleet attire with clean lines and logical design. Neutral, disciplined body language, precise lighting, and understated realism. The subject must appear fully Vulcan, not human with cosmetic alterations.

name: WALDO
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a classic Where’s Waldo–style illustrated search puzzle.

CORE RULE:
This is a genuine search puzzle. The subject MUST be difficult to find.

SUBJECT IDENTITY (CRITICAL):
• The subject’s REAL face must replace ONE Waldo’s face
• Do NOT invent, add, exaggerate, stylize, or modify facial features
• Preserve the subject’s true facial structure, proportions, and expression
• Translate the face only into the same illustrated line style and color palette as the other Waldos

INTEGRATION RULES (CRITICAL):
• The subject’s Waldo must be identical in size, pose complexity, clothing, line weight, and color to surrounding Waldos
• No emphasis, framing, centering, highlighting, or isolation
• The subject must not appear more detailed or cleaner than other Waldos

PUZZLE DIFFICULTY:
• Populate the scene with dozens or hundreds of Waldos
• The subject’s face is the ONLY distinguishing element
• Facial likeness must be subtle and blended — noticeable only upon close inspection

SCENE COMPLEXITY:
• Extremely dense, crowded environment with heavy visual noise
• Overlapping characters, props, signage, and activity
• No empty space

POSITIONING RULES:
• Place the subject’s Waldo in a random, non-obvious location
• Partially occlude the face or body where appropriate
• Avoid clean silhouettes or foreground placement

STYLE REQUIREMENTS:
• Hand-drawn illustration style
• Flat colors, thin black outlines
• Whimsical chaos consistent with classic Where’s Waldo art
• No photographic realism

ABSOLUTE PROHIBITIONS:
• DO NOT alter the subject’s face
• DO NOT add facial identifiers, accessories, or markings
• DO NOT exaggerate the subject’s features
• DO NOT simplify or reduce surrounding Waldos

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must function as a real Where’s Waldo puzzle where the only way to find the subject is by recognizing their real face hidden among many identical Waldos.

name: PHARAOH
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into an Egyptian Pharaoh or Cleopatra with authentic ancient Egyptian royal regalia.

SETTING SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a specific Egyptian setting, USE THAT SETTING
• If no setting is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE setting using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 6:
  - 0: Throne Room (seated on golden throne, stone pillars with hieroglyphs, commanding pose, torch light)
  - 1: Temple Interior (standing between massive columns, hieroglyphic walls, offerings visible, sacred atmosphere)
  - 2: Nile River Barge (royal boat with golden decorations, Nile and palms visible, sunset, servants rowing)
  - 3: Pyramid Construction Site (overlooking pyramid being built, workers distant, desert landscape, harsh sun)
  - 4: Palace Balcony (standing on ornate balcony, ancient city below, addressing crowd pose, golden sunset)
  - 5: Burial Chamber (inside decorated tomb, surrounded by treasures, wall paintings of gods, torch-lit)

CORE CONCEPT (CRITICAL):
• Subject becomes an ancient Egyptian ruler
• Gender-appropriate transformation (male pharaoh or female Cleopatra/queen)
• Wearing authentic royal regalia and ceremonial dress
• Subject's facial features and identity preserved
• Set in ancient Egyptian location from selected setting
• Photorealistic with historical accuracy
• Regal, powerful, divine atmosphere

IDENTITY RULES:
• Subject's facial features completely preserved
• Face remains recognizable as the subject
• Natural skin tone maintained (no unrealistic changes)
• Subject's identity clear despite royal transformation
• Eyes, nose, mouth structure unchanged
• Only regalia and setting transformed

GENDER-SPECIFIC TRANSFORMATION:

MALE PHARAOH:
• Nemes headdress (striped blue and gold cloth)
• False ceremonial beard attached to chin
• Ornate collar/pectoral necklace (usekh)
• White linen shendyt kilt with pleats
• Golden belt with royal cartouche
• Crossed arms holding crook and flail
• Bare chest with royal jewelry
• Sandals with golden details

FEMALE CLEOPATRA/QUEEN:
• Elaborate braided black wig with golden ornaments
• Golden uraeus (cobra) headpiece
• Dramatic kohl eye makeup extending to temples
• Ornate beaded collar necklace
• Flowing white linen pleated dress
• Golden belt at waist
• Arm cuffs and bracelets
• Holding was scepter or ankh symbol

EGYPTIAN MAKEUP AND STYLING:
• Heavy kohl eyeliner extending outward
• Dramatic eye makeup (both genders)
• Gold dust highlights on skin
• Reddened lips (females)
• Smooth, flawless complexion
• Traditional Egyptian beauty standards

ROYAL REGALIA DETAILS:
• Gold everywhere: jewelry, crown, accessories
• Lapis lazuli, turquoise, carnelian gemstones
• Intricate beadwork and patterns
• Hieroglyphic cartouches with symbols
• Royal symbols: uraeus (cobra), vulture, scarab
• Authentic ancient Egyptian craftsmanship

ARCHITECTURAL ELEMENTS:
• Massive stone pillars with papyrus capitals
• Walls covered in colorful hieroglyphs
• Painted ceiling with stars and gods
• Limestone or sandstone construction
• Torches in wall sconces
• Statues of Egyptian gods
• Lotus flower decorations

ATMOSPHERE AND LIGHTING:
• Warm, golden lighting
• Dramatic shadows from torches or sun
• Rich, saturated colors: gold, blue, red
• Mysterious and powerful mood
• Ancient, timeless feeling
• Divine or god-like presence

COLOR PALETTE:
• Egyptian blue (vibrant blue pigment)
• Gold and bronze tones
• Deep red and carnelian
• Turquoise and lapis lazuli blue
• White linen
• Black kohl and ebony
• Sandstone beige

CAMERA:
• Low angle emphasizing power and divinity
• Cinematic, regal framing
• Subject centrally composed
• Architectural grandeur visible
• Professional historical film quality

OPTIONAL ELEMENTS:
• Sacred animals: cats, falcons, cobras
• Incense smoke rising
• Golden artifacts and treasures
• Hieroglyphic inscriptions
• Lotus flowers in vases
• Servants or attendants at respectful distance
• Palm fronds or papyrus plants

RESTRICTIONS:
• No cartoon or stylized rendering
• No Hollywood costume party appearance
• No text overlays or captions
• No modern elements or anachronisms
• No fantasy or supernatural elements
• No changing subject's actual face structure
• Maintain historical authenticity

FINAL RESULT:
The image should transform the subject into a believable ancient Egyptian ruler in the selected setting with authentic regalia, pose, and atmosphere. Whether male pharaoh or female Cleopatra, the transformation should preserve the subject's identity while surrounding them with the grandeur, mystery, and power of ancient Egypt.

name: WALLACE & GROMIT
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into the visual style of Wallace & Gromit stop-motion animation.

STYLE & MATERIAL (CRITICAL):
• Hand-molded clay characters — NOT CGI
• Visible fingerprints, thumb marks, and clay deformation
• Slight asymmetry and soft, imperfect forms

FACIAL & BODY DESIGN:
• Preserve the subject’s recognizable facial structure
• Translate features into exaggerated clay forms — large eyes, simplified noses, rounded cheeks
• Expressive but minimal mouths
• Proportions slightly caricatured

POSE & MOTION:
• Subject should appear frozen mid–stop-motion frame
• Slight stiffness or off-balance posture encouraged

COLOR & LIGHTING:
• Soft, even lighting
• Muted but colorful clay palette
• No harsh shadows or modern cinematic lighting

ENVIRONMENT:
• Miniature clay-built sets — interiors, streets, or whimsical everyday locations
• Everything must appear sculpted from clay at miniature scale
• No realistic photographic textures

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must look like a real Wallace & Gromit stop-motion frame — hand-crafted clay, charmingly imperfect, and unmistakably British.

name: WANTED POSTER
message:
Take a picture and transform it into a wanted poster from different historical eras.

WANTED POSTER ERA SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt suggests a specific era, USE THAT ERA
• If no era is provided externally, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST DIGIT of the RANDOM SEED modulo 8:
  - 0: Old West (1800s) — Aged parchment, "WANTED DEAD OR ALIVE", reward in dollars, crimes like "Bank Robbery" or "Cattle Rustlin'", bullet holes, weathered edges
  - 1: Medieval (1300s-1500s) — Hand-drawn on parchment, "WANTED FOR WITCHCRAFT" or "HERESY" or "THIEVERY", reward in gold coins, royal seal, crude illustration style
  - 2: Pirate Era (1700s) — Weathered naval poster, "WANTED BY THE CROWN", crimes like "Piracy" or "Mutiny", reward in pieces of eight, water stains, rope burn marks
  - 3: Prohibition Era (1920s) — Black and white mugshot style, "PUBLIC ENEMY", FBI or police department header, fingerprints, crimes like "Bootlegging" or "Racketeering"
  - 4: Wild West Sheriff (1870s) — Hand-lettered, "REWARD" banner, local sheriff's office, crimes specific to frontier towns, coffee stains, torn corners
  - 5: Medieval Kingdom — Illuminated manuscript style, ornate borders, "BY ORDER OF THE KING", crimes like "High Treason" or "Sorcery", wax seal
  - 6: Victorian Era (1880s) — Formal typeset poster, "WANTED BY SCOTLAND YARD", British crimes, reward in pounds sterling, official government seal
  - 7: Renaissance (1500s) — Woodcut print style, Latin text mixed with English, "SOUGHT BY THE CHURCH" or noble house, elaborate border decorations

SUBJECT RENDERING:
• Subject's face clearly visible and recognizable
• Rendering style matches the era (photo for modern, sketch/drawing for historical)
• Subject appears in period-appropriate style:
  — Old West: Sepia-toned photograph or sketch
  — Medieval: Crude hand-drawn illustration
  — Pirate: Rough sketch or woodcut
  — Prohibition: Black and white mugshot
  — Victorian: Formal portrait engraving
  — Renaissance: Detailed woodcut print

POSTER ELEMENTS (ERA-APPROPRIATE):
• Large "WANTED" header (or era equivalent)
• Subject's name or alias
• List of crimes fitting the era and humorous based on subject's appearance
• Reward amount in period currency
• Physical description (height, weight, distinguishing features)
• "Approach with caution" or similar warning
• Official stamps, seals, or signatures appropriate to era
• Date in period format

AGING & DAMAGE EFFECTS:
• Weathered, aged paper texture
• Tears, creases, or worn edges
• Stains (coffee, water, blood) appropriate to era
• Faded ink or text
• Bullet holes, burn marks, or other damage for Western/Pirate eras
• Authentic period typography and fonts

STYLE:
• Authentic historical document aesthetic
• Period-accurate paper texture and color
• Era-appropriate printing or writing style
• Realistic aging and wear
• Humorous crimes that match subject's appearance or pose

FINAL RESULT:
An authentic-looking wanted poster from the selected historical era featuring the subject with appropriate rendering style, era-specific crimes and rewards, period-accurate typography, and realistic aging effects that make it look like a genuine historical document.

name: WARDROBE MALFUNCTION
message:
Take a picture of the subject frozen in a moment where their clothing is tearing, misfitting (shrunk or undersized), or hilariously failing.

The tear or malfunction must be physically integrated with the clothing texture and anatomy — fabric stretches, rips, or folds realistically across the subject’s body.

Include realistic lighting, shadows, and environmental context, such as a street, stage, gym, or indoor setting.

The final image must look like a real photograph capturing the exact comedic moment — absurd but believable, with no digital overlays or pasted elements.

name: WARNER BROS CARTOON
message:
Take a picture and transform the subject into a classic Warner Bros. Looney Tunes cartoon character integrated into the Warner Bros cartoon world.

SCENE TYPE SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies scene type, USE THAT SCENE
• If none is specified, SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the PRE-CALCULATED values
• These values are MANDATORY - you MUST use them for selection
• Use LAST DIGIT:
  - 0: "That's All Folks!" closing - subject's face as central character in concentric rings end card
  - 1: Looney Tunes title card - subject with classic WB characters in opening scene
  - 2: Desert chase scene - subject with Road Runner and Wile E. Coyote in Southwest desert
  - 3: Opera/theatre scene - subject with Bugs Bunny in "What's Opera, Doc?" style
  - 4: Hunting scene - subject with Elmer Fudd and Bugs/Daffy in forest
  - 5: Pirate ship - subject with Yosemite Sam on sailing ship
  - 6: Space scene - subject with Marvin the Martian on alien planet
  - 7: Bullfight - subject with Bugs Bunny in Mexican bullfighting arena
  - 8: Mansion/spooky - subject with Gossamer monster in haunted house
  - 9: City street - subject with Tweety and Sylvester in urban setting

CORE WARNER BROS STYLE:
• Bold black outlines around all characters
• Saturated vibrant colors (primaries and bright secondaries)
• Soft cel-style shading with minimal gradients
• Hand-painted background aesthetic
• Exaggerated cartoon expressions
• Squash and stretch animation principles
• Theatrical mid-20th century animation quality

SUBJECT TRANSFORMATION:
• Subject's face preserved but adapted to cartoon style
• Bold black outline defining subject
• Simplified features but recognizable
• Exaggerated cartoon expression
• Integrated naturally into WB cartoon world
• Cel-shaded coloring
• Subject appears as if they belong in Looney Tunes

FOR "THAT'S ALL FOLKS!" END CARD (Option 0):
• ONLY subject's face in center
• NO other characters present
• Concentric red rings background
• "That's all folks!" text in signature style
• Subject's face replaces Porky Pig
• Classic circular spotlight closing
• End card composition

FOR SCENES WITH CHARACTERS (Options 1-9):
• Subject AND classic Warner Bros characters together
• Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Porky Pig, Tweety, Sylvester, etc.
• All characters interact in scene
• Subject integrated as fellow cartoon character
• Classic character designs maintained
• Scene includes multiple WB characters
• Ensemble cast interaction

WARNER BROS CHARACTERS (when included):
• Bugs Bunny - gray rabbit, carrot, "What's up, Doc?"
• Daffy Duck - black duck, bill moves when talking
• Porky Pig - pink pig, bowtie, stuttering
• Tweety - yellow canary, big head, innocent
• Sylvester - black and white cat, lisp
• Yosemite Sam - red mustache, cowboy hat, pistols
• Wile E. Coyote - brown coyote, ACME products
• Road Runner - "Beep beep!", purple and blue
• Elmer Fudd - bald, hunting cap, rifle
• Marvin the Martian - Roman helmet, ray gun
• Tasmanian Devil - brown whirlwind
• Foghorn Leghorn - rooster, Southern accent

BACKGROUND STYLE:
• Hand-painted watercolor aesthetic
• Simplified scenery
• Atmospheric perspective
• Classic theatrical cartoon backgrounds
• Setting-appropriate (desert, forest, space, theater, etc.)
• Warner Bros color palette (bright, vibrant)

COLOR PALETTE:
• Bright primary colors (red, blue, yellow)
• Vibrant secondaries (orange, green, purple)
• High saturation
• Classic Technicolor cartoon appearance
• Consistent with 1940s-1960s Looney Tunes

ANIMATION STYLE:
• Cel animation aesthetic
• Slight texture suggesting paint on cel
• Clean lines and fills
• No digital gradients
• Flat colors with minimal shading
• Classic Chuck Jones or Friz Freleng style

COMPOSITION:
• Theatrical cartoon framing
• Characters clearly visible
• Dynamic poses and action
• Readable on small screen
• Classic cartoon staging

HUMOR & ENERGY:
• Looney Tunes slapstick energy
• Exaggerated expressions
• Cartoon physics
• Visual gags
• Theatrical performance style

FINAL RESULT:
The image should show the subject transformed into Warner Bros cartoon style - for "That's All Folks!" end card, ONLY the subject in center with rings; for other scenes, subject integrated WITH classic Looney Tunes characters in iconic WB cartoon settings, all with bold outlines, vibrant colors, and authentic 1940s-1960s theatrical animation aesthetic.

name: WARNING
message:
Take a picture of the subject and transform the image into an actual warning sign, safety poster, or instructional notice that explicitly shows the subject performing the exact action they are warned not to do.

VARIANT SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If external master prompt specifies variant, USE THAT
• Otherwise SELECT variant using RANDOM SEED modulo 2:
  - 0: TEXT-BASED WARNING SIGN
  - 1: SYMBOL-ONLY SAFETY SIGN

VARIANT 0 — TEXT-BASED WARNING SIGN:
• Presented as a real warning label, safety sign, or instructional poster
• Includes a visible headline such as WARNING, CAUTION, DANGER, or DO NOT
• Clear instructional or prohibitive text describing the mistake
• Subject is shown mid-action committing the forbidden behavior

VARIANT 1 — SYMBOL-ONLY SAFETY SIGN:
• ISO-style symbol-only warning sign
• NO TEXT ALLOWED anywhere in the image
• Uses universally recognizable safety pictograms
• Red prohibition slashes, yellow hazard triangles, or black-on-white icons
• Subject must still be clearly depicted performing the prohibited action
• Meaning must be immediately understandable without words

SUBJECT ROLE (MANDATORY):
• The subject must be shown actively performing the forbidden action
• The action must be clearly unsafe, incorrect, or rule-breaking
• The subject may appear unaware, careless, or mid-mistake

VISUAL DESIGN RULES:
• Clean, high-contrast composition typical of real safety signage
• Clear framing so the subject and the mistake are instantly readable
• Minimal background clutter
• No cinematic, painterly, or artistic stylization

INSTRUCTIONAL CONTEXT:
• Visual cues such as arrows, highlights, or symbols may be used
• The subject’s action must be the focal point of the sign
• Tone must be official and authoritative, not comedic in layout

REALISM:
• Photorealistic subject and environment
• Believable real-world setting appropriate to the warning context
• Lighting and perspective consistent with photographed signage

FINAL RESULT:
The final image must clearly and unmistakably appear to be a real warning sign, safety notice, or instructional poster that exists specifically to show the subject as an example of what NOT to do.

name: WARNING VIOLATION
message:
Take a picture and transform the image so the subject is clearly violating a visible warning sign.

VIOLATION SELECTION (CRITICAL):
• If an external master prompt specifies a violation scenario, USE THAT
• Otherwise SELECT EXACTLY ONE using the RANDOM SEED
• Use the LAST TWO DIGITS of the RANDOM SEED modulo 50:
  - 0: Feeding a wild animal under a 'DO NOT FEED' sign (animal about to bite)
  - 1: Petting an alligator next to an 'ALLIGATORS PRESENT' warning
  - 2: Touching a downed power line under an electrical hazard sign
  - 3: Standing on a cliff edge ignoring a 'DANGER: FALL HAZARD' sign
  - 4: Swimming past a 'NO SWIMMING' sign with rip currents visible
  - 5: Climbing a fence marked 'KEEP OUT'
  - 6: Leaning over a zoo enclosure railing marked 'DO NOT CROSS'
  - 7: Touching a hot surface labeled 'HOT'
  - 8: Standing under falling rocks near 'ROCKFALL ZONE'
  - 9: Ignoring a 'WEAR HEARING PROTECTION' sign near loud machinery
  - 10: Standing on railroad tracks under 'NO TRESPASSING'
  - 11: Smoking near a 'NO SMOKING – FLAMMABLE GAS' sign
  - 12: Touching industrial machinery labeled 'DO NOT OPERATE'
  - 13: Eating food labeled 'NOT FOR HUMAN CONSUMPTION'
  - 14: Drinking from a container labeled 'DO NOT DRINK'
  - 15: Standing under a suspended load marked 'DANGER: OVERHEAD'
  - 16: Ignoring a 'WEAR SAFETY GLASSES' sign while grinding metal
  - 17: Walking into quicksand under a warning placard
  - 18: Standing in floodwaters under 'ROAD CLOSED'
  - 19: Ignoring 'BIOHAZARD' signage while touching materials
  - 20: Climbing unstable scaffolding marked 'UNSAFE'
  - 21: Approaching a wild bison under 'DO NOT APPROACH'
  - 22: Touching a cactus under 'DO NOT TOUCH'
  - 23: Crossing thin ice under 'DANGER: THIN ICE'
  - 24: Standing near erupting geyser ignoring park warnings
  - 25: Handling fireworks under 'NO OPEN FLAME'
  - 26: Standing in an avalanche zone under posted warning
  - 27: Feeding seagulls under 'NO FEEDING WILDLIFE'
  - 28: Touching molten metal under heat hazard signage
  - 29: Standing inside restricted construction zone
  - 30: Leaning over shark tank under 'DANGER: SHARKS'
  - 31: Walking into laser lab ignoring eye safety warnings
  - 32: Standing near unstable tree marked for removal
  - 33: Touching electrified fence under 'HIGH VOLTAGE'
  - 34: Ignoring 'DO NOT ENTER – ACTIVE TESTING'
  - 35: Standing in blast radius marked on ground
  - 36: Handling chemicals without gloves under warning
  - 37: Sitting on fragile artifact under museum warning
  - 38: Touching exposed wiring in home fuse box
  - 39: Standing near wild moose under park warning
  - 40: Opening emergency exit mid-flight
  - 41: Touching dry ice with bare hands
  - 42: Ignoring 'NO PHOTOGRAPHY' in restricted zone
